name: Níjar
remarks: Thickness of reef core 15-30 m. Very important fore reef talus Prominent micrite coatings. New stratigraphy by ref. 1192. Abstract of ref. 1403 Bivalves are conspicuous and important components in the Messinian Nijar reef, a fringing reef which developed on the northern margin of the Almeria-Nijar Neogene basin in southeastern Spain. Bivalves appear in four distinct taphofacies that coincide with the facies and subfacies belts in which the reef has previously been divided: (1) In the reef core (Taphofacies 1) well-preserved, crevice-inhabitants occur. Sand- to gravel-sized bivalve fragments re included in the matrix that fills the framework voids. (2) Bivalve bioclasts appear in gravels surrounding reef-framework blocks in Taphofacies 2. Sheltering among blocks diminished breakage of shells, pointing to a hydraulic origin of shell reworking and fragmentation in this upper part of the slope. The recognizable fragments belong to bissally-attached, cemented, and endobenthic forms. Endolithic, and some cemented and endosedimentary bivalves remain in life position. (3) Bivalves are found in Taphofacies 3 as clasts in debris-flow breccias and constitute allochthonous assemblages coming downslope from the reef- talus. They also appear as sand- to gravel-sized particles in the calcarenites intercalating the breccias and only a few unbroken and sometimes articulated examples are considered to be autochthonous /parautochthonous in this environment. (4) Scarce, not fragmented, deep-water oysters are dispersed in the fine-grained sediments of the distal slope. The number of bivalve species is very low compared with the species richness of modern coral reefs and most of the recorded taxa have a present-day temperature distribution. All this supports the hypothesis of the marginal biogeographical character of the western Mediterranean Messinian reefs.
authors: Dabrio, C.J., Esteban, M. & Martin, J.M.
title: The coral reef of Níjar, Messinian (uppermost Miocene), Almería Province, S.E. Spain. -

name: Zeneta
remarks: Messinian reef within San Miguel de Salinas Basin. Porites reef with very low coral diversity and some coralline algal and foram crusts. Abstract of ref. 651: Small and isolated Messinian patch reefs showing a typical internal succession and an oligospecific reef-building community are described from the western margin of the San Miguel de Salinas Basin (SE Spain). These thrived in a mixed carbonate- siliciclastic environment and are known from two different stratigraphic levels. The reef growth is characterized by a shallowing-upward sequence and can be subdivided into four divisions: reef debris zone; coralline algal zone; branching coral zone; and reef crest zone. This ecological succession of Messinian reefs reflects an increasing water turbulence and the accommodation of the reef-building organisms to shallower-water settings, which is conditioned by its own upward growth. The start of reef growth is controlled by a reduced influx of terrigenous deposits, which derived from fan sediments reworked by waves. The reefs were killed by smothering with quartzose calcarenites. The low diversity of the reef-building community indicates an arrested ecological succession without climax stages, controlled by sedimentation rate and siliciclastic supply. A salinity increase can be excluded, because the reef- associated fauna indicates normal-marine conditions during reef growth. There is no evidence for subaerial exposure of the reefs during the formation of evaporites at the end of the Messinian.
title: Guild structure and aggradation pattern of Messinian Porites patch reefs: ecological succession and external environmental control (San Miguel de Salinas, SE Spain). -

name: Salt Mountain, Alabama
remarks: NP 7 nannoplankton zone Primarily corraline algae, sponges and corals in a muddy matrix. Corals and demo(?)sponges associated. Coralline algae more in fore reef position. Abstract of ref. 551: The Late Paleocene Salt Mountain Limestone from southwestern Alabama (USA) is a coral-algal-sponge buildup which further characterizes the faunal makeup of early post-Cretaceous reefs. Thin sectioning has disclosed a variety of lithologies, including large foram-algal packstone, algal bindstone, and sponge bafflestone. A low-diversity fauna of massive scleractinian corals caps the sequence, but may be developed intermittently throughout the section as well. The constructional importance of coralline algae and the low diversity of scleractinian corals are characteristic of Paleocene reefs in general. Sponges, however, are virtually unknown in earliest Tertiary sediments. Their abundance in the Salt Mountain demonstrates not only their local contribution to Early Tertiary reefs, but may also reflect an opportunistic response of sponges as reef constructors following the extinction of oligotrophic, rudist-coral reef communities of the Late Cretaceous. Abstract ref. 2185: The slow recovery of reef coral communities after the K-T extinctions has long been recognized, but the scarcity of Paleocene corals and reefs has inhibited study of early Tertiary reef diversification. A key question regarding this recovery concerns the extent to which changes in coral diversity affect the establishment of coral reef communities. Specifically, is the scarcity of Paleocene reefs the result of low coral diversity? We examined this question through investigations of the oldest Paleocene reef from the Gulf of Mexico region (the Salt Mountain Limestone) and newly revised generic level occurrence data for the Caribbean. The Salt Mountain Limestone is a Thanetian (Late Paleocene) shallow water patch reef in southern Alabama. It contains 12 species of reef corals including massive and platy zooxanthellate forms co-occurring with abundant branching-nodular apozooxanthellate species. The species richness and ecology of this Paleocene fauna approximates that of later Tertiary and modern reef communities from the northern Gulf of Mexico. Unlike younger reefs, however, the Salt Mountain reef community is dominated not by corals, but by coralline algae and a diverse group of hexactinellid sponges. Thus, Paleocene corals were comparable to later faunas, but the reef community was not. Looking at generic records, 23 reef coral genera are known from or range through the Caribbean Paleocene. This is lower than the number known from the later Tertiary and modern Caribbean, but only slightly so. There are numerous examples of later Tertiary coral reefs composed of fewer genera suggesting that lower taxonomic richness was not the primary reason for the lack of Paleocene coral build-ups. The absence of coral reefs was more likely the result of a break-down in coral-algal symbiosis or the lack of a few key taxa that structure Tertiary through Recent reef communities.
title: A Paleocene coral-algal-sponge reef from southwestern Alabama and the ecology of Early Tertiary reefs. -

name: Arun Field, Sumatra
remarks: Total thickness of buildup 370 m. 16.2 % avg. porosity. Early to middle Miocene. Abstract ref. 604: The Arun field is a giant gas-condensate field operated by Mobil and Pertamina with over 20,000 acres of closure at the top of the Arun reservoir. A middle-shelf patch reef complex of early to middle Miocene age is the producing facies at the Arun field. About 1,100 ft of porous limestones, encased in shales, create a stratigraphic trap for overpressured hydrocarbons. Three main carbonate lithologies were encountered during the examination of over 4,300 ft of core: (1) a reef facies consisting of vuggy, coral encrusting, red-algal boundstones, (2) a near-reef facies consisting of foraminiferal, mixed-skeletal packstones with gravel-size coral fragments, and (3) an interreef lagoonal facies consisting of benthonic-foram packstones. Twenty-two species of corals have been identified from Arun reef facies; major reef-forming coals, listed in order of decreasing abundance, are Porites cf P. lutea, Cyphastrea microphthalma, Astreopora myriophthalma, Stylocoeniella guentheri, Porites solida, and Acropora ssp. The calcified tube around the siphon of the mollusk Kuphus is common in near-reef sediments. Two off-reef lithologies, interpreted as middle-shelf facies, were observed in cores: (1) benthonic-foram and planktonic-foram packstones on the gentle northwestern flank of the reef, and (2) dark-gray foram, mixed-skeletal packstones with intraclasts, on the steep eastern flank of the reef. The Arun reef is comprised of limestones (with minor amounts of dolomite). No shale beds occur in the sequence, and all carbonate facies are in communication. A pervasive microporosity, occurring throughout the Arun Limestone, results from meteoric alteration of original carbonate mud to form a microrhombic porosity that accounts for about three-fourths of the field's total porosity. The remaining one-quarter is mainly vuggy porosity found in reef facies and, to a lesser extent, moldic porosity in lagoonal foram packstones where forams are preferentially dissolved.
title: Arun Field: a giant gas-condensate field producing from Miocene reef facies, North Sumatra Basin, Indonesia. -

name: Saipan, Northern Marianas, Pacific
remarks: Abstract of ref. 609: Miocene carbonates in the southern Mariana Islands are impressive for their lithologic diversity, thicknesses (over 250 m), and geographic extent (> 20% combined outcrop coverage over four major high islands: Guam, Rota, Tinian and Saipan). Sections are dominated either by lagoonal algal-foraminiferal wackestones and mudstones with locally abundant high-energy shelly-skeletal facies, or by rubbly to muddy, fore-reef-to-bank deposits of packstones and grainstones with highly diverse and variable biogenic clasts. Fresh to deeply weathered volcaniclastic material may comprise at least 80% of some high-energy fore-reef facies, whereas lagoonal and bank deposits usually contain less than 0.5% terrigenous material. Surprisingly, the Miocene in the Marianas lacks almost completely any reef-core facies. Several poorly developed coral-rich mounds on Saipan and localized laminated red algal buildups on Guam appear to constitute the extant reef-wall facies in the Miocene. The lack of buildups may be a matter of differential survival; it may result from headland erosion and benching associated with emergence of narrow reef tracts as has been postulated by others for south Guam. Alternatively, we are proposing that Miocene bathymetry and the volume of terrigenous influx militated against significant reef core formation. Radiometric age dating of these reef carbonates has proven unsuccessful because pervasive diagenesis has transformed the entire Miocene section into low-magnesium calcite with minor and occasional dolomite. Freshwater phreatic diagenesis accounts for the principal porosity variation and trace element distribution.
title: Miocene reef carbonates of Mariana Islands. -

Sedimentary textures and fossil occurrences are identical to those seen in Racine mounds, but typically the fauna (e.g., brachiopods, corals, echinoderms) is much less diverse. Local graded bedding, debris wedges, and mound fissures packed with trilobites or nautiloids (forming very local trilobite-moldic and nautiloid-moldic dolowackestones-packstones) are common. Collection entered by Foote.

name: Cape Greco
remarks: 80 m thick and 500 m wide patch reef. Construction by corals only. Rare serpulids, vermetid gastropods and encrusting corraline algae are present. Abstract of ref. 634: An Early Tertiary regressive sedimentary succession developed along an active plate margin in Cyprus. A varied clastic and carbonate succession of the Miocene, Pakhna Formation and then Messinian evaporites culminates the regression. Within the Pakhna Formation, two phases of the reef growth were developed. The Terra Member reefs have limited acicular fringe cement (probably aragonitic). This is overlain by an abundant, marine, bladed, formerly high-Mg calcite cement. Later cements present in the reef facies include micritised calcite spars, perhaps indicating microboring in cements during their precipitation. The Koronia Member limestones show abundant indication of early lithification with fringing acicular aragonite and micrite cements. Stable isotopic data of the botryoidal aragonite cements indicate a marine origin.
title: Patterns of reef sedimentation and diagenesis in the Miocene of Cyprus. -

name: Valzemola
remarks: Coral baffle- and bindstones are also developed. Total thickness about 15 m. Abstract of ref 640: The terrigenous and carbonate sediments of the transgressive Oligocene cycle of the Tertiary Piedmont Basin outcropping in the area of Valzemola (Savona, western Liguria, Northwest Italy ) and which are referable to the Molare Formation are analysed. The terrigenous sequence, represented by breccias, conglomerates and sandstones, overlies with an angular unconformity dolomitic or calcareous-dolomitic lithologies referable to the San Pietro dei Monti Dolomite Formation. These sequences are locally characterized by rich associations of coralline algae and corals, which by providing a stable substrate allowed the development of a true reef build up. Subsequently the biotherm was suffocated by fluvial sandstone and conglomerate. This may be associated with an intensification in the amount of terrigenous material being brought into the basin. A progressive shallowing continues until the introduction of conditions suitable for calcareous deposition in an intertidal or supratidal environment. The analysis of this reef deposit was carried out by examining seven stratigraphic sections. The paleoecological study of the coral fauna and the algal assemblage, the latter characterized by the significant presence either of the genus Lithophyllum, or of Lithothamnion, allowed some hypothesis on the environmental conditions which characterized this sector during the Late Oligocene. Nine different facies could be shown, from those seven directly connected to the reef and two to nearshore environments proving a regressive phase. Facies I: conglomeratic-sandstone representing a stage of colonization in a dominantly terrigenous environment. Facies II: coral framestone, representing a stage of diversification ('an inner reef front' near to the 'reef crest'). Facies III: coral bafflestone representing a colonization stage in an 'inner reef slope'. Facies IV: coral bindstone representing a stage of domination in a 'reef crest' environment. Facies V: coral bindstone alternating with floatstone, gives evidence of a colonization stage in a carbonate environment. Facies VI: coral and algae floatstone, representing a facies of accumulated reef debris. Facies VII: coral rudstone, representing an accumulation facies comparable with that of the 'rubble & pavement zone' of the back reef. Facies VIII: conglomerates and sands of a shallow marine environment, represent a regressive sequence. Facies IX: massive limestones with undulated-zoned structures, rhizoliths, calcite veins and pisoliths, evidence of an intertidal or supratidal environment.
authors: Fravega, P., Piazza, M., Stockar, R. & Vannucci, G.
title: Oligocene coral and algal reef and related facies of Valzemola (Savona, NW Italy). -

name: Xisha Islands III, South China Sea
remarks: coordinates need update. Ref. 2818: High-resolution sequence stratigraphic analysis revealed that the transgressive and highstand system tracts of the mid-Miocene Meishan Formation in the Beijiao and Ledong-Lingshui Depressions developed reef carbonates. The seismic features of the reef carbonates in these two areas include chaotic bedding, intermittent internal reflections, chaotic or blank reflections, mounded reflections, and apparent amplitude anomalies, similar to the seismic characteristics of the LH11-1 reef reservoir in the Dongsha Uplift and Island Reef of the Salawati Basin, Indonesia, which house large oil fields.
title: Evaluation and models of Cenozoic sedimentation in the South China Sea. -

name: Xisha Islands, South China Sea
remarks: Up to 1000 m thick reefs according to ref. 662. Abstract ref. 1648: The section between 0 and 400 m of well Xichen-1 was completely cored, which has provided rich data for various laboratory analyses on its reef succession. A complete and systematic review has been made on its diagenetic environment, processes and characteristics by means of thin section observations, electron probe analysis, C and O stable isotopic determinations of gastropod tests of individual genera at different well depths and different sediments at the same depth and the analysis of Mg/Ca and Mg/Sr. Non-algal boring of the micrite suite and the non-mixed water genesis of dolomitic have been proposed.
title: Evaluation and models of Cenozoic sedimentation in the South China Sea. -

name: Jukoupu, Shaoyang, Hunan
remarks: More than 20 m thick reef core and 150-200 m wide Reef builders are massive stromatopores, tabulate corals and cyanophycean algae. According to ref. 997 overall thickness 182 m. Boring gastropods. Marginal reef. Abstract of ref. 1553: The present paper describes 10 genera and 18 species of stromatoporoids with such most important forms as Actinostroma clathratum Nicholson; A. cf. crassepilatum Lecompte, Clathrostroma bifarium (Nicholson), Synthetostroma acttnostromoides Lecompte, Stromatopora hupschii Bargatzky, S. cf. cimacensis (Lecompte), S. cf. maillieuxi (Lecompte), Parallelopora ostiolata Bargatzky, P. goldfussii Bargatzky and Stachyodes insignis Yavorsky. These species may be correlated with those of West and South China, and also with those occurring in the equivalent beds of many European countries and Canada, providing evidence for determining the Chitzechiao Formation is late Middle Devonian in age. The Jukoupu reefs occur in the Middle Devonian Chitzechiao Formation, a transition belt with a facies change from open shallow-sea marl to platform shallow-sea carbonate rocks. Based on the difference in sedimentary features, the reefs may be divided into two parts. The reefs in the lower part are clearly stratified and consist of thick-bedded framestones with stromatoporoids and massive corals. The thick-bedded limestones are intercalated with thin-bedded yellow mudstone, marl or mud shale with a thickness of 20-30 cm, indicating short-term and periodic changes in sedimentary environment. The reefs in the upper part are separated from the lower reefs by a nearly 10 m thick layer of crinoidal limestone. The limestone with a total thickness of 120 m is poorly stratified, containing monotonous fossils mainly with crinoidal stems, dendritic or straticulate stromatoporoids and alveolites. Based on field observation and indoor identification, the Jukoupu reefs may be divided into 8 sedimentary microfacies, namely, micrites with massive stromatoporoids frames; mudstone-shale facies; micrites with massive compound coral frames; sparites with crinoidal fragments; biomicrosparites with biogenic incrustation; biobaffling micrites; oncolite micrites; and bioclastic micrites. The developmental process of the Jukoupu reefs may be as follows: nearshore normal shallow-sea environments.sbd.stromatoporoid reefs developed in the transitional belt.sbd.closed or semiclosed environments of back-reef facies abnormal salinity. The characteristics of the life assemblages and sedimentary facies generally vary with changes in sedimentary environments. Other species discussed are: Actinostroma voivojense, Gerronostroma tenuilaminae, Clathrostroma liujingense, Trupetostroma exquisitum, Stromatopora sinopachytexta, S. liujingensis, Salairella aspersa and Amphipora nonaxis.

name: Omulevka River, Yakutsk
remarks: Tabulate corals and stromatoporoids. Some of the largest know Hirnantian reefs are developed along Mirny Creek (NE Russia), part of the Omulev uplft: these are coral-stromatoporoid bioherms up to 20m thick, which end somewhere below the O/S boundary (Oradovskaya & Sobolevskaya, 1983): there are no reefs in the Llandovery strata immediately above. Older reef growth with mud mound in underlying Padun Fm.

name: Poleng, East Java Sea
remarks: Type 1 reefs of ref. 685. Low growth-ratio reefs. Reef core coral, coral debris, algal, foram-algal and shelf facies distinguished. Reef facies: Coral boundstones and packstones with coral heads up to 30 cm in diameter. Diverse compound corals, hydrozoans, branching corals, red algae (mostly encrusting), forams, echinoid and bivalve debris. Bioherms including pinnacle reefs.
title: Distribution and morphology of early Miocene reefs, East Java Sea. -
paper: Indonesian Petrol. Assoc., Proceedings Sixth Annual Convention

name: East Java Sea IV

title: Distribution and morphology of early Miocene reefs, East Java Sea. -

name: Jebel Assameur + Boukendil, Rich
remarks: 40-70 m thick pinnacle reefs. Borings evident from fig. 169 of James (1983). Lithophaga type. Second reef cycle. Abstract of ref 698: The Early and Middle Jurassic High Atlas sea extended as a marine trough across what is now the central and eastern portions of the High Atlas Mountains, southern Morocco. The sedimentary infilling of this sea is recorded by a thick sequence of limestones and marls punctuated by spectacular coral-algal reef horizons. A 1200 m-thick section of Aalenian and Bajocian sediments near Rich, Morocco, was studied in detail to document the upward-shoaling, basin-to-reef transition. The lower 900 m of the section represents deeper water deposition: it consists of monotonously interbedded, dark-hued marls and lime mudstones and wackestones that bear a pelagic fossil fauna, and scattered turbidities of lime grainstone. An overlying transitional sequence about 200 m thick records progressive shallowing, as shown by increased fossil diversity and abundance, an increase in algally micritized particles, a change from a pelagic to a benthic shelled fauna, an increase in limestone-to-marl ratio, and the appearance of small bioherms with scleractinian coral framework. The sequence is capped by a 100 m-thick horizon of very fossiliferous limestones and superbly preserved coral-algal reefs that grew in shallow water. Several lines of evidence suggest that some of the reefs grew on submarine ridges that were uplifted by Middle Jurassic tectonic movements.
title: Middle Jurassic shoaling of the Central High Atlas Sea near Rich, Morocco. -

name: Brazos County, Texas
remarks: Coral-stromatopore boundstones. Almost 100 m thick Subsurface data only. Outer ramp reef complex. Wave resistant. Sponges in fore reef only. This reef complex is about 7 km wide and 70 km long, and is up to 100 m thick. A shoaling-up succession from bioclastic wackestone to coral-stromatoporoid boundstone is characteristic for this bioconstruction. The reef-frame is marked by massive-nodular, vase-shaped, and laminar coral morphotypes, encrusting and branching stromatoporoids, and green algae. Lateral facial differentiation in fore-reef slope facies and lagoonal deposits is well developed. The vertical reefal succession shows indications of shoaling-up conditions into the zone of wave action with accumulations of dicerid rudists, other molluscs, and green algae.
authors: Finneran, J.M., Scott, R.W., Taylor, G.A. & Anderson, G.H.
title: Lowermost Cretaceous ramp reefs: Knowles Limestone, southwest flank of the East Texas Basin. -

name: Chay Peninsula, La Rochelle
remarks: Cymodoce zone Two reefal units separated by marls and shell coquinas. Abundant terrigenous debris present. Mainly scleractinian corals (Calamnophylliopsis) and solenoporacean algae, large component of thrombolite Diverse encruster guild with demosponges, brachiopods, serpulids, cyclostome bryozoans, cemented bivalves Up to 70% of reef framework is microbial Ref. 2172: Description of large reef caves
title: Les apports terrigènes dans les récifs du Séquanien du Sud de La Rochelle (Charente-Maritime). -

name: Mecsek Mountains
remarks: Giant volcanoes with atoll type build-ups, found as debris in basinal marls. Corals, chaetetids, stromatopores, coralline algae, rudists, ostreids and other mollusks.

name: Jebel Zaghouan

Base: Algae (Thaumatoporella, Solenopora, Paleodasycladus, Triporella, Macroporella)-solitary corals-stromatopores-sponges and rare bryozoans. According to ref. 1972 almost 50 % rudists(?) and 25 % microbialties.
authors: Ourribane, M., Soussi, M., Zaghbib-Turki, D. & Turki, M.M.

name: Kamaran Island, Red Sea
remarks: 6 m reef limestone (no age indicated). Below is marly limestone eseries with Rotalia beccarii, Polystomella crispa and Amphistegina lessonii.

name: Albéniz

name: Taninul
remarks: Boundstones only 35 % of section. Other are grain- and packstones. Rudists strongly dominating. 6 % of reef builders are corals. Abstract of ref. 757: The macrofaunal distribution of the mid-Cretaceous El Abra Limestone reef core is quantified from two measured sections in Taninul Quarry, San Luis Potosi, central Mexico. The faunal structure is transitional between typical Lower Cretaceous reefs dominated by corals with low density rudist bivalve packing. And densely-packed, rudist-dominated Upper Cretaceous reefs. The macrofauna is predominantly associations of unconnected individuals of caprinid rudists, with a low diversity of other shelly mollusks and corals. An examination of the alternation of paleocommunities defined by the dominant caprinid taxa corals. An examination of the alternation of paleocommunities defined by the dominant caprinid taxa reveals no pattern of biotic succession within the reef core. Large-scale sedimentologic features of mud and debris content, coupled with rudist growth type, suggest that paleocommunities may have been physically controlled.
title: Diagenesis of mid-Cretaceous rudist reefs, Valles Platform, Mexico. -
editors: Schroeder, J.H. & Purser, B.H.

name: Jebel el Kebar

authors: M'Rabet, A., Negra, M.H., Purser, B.H., Sassi, S. & Ayed, N.B.

name: Raga Hiraiga
remarks: Framework built by corals (diverse) and rudists (one species only). Corals encrusted by red algae. Buildup dimensions 20x50x1 m. Abstract of ref. 743: A coral-rudist limestone was newly discovered in the Lower Cretaceous (upper Aptian) sequence of the Miyako Group. It is small in scale but contains abundant frame-building organisms, notably autochthonous corals and rudists. Though vertical succession was not recognized, in some parts of the limestone, large and massive corals make a rigid framework, whereas in other parts the main frame-builder is Praecaprotina yaegashii (Yehara), a caprotinid rudist, which often forms clusters but does not show dense packing. This paper is the first concrete description of carbonate buildup in the Cretaceous of East Asia. Existence of coral-rudist buildup indicates that the northern limit of tropical-subtropical realm reached north Japan in late Aptian time. The influx of abundant clastic material may have prevented the buildup from the development of large-scale reefs, but small-scale buildups could grow, though temporarily or episodically, on the rocky shore in a transgressive stage.
title: Discovery of a coral-rudist builup in the Miyako Group, northeast Japan. -
paper: Trans. Proc. Palaeont. Soc. Japan, N.S.

name: Long Quarry Point, Torquay, England
remarks: Torcay reef complex. Stromatopores and scattered tabulate and rugose corals. 25 % of reef volume by stromatoporoids. Gradual upward transition from laminar to domical to bulbous stromatoporoid facies in a 150 m thick sequence. Only lower 50 m are regarded as reef. Upper part is back reef'
title: Facies variations in the Devonian limestones of eastern South Devon. -

name: Torquay, England
remarks: Torcay reef complex. Tabulate and rugose corals, stromatopores. Abstract of ref. 744: The Middle and Upper Devonian limestone successions at Torquay and in the Lemon Valley SW of Newton Abbot (England) are described. Lithostratigraphic units are proposed for the Torquay succession. The compositions of the coral faunas in both successions are outlined and contribute, together with the other available faunal evidence, towards a broad internal dating of these limestone sequences. Successions elsewhere in the limestones of eastern South Devon are briefly outlined. On the basis of this evidence, facies variations from the margin towards the center of the carbonate platform in eastern South Devon are demonstrated and interpreted as reflecting the development of barrier reefs along parts at least of the platform margin in Givetian times. The character of the reef-complex, named the Tor Bay Reef-Complex, is briefly compared with Devonian reefs elsewhere.
title: Facies variations in the Devonian limestones of eastern South Devon. -

name: Collades de Basturs, Lleida
remarks: Mound with colonial corals, skeletal sponges and rudists. Praeradiolites, Biradiolites. Taxonomic data refer to paucispecific rudist lithosomes at Vilanoveta. Abstract ref. 1703: The late Cretaceous saw the sessile rudist bivalves reach maxima of adaptive diversity and abundance on Tethyan carbonate platforms, yielding extensive 'rudist formations'. Meanwhile, reef frameworks built by corals were of notably limited development, although diverse associations of corals in tabular bedded units may accompany the rudist formations. The hypothesis of competitive displacement of reef- building corals by rudists has sometimes been invoked to explain these patterns. An alternative view is that they reflect passive faunal replacement mediated by environmentally triggered extinctions, perhaps together with changes in carbonate platform ecosystems. The hypothesis of competition between contemporaneous organisms cannot be tested by looking at patterns of biotic turnover alone, as such patterns are the effects of many factors. What is needed is detailed palaeoecological analysis of co-occurrences of the postulated competitors. The Santonian carbonate platform deposits of Sant Corneli in the southern Central Pyrenees contain abundant and diverse corals, as well as rudists. A spectrum of biotic assemblages, from coral-dominated to rudist-dominated, is found to correspond with a sedimentary facies gradient expressed both in vertical successions and in a lateral zonation. The corals and rudists largely occupied different biotopes, and even in mixed assemblages no evidence for competitive interference between neighbours (e.g. overgrowth relationships) has been detected. These observations imply little, if any, mutual interference between members of the two groups, in the occupation of space, while inferred nutritional differences between them allow us to reject trophic overlap. Similar distributional patterns reported for other Cretaceous assemblages lead us to conclude that there was probably little or no competition between rudists and corals, so undermining the competitive displacement hypothesis. We further dispute the underlying assumption that the rudists were occupying broadly the same kinds of habitats that hosted coral reefs at other times: the rudists usually thrived on flat to gently inclined mobile sediment surfaces, which we argue would have been unfavourable sites for reef development. Coral to rudist transition in closed-by Vilanoveta.
authors: Scott, R.W., Fernández-Mendiola, P.A., Gili, E. & Simó, A.
title: Persistence of coral-rudist reefs into the Late Cretaceous. -

authors: Skelton, P.W., Nolan, S.C. & Scott, R.W.
title: The Maastrichtian trangression onto the northwestern flank of the Proto-Oman Mountains: sequences of rudist-bearing beach to open shelf facies. -
editors: Robertson, A.H.F., Searle, M.P. & Ries, A.C.
paper: The Geology and Tectonics of the Oman Region, Geol. Soc. Spec. Publ.

name: Mimizan, Aquitaine
remarks: Vraconian = uppermost Albian Rudist 'reefs' near the northern edge of carbonate platform. Thickness and detailed composition unknown. Mostly bioclastic rudist limestones.
title: Relations faciès - environment au Crétacé moyen en Aquitaine occidetale. -

name: SE-Aquitaine Basin
remarks: Small red algal rudist bioherms, reworked.
title: Relations faciès - environment au Crétacé moyen en Aquitaine occidetale. -

name: Dax, Aquitaine
remarks: Red algal and rudist fragments.

name: S-Paris Basin
title: Cretaceous coral-rudist buildups of France. -

paper: European Fossil Reef Models, SEPM Spec. Publ.

name: Arudy
remarks: More than 1000 m thick buildup, resulting form interconnection of coral lenses. Coral bafflestones at the base, coral bindstones at the top. Hexacorals and corraline algae (no encrusters). Reef formed on tectonic high, surrounded by basinal marls.
title: Cretaceous coral-rudist buildups of France. -
editors: Toomey, D.F.
paper: European Fossil Reef Models, SEPM Spec. Publ.

name: E-Paris Basin
remarks: A few m thick coral patches with low debris content. Corals bored. More than 100 species detected. Abundant epifauna (bryozoans, sponges, bivalves) but no green algae or rudists. High degree of bioencrustation.
title: Cretaceous coral-rudist buildups of France. -
editors: Toomey, D.F.
paper: European Fossil Reef Models, SEPM Spec. Publ.

name: SE-Paris Basin
title: Cretaceous coral-rudist buildups of France. -
editors: Toomey, D.F.
paper: European Fossil Reef Models, SEPM Spec. Publ.

name: Vercors
remarks: Coral beds with green algae and forams. Buildup growth mostly controlled by hydrodynamics (oobioclastic banks).
title: Cretaceous coral-rudist buildups of France. -
editors: Toomey, D.F.
paper: European Fossil Reef Models, SEPM Spec. Publ.

name: La Fare + Martigues, Provence
remarks: Biostrome complex. Corals, stromatoporoids, rudists, chaetetids, bryozoans, hydrozoa.
title: Cretaceous coral-rudist buildups of France. -
editors: Toomey, D.F.
paper: European Fossil Reef Models, SEPM Spec. Publ.

name: Rocca di Cave
remarks: Atoll-like structure with sandy shoals and platform edge and small organic buildups behind the edge.
title: Upper Cretaceous reef models from Rocca di Cave and adjacent areas in Latium, central Italy. -
editors: Toomey, D.F.
paper: European Fossil Reef Models, SEPM Spec. Publ.

name: Rocca di Cave II
remarks: Only rudstones with caprinid and radiolitid rudists, branching corals and red algae.
title: Upper Cretaceous reef models from Rocca di Cave and adjacent areas in Latium, central Italy. -
editors: Toomey, D.F.
paper: European Fossil Reef Models, SEPM Spec. Publ.

name: Artena-Cori
title: Upper Cretaceous reef models from Rocca di Cave and adjacent areas in Latium, central Italy. -
editors: Toomey, D.F.
paper: European Fossil Reef Models, SEPM Spec. Publ.

name: Mfamosing Quarry
remarks: Hydrozoans, Bacinella as major components. Additionally coralline algae and serpulids. Up to 9 m thick boundstone intervals. Plenty of detrital quartz present.
title: Mid-Cretaceous shelf carbonates: the Mfamosing Limestone, lower Benue Trough (Nigeria). -

name: Bab Field, Abu Dhabi
remarks: 58 m thick buildup composed of caprinid rudists with some microbes and algae (Bacinella, Lithocodium). Only one caprinid species.
authors: Frost, S.H., Bliefnick, D.M. & Harris, P.M.
title: Deposition and porosity evolution of a Lower Cretaceous rudist buildup, Shuaiba Formation of eastern Arabian Peninsula. -
editors: Harris, P.M.

name: Jebel Kawr
remarks: Solenopraceans probably more important than sponges. Was Norian/Rhaetian. Norian according to Flügel (2002)
title: Upper Triassic reefs of the Oman Mountains: Data from the south Tethyan margin. -

name: Jebel Wasa north, Oman Mountains
remarks: Almost only sponges and few algae
title: Upper Triassic reefs of the Oman Mountains: Data from the south Tethyan margin. -

name: Birkat al Mawz
remarks: Olistolithes in basinal chert facies. Faint traces of bioerosion.
title: Upper Triassic reefs of the Oman Mountains: Data from the south Tethyan margin. -

name: Jebel Wasa south
remarks: Reef debris dominates with 72% floatstones and 28% rudstones. Some large reefal blocks. Point counting results: 60% pharetronid sponges, 13% chaetetids, 13% dijectoporids/spongiomorphids, 8% corals, 4% solenoporaceans, 2% crinoids.
title: Upper Triassic reefs of the Oman Mountains: Data from the south Tethyan margin. -

name: Wenlock Edge, Shrophire, England
remarks: Tabulate corals are dominant. Other reef builders are stromatopores, bryozans and rugose corals. Stromatolite crusts are also common.
title: The conditions of growth of the Wenlock Limestone (mid-Silurian) of Shropshire, England. -

name: Dudley, England
remarks: 1.5-3 m high reef masses dominated by tabulates, stromatopores, rugose corals and bryozoans.
title: Composition, structure and environmental setting of Silurian bioherms and biostromes in northern Europe. -
editors: Toomey, D.F.
paper: European Fossil Reef Models, SEPM Spec. Publ.

name: Heröya, Ringerike
remarks: Thin (1 m) but persistent biostrome, strongly dominated by favositids.
title: Composition, structure and environmental setting of Silurian bioherms and biostromes in northern Europe. -
editors: Toomey, D.F.
paper: European Fossil Reef Models, SEPM Spec. Publ.

name: Holmestrand
remarks: Laterally persistent biostromes with tabulate corals (favositids, heliolitids, Thecia sp. syringoporids), rugose corals, algae, bryozoans, stromatopores, and others. Small bioherms in horizons. Very diverse (80 species without algae).
title: Composition, structure and environmental setting of Silurian bioherms and biostromes in northern Europe. -
editors: Toomey, D.F.
paper: European Fossil Reef Models, SEPM Spec. Publ.

name: Baerum
remarks: Small lensoid bioherms (6 m length, 2 m thickness). Dominated by Halysitids (tabulate coral) and stromatoporoids. Other constructors are favositids, heliolitids and syringoporids. Girvanella and bryozoans as binders. Collection entered by Foote (1999)
title: Composition, structure and environmental setting of Silurian bioherms and biostromes in northern Europe. -
editors: Toomey, D.F.
paper: European Fossil Reef Models, SEPM Spec. Publ.

name: Skien
remarks: 0.5 m high and 2-3 m across. See reef 1805 for more remarks.
title: Composition, structure and environmental setting of Silurian bioherms and biostromes in northern Europe. -
editors: Toomey, D.F.
paper: European Fossil Reef Models, SEPM Spec. Publ.

name: Ringerike
remarks: Several bioherms. Individual structures 15 long and 8 m high (maximum). Dominated by encrusting Girvanella, Rothpletzella, Wetheredella and Halysis. Some Halysitids. upper Llandovery bioherms also in area (like 1803).
title: Composition, structure and environmental setting of Silurian bioherms and biostromes in northern Europe. -
editors: Toomey, D.F.
paper: European Fossil Reef Models, SEPM Spec. Publ.

name: Usk, Wales
title: The geology of the Usk Inlier (Monmouthshire). -

name: Malvern, England
title: Bioherms in the Wenlock Limestone of the Malvern area (Herefordshire, England). -

name: Liesberg, Jura
remarks: Mid-Oxfordian microsolenid biostrome. Corals moderately diverse, extremely rich associated faunas. 30-70 % skeletal biovolume. Below St. Ursanne reefs. Description also referring to Haute-Roches locality.
title: Upper Jurassic microsolenid biostromes of northern and central Europe: facies and depositional environment. -

name: Amelungsberg, Süntel
remarks: Anastomosing branching corals. Thamnasteria dendroida. Thrombolites. Solenoporaceans. Some pharetronid sponges. Serpulids, Rothpletzella sp. Upper Oxfordian. 4 m thick coral bank.
title: A coral-microbialite patch reef from the Late Jurassic (florigemma-bank, Oxfordian) of NW Germany (Süntel Mountains). -

name: Wadi Bani Kharus
remarks: Reworked biostrome. Packstone facies is 26 m thick. Lime mud matrix and some spar. Caprotinid and requienid rudists, corals and stromatropores. Additionally Solenopora, algae and microbes.
title: Carbonate sediment-fill of an oceanic shelf, Lower Cretaceous, Arabian Peninsula. -

name: Penobscot, Nova Scotia
remarks: Thin thrombolithic buildup on low angle ramp.
authors: Ellis, P.M., Crevello, P.D. & Eliuk, L.S.
title: Upper Jurassic and Lower Cretaceous deep-water buildups, Abenaki Formation, Nova Scotia Shelf. -

name: Bolishoi Balkhan
remarks: Probably plate 345. Coral biostromes (diverse) with some associated mollusks and brachiopods.
title: Nekotory rezultaty izuchennya nizhnemelovykh skleraktinii gornykh rainov zapadnoi Turkmenii. -

name: Bolishoi Balkhan II

name: Höbek Tepe, Amasya
remarks: Vaccinitesa and Yvaniella dominate hippuritid fauna. Upright growth position. Corals abundant. Some corallinacean and squamariacean debris. Bioerosion very scarce.
title: Late Cretaceous rudist-beds of the Amasya region (north-central Anatolia). -
paper: 6th Internat. Symposium on Fossil Algae and Carbonate Platforms

name: Lee Siding, Arizona
remarks: Coral-stromatolite-rudist reef. Back reef with coral-rudist fragments.
title: Biotic relations in Early Cretaceous coral-algal-rudist reefs, Arizona. -

name: Iberg, Harz
remarks: At least 800 m thick. Stromatopores of all growth forms, rugose and tabulate corals as well as crinoids are common. Renalcis is rare. 72 % of reef are rudstones. Reef growth terminated in rhenana condont zone.
title: Fazies, Bau und Entwicklungsgeschichte des Iberger Riffes (Mitteldevon und Unterkarbon III, NW-Harz, W-Deutschland). -

name: Lares & Ciales, Puerto Rico
remarks: Carbonate shelf with patch reefs. see also reef 1347.
title: Oligocene-Miocene extinction and geographic restriction of Caribbean corals: Roles of turbidity, temperature, and nutrients. -

name: Brizas del Caribe, Puerto Rico
remarks: Carbonate embayment with patch reefs. Borings more pronounced than in Oligocene reefs. see also reef 1347.
title: Oligocene-Miocene extinction and geographic restriction of Caribbean corals: Roles of turbidity, temperature, and nutrients. -

name: Rio Guajataca, Puerto Rico

name: Mona Island, Caribbean, Puerto Rico

title: Oligocene-Miocene extinction and geographic restriction of Caribbean corals: Roles of turbidity, temperature, and nutrients. -

name: Guánica, Puerto Rico
remarks: Abstract of ref- 834: About half the Caribbean hermatypic corals died out in the Caribbean during the latest Oligocene through Early Miocene, about 24-16 Ma. The majority of those corals that died out in the Caribbean are extant in the Indo-Pacific, i.e., they suffered geographic restriction, rather than extinction. The coral and coral associate faunas of three Upper Oligocene and three Middle Miocene fossil reefs in western Puerto Rico were compared. Coral genera at these sites suffered 50% regional extinction (extinction or restriction), equivalent to earlier reports of this Caribbean coral extinction/restriction event. Nearly all coral genera tolerant of both turbidity and cool water survived. Those tolerant of cool water or turbidity alone survived in much lesser proportions. Corals occurring on both patch reefs and shelf edge reefs survived in much greater proportions than those occurring on only patch reefs or only shelf edge reefs. There are no shelf edge barrier reef complexes documented from the Early or Middle Miocene in the Caribbean. the uppermost Miocene shelf edge reefs of Mona Island are the only known Miocene shelf edge reef deposits in the Caribbean. Coral associates, the endolithic sponges, bivalves, worms, and barnacles that live in coral skeletons, were almost completely unaffected by this event. Likewise, reef and off-reef gastropods, bivalves, and echinoids suffered only insignificant reductions in diversity. Only corals and large benthic foraminifera were strongly affected by the extinction. It is significant that zooxanthellate organisms were the primary victims of this extinction. Miocene endolithic sponge borings are significantly larger than their Oligocene counterparts, suggesting more intense bioerosion on Miocene than Oligocene reefs. Bioerosion is generally correlated with nutrient levels, and the apparently more intense bioerosion of Miocene corals may indicate enhanced nutrient availability on Miocene Caribbean reefs. Extensive Miocene phosphorites throughout the Caribbean indicate enhanced upwelling in the region during the time of the coral extinction/restriction. Biogeographic evidence from corals, coral associates, and molluscs corroborates this pattern, along with the evidence from bioerosion levels. Enhanced upwelling could account for the extinction/restriction by generally increasing nutrient levels and cooling Caribbean costal surface waters, thus restricting reef development to on-shelf patch reefs, where corals would be subject to more intense sedimentation. Modern reefs of the Eastern Pacific may provide a modern analogue to Miocene Caribbean reefs. This regional extinction was important in dividing a previously cosmopolitan reef fauna into several modern provincial faunas. This biogeographic separation was completed in the mid-Pliocene with the rise of the isthmus of Panama. Coral associates, which universally survived the Oligocene-Miocene event, also have much more cosmopolitan distributions than do corals.
title: Oligocene-Miocene extinction and geographic restriction of Caribbean corals: Roles of turbidity, temperature, and nutrients. -

name: Ancient Wall II, Alberta
remarks: see reef 1353. Includes Berland Carbonate Complex, Persimmon Range
title: Ancient Wall reef complex, Frasnian age, Alberta. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Ancient Wall, Alberta
remarks: Two stacked buildups. Reef formed by periodic growth of stromatoporoid biostromes. Probably plate 101, but position is west of Tip Top thrust. Together 300 m thickness. No platform edge. Platform facies along the reef margins.
title: Ancient Wall reef complex, Frasnian age, Alberta. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Slave Field, Alberta
remarks: Sediment-binding to baffling tabulate and bulbous stromatoporoids and some Amphipora float- and rudstones. Boundstones flanking and onlapping granitic high. Fringing reef. Up to 25 m thick. 5.8 km long.
authors: Dunham, J.B., Crawford, G.A. & Panasiuk, W.
title: Sedimentology of the Slave Point Formation (Devonian) at Slave Field, Lubicon Lake, Alberta. -

name: Swan Hills Buildup, Alberta
remarks: Atoll-like reef. 80 m thick. Stromatopores predominate by far (hemispheripcal, tabular and branching). Amphipora and encrusting green algae are present. 3 Stromatoporoids - Amphipora - Stromatoporoids 2 Table reef 1 Amphipora beds This for Givetian part 7.8 % avg. porosity.
title: Depositional sequences, facies and evolution of the Upper Devonian Swan Hills reef buildup, central Alberta, Canada. -

name: Swan Hills Buildup, Alberta
remarks: This for Frasnian part. Givetian is 1356
title: Depositional sequences, facies and evolution of the Upper Devonian Swan Hills reef buildup, central Alberta, Canada. -

name: Nisku, Brazeau, Alberta
remarks: Nisku reef trend, probably plate 124. Fasciculate rugose corals are predominatnt (dendroid forms most abundant). A few thamnoporoid corals, tabular stromatoporoids and some algal coatings (stromatoplaites, Renalcis). Average thickness 100 m, extension 1.5 km.
title: Facies and diagenesis of some Nisku buildups and associated strata, Upper Devonian, Alberta, Canada. -

name: Frasnes area
remarks: Reinterpreted as mud mounds by ref. 976 lower Givetian patch reefs are also present. Includes data from Arche, Nord and Lion quarries.
title: Les recifs paleozoiques Belgique. -

name: Philippeville
remarks: Horizon F 2h. 200-250 m thick, 1-4 km wide. Corals at base. Lamellate stromatopores in interior. Reinterpreted as mud mounds by ref. 976.
title: Les recifs paleozoiques Belgique. -

name: Renlies
remarks: 80 m thickness, 100-150 m basal diameter. Constracted by Tetracorals and tabulates. Additional sponges, brachiopods, bryozoans and crinoids bus minor stromatopores.
title: Les recifs paleozoiques Belgique. -

name: Jebel Madar
remarks: Microbe-coral-stromatoporoid patch reefs.
title: Early Cretaceous platform-margin configuration and evolution in the central Oman Mountains, Arabian Peninsula. -

name: Jebel Madar, Al Mudhaibi
remarks: 10 m thick biostrome composed of caprinids and requienids. Age revised, based on ref 2501.
title: Early Cretaceous platform-margin configuration and evolution in the central Oman Mountains, Arabian Peninsula. -

name: Wadi Laasi and El Assyi, Nakhl
remarks: Bioclastic coral-rudist limestone. 3 rudist species, corals not described. Some in-situ faunal assemblages. Overlain by rudist packstones with 7 rudist species.
title: Early Cretaceous platform-margin configuration and evolution in the central Oman Mountains, Arabian Peninsula. -

name: Wadi Nakhr
remarks: same facies as 1361. 4 m thick patch reef formed by small bioherms.
title: Early Cretaceous platform-margin configuration and evolution in the central Oman Mountains, Arabian Peninsula. -

name: Wadi el Assyi, Wadi Barakh, Wadi Laasi
remarks: Several biostromes in a 100 m thick interval. Caprinid, radiolitid and requienid rudists, oysters, corals and Nerinea.
title: Early Cretaceous platform-margin configuration and evolution in the central Oman Mountains, Arabian Peninsula. -

name: Wadi Hanjouriyah
title: Jurassic and Early Cretaceous platform margin configuration and evolution, central Oman Mountains. -
editors: Robertson, A.H.F., Searle, M.P. & Ries, A.C.
paper: The Geology and Tectonics of the Oman Region, Geol. Soc. Spec. Publ.

name: Wadi Qurr
remarks: Microbe-coral-stromatopore boundstones unit between Wadi Qurr and southern end of Wadi Dayqa.

editors: Robertson, A.H.F., Searle, M.P. & Ries, A.C.
paper: The Geology and Tectonics of the Oman Region, Geol. Soc. Spec. Publ.

name: Wadi Mi'aidin
remarks: Lithotis biostromes?

paper: The Geology and Tectonics of the Oman Region, Geol. Soc. Spec. Publ.

name: Seewarte, Carnic Alps
remarks: Almost no fossils in situ (only Amphipora in back reef). Sandy crinoid-stromatopore-Thamnopora limestones. Includes and Seewarte-Kellerspitzen and Cima Ombaldet.
title: Depositional environments in the Devonian limestone succession of the Cima Ombladet (Carnic Alps, Italy). -

name: Elbingerode, Harz
remarks: Reef growth from varcus-Zone (Givetian) to gigas-Zone (Fransian). Stromatopores and corals (Heliolites, Thamnopora, ì Phillipsastrea). No in situ framework (eroded?).
title: Charakter und Ende der devonischen Riffentwicklung im Elbingeröder Komplex (Harz). -

name: Puale Bay, Alaska
remarks: Bedded coral biomicrite with spongiomorphs and brachiopods. 45 m thickness.
authors: Wang, J., Newton, C.R. & Dunne, L.
title: Late Triassic transition from biogenic to arc sedimentation on the Peninsular terrane: Puale Bay, Alaska Peninsula. -

name: Jasper, Alberta
remarks: Basal stromatolite mounds up to 30 m thick. Individual mounds closely spaced. Inter-mound sediments are siltstones and shales.
title: The Late Proterozoic Yellowhead carbonate platform west of Jasper, Alberta. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Jasper II, Alberta
remarks: Younger mounds (compare reef 1371). Smaller and shallower water than in basal mounds.
title: The Late Proterozoic Yellowhead carbonate platform west of Jasper, Alberta. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Dobbin Bay, Ellesmere Island
remarks: Renalcis mounds up to 3 m thick and 6 m wide. 2-15 m water depth Late Early Cambrian

editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Forteau Bay, Labrador
remarks: Archaeocyaths predominate (40 % of limestone). Renalcis with 30 % of reef. Coalescended reef complex at Fox Cove is 15.5 m thicka and 130 m wide. Individual mounds less than 1 m thick.
authors: James, N.P., Kobluk, D.R. & Klappa, C.F.

editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Port au Port, Newfoundland
remarks: Microbe bioherm on siliciclastic carbonate shelf. 10 m high, 80 m wide. Basal Thrombolite, upper stromatolite zone. Cape Ann Member

name: E-Wernecke Mountains, Yukon
remarks: Bonnia-Olenellus Zone. Max. 1 m thick and 3 m long. 50 % of volume is matrix (Mudstone and sparite). Archaeocyaths (10-60 %) and microbes (Renalcis, Epiphyton, Grivanella).

name: Mackenzie Mts., NW Territories
remarks: Age indicated as earliest Late Cambrian (Marjuman) Ramp-style slope. Up to 25 m thick and 120 m wide. Girvanella, Epiphyton, Renalcis.

name: Misty Creek, Arctic Red

name: Mingan Islands II, Quebec
remarks: See reef 1382 for remarks. Includes Ile Nue Mingan locality

editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Mingan Islands, Quebec
remarks: Early Middle Ordovician biostromes, bioherms and bioherm complexes (up to 6 m thick). Lithistid sponges (10-30 % of reef volume), seven genera Bryozoans relatively diverse (encrusting and branching), ten genera Tabulate corals up to 20 % of reef volume (Billingsaria and Eofletcheria). Solenoporaceans rare. Micritic crusts (microbes). Very rare stromatoporoids. Includes Petite Ile au Marteau locality
title: Middle Ordovician (Chazyan) bioherms and biostromes of the Mingan Islands, Quebec. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Long Point, Port au Port, Newfoundland
remarks: Blackriverian Tabulate corals (Labyrinthites) very dominant. 60-95 % of rock volume. Some stromatopores and bryozoans. Diversity updated Maximum thickness 15 m (rare), width below 12 m. Tyrpanites borings. Lourdes Limestone of the Long Point Group. Black Duck Member
title: Middle Ordovician coral reefs; western Newfoundland. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Johnson Creek, Yukon
remarks: Gryphea bank, 15-18 m thick
title: Lower Jurassic Gryphea bank, northern Yukon. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Harrison Lake, B.C.
remarks: Buchia banks. Biostromes less than 1 m thick, interbedded with sandstone.
title: Early Cretaceous Buchia banks, British Columbia.-
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Taseko Lake, B.C.
remarks: Buchia banks and coquinas. Up to tens of m thick biostrome intervals.
title: Early Cretaceous Buchia banks, British Columbia.-
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Mount Laurier, British Columbia
remarks: Reworked shell banks. Up to 125 m thick.
title: Upper Triassic shell banks, Mount Laurier area, northeastern British Columbia. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Table Point, Newfoundland
remarks: See remarks of reef 1389.
title: Lithistid sponge bioherms, early Middle Ordovician, western Newfoundland. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Port-au-Choix, Newfoundland
remarks: Lithistid sponge bioherms. Up to 1 m thick and 6 m wide. Sponges (Hudsonospongia, Anthaspidella, Archaeoscyphia) with less abundant bryozoans, ostracodes, mollusks, pelmatozoans and some calcareous algae. Localities are Gargamelle Bay and Pointe Riche.
title: Lithistid sponge bioherms, early Middle Ordovician, western Newfoundland. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Chicoutimi, Quebec
remarks: Uppermost Caradocian. Trenton Group 40 cm thick and 8 m wide. Bryozoans, corals, stromatopores and receptaculit algae as reef builders. Pelmatozoans and gastropods common.
authors: Harland, T.L., Pickerill, R.K. & Fillion, D.
title: Establishment and development of patch reefs in the intracratonic Ordovician sequence near Chicoutimi, Quebec. -

name: S Mackenzie Mts. II, N.W.T.
remarks: 300 m thick dolomitized boundstone sequence of thrombolites and Renalcis.
title: Continental margin reef tract of Early Ordovician age, Broken Skull Formation, Mackenzie Mountains, northwest Canada. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: S Mackenzie Mts., N.W.T.
remarks: Coalesced bioherms. 123 m thick barrier reef complex. Framework composed of Thromoblites and Renalcis.
title: Continental margin reef tract of Early Ordovician age, Broken Skull Formation, Mackenzie Mountains, northwest Canada. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Mount Wilson, Alberta
remarks: Up to 2 m thick and 10-15 m wide patch reefs. Above storm wave base, below fair weather wave base. Open marine shelf.
title: Early Ordovician cryptalagal-sponge reefs, Survey Peak Formation, Rocky Mountains, Alberts. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Wilcox Pass, Alberta
remarks: see reef 1394 for remarks.
title: Early Ordovician cryptalagal-sponge reefs, Survey Peak Formation, Rocky Mountains, Alberts. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Caughnawaga, Quebec
remarks: Framework composed of trepostome bryozoans, pelmatozoan holdfasts, tabulate corals and rare lithistid sponges.
title: Small early Middle Ordovician patch reefs, Laval Formation (Chazy Group), Caughnawaga, Montreal area, Quebec. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Green Head, Newfoundland
remarks: Thrombolites, tabulate corals (Lichenaria) and Renalcis forming rigid framework. 12 m thick, > 80 m wide. 3 distinct biotic associations.
title: Coral-Renalcis-Thrombolite reef complex of Early Ordovician age, St. George Group, western Newfoundland. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Steinvika
remarks: Thickness 4-6 m, wideness 28-35 m. Stromatopores, rugose and tabulate corals, algae, microbes and scarce bryozoans. Boring polychaets mentioned. Cystoids also important.
title: Middle Ordovician reefs of Norway. -

name: Bergevika, Helgöya
remarks: Largest reef is 15 m thick and 50 m wide. Stromatoporoids very dominant in major reef.
title: Middle Ordovician reefs of Norway. -

name: Asstranda
remarks: See reef 1398 for remarks.
title: Middle Ordovician reefs of Norway. -

name: Asjördet
remarks: Patch reef, thickness 4-6 m, lateral extent 10-20 m. Solenopora more important than in reef 1398. Cystoids absent.
title: Middle Ordovician reefs of Norway. -

name: Eddies Cove West, Newfoundland
remarks: See reef 1402.
title: Early Ordovician Thromolite reefs, St. George Group, western Newfoundland. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Boat Harbor, Newfoundland
remarks: Small thrombolite mounds
title: Early Ordovician Thromolite reefs, St. George Group, western Newfoundland. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Eddies Cove West, Newfoundland
title: Early Ordovician Thromolite reefs, St. George Group, western Newfoundland. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Port au Port, Newfoundland
remarks: Thrombolitic mound with abundant fenestrae. Jeffersonian-Cassinian regional stages
title: Early Ordovician Thromolite reefs, St. George Group, western Newfoundland. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Bessels Fjord II, Greenland
remarks: 50 m maximum thickness, 200 m laterally. Starting probably in latest Ashgillian but certainly ranging into the earliest Silurian.
title: Latest Ordovician-earliest Silurian carbonate mounds, western north Greenland. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Hall Land, Greenland
remarks: Graptolithes (Climacograptus inuiti) indicate latest Ordovician, conodonts earliest Llandovery age.
title: Latest Ordovician-earliest Silurian carbonate mounds, western north Greenland. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Gaspé Peninsula, Quebec
remarks: Nearly 600 m thick reef complex at margin of siliciclastic shelf. 4 subdivisions. Relatively little debris. Fore reef slope 30°. Stromatopores and microbes as binders.
title: Stromatoporoid-coral reefs of the upper West Point reef complex, Late Silurian, Gaspe Peninsula, Quebec. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Gaspé Peninsula II, Quebec
remarks: Stromatactic mounds of Gros Morbe Member of West Point Formation. Sponges only present as spicules. Some echinoderms, favositid corals, stromatopores and bryozoans are present. Small dasycaldaceans present.
title: Non-skeletal bioherms of the lower reef complex of the West Point Formation, Late Silurian, Gaspe Peninsula, Quebec. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Attawapiskat River, Ontario
title: Attawapiskat patch reefs, Lower Silurian, Hudson Bay lowlands, Ontario. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Attawapiskat River, Ontario
remarks: Stromatopore-coral patch reefs described. Dimensions (6 m thick, up to 250 m wide) point to biostrome rather than reef mound. High percentage of micrite mentioned.
title: Attawapiskat patch reefs, Lower Silurian, Hudson Bay lowlands, Ontario. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: East Point, Anticosti Isl., Quebec
remarks: Bioherm cluster (50 bioherms). 1-4 m thick, 2-10 m wide. Catenipora and Paleofavosites. Rare macroborings but widespread microborings according to Copper, pers. comm.
title: Upper Ordovician and Lower Silurian reefs of Anticosti Island, Quebec. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: South Point, Anticosti Isl., Quebec
remarks: Small Catenipora reef.
title: Upper Ordovician and Lower Silurian reefs of Anticosti Island, Quebec. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: W-Anticosti Isl., Quebec
remarks: Point Laframboise bioherms. Diverse corals and alga Wetherdella. Rare stromatoporoids. 3-4 m thick, 6-10 m wide. Hinantian stage.
title: Upper Ordovician and Lower Silurian reefs of Anticosti Island, Quebec. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Vaureal River, E-Anticosti Isl., Quebec
remarks: Patch reef and biostromes in Prinsta member Coral-stromatoporoid
title: Upper Ordovician and Lower Silurian reefs of Anticosti Island, Quebec. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: N-Anticosti Isl., Quebec
remarks: Rawtheyan stage. Small 1 m thick, 3 m wide bioherms. Tabulate and rugose corals (cerioid to cateniform).
title: Upper Ordovician and Lower Silurian reefs of Anticosti Island, Quebec. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: SW Point, Anticosti Isl., Quebec
remarks: 5 m thick, up to 40 m diameter. 40 bioherms. Tabulate and rugose corals dominate. Additionally stromatopores.
title: Upper Ordovician and Lower Silurian reefs of Anticosti Island, Quebec. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Rockville, Manitoulin Isl., Ontario
remarks: Stromatopores and rare favositids and bryozonas.
title: An Early Silurian reef complex, Manitoulin Island, northern Ontario .-
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Manitowaning, Manitoulin Isl., Ontario
remarks: 300 reefs. Maximum 12 m thick, 200 m wide. Massive biolithite with scattered pockets of calcarernite. Cerioid and phaceloid rugosans, stromatopores, tabulate corals. Tabulate corals (Favosites>Halysites, Syringopora) predominate. Stromatoporoids second. Thick micrite encrustations. High porosity and occasional bitumen showings.
title: An Early Silurian reef complex, Manitoulin Island, northern Ontario .-
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Drummond Island II, Michigan
remarks: Bryozoan mounds up to 3 m thick and 5-10 m wide. Trepostome bryozoans (Hallopora).
title: Drummond Island bryozoan reefs, Lower Silurian, Michigan. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Lock Haven, Pennsylvania
remarks: 10 m thick, 300 m wide. Massive tabulate corals, branching tabulate corals and branching trepostome bryozoans. Calcarenite apron around reef lacking bryozoans and corals.
title: Lock Haven coral-bryozoan reef, Middle Silurian, Pennsylvania. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Alba, Michigan
remarks: Dolomitized barrier reef of trepostome bryozoans and unidentified stromatopores.
title: Alba stromatoporoid-bryozoan reef, Middle Silurian, Michigan. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Honora Bay, Manitoulin Isl., Ontario
remarks: Rhuddanian stage. Trepostomes bryozoans and some encrustings ones. 1 m thick and 3 m wide bioherms. 4 species of bryozoans and one coral mentioned, but incompletely studied.
title: Honora Bay bryozoan bioherms, Lower Silurian, Manitoulin Island, Ontario. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Coryell, Texas
remarks: Edwards stage rudist bioherms. Central Texas reef trend.
title: Edwards Formation (Lower Cretaceous), Texas: Dolomitization in a carbonate platform system. -

name: Niagara Gorge, New York
remarks: Bryozoan crust mounds. Bryozoan bafflestone overlain by encrustings bryozoans. Bioherms situated on crinoidal shoals. 2 m high, 3-4 m wide.
title: Beck and Searly bryozoan reefs, Middle Silurian, Niagara Gorge, Ontario and New York. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Altoona, Pennsylvania
remarks: Encrusting bryozoans at base, overlain by coral-stromatopore bindstone.
title: Altoona bryozoan-coral-stromatoporoid reef, uppermost Silurian, Pennsylvania. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Gascons, Gaspé, Quebec
remarks: Bryozoan-coral-algal-stromatopore bioherms. 15 m surface, 50 m subsurface. Width 60 m. Cladoporid bryozoans (probably tabulate corals). Llandovery part of 65 m thick reef complex
title: Lower Silurian biostromes and bioherms of southern Gaspe, Quebec Appalachians. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Marcil Anticline, Gaspé, Quebec
remarks: Wenlock part of reef 1426
title: Lower Silurian biostromes and bioherms of southern Gaspe, Quebec Appalachians. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Marcil Anticline, Gaspé, Quebec
remarks: Rugose coral biostromes up to 15 m thick. Accessory tabulate corals, stromatopores and encrusting bryozoans.
title: Lower Silurian biostromes and bioherms of southern Gaspe, Quebec Appalachians. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Gascons, Gaspé, Quebec
remarks: Wenlock portion of reef 1425
title: Lower Silurian biostromes and bioherms of southern Gaspe, Quebec Appalachians. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Southhampton Island, N.W.T.
remarks: Hansine Lake area. Bioherm complexes of stromatolite mounds with stromatopores-coral mounds. Circular tabulate and rugose coral mounds up to 50 m across, less than 2 m thick.
title: Early Silurian bioherms, Southampton Island, N.W.T. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Lake Memphremagog, Quebec
remarks: Only reworked debris present.
title: Upper Silurian reefal facies of the Memphremagog - Marbleton area, Eastern Townships, Quebec Appalachians. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Marbleton, Quebec
remarks: Mostly rud- and floatstones. Reefal unit 200 m thick. Kerogen in microfractures.
title: Upper Silurian reefal facies of the Memphremagog - Marbleton area, Eastern Townships, Quebec Appalachians. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Allenwood, Pennsylvania
remarks: Favosites patch reef. Below fair weather, above storm wave base.
title: Favositid patch reef, Early Silurian, Allenwood, Pennsylvania. U.S.A. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Pipe Creek, Indiana
remarks: 11 miles SW of Marion, Indiana. Possibly older (Ludlov). 48 m thick and 1.8 km wide. Steep flanks. Reef crest with Renalcis-stromatopore-tabulate coral framestone. Reef flank with bryozoans, stromatactis, stromatopores, corals in pack-, rud-, bind- and framestones. Highest porosity in interreef sediments. Fossil in collection (Miller) were collected from the flank beds of the reef. Five lithologies were recognized: limestone, swirly limestone, dolomite and dolomitic limestone, silty mudstone, and interreef siltstone. 97% of the beds in the measured sections were limestone or swirly limestone. limestone described as white to gray, coarse-grained, and highly fossiliferous. swirly limestone described as argillaceous, characterized by milky while sparry calcite mixed with stringers and blobs of green silt to clay sized particles, medium to coarse-grained gray limestone and echinodermal debris
title: Depositional facies and diagenesis of the Pipe Creek Jr. Reef, Silurian, Great Lakes Region, Indiana. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Fury Beach, Somerset Isl., N.W.T.
remarks: Lithistid sponge mounds in deep subtidal environment. Overlain by coral-rich crinoidal wackestone. 50 % fossils, rest is micrite and spar. 15 m thick. Up to 35 m wide. Between fair weather and storm wave base.
title: Sponge-dominated reef mounds in the Douro Formation (Upper Silurian) of Somerset Island, N.W.T. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Pressure Point, Somerset Isl., N.W.T.
title: Sponge-dominated reef mounds in the Douro Formation (Upper Silurian) of Somerset Island, N.W.T. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Petit Rocher, New Brunswick
remarks: Massive stromatopore facies with stromatolites, Thamnopora facies, breccia facies. Bind- and bafflestones.
title: The Late Silurian Laplante reefs of northern New Brunswick, Canada. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Qpsalquitch R., New Brunswick
remarks: Subfacies of a reef complex. Stromatopores and microbial micritic crusts dominate. Associated tabulate corals.
title: The Late Silurian Laplante reefs of northern New Brunswick, Canada. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Petit Rocher II, New Brunswick
remarks: See 1435 for remarks.
title: The Late Silurian Laplante reefs of northern New Brunswick, Canada. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Wayne, West Virginia
remarks: Subsurface data, Lockport dolomite. 6 m thick stromatopore boundstone. Abundant crinoids and corals. Bryozoans and calcisponges rare.
title: Stromatoporoid reefs and banks in the Silurian of the Appalchian Basin. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Johnson, Kentucky
remarks: Subsurface data, Lockport dolomite. Skeletal bank with tabulate corals, tabulate stromatopores and ramose bryozoans.
title: Stromatoporoid reefs and banks in the Silurian of the Appalchian Basin. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Kap Tyson, Hall Land, Greenland
remarks: Slope mound. See also reef 1440.
title: Franklinian reef belt, Silurian, North Greenland. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Koch Fjord, Peary Land, Greenland
remarks: Incipient stage of buildup comlex.
title: Franklinian reef belt, Silurian, North Greenland. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Newman Bugt, Nyeboe Land, Greenland
remarks: Slope mound. See also reef 1440.
title: Franklinian reef belt, Silurian, North Greenland. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Kap Jefferson, Washington Land, Greenland
remarks: Platform margin buildup.
title: Franklinian reef belt, Silurian, North Greenland. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Kap Ammen, Hall Land, Greenland
remarks: Stromatopores and corals. Stromatactis very important.
title: Franklinian reef belt, Silurian, North Greenland. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Kap Independence, Washington Land, Greenland
remarks: Slope buildup. Stromatactis important. Stromatopores and corals present. Stromatoporoid-tabulate coral bindstone association buildup of ref. 1511. Acted as stabilizers of sediment. 600 m thick. Similar reef on Hans island described by ref. 1104.
title: Franklinian reef belt, Silurian, North Greenland. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Central Warming Land, Greenland
remarks: See reef 1443 for remarks.
title: Franklinian reef belt, Silurian, North Greenland. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Kap Quensel, Wulff Land, Greenland
remarks: Intrashelf buildup.
title: Franklinian reef belt, Silurian, North Greenland. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Aphrodite Sö, Wulff Land, Greenland
remarks: Rink Firn Mounds. Platform margin-deeper ramp buildups. Stromatactis-rich lime mudstone and stromatopore-coral boundstones.
title: Franklinian reef belt, Silurian, North Greenland. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Nisku, Bigoray, Alberta
remarks: Nisku reef trend. Branching corals dominant. Initially below wave base. Probably plate 124.
title: The Upper Devonian Nisku reef trend in central Alberta. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: White Man Gap, Canmore, Alberta
remarks: Bulbous stromatopores, Amphipora floatstone and featureless mudstone. Mud trapped from intertidal sources in a relatively deep water setting. Fairholme. Probably plate 101.
authors: Bloy, G.R., Leggett, S.R. & Hunter, I.G.
title: The Lower Fairholme reef complex (Cairn Formation), White Man Gap area, Canmore, Alberta. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: N Holitna Basin, Sleetmute, Alaska
title: Silurian-Devonian algal reef mound complex of southwest Alaska. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: White Mountain, McGrath, Alaska
remarks: Nixon Fork terrane. Stromatolite reef mounds on a carbonate ramp. Some aphrosalpingid sphinctozoans associated. Up to 500 m thick. Probably plate 125.
title: Silurian-Devonian algal reef mound complex of southwest Alaska. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: N Holitna Basin, Sleetmute, Alaska
remarks: Coalescended thrombolite mounds. Continuous reef growth from Prodolian to Pragian? Probably plate 125.
title: Silurian-Devonian algal reef mound complex of southwest Alaska. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Montauk Bluff, Alaska
remarks: Only foreslope debris is present.
title: Coral-stromatoporoid reef complex, late Early Devonian age, Ogilvie Formation of east-central Alaska and adjacent Yukon Territory. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Squaw Mountain, Ogilvie Mts, Alaska
remarks: Probably plate 123. Over 40 m thick coral-stromatopore reef complex overlying Renalcis bioherms. 50-70 % made of coral framestones, half of them in situ. Colonial rugosans (Xystriphyllum, Spongophyllum) tabulates (Favosites) and tabular to lamellar stromatopores. Stromatopores often on coral heads. Microbes are Renalcis and Girvanella.
title: Coral-stromatoporoid reef complex, late Early Devonian age, Ogilvie Formation of east-central Alaska and adjacent Yukon Territory. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Sierra, British Columbia
remarks: Base is intensly dolomitized. Within basin facies. Stromatopores very dominant. Algae and corals rare.
title: Sierra reef complex, Middle Devonian, northeastern British Columbia. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Cripple Creek, Fairholme, Alberta
remarks: Margin of Fairholm reef complex. 300 m thick reef complex. 30 km wide, > 100 km long. Stromatoporoids, aphiporids, corals, mollusks. Coalescended knoll reefs.
title: Cripple Creek margin, north Fairholme reef complex, Frasnian age, Alberta. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Mercy Bay, Banks Island, N.W.T.
remarks: 50 patch reefs, up to 60 m thick and 150 m wide. Shallow siliciclastic shelf.
title: Mercy Bay patch reefs, Frasnian, Banks Island, Canadian Arctic Archipelago. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Golden Field, Alberta
remarks: Reef fringing a granitic island.
authors: Gosselin, E.G., Smith, L. & Mundy, D.J.C.
title: The Golden and Evi reef complexes, Middle Devonian, Slave Point Formation, northwestern Alberta. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Evi Field, Alberta
remarks: 42 m maximum thickness. Intraplatform to platform margin facies.
authors: Gosselin, E.G., Smith, L. & Mundy, D.J.C.
title: The Golden and Evi reef complexes, Middle Devonian, Slave Point Formation, northwestern Alberta. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Normandville, Alberta
remarks: Probably marginifera zone. 10 m thick stromatopore-algal(?) reefs. Five stromatoporoid species. Labechiid and other forms.
title: A stromatoporoid patch reef in the Upper Devonian Wabamun Group, Normandville Field, north-central Alberta. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Allstones Creek, Alberta
remarks: Coralline patch reef overlying bryozoan shoals. Situated in paleo-channel between platform reefs. Colonial rugose corals.
title: Allstones Creek reef (Frasnian), Alberta. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Hummingbird and Whiterabbit, Alberta
remarks: Margin of platfrom reef complex. Middle Frasnian, Fairholme.
title: Hummingbird and Whiterabbit reef margins (Frasnian), Alberta. -

name: Romberg, Brilon

name: Grünewiese
remarks: Grünewiese: Small differentiated bioherm of massive boundstones, and bedded reef debris. Knobby to hemispherical, laminar and encrusting reef builder morphologies. Stromatoporoids, alveolitids and chaetetids prevailing. Occasional solitary rugosans. 17 species of tabulate corals 10 species of rugose corals 7 species of stromatoporoids 1 species of chaetetids 10 species of algae and microbes 1 species of encrusting forams 6 species of bryozoans Micrite envelopes. Rare macroborings (Trypanites). Distinct ecological succession. Bredenbruch: Massive rugose corals (Hexgonaria) and ramose tabulate and rugose corals. 15 m thick bioherm.
title: Die devonischen Riffe im Rheinischen Schiefergebirge. Teil 1. -
