name: Mc Kinley Bay, Ellesmere Isl., N.W.T.
remarks: See reef 1860 for remarks.
authors: Morin, J., Desrochers, A. & Beauchamp, B.
title: Facies analysis of Lower Permian platform carbonates, Sverdrup Basin, Canadian Arctic Archipelago. -

name: Mc Kinley Bay, Ellesmere Isl., N.W.T.
remarks: See reef 1860 for remarks.
authors: Morin, J., Desrochers, A. & Beauchamp, B.
title: Facies analysis of Lower Permian platform carbonates, Sverdrup Basin, Canadian Arctic Archipelago. -

name: Delphi, Indiana
remarks: 62 m thick reef complex. Faunal abundance distribution maps. Stromatopores far more important than favositid corals.
authors: Archer, A.W., Bottjer, D.J., Horrowitz, A.S., Kelly, S.M., Krisher, D.L. & Shaver, R.H.
title: Stratigraphy, structure, and zonation of large Silurian reef at Delphi, Indiana. -

name: Cedar Springs, Tennessee
remarks: Shallow water mud mounds, mostly formed by hydrodynamic activity and trapping by bryozoans. Small 0.3-2 m mounds. Encrusting bryozoans and algae dominant.
title: Sedimentology and distinction of carbonate buildups: Middle Ordovician, east Tennessee. -

name: Red House Branch, Tennessee
remarks: Interpreted as deeper water patch reefs on the proximal slope. 2-10 m in diameter. Stromatactis mounds and cavities common. Bryozoa and no algae. Abstract ref. 1116: Investigation of extensive skeletal grainstone deposits that comprise much of the Middle Ordovician sequence in East Tennessee revealed 2 distinct carbonate buildup complexes. The Rockdell Formation comprises abundant pelmatozoan-bryozoan grainstones and packstones and lesser deposits of lime wackestone. These deposits represent carbonate sand shoals, consisting of a mixture of in situ and transported skeletal grains, which surround relatively small, isolated to anastomosing, lime-mud mounds. The Rockdell buildup was developed in shallow-water, high-energy conditions on a relatively stable platform. The Holston Formation is dominated by bryozoan-pelmatozoan packstones that surround roughly elliptical masses of bryozoan wackestone/boundstone. The Holston represents a series of lime-mud bryozoan patch-reefs that were surrounded by piles of in situ skeletal sand produced in pelmatozoan-bryozoan thickets. The Holston buildup developed in deeper water on the outer platform or perhaps downslope. Recognition and distinction of these 2 buildups is based on consideration of a number of criteria including: color, overall composition and distribution of flora and fauna; composition and distribution of bryozoan fauna; types and distribution of component lithofacies; and character of associated lime-mud deposits. Distinction of these buildups has major importance in the determination of East Tennessee paleogeography during the Middle Ordovician and also has implications for possible hydrocarbon exploration in these deposits. The criteria applied here may be useful in making distinctions among other carbonate buildups in the geologic record.
title: Sedimentology and distinction of carbonate buildups: Middle Ordovician, east Tennessee. -

name: Rockdell, Virginia
remarks: Biostromal 85 m thick and 50 x 35 km laterally. On ramp buildup.
title: Geometry, facies, and development of Middle Ordovician carbonate buildups, Virginia Appalachians. -

name: Catawba, Virginia
remarks: Biostromal downslope buildup. 160 m thick, 8 x 1 km wide. Mound-like configuration with domelike mud cores up to 50 m thick. Associated hardground surfaces.
title: Geometry, facies, and development of Middle Ordovician carbonate buildups, Virginia Appalachians. -

name: Murat, Virginia
remarks: Well developed core facies. 65 m thick, 25 km wide. Associated hardground surfaces.
title: Geometry, facies, and development of Middle Ordovician carbonate buildups, Virginia Appalachians. -

name: Effna, Virginia
remarks: 65 m thick, 65 x 25 km laterally. Elongate form. Carbonate sands common.
title: Geometry, facies, and development of Middle Ordovician carbonate buildups, Virginia Appalachians. -

name: Staunton, Virginia
remarks: Three small isolated buildups, locally reefal with abundant bryozoans and calcareous algae. Downslope buildup. 20-55 m thickness, 3-8 km wide.
title: Geometry, facies, and development of Middle Ordovician carbonate buildups, Virginia Appalachians. -

name: Tazewell, Virginia
remarks: On-ramp buildup. Biostromal. 35 m thickness, 45 km diameter.
title: Geometry, facies, and development of Middle Ordovician carbonate buildups, Virginia Appalachians. -

name: Porterfield, Virginia
remarks: Marine cement important. Mostly wackestone with ramose bryozoans. Encrusting bryozoans locally common. Other fossils are pelmatozoans, brachiopods, trilobites, Girvanella and sponge spicules. 250 m thick, 20 km wide. Downslope buildup. All buildups of this type similar to Waulsortian mud mounds in dominance of carbonate mud, low content of frame builders, presence of baffling organisms abundant stromatactis and echinoderm flank beds. High energy setting for mounds, but surrounded by deep ramp shaly limestone (sometimes anoxic). Fibrous and blocky cements up to 18 %.
title: Geometry, facies, and development of Middle Ordovician carbonate buildups, Virginia Appalachians. -

name: Gate City, Virginia
remarks: Shallow ramp buildup of several stacked biostromes. 60 m thick, 60 km width. All buildups in the area interpreted as shallow ramp setting.
title: Geometry, facies, and development of Middle Ordovician carbonate buildups, Virginia Appalachians. -

name: Garnier Bay, Somerset Isl., N.W.T.
remarks: eight species of corals listed. Two added for sponges, one for bryozoans
title: Upper Silurian lithistid sponge reefs on Somerset Island, Arctic Canada. -

name: Presque Isle Co. W, Michigan
remarks: Subsurface data. Producing reservoirs. Porosity 3.8-19.6 % (8.5 % average).
authors: Aminian, K., Ameri, S. & Bomar, R.M.
title: Evaluation of Silurian-Niagaran reef belt in northeastern Michigan. -

name: Presque Isle Co. E, Michigan
remarks: see reef 1875 for remarks.
authors: Aminian, K., Ameri, S. & Bomar, R.M.
title: Evaluation of Silurian-Niagaran reef belt in northeastern Michigan. -

name: Kuppen, Gotland
remarks: Strongly dominated by a single stromatopore species: Clathrodictyon mohicanum (40 %). Other forms are Parallelostroma, Stromatopora... Low diversity. Several biostromes 0.5 to 5 m thick and traceable for 1 km. Ref 1893: Nearly 50 % coverage of stromatoporoids. 50 % matrix with 25 % micrite, 5 % sparite and 20 % skeletal sand and debris. Faunal list in collections refer to middle biostrome at Kuppen (coll. 34406) and Fakle .
title: Factors controlling the growth of stromatoporoid biostromes in the Ludlow of Gotland, Sweden. -

name: Shizuizigou, Shaanxi
remarks: Reef core of thrombolites (baffling and binding). Additionally some red algae, corals (Subalvealites, Heliolites). Small coalesced bioherms (< 1 m in diameter).
title: Llandovery bioherms of Guangyuan (NW. Sichuan) - Ningqiang (S. Shaanxi) area. -

name: Huashito, Sichuan
remarks: Largest bioherm in area. 30.4 m thick, 120 m long. Enclosed in shales. Reef base: packstones and grainstones. Reef core: Bafflestones. Corals > stromatopores baffler > binder Similar reefs close-by are Qunilingdiwan (Collection 23252) and Shijiaoshan (Coll. 23253)
title: Llandovery bioherms of Guangyuan (NW. Sichuan) - Ningqiang (S. Shaanxi) area. -

name: Alpena, Michigan
remarks: Reefs in Hamilton Group. Slopes dipping up to 30-40 °. Reef builders Favosites, Acervularia and Stromatopora. 12 m thick.
title: Paleozoic coral reefs. -

name: Maumee, Ohio
remarks: Salina Group. Stromatolitic mound with Hemispherical stromatolite unit (mound) at base and stromatolitic dolobreccia at top. Favosites and microbial mesoclots. Abstract of ref. 2160: A completely dolomitized Silurian reef at Maumee, Ohio, U.S.A., is uncommon among early Paleozoic reefs in that its framework consists of about 95% thrombolite boundstone and 5% corals. The reef lithified syndepositonally, as evidenced by centimeter- to meter-scale growth framework cavities within it that are completely filled with internal sediment. The largest cavities, 2--3.5 m in diameter, are probably the largest ever recorded in a thrombolite reef. Four main types of components are distinguished in the reef framework: (1) dense bushy mesoclots, (2) dense rounded to subrounded mesoclots, (3) saccate microstructures, and (4) crusts, mostly structureless, but also containing dense bushy mesoclots. The dense bushy components are abundant; rounded to sub-rounded mesoclots less so, and the remaining components are rare. The dense bushy and rounded to subrounded mesoclots are interpreted to represent the calcified remains of what were initially either aggregates of the probable filamentous cyanobacterum Angulocellularia or aggregates of renalcid calcimicrobes, or both, and the saccate mesoclots as the calcimicrobe Renalcis sensu stricto. It is speculated that syndepositonal lithification of the reef framework was accomplished by impregnation of unlithified protomesoclots by micrite to create mesoclots along with the formation of micritic cement around and between mesoclots that served to fuse together successive generations of mesoclots. The direction of branching of bushy mesoclots in the reef indicates that unlithified protomesoclots were able to grow upward, laterally, and downward. This ability, along with syndepositional lithification to create mesoclots and to cement them together, enabled the protomesoclots and mesoclots to create reef knobs and, eventually, to roof over spaces that were centimeters to three or more meters in width and height to create growth framework cavities. Features indicative of rapid deposition including graded bedding, poor sorting of bioclasts, and textural inversion are common in internal sediment in meter-size cavities. These features suggest that storms, possibly hurricanes, were at least as important, and probably more so, than 'everyday' wave energy in transporting sediment into all cavities in the reef, regardless of size.
title: Petrography of a Cayugan (Silurian) stromatolite mound and associated facies, Ohio. -

name: Lime Hills, Holitna Basin, Sleetmute, Alaska
remarks: 500 m thick algal reef complex. Lower part with coalescing mounds (thrombolitic), upper part with layered stromatolitic mudstone to wackestone. Sponges common in Silurian part of buildup. Some dasycladaceans.
title: Comparative study of the sedimentology and paleoecology of middle Paleozoic algal and coral-stromatoporoid reefs in Alaska. -
paper: Proc. 5th Int. Coral Reef Congr., Tahiti

name: Marine Pool, Illinois
remarks: Producing reservoir.
title: Marine Pool, Madison County, Illinois, Silurian reef producer. -

name: Williamsville and Buffalo, New York
remarks: Edgecliff Member of Onondaga Limestone. Predominance of colonial rugose corals (15-16 species), 10 solitary rugose coral species and 15 tabulate coral species, but only 2 stromatopore species. Mostly tabulate corals. Flank beds dipping 5-10 °.
title: Petrography and evolution of Niagaran (Silurian) reefs, Indiana. -

name: Bluffton, Indiana
remarks: Completely dolomitized.
title: Petrography and evolution of Niagaran (Silurian) reefs, Indiana. -

name: Peters Field, St. Clair, Michigan
remarks: 110 m thick, about 2 km long. Oil field. Several other productive reefs in the area (ref. 1128), e.g. Big Hand, Belle River Mills and Marine City fields. Reef in Engadine Dolomite. Stromatopores at base. In reef core: corals, crinoids, stromatopores and bryozoans.
title: Geology of Peters Reefs, St. Clair, County, Michigan. -

name: Clarendon, New York
remarks: See reef 1885 for remarks.
title: Middle Silurian patch reefs in Gasport Member (Lockport Formation), New York. -

name: Frontier Quarry, Lockport, New York
remarks: Gasport Member of Lockport Fm. Collection of Foote Reef sudivided in Initial reef facies with delicate branching corals (Halysites, Cladopora) and branching bryozoans (Hallopora). Encrusters Girvanella, trepostome bryozoans and tabulate coral Alveolites. Reef core facies with umrella-shaped asymmetrically shaped stromatopores and a few favositids. Reef flank facies with debris of stromatopores, tabulate corals and others. Reef thicknesses in area: 3-12 m. Reefs less diverse than Niagaran reefs of Michigan. Example for reef succession in Walker and Alberstadt (1975).
title: Middle Silurian patch reefs in Gasport Member (Lockport Formation), New York. -

name: Rapid River, Kalkaska Co., Michigan
remarks: Pinnacle reef behind barrier reef complex. Producing reservoir. 100 - 130 m thick and up to 3 km long. General pattern in subsurfac pinnacle reefs:# Stromatopore core overlain by stromatolitic zone.
authors: Mesolella, K.J., Robinson, J.D., McCormick, L.M. & Ormiston, A.R.
title: Cyclic deposition of Silurian carbonates and evaporites in Michigan Basin. -

name: Rockford, Mecer Co., Ohio
title: Silurian reefs of northern Indiana: reef and interreef macrofaunas. -

name: Holmhällar, Gotland
remarks: Around 5 m thick. Subcircular belt 500 m in diameter. Stromatopores (Plectostroma, Parallelostroma) dominant (50-65 % of reef volume). Others are rugose corals. Eke beds and Hamra beds
title: Deposition and palaeoecology of an Upper Silurian stromatoporoid reef on southernmost Gotland, Sweden. -

name: Temiscouta, Quebec
remarks: Skeletal framework of stromatopores and corals, encrusting algae and microbes. Barrier reef(?) complex along outer margin of a nearshore siliciclastic bank.
title: Silurian reefs. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Pen Island No. 1, Hudson Bay, Ontario
remarks: Subsurface data. Skeletal framwork of stromatoporoids, corals and skeletal algae. Binding by microbes.
title: Silurian reefs. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Cabot Head, Bruce Peninsula, Ontario
remarks: Maximum: 1m thick, 2.5 m wide. Bryozoan-coral bioherms. Mostly branching bryozoa, encrusting bryozoa, rugose and tabulate corals. Abstract or ref. 1136: Several small, previously undescribed bioherms are present in the shallow shelf dolostones of the Manitoulin Formation (Llandoverian) at the Cabot Head and Wingfield Basin localities in the northernmost portion of the Bruce Peninsula region of southern Ontario (Canada). The bioherms, commonly associated with carbonate tempestites, range from 0.3 to 1.0 m in height and 0.9 to 2.5 m in width and are composed of bafflestones-floatstones and minor bindstones. The chief components of the bioherms are dolomitized lime mud and branching bryozoans. Bioherm building by bryozoans, although common in the ancient record, represents a great divergence from the mostly accessory frame encrusting role of bryozoans in modern environments. Minor skeletal components of the bioherms include echinoderms, rugose and tabulate corals and brachiopods. Laminar encrusting bryozoans exist in the top 10 cm of one of the bioherms. Some of the bioherms show evidence of water agitation that may be the result of current action induced by storm or tidal processes. This evidence includes offlapping debris and abrupt near-vertical margins aligned approximately perpendicular to depositional slope of the basin. The occurrence of the Manitoulin Formation bryozoan bioherms on the Bruce Peninsula stretches the already known Llandoverian reef complex on Manitoulin Island further to the south. The reason why these bioherms did not reach sizes comparable to large Llandoverian or Wenlockian reefs and did not make the shift to a coral-stromatoporoid community is probably related to a complex interaction of internal and external factors such as community development, bathymetry, clasticity, and salinity.
title: Dolomitized bryozoan bioherms from the Lower Silurian Manitoulin Formation, Bruce Peninsula, Ontario. -

name: Grand Rapids, Manitoba
remarks: Dolomitized coral-stromatoporoid biostromes at several levels. Related to sea level.
title: Depositional dynamics of cyclis carbonates from the Interlake Group (Lower Silurian) of the Williston Basin. -

name: Wahringa Farm, Bakers Swamp, NSW
remarks: 5 m thick microbial mound with Stromatactis and some birdseyes. Girvanella dominant (2 species). Some bryozoans. Large slumped clast derived its seems from a localized, small carbonate body that formed on the fringes of an Early Ordovician volcanic island.
authors: Wolf, K.H., Flügel, E. & Kemezys, K.J.
title: Ordovician calcareous algae from a bioherm, Blathery Creek Volcanics, New South Wales (Australia). -

name: Dolayba
remarks: Patch reef complex. Tabulate corals and ? Not described.
title: Silurische Halysitidae (Coelenterata, Tabulata) von Bithynien (Nordwest-Türkei) und biofazielle Beziehungen der Gondwanischen Halysitinae und Cateniporinae. -

name: Trinity Lake, Jasper, Alberta
remarks: Composite thrombolite mounds. Up to 27 m thick and 30 m wide. Inner margin of a mud-dominated carbonate complex. See reef 1787 for more remarks.
title: Cambrian reefs and mounds. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Gayna River, Mackenzie Mts.
remarks: 40 m thick biostrome or bioherm at headwaters of Gayna River.
title: Ordovician reefs and organic buildups. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Ware, British Columbia
remarks: Small (1 m) stromatolithic mounds on Macdonald Platform. Shelf edge probably also reefal, but destroyed by dolomitization.
title: Ordovician reefs and organic buildups. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Pine Pass, British Columbia
remarks: Coral bioherm (colonial and solitary). 2.5 m thickness. Within Kawka Platform.
title: Ordovician reefs and organic buildups. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: N Franklin Mts., N.W.T.
remarks: Stromatolitic biostromes and bioherms on Mackenzie carbonate platform.
title: Ordovician reefs and organic buildups. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Kingston, Ontario
remarks: Small (1 m) stromatolite bioherms. Upper Gull River Fm., St. Lawrence Platform. Very shallow, near-shore.
title: Algal bioherms of the Upper Gull River Formation (Middle Ordovician) near Kingston, Ontario. -

name: Mississauga, Ontario
remarks: 20 % bryozoans (Stigmatella, Heterotrypa) 50-70 % sediment and cement. Rest brachiopods, pelmatozoans and other. 5-10 % cavities with microbes, worms and bryozoa.
title: Upper Ordovician (Richmondian) cavity-dwelling (Coelobiontic) organisms from southern Ontario. -

name: Gore Bay, Manitoulin Island, Ontario
remarks: Coral-stromatoporoid biostrome. 4 m thick. Corals: Tetradium, Columnopora, Cyathophylloides Stromatopores, Labechia, microbes (Girvanella, Hedstroemia). Kagawong member of Georgian Bay Fm.
title: Paleoecological succession leading to Late Ordovician biostrome on Manitoulin Island, Ontario. -

name: Whitemud, Clearwater R., Alberta
remarks: Dolomitic biohermal mounds (a few meters)
title: Methy Dolomite of northeastern Alberta: Middle Devonian reef formation. -

name: Monkman Lake, British Columbia
remarks: Several stacked stromatopore bioherms. Total thickness 24 m. 60-80 m wide.
title: Depositional history of the Devonian succession in the Rocky Mountains southwest of the Peace River Arch. -
paper: Current Res. Part C, Geol. Survey of Canada

name: Mt. Buchanan, British Columbia
remarks: 112 m thick stromatopore-amphipore biostrome.
title: Depositional history of the Devonian succession in the Rocky Mountains southwest of the Peace River Arch. -
paper: Current Res. Part C, Geol. Survey of Canada

name: Leduc & Acheson, Alberta
remarks: 300 m thick, 16 x 5 km wide. Stromatoproid fragments and unidentifiable dolomitized corals. some bryozoans.
title: Stratigraphy and facies analysis of Upper Devonian reefs in Leduc, Stettler and Redwater areas, Alberta.-

name: Duhamel, Alberta
remarks: Calcilutites with abundant stromatopores, corals and amphiporids. Abstract of ref. 2125: The Duhamel reef is an isolated Upper Devonian Leduc Formation limestone bioherm, situated immediately NNE of the Bashaw reef complex in south-central Alberta. Although Duhamel has a relatively small basal area (less than 12 km2), this reef rises some 275 m above the platform facies. From seismic data it is interpreted that there is a raised peripheral reef rim that appears to be elevated about 25 m relative to the interior of the reef. Although late-stage accretionary growth about the periphery of the reef complex may have contributed to its development, the raised rim at Duhamel is interpreted to be principally of secondary origin. Optimal hydrocarbon recovery could be realized if all production wells were drilled into the raised reef rim. The Duhamel example shows that even relatively small Leduc reefs can exhibit raised rims and that these rims may be seismically visible.
title: Stratigraphic evidence for tectonic and current control of Upper Devonian reef sedimentation, Duhamel area, Alberta, Canada. -

name: Summit Peak, N-Wallowa Mountains, Oregon
remarks: Early Norian. Dachstein-type reef according to G. Stanley (coral-calcareous sponge reef mound) RCM Edit May 2015: Updated with semi-quantitative data from Martindale et al 2012. This changes the patch reefs from coral-sponge reef mounds to microbial-coral or microbial-red algal true reefs. Several of the patch reefs show subtle vertical and horizontal zonation of the diminutive framework builders although due to the small size of the framework builders, this is difficult to see in outcrop. Summit Point reefs are multiple stacked patch reefs, roughly 5-60m thick with skeletal and oncoidal wackestones to floatstones (oncoids, ooids, and intraclasts or skeletal debris) between reef buildups.
title: Upper Triassic , Dachstein-type reef limestone from the Wallowa Mountains, Oregon: first reported occurrence in the United States. -

name: S-Wallowa Mountains, Oregon
remarks: Was Carnian/Norian Now dated as early Norian (Flügel, 2002).
title: Upper Triassic , Dachstein-type reef limestone from the Wallowa Mountains, Oregon: first reported occurrence in the United States. -

name: Milk River, Alberta
remarks: Oyster reef Back barrier lagoonal setting. 0.6 -1.3 m thick.
title: Mesozoic reefs and other organic accumulations in Canada and adjacent areas. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Merrill Ranch, Monarch, Alberta
remarks: Lagoonal intertidal setting. Up to 4.5 m thick oyster biostrome. Additionally arenaceous forams. Unbored!
title: Mesozoic reefs and other organic accumulations in Canada and adjacent areas. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Willow Creek, Drumheller, Alberta
remarks: Oyster reef (biostrome). Up to 4 m thick, 4 km wide? Unbored and bored oysters Estuarine or barrier lagoon. Other refs. in ref. 1151.
title: Mesozoic reefs and other organic accumulations in Canada and adjacent areas. -
editors: Geldsetzer, H.H.J., James, N.P. & Tebbutt, G.E.

name: Logan Co., North Dakota
remarks: Only locality 5 of ref. 1152 with in situ oysters. 3 oyster species. Plenty of Cliona borings.
title: Palaeoecology of Maestrichtian oyster assemblages in the Fox Hills Formation. -
editors: Caldwell, W.G.E.

name: Kemmerer, Wyoming
remarks: Salt marsh or estuarine. 2 oyster species. 0.5 m thick.
title: Stratigraphy of the Frontier Formation (Upper Cretaceous), Kemmerer area, Lincoln County, Wyoming. -
paper: Wyoming Geol. Ass. 25th annual field conference, guidebook

name: Green Island Inlier
remarks: Extreme marginal setting. brackish water indicated by other macrofauna, lignite seams. Rudists accompanied by dasycladaceans and ostracods. All Campanian-Maastrichtian rudist frameworks are more coppices and thickets rather than biostromes or reefs.
title: Jamaican coral-rudist frameworks and their geologic setting. -

name: Benbow Inlier
remarks: Only clusters of rudists with a few corals. Jubilee Limestone. Caprotinid biostromes. Some microbial crusts.
title: Jamaican coral-rudist frameworks and their geologic setting. -

name: Central Inlier
remarks: late Santonian to Maastrichtian rudist frameworks. See reef 1935 for remarks. Patch reef with low mounds of radiolitid clusters that were successively overlain by 0.5 m of cobbly limestones with abundant corals, a thin, reddish soil, 0.5m of in-situ rudists, another reddish soil zone, and a highly fragmented zone with radiolitid rudist fragments followed by a small diversity of rudists.
title: Jamaican coral-rudist frameworks and their geologic setting. -

name: Pointe-à-Pierre, Trinidad
remarks: Exotic flysch block.
title: Structure and evolution of Antillean Cretaceous rudist frameworks. -

name: Maldon Inlier
remarks: Coral reef overlain by 15.6feet of clay-shale; overlain by small rudist biostrome; overlain by 4feet of whitish beds; overlain by small rudist biostromes 5.2feet thick; overlain by 32 inches of low relief, reefal beds of rudists; overlain by 30 feet of soft (siliciclastic) beds; overlain by rudist biostromes
title: Structure and evolution of Antillean Cretaceous rudist frameworks. -

name: Barrio Barrancas, Puerto Rico
remarks: Monospecific Caprinuloidea bank. 10 m thick.
title: Structure and evolution of Antillean Cretaceous rudist frameworks. -

name: Central Inlier
remarks: Mollusc debris at base, followed by upright and prone radiolitid and biradiolitid rudists, overlain by horn-shaped Antillocaprina, Titanosarcolites rudists on top with radiolitid rudists, overlain by carbonate mud Antillocaprina comes and goes rudists, relatively fewer corals, actaeonellid gastropods locally abundant
title: Structure and evolution of Antillean Cretaceous rudist frameworks. -

name: Lambs River, Marchmont Inlier
remarks: Mature coppice phase of Type B (ref. 1155) rudist framework evolution. Stromatoporoid heads, Titanosarcolites, Biradiolites, Plagioptychus, Radiolites,Torreites & Antillocaprina rudists, various oysters, Brachiodonte (bivalve), algae
title: Structure and evolution of Antillean Cretaceous rudist frameworks. -

name: San Polo, Matese
remarks: Rudist-coral-red algal patch reefs at platform edge.
authors: Accordi, G., Carbone, F. & Sirna, G.
title: Relationships among tectonic setting, substratum and benthonic communities in the Upper Cretaceous of northeastern Matese (Molise, Italy). -

name: Monte Girifalco, Mt. Carseolani
remarks: Upper Santonian-Campanian. 3-4 m thick sequence of dolomites with radiolitid banks (inter-supratidal). 8 rudist species.
title: Alcune facies a rudiste dei Monti Carseolani: descrizione e correlazione dal bordo occidentale all'interno della piattaforma Laziale-Abruzzese. -

name: Ricetto, Mt. Carseolani
remarks: 4-5 m thick biostrome. Hippurites (3 species) and corals.
title: Alcune facies a rudiste dei Monti Carseolani: descrizione e correlazione dal bordo occidentale all'interno della piattaforma Laziale-Abruzzese. -

name: Pietrasecca, Carseolani Mountains
remarks: Nine rudist species constructing biostrome
title: Alcune facies a rudiste dei Monti Carseolani: descrizione e correlazione dal bordo occidentale all'interno della piattaforma Laziale-Abruzzese. -

name: Monte Grisa, Triest
remarks: Although 11 rudist species in area (mostly radiolitits) buildups consist of monospecific assemblages (e.g. Katzeria hercegovinaensis).
authors: Caffau, M., Radrizzani, C.P., Plenicar, M. & Pugliese, N.
title: Rudist fauna and microfossils of the late Senonian (Monte Grisa area, Karst of Trieste, Italy). -

name: Brac
remarks: 1 to 4 m thick and 2 to 20 m wide mud mounds with stromatolites and Stromatactis.
title: Eine erweiterte Riff-Typologie und ihre Anwendung auf kretazische Biokonstruktionen. -
paper: Bayer. Akad. Wiss., math.-naturwiss. Klasse, Abh., N.F.

name: Oberstdorf
remarks: Coral-stromatopore bioherms in Schrattenkalk (up to 4 m thickness and 50 m width). Basement are rudist (requienid) limestones. Ref. 1159 Chaetetids, stromatopores, and other sclerosponges. 4 coral species, microbial crusts, corallinacean crusts. According to ref. 1514 thirty coral species present. 98 % colonial forms. High debris, very rare in situ framestones.
title: Eine erweiterte Riff-Typologie und ihre Anwendung auf kretazische Biokonstruktionen. -
paper: Bayer. Akad. Wiss., math.-naturwiss. Klasse, Abh., N.F.

name: Fenoliga, Istria
remarks: Classified as paucispecific, simple, dendriform radiolitid-biostromes by ref. 1159. Several biostromes, less than 1 m thick. Some microbes as binders.
title: Eine erweiterte Riff-Typologie und ihre Anwendung auf kretazische Biokonstruktionen. -
paper: Bayer. Akad. Wiss., math.-naturwiss. Klasse, Abh., N.F.

name: Grünbach, Niederösterreich
remarks: Dendriform Hippurites-Bioherms. 1- 2 m in diameter and thickness. Some microbial crusts around rudists. Cliona and microbe borings.
title: Eine erweiterte Riff-Typologie und ihre Anwendung auf kretazische Biokonstruktionen. -
paper: Bayer. Akad. Wiss., math.-naturwiss. Klasse, Abh., N.F.

name: Tres Lagunas, Patagonia
remarks: Thick branching corals and bivalves (Gryphea, Ostrea).
title: pers. comm.

name: Lago Fontana, Patagonia
remarks: Coral assemblage in olistostrome member of Vallcarga Fm. 36 genera belonging to 2 orders and 9 suborders. Few reef building genera: E.g. Actinastraea Astraraea Holocoenia Fungiastraea Colonial forms predominate but mostly of small size (less than 10 cm). Large borings evident on plates
title: pers. comm.

name: Cuatretonda, Valencia
remarks: Bioherms of mostly small Pironea (3 species). One Hippurites sp. Very few corals. 1.2 m max. thickness. Around 45 m wide complex.
title: Le Campanien et le Maastichtian à rudistes et grands foraminifères de Quatretonda (Province de Valence, Espagne): une clef pour la biozonation et les corrélations stratigraphiques dans le domaine mésoéen. -

name: Ostuni
remarks: Rudist massive organogenic limestones. With Favus n.gen.
title: Favus antei, a new genus and species of a bizarre 'Big Cell' radiolitid from the Upper Cretaceous of eastern Tethys. -

name: Khashm Tawqi
remarks: see reef 1957 for remarks.
title: A new canaliculate rudist bivalve from the Aruma Formation of central Saudi Arabia. -

name: Khashm Buwaibiyat
remarks: 2 m thick prominent biostrome at road. 2 rudist species dominant (Biradiolites and a new form Eodictyoptychus). Matrix is fine bioclastic packstone.
title: A new canaliculate rudist bivalve from the Aruma Formation of central Saudi Arabia. -

name: Khenchela
remarks: Late Santonian to early Campanian. Vaccinites bioconstructions. 5 species described (+ 1 ssp.)
title: Les rudistes de la formation carbonatee brechique du Santonien de Khenchela (Algerie). -

name: Stranice
remarks: Hippuritid bioherms (15 m thick) overlying calcarenites with corals and radiolitids.
title: Le récif de rudistes près de Stranice (N.O. de la Yougoslavie). -

name: Barranc del Racó, Bocairent
remarks: Rudist thicket with Hippurites, echinoids, colonial (Actinacis, Procladocora) and solitary corals in biomicritic matrix. 2 m thick.
authors: Pons, J.M., Gallemi, J., Höfling, R. & Moussavian, E.
title: Los Hippurites del Barranc del Racó, microfacies y fauna asociada (Maastrichtiense Superior, sur de la provincia de Valencia). -

name: Soria
remarks: Rudist limestones in unit 4 (Ethelia in 'milieux récifaux'). Up to 5 m thick.
title: La serie carbonatee Coniacien superieur a Santonien dans la region de Soria (Chaînes Ibériques septentrionales): Analyse et interpretations. -

name: Dugi Otok Island
remarks: Rudist buidlups and biostromes. No description.
title: Upper Cenomanian-Lower Turonian sea-level rise and its consequences on the Adriatic-Dinaric carbonate platform. -

name: Ruvo di Puglia
remarks: Patch reef with radiolitids (2 species) and caprinids (2 species). Up to 5 m thick.
title: Studio stratigrafico e paleoambientale di una successione Cenomaniano-Turoniana (Calcare di Bari) affiorante presso Ruvo di Puglia. -

name: Saint-Baudille
remarks: Bioherms with microsolenid corals. 10-100 m width 15-20 m thickness.
title: Kimmeridgien supérieur et Portlandien du Languedoc. -

name: Le Gare de Ponteau-Saint-Pierre, Provence
remarks: Lamellar corals dominant, often encrusted by red algae: Hydnophoromeandraraea forming lagest parts. Micrite ranging from 50 to 5%
title: Les constructions a cnidaeres des calcaires Urgoniens (Barrémien) de Provence, et leur environment. -

name: Notre Dame de Beauregard, Orgon
remarks: Rudist limestones with corals and hydrozoans, overlying coral biostromes
title: Les constructions a cnidaeres des calcaires Urgoniens (Barrémien) de Provence, et leur environment. -

name: Orgon
remarks: Diverse corals. Actinastrea, tabulogyra, Dimorphocoenia, Columnastrea, Calmophyliopsis, Microsolena, ... Associated are oysters and other bivalves and bryozoans.
title: Les constructions a cnidaeres des calcaires Urgoniens (Barrémien) de Provence, et leur environment. -

name: Alcabideche
remarks: Association fo stromatoporoids, Lithocodium aggregatum and diverse coral (thamnasteriids, astrocoenids, microsolenids, calamophylliids, stylinids).
title: Les formations bioconstruites du Crétacé inférieur d'Estremadura (Portugal). -

name: Ponta da Rana
remarks: Bioaccumulations of rudists (toucasiformes and capriniformes): 6 species. 3 m maximum thickness.
title: Les formations bioconstruites du Crétacé inférieur d'Estremadura (Portugal). -

name: Sao Juliao
remarks: Like reef 1966, but not as diverse (obsolete) Rudist bioconstruction Bedoulian age.
title: Les formations bioconstruites du Crétacé inférieur d'Estremadura (Portugal). -

name: Ugolka, Carpathians
remarks: Urgonian facies 2-150 m thick. Biomoirphic limestones with whole skeletons of corals and algae. 24 coral species. 2 chaetetid sp., 11 algal sp. Cores 5-20 m thick and 5-10 m wide, 8-100 m long. Upper sublitoral.
title: The Urgonian facies of the Soviet Carpathians. -

name: Boljevac, Arnaut River
remarks: Rudist biostromes with Toucasia, Matheronia, Monopleura and Requienia. Very small coral bioherms in the vicinity.
title: L'Urgonien de la partie médiane des Carpatho-Balkanides yougoslaves (Serbie orientale). -

name: Mokhorotubani, Dzirul Massif
remarks: Massive organogenic limestones. Exclusively corals (diverse) Dolomitic.
title: Les calcaires Urgoniens de Géorgie. -

name: Shkmeri, Dzirul Massif
remarks: Large organogenic structure (up to 130 m) of bioherm type. Composed of corals and chaetetids. Diverse corals in spite of poor preservation.
title: The corals of the Urgonian facies of Georgia. -

name: Ali-Goresha area, Dzirul Massif
remarks: Coral-rudist biostromes of 4-10 m thickness. Corals dominant and very diverse. Rudists mostly requienids and diceratids.
title: The corals of the Urgonian facies of Georgia. -

name: Manistee County, Michigan
title: Seismic data-processing techniques in exploration for reefs, northern Michigan. -
paper: Reefs and Evaporites - Concepts and Depositional Models. - AAPG Studies in Geology

name: Barre de la Jaume, Var
remarks: Rudist-coral communities on palaeohigh. Small chaetetid bioherms at base. Surrounded by bioclastic limestones.
title: Paléoenvironments et Sédimentologie des formations récifales à rudistes du Sénonien inférieur de Sainte-Anne d'Evenos, Massif du Gros Cerveau (Var, S.E. France). -

name: Barres de Cuers
remarks: Small coral bioherms in first limestone formation. Bryozoans and bivalves associates. Up to 4 m thick.
authors: Arnaud, M., Monleau, C. & Moulan, G.
title: Les relations plate-forme - bassin - continent dans le Bathonien de Provence. -

name: Jebel Ouenza
remarks: Gargansian stage coral biostromes. With calcisponges (chaetetids?) Up to 13 m thick.
title: La plate-forme carbonatée de l'Ouenza (sud Constantinois-Algérie). Organisation et dynamique durant l'Aptien supérieur. -

name: Murchas
remarks: Coral-oyster patch reefs. Upt to 3-4 m thick and 18 m wide. Siliciclastic ramp setting. Corals are Heliastrea, Porites, Tarbellastrea, Mussismilia. Oyster Hyotissa squarrosa up to 70 % of the reef. Rare encrusters. Some rhodolites. 10 % is sparry calcite.
authors: Braga, J.C., Jimenez, A.P., Martin, J.M. & Rivas, P.
title: Middle Miocene coral-oyster reefs, Murchas, Granada, southern Spain. -

name: Sebaa Chioukh Hills, Orania
remarks: 6 coral species. Fauna dominated by Tarbellastrea and Porites. Several bryozoans
title: Messinian coral reefs of western Orania, Algeria. -

name: Traras, Orania
remarks: More marls and more finger colonies of Porites than in reef 1979.
title: Messinian coral reefs of western Orania, Algeria. -

name: Ofaqim II
remarks: 12 m thickness. 100-150 m width. Massive faviid corals dominant. Others are stylophorids and poritids. 40-80 % of reefs are coral. Other are corraline algae and encrusting forams. Rare bryozoans.
title: Middle and Upper Miocene reefs and carbonate platforms in Israel. -

name: Ziqlag Hills
remarks: Type locality of Ziqlag Formation. Mostly back reef deposits
title: Middle and Upper Miocene reefs and carbonate platforms in Israel. -

name: Sharm el Luli
remarks: Three individual prograding reef bodies. Each some 25 m thick.
authors: Purser, B.H., Plaziat, J.-C. & Rosen, B.R.
title: Miocene reefs of the northwest Red Sea. -

name: Wadi Sharm el Qibli
remarks: Massive and branching corals: Stylophora, Tarbellastraea, Montastrea. Somewhat protected. Reef slopes with abundant siliceous debris rich in molluscs and coralline algae. Loc. Wadi Sharm el Bahari very close.
authors: Purser, B.H., Plaziat, J.-C. & Rosen, B.R.
title: Miocene reefs of the northwest Red Sea. -

name: Belus-Peyrehorade
remarks: 60 coral species. Locally Delicate, globular and lamellar morphologies. Mostly big and massive branched and domal.
title: Structural and faunal evolution of Chattian - Miocene reefs and corals in western France and the northeastern Atlantic Ocean. -

name: Abese-Estoti + Escornebeou, Aquitain
remarks: Up to 100 coral species. 50 massive globular species, 15 branched 10 phaceloid, 6 lamellar. 3 m thick patch reefs, traceable for 200 m. Associated with hydrozoans. Algae very rare. Carbonate ramp. Le Bois (Escornebeou) locality further west is subreefal envrionment with massive corals (about 25 species in 18 genera).
title: Structural and faunal evolution of Chattian - Miocene reefs and corals in western France and the northeastern Atlantic Ocean. -

name: St. Martin-d'Oney
remarks: Rich coral fauna. Additionally millporids and molluscs.
title: Structural and faunal evolution of Chattian - Miocene reefs and corals in western France and the northeastern Atlantic Ocean. -

name: Le Peloua
remarks: 50 coral species. Coral colonies up to 1 m in diameter. Small fringing reefs.
title: Structural and faunal evolution of Chattian - Miocene reefs and corals in western France and the northeastern Atlantic Ocean. -

name: Gamachot near Villandraut, Bazadais, Gironde
remarks: In-place Porites colonizing marls. Coral carpet on muddy substrate. 1 m thick bank interrupted by brackish deposits.
title: Structural and faunal evolution of Chattian - Miocene reefs and corals in western France and the northeastern Atlantic Ocean. -

name: Capo Tindari, Sicily
remarks: Fragmentary coral reef material. Reef grown on metamorphic basement.
title: Miocene reef distributions and their associations in the central Mediterranean region: an overview. -

name: Jabal al Akhdar
remarks: Reefs with abundant branching corals in recrystallized micritic groundmass. Associated with coralline algal carbonates.
title: Miocene reef distributions and their associations in the central Mediterranean region: an overview. -

name: Bonifacio Basin, Corsica
remarks: See reef 1992 for remarks.
title: Miocene reef distributions and their associations in the central Mediterranean region: an overview. -

name: Aleria, Corsica
remarks: Coral-algal bioherms with pectinids and echinoids.
title: Miocene reef distributions and their associations in the central Mediterranean region: an overview. -

name: Bonifacio Basin, Corsica
remarks: Coral-red algal reefs. Extensive development of bioherms in Bonifacio Basin. Four coral reef episodes. late Aquitanian to Langhian.
title: Miocene reef distributions and their associations in the central Mediterranean region: an overview. -

name: Ales-Villagreca, Sardegna
remarks: 25 m thick coral bioherms with bryozoans and coralline algae. Underlain by siliciclastic rocks.
title: Miocene reef distributions and their associations in the central Mediterranean region: an overview. -

name: Palmi, Rocca Campana, Calabria
remarks: Seven coral species in area but only Tarbellastraea and Porites common
title: Upper Miocene peri-Tyrrhenian reefs in the Calabrian Arc: sedimentological, tectonic and palaeogeographic implications. -

name: Vibo Valentia Airport, Calabria
remarks: latest Tortonian to early Messinian coral reef with Tarbellastraea, Porites, and Palaeoplesiastraea. Abundant boring bivalves (Lithophaga) and clionids. 'At least' five scleractinian species.
title: Upper Miocene peri-Tyrrhenian reefs in the Calabrian Arc: sedimentological, tectonic and palaeogeographic implications. -

name: Milazzo and Rometta, NW Peloritani Mts., Sicily
remarks: Brecciated Porites reef debris only at Milazzo. Abundant Lithophaga borings. At Santa Lucia del Mela associations with coralline algae and bryozoans. At Rometta Porites and Tarbellastraea reefs
title: Upper Miocene peri-Tyrrhenian reefs in the Calabrian Arc: sedimentological, tectonic and palaeogeographic implications. -

name: Santo Stefano di Camastra, Sicily
remarks: Large quarry. Porites reefs with prominent breccia horizons. Crustose coralline algae, bryozoans, vermits gastropods and regular echinoids. Reef capped by sandy clays
title: Upper Miocene peri-Tyrrhenian reefs in the Calabrian Arc: sedimentological, tectonic and palaeogeographic implications. -

name: Serra de Tramuntana, NW Mallorca
remarks: Up to 16 m thick reefs in medium- to coarse-grained terrigenous fans. One reef (coll. 69929) without terrigenous influx. Porites dominates coral fauna. Massive and encrusting corals dominant. Red algae abundant. Matrix wackestones with coral fragments, serpulids, bryozoans and oysters.
authors: Esteban, M., Braga J.C., Martín, J. & Santisteban, C. de
title: Western Mediterranean reef complexes. -

name: Guercif
remarks: Coral reefs up to 10 m, but only 2-4 m thick in average. Porites and Tarbellastrea dominate.
authors: Esteban, M., Braga J.C., Martín, J. & Santisteban, C. de
title: Western Mediterranean reef complexes. -

name: Lisboa
remarks: Less than 50 m thick coral reef (11 species).
authors: Esteban, M., Braga J.C., Martín, J. & Santisteban, C. de
title: Western Mediterranean reef complexes. -

name: Central Mallorca
remarks: Position doubtful. Red algal mounds (12 m thick, tens of m wide).
authors: Esteban, M., Braga J.C., Martín, J. & Santisteban, C. de
title: Western Mediterranean reef complexes. -

name: Alacant region

name: Sudak, Crimea
remarks: Corals, solenoporaceans (including rodolites), calcareous sponges. Sometimes associated microbes. Bioherms around 50-60 m thick. Reef growth limited to upper Callovian - lower Oxfordian according to ref. 1529. Abstract of ref. 1529. Rich and various crinoidal assemblages existed at Callovian-Oxfordian time in the Sudak environs on Crimea. 22 species are described: Dolichocrinus aberrans, Eugeniacrinitescaryophilites, E. quenstedti, Pilocrinus moussoni, Cyrtocrinus nutans (order Cyrtocrinida), Millericrinus annulatus, M. convexus, M. echinatus, M. etalloni, M. goupilianus, M. granulosus, M. knorri, M. milleri, M. multipunctatus, M. rotiformis, M. thiollieri (order Millericrinida), Balanocrinus dumortieri, B. subteres, Margocrinus modestus, Chariocrinus? burgundicus, Isocrinus amblyscalaris and 'Pentacrinus' cingulatissimus (order Pentacrinida). The described species belong to two ecological types: cirriferous (long-stalked plastic, long-stalked immovable and short-stalked forms) and cirriless (long-stalked and short-stalked). Crinoids occupied four trophic tiers and inhabited four types of the biotopes: interreef depressions, interreef rises, reef slopes and reefs. A certain connection exists between biotope types, trophic tiers of crinoids and their ecological types. Tubular worms, bryozoans, bivalves, sponges and corals were settling on crinoid stalks in a certain sequence during the lifetime of crinoids or after their perishing. Millericrinid stems were damaged by parasites, predators and scavengers. Pentacrinid stems were twisted, depending on the environmental dynamics. Atrophy of cirri is typical for tong-stalked flexible pentacrinids.
title: Biogermnie massivy v verchnejurskich otlozheniyach gornogo Krima i Severnogo Kavkaza. -
paper: Iskopaemie rifi i metodika ich izuchenya. - Trudy tretiei paleoekologo - litologicheskoi s

name: Shtschebetovka, Crimea
remarks: Reef growth limited to upper Callovian - lower Oxfordian according to ref. 1529. Reef blocks of 1-2 km2 extension and 100-200 m thickness. Limestones cloddy, cavernous and recrystallized. Big coral and algal nodules. Cryptobionts like crinoids common.
title: Biogermnie massivy v verchnejurskich otlozheniyach gornogo Krima i Severnogo Kavkaza. -
paper: Iskopaemie rifi i metodika ich izuchenya. - Trudy tretiei paleoekologo - litologicheskoi s

name: Fawn Lake, Horn Plateau, N.W.T.
remarks: Pinnacle reef complex. ensensis to varcus Zone 650 m wide - 125 m thick. Colonial corals (rugose and tabulate) and massive and tubular stromatoporoids surrounded by sand gravel sized crinoid coral sediment. Much of the reef is composed of fragmented reef-derived debris Several algae and some microbes. Rare bryozoans. Not more than 10 % micrite in reef core. 15 species or rugose corals in framework indicated by ref. 1600. Rugosa as primary frame builders. Abstract of ref. 1603: Agastophyllum eximium gen. et sp. nov., a massive digonphyllid coral, is described from the reef flat and organic reef macrofacies of Vopni and Lerbekmo (1972). Dialeptophyllum vopnii gen. et sp. nov., a solitary kyphophyllid coral, is described from the reef flank macrofacies. Thryptophyllum undafundus gen. et sp. nov. is described from the reef flat and reef flank macrofacies, and is referred to a new subfamily of the named Thrptophyllinae. Agastophyllum eximium and Thryptophyllum undafundus are Giventian, Middle varcus zone age; Dialeptophyllum vopnii is presumed to belong to the same zone, and is certainly Givetian. Four undescribed species of Agastophyllum are reported from late Eifelian strata of Western Canada. Dialeptophyllum vopnii and an unnamed Emsian species from the Nelichen Formation of the Indigirka River drainage area of the northeastern Soviet Union are the only known species of Dialeptophyllum. An early Givetian species from the Rockport Quarry Limestone of Michigan, originally described by Ehlers and Stumm (1949), under the name Spongophyllum romingeri, is transferred to the new genus Thryptophyllum.
title: Sedimentology and ecology of the Horn Plateau Formation: A Middle Devonian coral reef, Northwest Territories, Canada. -

name: Mercy Bay, Banks Island, N.W.T.
remarks: Zonation: Lower bioherm (33 m thick) overlain by two biostrome layers (30 m thick). Bioherm (from base to top): - 5 m Coral bindstone and bafflestone. -2 m stromatoporoid bindstone - 10 m Stromatoporoid framestone and rudstone Stromatopores dominant in shallower water.

name: Sagara district
remarks: Abstract of ref. 1238: Eight fossil molluscan species, including Cryptopecten yanagawaensis (Nomura and Zinbo) and Turbo (Marmarostoma) mekamiensis Nishiwada, are described on the basis of material obtained from the late Early to early Middle Miocene Megami and Ebie limestones in the Sagara district, Shizuoka Prefecture, Japan. Cryptopecten yanagawaensis has been recorded from late Early to early Middle Miocene formations in Japan. The occurrence of this species indicates that the reef limestones in the Megami Formation were formed within the Japanese faunal realm in Miocene time. In this paper some comments are made on the origin and sedimentary environments of the limestones in the Megami Formation.
authors: Ozawa, T., Inoue, K. & Tomida, S.
title: Early to Middle Miocene molluscan fossils from the Megami and Ebie limestones in Shizuoka Prefecture and their implications for the formation of a Miocene coral-algal reef within the Japanese faunal realm.. -

name: Havelock Island, Andaman Islands
remarks: Abstract of ref. 1242: Carbonate rocks are widespread on the Andaman-Nicobar Islands, northern Indian ocean, ranging in age from Early Miocene to Pleistocene. Lithologically they range from deep water to shallow water calcarenites. Thin section analysis of the limestones showed the following major lithofacies: lithic foraminiferal-algal grainstone-packstone; lithic foraminiferal-algal wackstone-mudstone; volcanoclastic packstone-wackstone/radiolarian cherts; foraminiferal packstone; coralgal boundstone and coarse lithic foraminiferal-algal-molluscan packstone-grainstone. They exhibit sequential changes in their fabrics, biogenic and clastic constituents. Depths of deposition ranged from high energy, shallow neritic (lithic foraminiferal-algal grainstone-packstone facies) at the beginning of Early Miocene to progressively lower bathyal marked successfully by lithic foraminiferal-algal wackstone-mudstone, volcanoclastic packstone-wackstone and radiolarian chert facies. The sudden influx of glass shards and tephras in the later Early Miocene suggests that progressive deepening of the basin occurred contemporaneously with explosive volcanism in neighboring areas. During this interval of basinal subsidence, the limestones received abundant argillaceous material from subaerial erosion of nearby volcanic terrain. Gradual reduction in the frequency of glass shards and pumice from Middle Miocene (Ongeian Stage) onwards indicates culmination of volcanic eruptions and basinal stability. Gradual shallowing to subtidal and patch reef (coralgal facies) environments began to form from the Middle Miocene onwards at Little Andaman, Havelock, Nicholson and other islands. Deep basinal conditions prevailed during the Late Miocene to Early Pliocene at Neill, Sir Hugh Rose and Car Nicobar Islands. These different conditions may be attributed to tectonism in the Andaman sea region which occurred during the close of Middle Miocene. Thereafter, younger limestone facies of Plio-Pleistocene age, reflect a shoaling upwards to probable intertidal conditions due to rapid infilling and vertical uplift of the basin floor. No hydrocarbons were observed in the limestone sequences. The regional stratigraphic and petrographic studies reveal the presence of potential reservoir rocks in the Ongeian-Havelockian limestones of Middle Miocene age on the Andaman-Nicobar Islands.
title: Stratigraphy and depositional environments of Neogene limestones of Andaman Nicobar Islands northern Indian Ocean. -

name: Little Andama Island, Andaman Islands
remarks: see reef 2029.
title: Stratigraphy and depositional environments of Neogene limestones of Andaman Nicobar Islands northern Indian Ocean. -

name: Small Nggela Island
remarks: Abstract of ref. 1243: Most of the sedimentary rocks of Small Nggela are early Miocene in age (dated by nannofossils and foraminifera). In the north, uniform volcaniclastic arenite (the Siota Beds) crops out. Much of the central, western and eastern parts of the island contain diverse strata including pillow lava, calcarenite, volcaniclastic arenite, grit and breccia (the Ghumba Beds). The Siota and Ghumba Beds, which are separated by a 1-1.5 km wide, east-trending ophiolite wedge, are considered to have been deposited in a forearc basin. The ophiolite wedge arrested the northward transport of coarse sediment and was emergent during the late Oligocene and early Miocene. The sediment and the ophiolite wedge are considered to have overlain a southward-descending Benioff zone. Well-bedded laminated arenite lacking basalt and rudite (the Ndandala Sandstone) is present in the south-western part of the island and is probably significantly younger than the underlying Ghumba Beds. A veneer of early-mid Pliocene limsteone (the Florida Limestone), representing a patch reef environment, was deposited upon the Ghumba Beds after they were folded.
title: Cenozoic stratigraphy of Small Nggela Island Solomon Islands: Early Miocene deposition in a forearc basin followed by Pliocene patch reef deposition. -

name: Salawati
remarks: Subsurface oil field. Up to 490 m thickness according to ref. 1244. Mud rich. 16.5 % porosity. Abstract ref. 1244: Recent exploration activity in the Salawati basin, along the northwestern tip of Iran Jaya, Indonesia, resulted in significant oil discoveries. Reservoir and trap are provided by highly porous and permeable Miocene reef rocks which yielded oil at rates of up to 32,000 bbl/day from individual wells. The Salawati basin is a structural-stratigraphic basin containing more than 4600 m of marine Tertiary sedimentary deposits. The basin is bounded on the north by the Sorong fault zone which separates the Australian continental plate from the Pacific oceanic plate. Basin development was initiated in the Miocene when local downwarping and increased water depths resulted in the deposition of a basinal limestone and shale sequence in the area. Toward the east and south margins of the basin these sediments are replaced by shallow-water carbonate rocks which form a well-defined shelf and associated shelf margin. The productive reef belt is just basinward of the shelf and shelf-margin area. The reefs, which reach heights in excess of 490 m, range in areal extent from 5-124 km2. Porosities within the reefal carbonate rocks are as much as 43% and average 20-30%. Late Pliocene-Pleistocene normal faults which cut many of the reefs, combined with postreef structural tilt, modified considerably the original configuration of the reefs and the associated oil accumulations. The knowledge gained from the current exploration program concerning reef morphology, porosity variations, tectonic history, and other factors which control the oil accumulations should expedite future exploration efforts in the basin. The Foraminifera Globigerina, Globorotalia, Orbulina, Alveolinella, Marginopora, Sorites, Flosculinella, Rotalia, Elphidium, Cellanthus, Amphistegina, Operculina, Gypsina, Ammonis and Miliolids are mentioned, Coral, hydroxoan and algal (Amphilhoa, Lithophyllum, Aethesolithon, Corallina and Archeolithothamnium) debris are mentioned.
title: Oil bearing reefs in Salwati Basin of Irian Jaya Indonesia. -

name: Silifke
remarks: Abstract of ref. 1246 (part): The Miocene sediments overlying the basement rock units are transgressive and grade into each other vertically and laterally. They are represented by polygenic conglomerates, sandstones, marls and reef limestones. Five planktonic foraminiferal biozones, 3 Burdigalian and 2 Helvetian to Tortonian (?), were defined in these formations.
title: Basement rock units and the Miocene stratigraphy of Silifke region. -

name: Miaru, Papua New Guinea
remarks: 50 m thick fossiliferous beds in Era Beds. Several 2-3 m thick coral horizons, corals often in growth position. Pulses of clastic sedimentation throughout the reefal interval.

title: Golden Spike reef complex, Alberta. -

name: San Andrés Island, Columbia
remarks: Principal reef builders: Millepora, lime-secreting algae and abundant Acropora, Diploria, Montastrea and Porites.
title: Modern and ancient reef complexes and associated limestone diagenesis of San Andres Island, Columbia. -

name: San Andrés Island, Columbia
remarks: Abstract of ref. 1259: San Andres is a small coralline island 136 km east of the Caribbean coast of Nicaragua. Surface mapping and paleontologic data indicate reefs have been growing actively in the area at least since early Miocene time. Because of the offlap relations of the ancient reef complexes, accessibility of progressively younger rocks is simplified. Field and laboratory examination of both modern and ancient reef complexes indicates five major bottom facies: (1) forereef flank, (2) reef, (3) backreef platform, (4) backreef lagoon with patch reefs, and (5) shore area. Principal builders of the reefs were Millepora and lime-secreting algae with abundant Acropora, Diploria, Montastrea, and Porites. From X-ray and petrographic studies of the limestones, a sequence of carbonate diagenesis has been determined for the San Andres area. During early stages of diagenesis, sediments initially are cemented by grain welding and aragonite precipitation between grains. This early type of cementation is most common in the supertidal and intertidal zones. Subsequent calcite cementation occurs by dissolution-precipitation after aragonite. After calcite precipitation, no evidence can be found of the preexisting aragonite cement. Although inversion of aragonite to calcite commonly occurs in grain material, dissolution-precipitation seems to be the major process of cementation. During the diagenetic sequence, four responses may be expected: (1) magnesium is removed and high-magnesium calcite stabilizes to low-magnesium calcite, (2) aragonite can stabilize to calcite, (3) aragonite may be dissolved, and (4) sediments may become dolomitized. The time required for any of these reactions is variable and depends on the chemical environment. X-ray analyses indicate that all samples older than middle Pleistocene have stabilized to low-magnesium calcite or dolomite. The result of the diagenetic sequence is the development of a low-magnesium calcite limestone, a dolomite, or a combination of the two. Porosity in the San Andres area is primary, secondary, or occluded and development depends on exposure of carbonate material to a subaerial environment before mineral stabilization occurs.
title: Modern and ancient reef complexes and associated limestone diagenesis of San Andres Island, Columbia. -

name: Emperor Seamount, Pacific
remarks: Abstract of ref. 1265: This paper is a review of the present knowledge of coral reef ecology and paleoecology in the Hawaiian-Emperor Chain during the last 70 Ma. Research on fossil coral deposits throughout the H-E Chain has played a major role in producing information concerning the subsidence, uplift and drowning of individual islands, as well as the paleocirculation of the North Pacific Ocean during Tertiary time. The origin of the Hawaiian Islands and seamounts over the Hawaiian hotspot and their subsequent subsidence and transport by plate motion to the north and northwest are reviewed and new data concerning uplift of the central high Hawaiian Islands caused by lithospheric flexure and the effect of sea level change on the geological evolution of individual islands are presented. The Darwin Point, where atolls drown to form guyots, is redefined in dynamic terms as a function of climate and sea level history. The absence of coral reefs during the first half of Hawaiian history is evidence ...
title: Paleooceanography of coral reefs in the Hawaiian-Emperor Chain: Revisited. -

name: Baixo, Porto Santo, E-Atlantic
remarks: Abstract of ref. 1266: Ephemeral coral reefs developed in the Miocene on the submarine slopes of the Porto Santo and Madeira volcanic complexes. The paleontology of these reefs is discussed. Danaia calcinata described from Baixo, near Porto Santo by Mayer (1864) as a tabulate coral is identified here as synonymous with Pocillopora madreporacea (Lamarck, 1816). Corals: Thamnasteria sp., Stylina aff. girodi Efallon and Stylina sp.
title: Pocillopora in the Miocene reef at Baixo Porto-Santo eastern Atlantic. -

name: Perico Hills
remarks: 4.5 m thick silicified coral biostrome. Abstract of ref. 1279: During the Hauterivian-Barremian, local coral biostromes, possibly patch reefs, developed within shallow marine lagoons fringing Early Cretaceous volcanoes in Peru. The dominant coral is S. columbaris sp. nov. which is similar to European stylinid species of Late Jurassic and Early Cretaceous age having 6-fold septal plans. The biostrome is part of the Atocongo Formation, Lima Group, exposed at Perico Hill (Cerros Perico) about 95 km south of Lima. Only 2 other lower Cretaceous stylinid corals were described from South America.
title: Stylina columbaris n.sp. in a Lower Cretaceous coral biostrome, Peru. -

name: Serranía de Cocinas, Guajira Peninsula, Columbia

name: Norman Wells, N.W.T.
remarks: Average porosity 10 %, permeability around 110 md. 4 growth stages in 160 m thick reef. Diversity not described but all groups (stromatoporoids, tabulate and rugose corals) with different species and growth forms. Ranging into Frasnian Abstract of ref. 2126: The Middle-Upper Devonian Kee Scarp reef complexes are oil-producing, stromatoporoid-dominated carbonates. Episodic increases in the rate of sea level rise produced multiple cycles of reef growth that exhibit backstepping characteristics. These carbonates have original interskeletal, intraskeletal, and intergranular porosity, mostly occluded by nonferroan, dull luminescent cements. Secondary porosity, represented by micropores of various types, developed during diagenesis by aggrading neomorphism and dissolution. The micropores represent the main reservoir porosity in the Kee Scarp limestone. Micropores in the Kee Scarp limestone can be classified into four categories based on their shapes.
title: The study of natural fractures in a reef complex, Norman Wells oil field, Canada. -
editors: Tillman, R.W. & Weber, K.J.

title: Cenozoic biogenic mounds and buried Miocene(?) barrier reef on a predominantly cool-water carbonate continental margin - Eucla basin, western Great Australian Bight. -

name: JA90-23, Eucla Shelf, Great Austr
remarks: Abstract of ref. 1288: The southern continental margin of Australia is the largest area of cool-water carbonate shelf deposition on the globe. Interpretation of 5495 km of airgun seismic-reflection data in the western part of the Great Australian Bight indicates that the 700-m-thick Cenozoic section of the offshore Eucla basin was deposited largely as a prograding cool-water, middle- to high-latitude carbonate ramp, characterized by widespread development of broad, low-relief, biogenic (bryozoan[?]-sponge), shelf and upper-slope mounds. The succession also contains a spectacular and extensive (>475 km long) buried middle Miocene barrier reef (the Miocene Little Barrier Reef) parallel to the modern shelf edge. This rimmed carbonate platform margin represents an episode of warm-water sedimentation during a global climatic optimum, probably coupled with strong eastward flow of a proto-Leeuwin Current. The late Miocene eustatic sea-level fall produced an areally restricted debris-apron sequence at the foot of the reef escarpment. The carbonate platform is capped by a Neogene cool-water carbonate ramp succession typified by aggradational to sigmoidal sequences, punctuated by periods of cold(?)-water, sea-floor erosion. Interpretation of this succession in the light of global and local tectonic and oceanographic events illustrates the dominant influence of water temperature on carbonate platform and reef growth throughout the Cenozoic.
title: Cenozoic biogenic mounds and buried Miocene(?) barrier reef on a predominantly cool-water carbonate continental margin - Eucla basin, western Great Australian Bight. -

name: Tattsfield, Weald, England
remarks: Early marine peloidal cements important for reservoir quality. Average porosity around 8-10 %. Lower part of reefs with laminar Thamnasteria and digitate Thecosmilia. Upper part with robust branching Thecosmilia and massive Isastrea. Stromatolitic crusts present.
authors: Sun, S.Q., Fallick, A.E. & Williams, B.P.J.
title: Influence of original fabric on subsequent porosity evolution: an example form the Corallian (Upper Jurassic) reefal limestones, the Weald Basin, southern England. -

name: Halton, Carnforth, Great Britain
remarks: Cracoen type reef. Framework composed of microbes, bryozoans, lithistid sponges and bryozoans.
title: A Late Dinantian peloid cementstone-palaeoberesellid buildup from North Lancashire, England. -

name: Ballykane
remarks: Individual mounds up to 100 m thick. Waulsortian sequence about 200 m thick. Corals very rare but present (tabulates, rugose).
authors: Somerville, I.D., Strogen, P. & Jones, G.L.
title: Mid-Dinantian Waulsortian buildups in the Dublin Basin, Ireland. -

name: Rathkeale, Shannon Estuary
remarks: Thickest development of all Waulsortian mounds worldwide.
title: Ramp sedimentation in the Dinantian limestones of the Shannon Trough, Co. Limerick, Ireland. -

name: Krachoua
title: Sur les gisements fossilifères du Jurassique moyen et supérieur du Sahara Tunisien. -

name: Tenia Island, New Caledonia, Melanesia
remarks: Belongs to France
title: Coral reefs of New Caledonian. -
editors: Jones, O.A. & Endean, R.
paper: Biology and Geology of Coral Reefs, vol. 1: Geology 1

name: Kangjia-ping, Cili, Hunan
remarks: Paleofusulina zone according to ref. 1326 Ref. 1700 states Wuchipangian age. Rugose coral (Waagenophyllum) reef. 40-50 % of rock is formed by corals. Single colonies up to 1 m high. Addtionally sphinctozoans, hydrozoans (?), Tubiphytes, Archaeolithoporella, red algae (Parachaetetes, Solenopora), bryozoans. All of them rare in coral reef core. Reef 35-57 m thick. Dolomitization only in west. Paleontological data from eastern sections with many sponges
authors: Shen, J.-w., Kawamura, T. & Yang, W.-r.
title: Upper Permian coral reef and colonial rugose corals in northwest Hunan, South China

name: Mole Creek, Tasmania
remarks: Original age call: Caradocian-Ashgillian Small coral-stromatopore bioherms in Den Formation (Gordon Group). Tabulate (favositid, heliolitid, halysitid) corals, rugose (solitary and compound) and diverse stromatopores (10 species assigned to 2 morphotypes) are important. Some bioherms dominated by stromatopores, others by corals (mostly tabulates). Environment characterized as outer platform, but fitting to ramp as well.
title: Facies and paleoecology of the Late Ordovician (Caradoc-Ashgill) stromatoporoid bioherms of Tasmania, Australia. -

name: Houshan, Guilin, Guangxi
remarks: Western margin of Guilin platform. Coral bafflestone reef behind an algal-stromatoporoid platform margin reef. Composed exclusively of rugose coral Smithiphyllum ( 3 species). Brachiopods as dwellers. Some solenoporacean fragments. -> Collection of Miller Coral bioherm (Smithiphyllum) 8 m thick and 30 m wide. Base is Stromatactis limestone, top is peloidal packstone followed by receptaculid-algal limestone. Ref:. 1866: Reef complex with 'Algal'-stromatoporoid reef receptaculid-algal reef Smithiphyllum bioherm algal mounds 30 m exposed thickness. Lateral differentiation into back-reef, reef flat and margin, margina fore-slope. Stachyodes most abundant in reef flat. Calcimicrobes prevail in reef-slope: Renalcis, Epiphyton, Rothpletzella Cavities and veins filled with radiaxial-fibrous calcites
title: A Late Devonian (Frasian) coral-bafflestone reef at Houshan in Guilin, South China. -

name: Laliderer Tal
remarks: Earliest small buildups in Northern Alps. Homoclinal ramp setting.
title: Facies and biota of Anisian to Carnian carbonate platforms in the Northern Calcareous Alps (Tyrol and Bavaria). -

name: Xifeng-Kaiyang, Guizhou
remarks: Phosphatic stromatolitic bioherms: 1 m thick, up to 100 m wide.
title: Phosphatic stromatolite bioherms and associated microbial fossils from the Sinian Doushantuo Formation, central Guizhou, South China. -

name: Maurice Ewing Bank, South Atlantic
remarks: Seismic evidence for a succession of carbonate buildups. Age Jurassic/Cretaceous, most probably early Cretaceous.
title: Seismic evidence for carbonate buildups at the northern edge of the Maurice Ewing Bank, Falkland Plateau. -
