name: Globocec
remarks: 5 m and 7 m thick intervals with rock-forming Cochlearites.
title: Lower Jurassic beds with bivalves in south Slovenia. -

name: Inhoca
remarks: Ostrea bank. Oysters with abundant borings.
title: Über Tertiär und obere Kreide aus Portugiesisch-Ostafrika. -
paper: Abhandlungen der Bayerischen Akademie der Wissenschaften, math.-naturwiss. Klasse

name: Albenza, Southern Alps
remarks: 3 m thick, 8 m wide patch reef. Lithocodium and Bacinella bindstone at base. Then coral-dominated reef with solenopraceans, tabulozoans, 'sphinctozoans' and some hydrozoans. Stongly encrusted by Lithocodium and Bacinella. Micritic groundmass. Ref. 1340: Alternations of marine and meteoric diagenetic conditions, most probably caused by relative sea level fluctuations, are recorded in an Upper Triassic (Rhaetian) patch reef in the Calcare di Zu Formation, Lombardian Basin. Three main types of cements have been distinguished: 1) isopachous fibrous calcite cement, partially to completely filling mostly secondary solution cavities; 2) radial-fibrous calcite cement in which strongly turbid relics of precursor fibrous cements suggesting a neomorphic origin can be observed, and 3) equant spar calcite found both as a last cement occluding the remaining void space after the cementation by the fibrous cements and as a neomorphic product in corals. Both marine and non-marine internal sediments are present in the patch reef. The marine internal sediments are composed of fecal pellets, peloids, micrite and bioclasts. They could be precedent, successive or contemporaneous to the isopachous marine cement and could have a geopetal disposition or may completely fill cavities. The observations made indicate that a 'peloidal texture' (a nucleus of anhedral HMC crystals from which fibrous crystals radiate) could result from the introduction of peloids/fine-grained micritic intraclasts into fibrous marine cements during their growth. This texture has not been observed in geopetal infill peloids. Non marine internal sediments are composed of crystal silts and their deposition was preceded by the partial dissolution of the isopachous fibrous cements.
title: Diagenesis of a Rhaetian patch reef (Lombardian Basin, Southern Alps). -
paper: Rivista Italiana di Paleontologia e Stratigrafia

name: Denti della Vecchia, Lugano, Southern Alps
title: Diagenesis of a Rhaetian patch reef (Lombardian Basin, Southern Alps). -
paper: Rivista Italiana di Paleontologia e Stratigrafia

name: Annan Seamount, Atlantic Ocean
remarks: Abstract ref. 1342: Phosphatidized bioclastic limestomes of Early Tertiary age were dredged from the crest of a seamount in the equatorial Atlantic. The samples were recovered from water depths of 700-970 m but clearly were deposited in a high-energy reefal environment, thus indicating significant Tertiary subsidence. The vertical movement probably reflects reactivation of an old structural line, the Guinee Fracture Zone, which may have had important effects on the transfer of bottom waters of polar origin between the Sierra Leone and Gambia basins. Examination of foraminiferal limestone coating the shallow water material suggests that deep-water conditions were established on the seamount by Middle Miocene time. All phosphatized samples are covered with a layer of ferromanganese oxides which, from textural and faunal evidence, is Paleocene or Eocene in age and of shallow water origin. Pervasive phosphatiziation of the bioclastic limestones probably was accomplished before the end of the Eocene while the crest of the seamount was near sea level, because Upper Eocene limestone of shallow water facies is unaffected by such radical diagenesis. Phosphatization probably was associated with vigorous upwelling near the seamount and has been taken to an unusually advanced stage, resulting in a phosphorite of high economic grade. P2O5 contents are in the range of 37-41%. The purity of the phosphorites may be related to the intensity of upwelling during the Early Tertiary, but other factors such as the paucity of terrigenous detritus, frequent reworking of the sedimentary capping of the seamount, and a high primary porosity of the limestones may have been important in their formation. The Early Tertiary period of phosphorite deposition on the seamount and in northwest Africa ended before the close of Eocene time in both areas, while shallow water conditions prevailed. The cessation of phosphorite formation probably reflects major changes in the surface circulation of the Atlantic during the Eocene.
title: Deep sea phosphorite of Tertiary age from Annan Seamount eastern equatorial Atlantic. -

name: Annan Seamount, Atlantic Ocean
remarks: Dredged material with corals, crustose coralline algae, bryozoa, molluscs and larger forams. Abstract of ref. 1342: Phosphatidized bioclastic limestomes of Early Tertiary age were dredged from the crest of a seamount in the equatorial Atlantic. The samples were recovered from water depths of 700-970 m but clearly were deposited in a high-energy reefal environment, thus indicating significant Tertiary subsidence. The vertical movement probably reflects reactivation of an old structural line, the Guinee Fracture Zone, which may have had important effects on the transfer of bottom waters of polar origin between the Sierra Leone and Gambia basins. Examination of foraminiferal limestone coating the shallow water material suggests that deep-water conditions were established on the seamount by Middle Miocene time. All phosphatized samples are covered with a layer of ferromanganese oxides which, from textural and faunal evidence, is Paleocene or Eocene in age and of shallow water origin. Pervasive phosphatiziation of the bioclastic limestones probably was accomplished before the end of the Eocene while the crest of the seamount was near sea level, because Upper Eocene limestone of shallow water facies is unaffected by such radical diagenesis. Phosphatization probably was associated with vigorous upwelling near the seamount and has been taken to an unusually advanced stage, resulting in a phosphorite of high economic grade. P2O5 contents are in the range of 37-41%. The purity of the phosphorites may be related to the intensity of upwelling during the Early Tertiary, but other factors such as the paucity of terrigenous detritus, frequent reworking of the sedimentary capping of the seamount, and a high primary porosity of the limestones may have been important in their formation. The Early Tertiary period of phosphorite deposition on the seamount and in northwest Africa ended before the close of Eocene time in both areas, while shallow water conditions prevailed. The cessation of phosphorite formation probably reflects major changes in the surface circulation of the Atlantic during the Eocene.
title: Deep sea phosphorite of Tertiary age from Annan Seamount eastern equatorial Atlantic. -

name: Ilych River, Pechora
remarks: Up to 40 m thick, 120 m wide. Up to 500 m thick according to ref. 1420. Late Wenlockian microbial mound (70 m) and Ludlovian framework with tabulate and branching rugose corals, stromatoporoids, bryozoans and microbes). Diverse stromatolite forming calcified microbes: Epiphyton, Girvanella, Wetheredella, Rothpletzella, Hecetaphyton ... Only abundant metazoan are aphrosalpingid sphinctozoan sponges. High energy platform margin setting. Ref. 2268: This reef shed vast amounts of allochthonous sediments to the adjacent submarine slope
title: Rifie v Paleozoe Pechorskova Urala. -

name: Niyayu, Pechora
remarks: 360 m thick reef. Main framework builders: Fistulella (problematic hydrozoan), stromatoporoids (Clatrodyction, Columnostroma), rugose corals, Spongophylloides, Zelolasma, Aphyllum, Solenopora, Parachaetetes, Renalcis, Epiphyton, Girvanella, Ikella. Rich in brachiopods
title: Rifie v Paleozoe Pechorskova Urala. -

name: Kozhym River, Pechora
title: Rifie v Paleozoe Pechorskova Urala. -

name: Finnmark Platform, Barents Sea
remarks: See reef 2164 for remarks
authors: Blendinger, W., Bowlin, B., Zijp, F.R., Darke, G. & Ekroll, M.
title: Carbonate buildup flank deposits: an example from the Permian (Barents Sea, northern Norway) challenges classical facies models. -

name: Finnmark Platform, Barents Sea
remarks: Microbial boundstones predominate. Packstone matrix with bryozoans, crinoids, Tubiphytes and forams. Stromatactis limestones at base, bryozoan-cement framestones at top. 160 m interval cored. Buildup flank with up to 45° dip angle. Cement alone forms around 46 % of buildup volume. 38 % biogenic particles. 16 % overall micrite (including microbially induced).
authors: Blendinger, W., Bowlin, B., Zijp, F.R., Darke, G. & Ekroll, M.
title: Carbonate buildup flank deposits: an example from the Permian (Barents Sea, northern Norway) challenges classical facies models. -

name: Ardmore, Oklahoma
remarks: Small patch reef formed by an richthofenoid ancestor.
title: Ardmosteges orchamus new genus, new species, in the Early Pennsylvanian of Oklahoma - possible ancestor to the Permian richthofenoid brachiopods. -

name: Lopushna
remarks: Abstract ref. 1348: Upper Jurassic (Oxfordian-Tithonian) reef-bearing carbonates are developed throughout the Ukrainian part of the Carpathian foredeep. These occupy an up to 50-km-wide area in which they attain thicknesses of 500-1000 m, occur at depths ranging between 1 and 7 km, and are covered Early Cretaceous to Miocene sediments. Upper Jurassic strata can be differentiated into reef-core, pre-reef, and back-reef facies. Reservoir development occurs in the karstified, crestal parts of reefs (e.g., Kakhanovka and Letnya fields) and also in detrital back-reef carbonates (Rudky and Lopushnya fields). The potential of this oil and gas play is not yet exhausted, particularly in the area of back-reef facies development under the Carpathian thrust sheets. Reservoir prediction is difficult due to insufficient core control and therefore is based on sedimentological log analyses. Different facies types are characterized by consistent well-log parameters, including shale content, primary and secondary carbonate texture, structure of associated lithotypes, etc. Different facies types can be correlated with characteristic log parameters. Nine facies types are recognized according to the scheme of J. L. Wilson. This opens the possibility to construct regional facies maps, to trace in time and space the development of the actual reef belt, and thus to enhance reservoir prediction. Sedimentological log analysis, combined with seismic criteria, proved to be an effective tool in the analysis of carbonate prospects, as evidenced by the discovery o the genetically unique Lopushnya field. Regional paleosedimentological reconstructions of the Upper Jurassic basin form the basis for evaluating the remaining hydrocarbon potential of the back-reef facies domain in the Ukrainian part of the Carpathian foredeep and the adjacent Romanian territory.
title: Oil and gas in Jurassic reefal complexes of the west Ukrainian Carpathian Foredeep

name: Rudky
remarks: Gas field. Oxfordian Rudky reefs and Kimmeridgian-Tithonian (Oparian) barrier reefs.
title: Oil and gas in Jurassic reefal complexes of the west Ukrainian Carpathian Foredeep

name: Amouslek
title: Archaeocyaths of the Lower Cambrian of Morocco. -

name: Ounein, Lemdad Syncline, High Atlas
remarks: Several archaeocyath-microbe bioherm levels. Regular volcaniclastic influx Radiometric dates available (517 Ma)
authors: Geyer, G., Landing, E. & Heldmaier, W.
title: Faunas and depositional environments of the Cambrian of the Moroccan Atlas regions. -

name: Tiout
remarks: The lower Atdabanian Amouslek-Tazzemourt-Tiout reef barrier. Archaeocyathid-bioherm facies laterally grading into oolitic limestones. Relatively diverse archaeocyathid assemblage. Series of small kalyptrae (Individually up to 10 m) in open shelf shales. Tiout Member of Amouslek Fm. Includes data from Tazemmourt section 30°23°N/ 08°48°W.
authors: Geyer, G., Landing, E. & Heldmaier, W.
title: Faunas and depositional environments of the Cambrian of the Moroccan Atlas regions. -

name: Kur-Teke, Pamir, Tadzhikistan
remarks: Massive hydrozoan-algal reefal limestones. 35-80 m thickness. Diverse rugose corals in Murgabian and Djulfian.
title: Distribution, taxonomy and morphology of Permian Rugosa of southeastern Pamir (Tadhikistan). -
paper: Boletín de la Real Sociedad Espanola de Historia Natural, Sección Geológica

name: Igualada, Ebro Basin
remarks: Fringing reefs interfingering with deltaic deposits. 43 coral species (35 genera). Slightly more than 10 m thick, 50 m wide.
title: New Eocene coral species from Igualada (Barcelona, NE of Spain). -
paper: Boletín de la Real Sociedad Espanola de Historia Natural, Sección Geológica

name: Putou, Chengbu, Hunan
remarks: Barrier type reef with black shales in fore reef. Only stromatoporoid-coral community observed. Domination stage. Reef rests directly on black shales, without intercalation of bioclastic limestones. Few for reef talus. See reef 2173 for more remarks.
title: New thinking about research on Devonian reefs and oil exploration in Hunan, China. -
paper: Boletín de la Real Sociedad Espanola de Historia Natural, Sección Geológica

name: Luguan, Xinhua, Hunan
remarks: Restricted platform facies with dominant Amphipora. Abstract of ref. 1355: Devonian reefs in Hunan were developed in the late Givetian and early Frasnian. Most reefs have been discovered in the area of carbonate platform facies and regarded as biostromes or patch reefs. Rare oil shows have been found in these kinds of reefs. Some so-called 'reef mounds' have abundant oil shows, but they have been considered to have developed only on a few elevated blocks in the area of inter-platform depressional facies. Based on research on reef distribution and characters of sedimentography and paleoecology, this paper proposes that many so-called 'biostromes' are not layered but instead are narrow along the edges of platforms as barrier reefs. Some 'reef mounds' are only the upper parts of barrier reefs, which extended towards the depressional facies area and were broken by faults. If this is true, they will be found along the edges of platforms and are not restricted within narrow limits. Because these parts of the reefs are preserved in the black shales and have fine oil shows, great attention should be paid to them in oil exploration.
title: New thinking about research on Devonian reefs and oil exploration in Hunan, China. -
paper: Boletín de la Real Sociedad Espanola de Historia Natural, Sección Geológica

name: Perán-Carranques, Cantabria
remarks: 26 reef building taxa described. Corals (especially tabulates) dominant in framework facies. 15 genera of rugose corals (mostly solitary). Up to 15 m thick massive reefs in shallowing upward sequence. Proximal carbonate ramp. Small and scarce macroborers evident on plates of ref. 1595. Abstract of ref. 1595: From four outcrops of the Portilla Fm. and one outcrop of the Candas Fm. in the W Cantabrian Mountains 17 species and subspecies of solitary and phaceloid rugose corals are described. They belong to 15 different genera. The stratigraphical classification of four of the localities in question as Upper Givetian is confirmed by means of the identified coral faunas, and this age is also probable for the fifth locality. The rugose coral genera BREVISEPTOSIA n. gen. and SINAXIS n. gen. are erected in this paper; moreover the following 13 new species and subspecies are described and figured: Schindewolfia plena n. sp., Neaxon variabilis n. sp., Catactoechus bonarensis n. sp., Metrionaxon transitorius n. sp., Famennelasma antiquum n. sp., Breviseptosia pulchra n. gen. et n. sp., Sinaxis bulbosa n. gen. et. n. sp., Cyathophyllum (C.) postarduum n. sp., Thamnophyllum caespitosum leonense n. ssp., Acanthophyllum confusum n. sp., Stringophyllum buechelense cantabricum n. ssp., Stringophyllum crassimarginatum n. sp. and Solipetra fontainei n. sp. The number of genera and species of the normally ahermatypic classified small solitary corals without dissepimentarium is unusually great with respect to the reef facies of the Portilla Formation. A part of them even occurs together with compact flat colonies of back reef corals of the 'reef meadows' or even together with large solitary corals. So we have to assume that the 'Portilla environment' of the investigated localities was characterized by a very narrow-spaced irregular morphological pattern of its sea bottom.
authors: Fernández, L.P., Fernández-Martínez, E., García-Ramos, J.C., Méndez-Bedia, I. & Soto, F.
title: A sequential approach to the study of reefal facies in the Candás and Portilla Formations (Middle Devonian) of the Cantabrian Zone (NW Spain). -
paper: Boletín de la Real Sociedad Espanola de Historia Natural, Sección Geológica

name: Ardagh Quarry, Kingscourt
remarks: 95 m thick micritic buildup with abundant brachiopods, bivalves, blastoids - dominated by colonial rugose corals at the top (together with bryozoans, algae, forams). 74 % colonial, 26 % solitary Rugosa. 16 species, 10 genera Fauna similar to, but less fragmented than coeval platform facies.
title: Rugose coral faunas form Upper Viséan (Asbian-Brigantian) buildups and adjacent platform limestones, Kingscourt, Ireland. -
paper: Boletín de la Real Sociedad Espanola de Historia Natural, Sección Geológica

name: Sacharnaja Golova, South Primorye, Sichote-Alin
remarks: Reef-like coral communities with Margarophyllia, Margarosmilia, Pachysolenia, Palaeastraea, Protoheterastrea, Stylophyllopsis, Volzeia. Sphinctozoan Sollasia
title: Early Mesozoic reef-like coral communities development in the Russian Far East. -

remarks: Scleractinians: Beneckastraea, Distichophyllia, Kuhnastraea, Palaestraea, Retiophyllia, Rhaetiastraea, Stuorezia, Thamnotropis. 'Hydroids', calcareous algae additional framework builders. 40% endemic corals

name: Hembrillo Canyon, San Andres Mts., New Mexico
remarks: Maximum thickness 34 m. Phylloid algae, coquinoid fusulind lenses, brachiopods and crinoids are present. Ref. 2239 describes abundant dasycladaceans and tubular forams in addition to phylloids. Microbes concluded from common peloids Coated grains! Two horizons with bioherms. Massive cementstones form base of buildups. Up to 7% porosity
title: Late Pennsylvanian phylloid-algal bioherms, Orogrande Basin, south-central New Mexico and west Texas. -
editors: Barker, J.M.
paper: Geology of the Sierra Blanca, Sacramento, and Capitan Ranges, New Mexico. - N. M. Geol.Soc

name: Montezuma, New Mexico

title: History of a late Carboniferous phylloid algal bank complex in northeastern New Mexico. -

name: Miller Creek, Meeker, Colorado
remarks: Upper Minturn Formation phylloid algal-mound (about 7 m thick). Hydrocarbon staining of fractures. Phylloid-algal packstone/grainstone. Fibrous submarine cement. Ivanovia dominant. Besides phylloids, Epimastopora is present. At the base also bryozoans, Girvanella and worm tubes as reef builders. Cement up to 50 % of buildup.
title: Pennsylvanian (Minturn Formation) algal-mound facies, Rio Blanco County, Colorado. -

name: Altoona, Kansas
remarks: Bryozoan reef developed south of a tidal channel. Encrusting bryozoans (Meekoporella dehiscens) dominant (10-100 %). 16 species, 7 genera among the 4 common Paleozoic orders. Termination of growth by grainstone sedimentation.
authors: Cuffey, R.J., Gooden-Seay, J.A. & Heckel, P.H.
title: Incipient bryozoan reef-mounds in the Upper Pennsylvanian of southeastern Kansas (USA). -

name: L'Original, Ottwa Valley, Ontario
remarks: Blackriverian tubicolous build-ups. Dune shaped-mounds composed of Tymbochoos (suspension feeding polychaet). Microbes associated (abundant where abundance of Tymbochoos decreases). Rare other fossils (bryozoa, bivalves). 48 mounds in area. Up to 5 m length and 0.5 m thickness. Buildups on oolites either in intertidal channels or shallow subtidal shoals.
title: Morphology and palaeoecology of a primitive mound-forming tubicolous polychaete from the Ordovician of the Ottawa Valley, Canada. -

name: Rübeland, Harz
remarks: Thrombolitic mudstones, spar layers, stromatolites. Hexactinellid sponges as only macrofossils. 80 m thick, 260x150 m lateral extension.
title: Controls on the origin and composition of a Devonian mud mound (Frasnian of the Harz Mountains) with special respect to the construction and formation of zebra-limestones. -

name: Süchteln-Sittard, Krefeld
remarks: Youngest stromatoporoid biostromes worldwide. Shallow inner ramp setting (transition to outer ramp). Mixed-carbonate-siliciclastic ramp. Medium diversity: Five massive growing genera and one branching form. Framestones absent. Some Syringopora (tabulate corals). Rare algae: Girvanella, kamaenid algae, Solenopora. Tiny tubular borings in some stromatoporoids.
title: Facies and stromatoporoid biostromes in the Strunian (latest Devonian) of the Aachen region, Germany. -

title: Stratigraphic architecture and diagenesis of middle to late Paleozoic reefs and mounds of the Bolshoi Karatau mountains, Kazakstan and the Southern Urals, Russia: an example of biotic demise and recovery. -

name: Karachaganak Field
remarks: Depressed rim platform ramp. Thrombolite algal mounds. Abstract ref. 1388: Facies analysis and laboratory study has been completed on Upper Devonian to Lower Permian reefs and mounds of southern Kazakstan and Russia. Famennian reefs are composed of Girvanella-Renalcis-sponge-brachiopod boundstone and calcitic cementstone and form reef-rimmed platforms. Tournaisian and Lower Visean carbonates lack an organic margin and form ramps that contain Waulsortian mud mounds rich in crinoids, sponges, and rugose corals. Middle Visean through Serpukhovian carbonates consist of grainstone-rimmed platforms and slopes. Waulsortian mounds located in slope settings are composed of bryozoan-sponge-Tubiphytes-algae boundstone and calcitic cementstone. Bashkirian shelf margins consist of Donezellid-Archaeolithoporella-brachiopod boundstone and aragonitic cementstone. Lower Permian shelf margins and slope mounds are comprised of bryozoan-Tubiphytes-algae boundstone and calcitic cementstone and Palaeoaplysina rudstone. Devonian through Lower Carboniferous reefs and slope mounds are tight due to cementation; dolomitization and karsting enhance porosity in shelf margins and interiors. Middle Carboniferous and Lower Permian slope mounds and margin facies are porous due to exposure related diagenesis. These data suggest that: 1) following a Late Devonian extinction event, major shifts took place in the composition and spatial distribution of reef and mound biota as carbonate benthos became re-established, and; 2) the distribution of reservoir-grade porosity is strongly influenced by early-marine cementation, dolomitization and meteoric-related diagenetic processes. Corresponding shifts in the morphology of carbonate platforms, and the spatial distribution of potential reservoirs, suggest a strong biotic and abiotic influence on platform architecture and reservoir development. Comparisons with study of Karachaganak and Tengiz fields confirm these observations.
authors: Zempolich, W.G., Cook, H.E., Zhemchuzhnikov, V. G., Zorin, A.Ye.
title: Stratigraphic architecture and diagenesis of middle to late Paleozoic reefs and mounds of the Bolshoi Karatau mountains, Kazakstan and the Southern Urals, Russia: an example of biotic demise and recovery. -

name: Shernyadeyta River, Chernyshev Ridge
remarks: Stromatoporoid-microbial mounds and banks. 200-300 m thick bank with 4-6 m thick bioherms. Microbes and alage: Renalcis, Izhella, Shuguria, Epiphyton, Sphaerocodium, Girvanelly, Chbakovia, Paleomicrocodium, Ortonella and solenoporids. Various isopachos fibrous texture through microbial crusts.
title: Organic buildups and reefs on the Paleozoic carbonate platform margin, Pechora Urals, Russia. -

name: Verchnyaya Pechora River
remarks: 300 m thick buildup (locally up to 1000 m). Microbial associations comprise more than 50 % of all reef boundstones. Coalesced small biostromes and bioherms (3 m thick). 25 species of calcareous algae in whole region Plenty of reef debris flows. Continuing into Emsian.
title: Organic buildups and reefs on the Paleozoic carbonate platform margin, Pechora Urals, Russia. -

name: Verchnyaya Pechora River
remarks: See reef 2247.
title: Organic buildups and reefs on the Paleozoic carbonate platform margin, Pechora Urals, Russia. -

name: Lemva River, Pechora, Urals
remarks: Pragian to lower Emsian. Up to 1000 m thick reef complex extensively dolomitized. Appears to be microbial mound. Ikella, Garwoodia, Ortonella and Girvanelly at base. Cavernous porosity.
title: Organic buildups and reefs on the Paleozoic carbonate platform margin, Pechora Urals, Russia. -

name: Kozhym River
remarks: see reef 914.
title: Organic buildups and reefs on the Paleozoic carbonate platform margin, Pechora Urals, Russia. -

name: Lec-Elec River, Pechora
remarks: Pragian part is 360 m thick. Lower Emsian part is 220 m thick. Wetheredella-Stachyodes boundstones associated with Ikella-Fistulella, and Solenopora-metazoan boundstones.
title: Organic buildups and reefs on the Paleozoic carbonate platform margin, Pechora Urals, Russia. -

name: Ilych River, Urals
remarks: Massive structure 1x1.5 km across. 110 m thick. Framework dominated by encrusting Girvanella, Rothpletzella and other microbes. Subordinate heliolitids (Plasmoporella, Heliolites, Propora), tabulate and rugose corals and hydroid problematica (Fistulella).
title: Organic buildups and reefs on the Paleozoic carbonate platform margin, Pechora Urals, Russia. -

name: Lec-Elec River, Pechora
remarks: Patch reefs composed of an alternation of microbial-coral and stromatoporoid boundstones. 60-80 m thick. Interbeds of microbial mudstones with Stromatactis. framework dominated by encrusting Girvanella, Garwoodia, Ikella with subordinate stromatoporoids, favositids and bioclastic debris.
title: Organic buildups and reefs on the Paleozoic carbonate platform margin, Pechora Urals, Russia. -

name: Bolshaya Usa River, Polar Urals
remarks: Extensively dolomitized. About 170 m thick. Stromatolites predominate. Calcimicrobes: Girvanella, Renalcis, Ikella. Stromatoporoids, branching tabulates and rare rugose corals only in lower part of the reef.
title: Organic buildups and reefs on the Paleozoic carbonate platform margin, Pechora Urals, Russia. -

name: Olysya, Bolshaya Nadota River, Urals
remarks: Massive to poorly bedded, recrystallized structure. 200 m thick. 2 x 4 km across. Stromatolitic boundstones predominate. Irregular cavities with filled by fibrous blocky calcite cements. Crinoids, brachiopods, gastropods, bryozoans occur locally. Reef talus in the east.
title: Organic buildups and reefs on the Paleozoic carbonate platform margin, Pechora Urals, Russia. -

name: Attawapiskat River, Ontario
remarks: Outcrop of Attawapiskat Formation. 8.3 m thick. Stromatoporoid-coral framework overlain by crinoid-rich caprock or bioclastic packstones/rudstones. Abstract or ref. 1423: Outcrop exposures along the Attawapiskat River in the Hudson Bay Lowlands of northern Ontario clearly reveal the morphology of Silurian (upper Llandoverian) reefs of the Attawapiskat Formation and the relationships between reef cores, flanking beds, and post-reef beds. These relationships indicate that the reefs had a syndepositional relief of at least 8-10 m. The relief of the reefs is indicated by debris-flow lenses encased within flanking beds, a debris-flow fan at the base of a reef, thin reef-flanking beds truncated against a vertical reef face, penecontemporaneous brachiopod beds on the flanks of reefs, and three large slide blocks that apparently slid over the side of a reef. Reefs of the Attawapiskat Formation are largely limestones with a wide range of lithologies. from stromatoporoid-, coral-, and cement-rich boundstones to alga- cement-rich boundstones. Thick, laterally extensive Nuia grainstone beds, a product of widespread Nuia monocultures in supratidal to intertidal ponds, are present above the reefs. The most important diagenetic processes were early marine cementation (predominantly radial-fibrous calcite), shallow burial diagenesis, and pervasive neomorphism. Schematic reconstructions of the depositional history of the Attawapiskat Formation in outcrop, constructed from observations of outcrop relationships, show a stratigraphic succession that was controlled by relative-sea-level changes. Reefs growth was terminated by a relative-sea-level fall, but subsequent minor relative-sea-level fluctuations resulted in alternating deposition of supratidal to shallow subtidal sediments for a short time before the final retreat of the Silurian seas from the Hudson Bay Platform; only supratidal evaporite facies are present in the remainder of the Silurian section above the Attawapiskat Formation.
title: Lower Silurian sequence stratigraphy and sea-level history of the Hudson Bay Platform. -

name: Knoxboro, Central New York State
remarks: Biomicrite and biosparite at base. Initial colonization and stabilization by Favosites. Late Favosites and Tryplasma Includes data for Mosquito Point reef and four Munnsville reefs. On a global basis, carbonate buildups of Early Devonian age are little known compared to examples from Silurian and later Devonian time, and they may be rare in occurrence. Study of the Knoxboro buildup (a patch reef) and related buildups of the Deansboro Member of the Coeymans Formation (Lower Devonian) from central New York has provided insight into the style and development of buildups of this age. The Knoxboro buildup formed on an open marine carbonate platform, and it exhibits 3 distinct vertical stages of sedimentologic and biologic development. Stage I, initial colonization and substrate stabilization, is recognized by the growth of moderately large favositid tabulate corals on a crinoidal calcarenite substrate. Most tabulates are preserved in growth position. Stage II, growth to mean wave base, is characterized primarily by beds of micrite and biomicrite-biomicrudite with in situ colonies of dendroid Favosites and Tryplasma corals. These beds form the core of the buildup. Channels, mostly filled with crinoidal debris, cut into beds formed during Stage II. Stage III diversification, is marked by beds of crinoidal debris which blanket the biomicrite core. Planar tabulate (favositid) corals and stromatoporoids (the latter often encrusting the former) are conspicuous in these uppermost beds. Localized occurrences of articulated crinoid columnals represent crinoid patches that occupied somewhat protected locations in the buildup area. Faunal diversity reaches a maximum in these beds, although diversity appears to be no greater than that of equivalent non-buildup facies of the Deansboro Member. This tabulate and colonial rugose coral buildup is transitional in form and faunal composition between North American midcontinent Silurian buildups and later buildups of Middle Devonian age.
title: Anatomy of an Early Devonian carbonate buildup, central New York. -

Bryozoans predominate: Membranipora lapidosa, Nitscheina kischinewensis, Schizoporella eichwaldi, S. tetes, S. variabilis, S. mariae... Algae: Lithophyllum ucrainicum, Melobesia badjii, Jania dnestrovica... Others are bivalves and serpulids. Base of buildups are bryozoan limestones, middle part with bryozoan-algae-foram (Nubecularia) limestones, upper part with algae-Nubecularia limestone.

name: Searcy Co., Arkansas
remarks: Type II thrombolitic mounds of ref. 1431. 6 m synoptic relief. Thrombolites-encrusting bryozoans-fenestrate bryozoans-encrusting forams-spicular alga as mound builders. Phylloid algae more common than in type I mounds (reefs. 2272, 2273).

name: Washington Co., Arkansas
remarks: Early Serpukhovian 15-20 m thick, 50 m lateral extension. Type I thrombolitic mounds with about 3 m synoptic relief. Interfingering with oolitic and bioclastic grainstones. Reticulate framework and encrusted metazoans. Thrombolites-encrusting bryozoans-fenestrate bryozoans (Archimedes dominant)-encrusting forams-spicular alga as main mound builders. Tyrpanites and acrothoracican barnacle borings according to ref. 1517.
title: Late Mississippian thrombolite bioherms from the Pitkin Formation of northern Arkansas. -

name: Battle Mountain, Nevada
remarks: Dominated by Renalcis and Epiphyton. Proaulopora. Archaeocyathids (important taxa only): Mackenziecyathus, Siderocyathus, Keriocyathus, Archaesycon, Molybdocyathus. Abstract of ref. 1995: Abstract: Several new occurrences of archaeocyathan-calcimicrobe-built reefs have been discovered in the upper Harkless Formation (Bonnia-Olenellus Zone) in Esmeralda County, Nevada. Initial analyses of the paleoecology of these reefs show that the community structure consisted of several genera of archaeocyaths acting as the framework entity with calcimicrobes acting as the binding entity. Since the reefs are found in the upper Harkless, they are among the youngest known metazoan-built reefs in western North America and represent the last pulse of metazoan reef building prior to their global disappearance in the Middle to Late Cambrian. The mechanism or mechanisms that contributed to the demise of the metazoan reefs are unknown; therefore, we are studying these reefs in part to test hypotheses concerning the collapse of the Early Cambrian metazoan reef communities. These reefs contain the typical assemblage of Early Cambrian reef dwellers such as trilobites, echinoderms, and brachiopods; however, at one locality coralomorphs are conspicuously present. These coralomorphs are approximately 12 cm long by 18 cm wide, are found scattered throughout the reefs, and constitute only a small percentage of the reef by volume. The coralomorphs have definite polygonal corallites which do not share walls, and resemble cerioid tabulate corals without obvious tabulae. Septa occur as obscure processes that project into the center of the corallites, dividing the corallites in half. These coralomorphs are similar to the genus Rosellatana, Kobluk, 1984 from the Lower Cambrian Cassiar Mountains of British Columbia.
authors: Debrenne, F., Gandin, A. & Gangloff, R.A.
title: Analyse sédimentologique et paléontologie de calcaires organogènes du Camrien Inférieur de Battle Mountain (Nevada, U.S.A.). -

name: Wat Samakki Tham
remarks: Black massive limestone with scattered corals. Tabulata (Protomichelinia, Sinopora) Rugosa: Solitary, fasciculate (Pseudohuangia) and massive. Pseudohuangia up to 1 m in diameter. Calcareous sponges locally abundant. Some brachiopods.

Rugosa solitary, fasciculate and massive. Recognized taxa (incomplete list): Thamnopora Scoliopora Caunopora Alveolitidae Heliolites Thamnophyllum Phillipsastrea

name: Guguk Bulat, Sumatra
remarks: Algae are very abundant (e.g. Ungdarella) but not studied. Sponges are common. One species especially common: Molengraffia tabulata. Corals: very scarce fasciculate tabulates (Aulopora) and scarce solitary rugose, but abundant massive Waagenophyllidae (80 % Wentzelloides, 20 % Ipciphyllum).

name: Bayan Gol, Zavkhan Basin
remarks: Calcimicrobial domal bioherms, up to 1 m in height and 2 m in diameter. Dominated by Korilophyton. Tarthinia is a minor component. Bioherm stacks as substrate for domal stromatolites. Should be plate 419. Abstract of ref. 1452: The Neoproterozoic-Cambrian succession in the Zavkhan Basin of western Mongolia preserves early Cambrian bioconstructions of Nemakit-Daldynian to Botomian age. As elsewhere (Siberia, Morocco), the Nemakit-Daldynian bioconstructions in the upper Tsagaan Gloom Formation to lower Bayan Gol Formation interval were purely calcimicrobial. Spectacular calcimicrobial 'patch reefs' of presumed Tommotian age are present in the lower Bayan Gol Formation. In contrast, late Atdabanian-early Botomian bioconstructions are varied and well developed in the upper Salaany Gol Formation including, in addition to calcimicrobial bioherms, Gordonophyton-Razumovskia crusts, radiocyathan-archaeocyathan bioherms and thickets of the ramose archaeocyath Cambrocyathellus. These latter Zavkhan Basin buildups show some ecological and sedimentological features in common with coeval bioconstructions in South Australia, which also developed under a tectonically active regime.
authors: Kruse, P.D., Gandin, A., Debrenne, F. & Wood, R.
title: Early Cambrian bioconstruction in the Zavkhan Basin of western Mongolia. -

name: Salaany Gol, Zavkhan Basin
remarks: 40 m thick interval with several mounds. Individual mounds up to 5 m thick and more than 10 m long. Well developed cements. Three types of bioconstructions: - Gordonophyton-Razumovskia crusts supporting a cryptic community of coralomorphs, cribricyaths and archaeocyaths in shelter cavities. - radiocyathan-archaeocyathan bioherms. 29 species of archaocyaths, 4 species of calcimicrobes, 2 problematic reef builders. - calcimicrobial bioherms with Gordonophyton, Batinevia, Proaulopora and rafts of Razumovskia. Archaeocyaths as debris. Should be plate 419.
authors: Kruse, P.D., Gandin, A., Debrenne, F. & Wood, R.
title: Early Cambrian bioconstruction in the Zavkhan Basin of western Mongolia. -

name: Tayshir, Zavkhan Basin
remarks: Calcimicrobial patch reefs in sandstone. Very shallow water. Growth up to sea level indicated by flat upper tops. Mounds up to 0.7 m thick and 3 m in diameter. Should be plate 419.
authors: Kruse, P.D., Gandin, A., Debrenne, F. & Wood, R.
title: Early Cambrian bioconstruction in the Zavkhan Basin of western Mongolia. -

Diverse coralline algae (Mesophyllum, Lithoporella (23 %), Spongites (20 %), Neogoniolithon). Larger forams and bryozoans also common. Up to 70 % of Matrix. Surrounded by well bedded packstones and algal crust-branch rudstones.

Rarely: Montlivaltia, Actinastrea, Heliocoenia, Stilosmilia, Comoseris, Anabacia. RED ALGAE: Solenopora, rarely Marinella, Ungdarella, Melobesia, Petschoria, Donezella, Komia, Lithophyllum. CYANOBACTERIA: Girvanella, Ortonella, Renalcis, Rothpletzella, stromatolites. Sometimes abundant stromatoporoids, chlorophyta, porifera, bryozoans and others.

name: Rama Ride, Banda Sea
remarks: Reefal platform. Decimeter-sized coral fragments (e.g. Porites pusilla). Many larger foraminifera. Abstract ref. 1472: In December 1995 we dredged early Miocene coral-reef carbonates and early/middle Pliocene slope carbonates outcropping on the submerged Rama Ridge. This indicates that some of the Banda Sea Ridges were present during early Miocene times. Subsequent major tectonic subsidence occurred between middle Miocene and early Pliocene times. These results concur with the hypothesis of a relatively recent age for the North Banda Sea basement.
authors: Cornée, J.-J., Butterlin, J., Saint-Marc, P., Rehault, J.-P., Honthaas, C., Laurenti-Ribaud, A.

name: Zuune Arts
remarks: Mixed carbonate-siliciclastic shelf setting. Individual bioherms less than 2 m thick and wide. Upsection coalesced to form up to 15 m thick complexes. Surrounded by grainstones with little archaeocyath debris. Four types of reef buildups: Calcimicrobe boundstones Calcimicrobe bafflestones Radiocyath-archaeocyath-cribricyath bioherms Archaeocyaths form up to 20 % of rock volume. 12 species. 1 Radiocyath species 10 calcimicrobe species.
authors: Wood, R., Zhuravlev, A.Y. & Anaaz, C.T.
title: The ecology of Lower Cambrian buildups from Zuune Arts, Mongolia: implications for early metazoan reef evolution. -

name: l'Épine
remarks: In situt reefs up to 11 m thick and 20 m across. Diverse macro- and microborings. High species diversity, but low ecological diversity. Abstract of ref. 1490 During the late middle Oxfordian, patch reefs grew on the northern margin of the Paris Basin. According to the facies analysis of the reef and inter-reef sediments, the environment was a warm, clear and agitated sea with highly episodic sedimentation. The bioherms were a short-lived phenomenon during the third phase of regional reefal development. Sequence stratigraphically, they are associated with a highstand system tract. Volumetrically and trophically dominant organisms were microbes now represented by massive clotted leiolite, 'stalactitic' hemispheroids with purely thrombolitic texture are restricted to open caves. Corals were of structural, reef-building importance due to their rapid upward growth. The patch reefs are characterised by thickets of ramose corals which developed a very open framework. In the vicinity of these patch reefs, though in hydrodynamically higher-energy environments, grew thickets of more stoutly branched corals. However, they are rarely preserved in situ and are generally represented as abundant coral rubble. The reef taxa are characterised by the notable absence of several groups (e.g. oysters, serpulids, bryozoans, pectinids) occurring at other localities where reefs of similar age developed in similar environmental conditions. The reefs also have strikingly modern aspects to them, in particular the presence of cryptic elements within caves and a sponge-dominated borer association. Dwellers belong to various life-form types although encrusting taxa are exceedingly rare. This may be explained by the presence of soft microbial films on most surfaces. The palaeoecological analysis suggests that the major controls on faunal composition and high diversity were elevated nutrient levels, highly episodic sedimentation and probably seasonal environmental disturbances. Structural and functional aspects of the reef community (grazers trigger framebuilders, borers trigger binders, binders hamper borers) allow ecological comparisons to be made with contemporaneous, as well as Recent, reefs. The unique combination of ecological factors resulted in a specialised, previously undescribed, community which differs from both Tethyan and northern localities in various aspects. These include cavities with cryptofauna, prominence of grazing gastropods and high faunal diversity in a microbially dominated build-up.
title: Late Jurassic coral/microbial reefs from the northern Paris Basin - facies, paleoecology and paleobiogeography. -

name: Oberwössen, Bavaria

Litho- and biofacies of this reef were investigated by the authors of this paper. New results allow a new palaeogeographic interpretation of some elder boreholes of Rügen Island.

name: Shahmirzad, Elburz
remarks: Calcareous demosponges (Rankenella) occupy 50 % of the reef volume. Sponges encrusted by bacteria Abstract of ref. 1501: Middle and Late Cambrian reefs were built mainly by cyanobacterial communities. A few reefs with a metazoan as well as an algal component, however, are known from this interval. A Middle Cambrian reef formed primarily by spicular demosponges is described here from the Mila Formation in the Elburz Mountains, northern Iran. The reef is enclosed within calcareous grainstones which contain terminal Middle Cambrian (late Mayan) trilobites. The Mila Formation reef was constructed by sponges of the family Anthaspidellidae and bacterial (algal?) sheaths, and is the earliest metazoan reef to be documented from the interval after the demise of archaeocyath sponges. The reefal community is typical of subsequent reefal communities of Early-Middle Ordovician age. The Ordovician examples differ only by the incorporation of additional metazoan elements.
authors: Hamdi, B., Rozanov, A.Y. & Zhuravlev, A.Y.
title: Latest Middle Cambrian metazoan reef from northern Iran

name: Argentina Range, Pensacola Mts.,
remarks: Glacial erratics on King George Island (South Shetland Islands) thought to derive from Argentina Range. Abstract of ref. 1504: Twenty six species of archaeocyaths are described (seven in open nomenclature), including Naimarkcyathus elenae gen. et sp. n. representing a new family Naimarkcyathidae and superfamily Naimarkcyathoidea of the order Archaeocyathida, from the Cambrian limestone erratics in the glacio-marine sediments of the Oligocene Polonez Cove and Early Miocene Cape Melville Formations on King George Island (South Shetland Islands, West Antarctica). They are accompanied by coralomorphs and calcified cyanobacteria. The archaeocyathan assemblage closely resembles allochthonous assemblages from the Weddell Sea and Whichaway Nunataks. Current reconstructions of icestream movement and iceberg drift, and similarities in species composition, suggest the Argentina Range limestones as a source of these erratics. The species Stapicyathus stapipora, Prethmophyllum subacutum, Aporosocyathus mucroporus, 'Mennericyathus' dissitus, Paranacyathus sarmaticus and Archaeopharetra irregularis are added to the list of common species for Antarctica and Australia. The total list of the common Australian-Antarctic archaeocyaths now include 31 of all of the 52 well defined Antarctic species. The archaeocyaths of King George Island, and Early Cambrian Antarctic archaeocyath assemblages (except these of the Mt. Egerton in the Byrd Glacier area) are of uppermost Botomian age (Syringocnema favus Beds) as in South Australia. This means that archaeocyaths did not reach Antarctica until latest Botomian time. Erratic blocks containing archaeocyaths represent various reef facies similar to the Shackleton Limestone facies and those of South Australia. The occurrence of small shelly fossils (Dailyatia ajax, ? Byronia sp., Halkieria parva, Thambetolepis delicata and Albrunicola bengtsoni) which are typical of the Parara Limestone, of the Syringocnema favus archaeocyathan assemblage, and of Hadimopanella antarctica and certain brachiopods in erratics of different lithologies, suggests a very similar faunal and facies succession for Antarctica and South Australia and therefore, a comparable basin history.
title: Early Cambrian archaeocyaths from glacial erratics of King George Island (South Shetland Islands), Antarctica. -

name: Hackberry Draw and Chinaberry Draw, Capitan, Texas
remarks: Abstract ref. 1533: The Permian Capitan reef of the Guadalupe Mountains was bound, lithified, and preserved by microbially precipitated micrite. A microbial origin or association is based on the distribution, texture, fossil content, and order of microstratigraphic succession. In samples from the middle Capitan Formation, micrite layers (about 1 cm thick) encrusted the top, sides, and undersides of in situ organisms and also piled above organisms in thick (0.5 to > 3 cm) accumulations, with high angles of repose (up to 90°). Primary encrustations commonly consist of thin, homogeneous, subparallel layers of Archaeolithoporella---interpreted to be a red alga that probably lived in dimly lit cavities. Secondary encrustations (0.5--30 mm thick) contain 10--50 µm diameter peloids and fossil cyanophytes, and are usually bound by thin layers of micrite. Secondary encrustations of gravity-defying peloidal micrites are interpreted as having precipitated within mucilaginous microbial aggregations, probably in dark cavities. The secondary microbial micrites were followed by cavity-filling, aragonitic botryoids. Thin (< 1 mm) layers of clotted micrite were deposited on the first botryoids, probably by microbial biofilms. In contrast to samples from the middle Capitan Formation, samples from the upper Capitan Formation taken near the transition from reef to outer shelf are composed of smaller (1--2 mm) framework organisms and are bound by layers of thinner (< 1 mm) primary encrustations. In the upper Capitan Formation samples, dense, clotted micrite forms secondary encrustations (£ 1 mm thick), commonly underneath primary framework. Secondary encrustations are succeeded by more abundant tertiary encrustations (1--4 mm thick) of sparse, clotted micrite with vague dendritic structures. The secondary and tertiary encrustations are interpreted as microbial. The samples from the upper Capitan Formation were deposited in the shallowest part of the reef (< 1 to 10 m deep), and most of the samples from the middle Capitan were deposited in deep water (10--140 m). The difference in the encrustations and in the overall scale of the two fabrics is probably related to differences in environmental energy during deposition.
authors: Kirkland, B. L., Dickson, J. A. D., Wood, R. A., and Land, L. S.
title: Microbialite and microstratigraphy: the origin of encrustations in the middle and upper Capitan Formation, Guadalupe Mountains, Texas and New Mexico, USA. -

name: Al-Abiad
remarks: Only oyster Ambigostrea villei (cited as Lopha villei) present. Later unpublished report (web) additionally cites Oscillopha figari and Nicaisolopha nicaisei Artulated valves prevalent in lower part. Higher up, shells increasingly broken. Borings on both valves. Up to 40 m thick. Abstract of ref. 1534: Phosphorite grains were authigenically precipitated within precursor marl and biosiliceous deposits during high water level and intense upwelling within the Tethys Ocean to the north of Jordan. With falling sea level, the oyster Lopha villei colonized bathymetric highs in the shallow shelfal environments in east-central Jordan during the uppermost Campanian--Lower Maastrichtian (Late Cretaceous). The oyster bioherms in the epeiric southern shelf of the Tethys formed small basins several hundreds of meters across and about 40--50 m deep. Under these lowstand conditions, oyster shells were shed off the bioherms and deposited as large cross-bedded units on the flanks of the basins. At the same time, precursor phosphatic sediments were reworked and winnowed to form high-grade phosphorite sand. More than 250 million metric tons (250 x 109 kilograms) of phosphorite sand were deposited basinward of the oyster beds. As sea level continued to fall, the oyster bioherms formed partially silled basins with low biological diversity in which marl and/or bituminous marl was deposited. The marls are overlain by the transgressive phosphatic marl and chalk of the Muwaggar Formation, which were deposited under open marine conditions.
title: Role of upper cretaceous oyster bioherms in the deposition and accumulation of high-grade phosphorites in central Jordan. -

name: Barrett Canyon, Salton Sea, California
remarks: Siderastrea menhalli bank with patch reefs in sandstones of the Latrania Member. Bank 1-2 m thick, 20 m wide and 500 m long. Little or no evidence of bioerosion. Patch reefs with some Porites carrizensis, Siderastrea california and S. fainbanksi dispersed between large S. menhalli colonies.
title: Ecology and morphology of the Caribbean Mio-Pliocene reef-coral Siderastrea. -

name: E Canning Basin
remarks: Position doubtful Abstract ref. 1551: Miospores from boreholes through the earliest sediments associated with the onset of the formation of reef complexes on the Lennard Shelf of northern Western Australia include representatives of the Geminospora lemurata-Cymbosporites magnificus and Contagisporites optivus-Cristatisporites triangulatus Assemblage Zones. The palynofloral evidence indicates that deposition of the reef sequence began in the mid-Givetian, rather than latest Givetian as previously thought. Palynomorphs become sparser with increase in carbonate content and consequently middle Frasnian to Famemmian palynomorph zones cannot be distinguished in the reef complexes.
title: A mid-Givetian miospore age for the onset of reef development on the Lennard Shelf Canning Basin Western Australia. -

name: Fombuena
remarks: Largest mounds 1.8 m thick, 6 m wide. Complexes up to 5 m thick. Baffling most important, second is biocementstone. Absence of boring organisms. Three stages of community development: Stabilization, colonization, diversification, but no domination. Abstract of ref. 1560: Mud-mound complexes identified within the early to middle Ashgill Cystoid Limestone Formation of northeastern Spain are the first fossil build-ups to be described in the high latitude north-facing margin of Gondwana. Mud-mound complexes comprise individual lenticular mounds (composed of floatstones, cephalopod-rich mudstones and cementstones), flanks and intermound deposits (including pelmatozoan packstones and floatstones). The small mounds are mainly composed of bryozoans, cystoids and crinoids, and were developed on outer ramp environments. Mound initiation depended upon the stabilization and colonization of densely packed lenses of pelmatozoan-rich sediments. In a mid-ramp setting, pelmatozoan-bryozoan meadows were episodically degraded by common wave- and storm-induced processes, the development of semi-consolidated substrates, and the periodic influx of terrigenous material. Finally, during the Hirnantian regression, the Iberian mixed (carbonate-siliciclastic) platform was exposed to subaerial conditions sufficiently for erosion and karstification to occur. From a palaeogeographical point of view, the pattern of the Ashgill Iberian platform deposition is characterized by episodic exclusion of carbonates from most nearshore environments by a shoreline source of siliciclastic sediments. A similar interpretation to that made on the Iberian Cystoid Limestone Formation, in terms of gradual proximality-distality changes, is proposed for comparable facies types in Ashgill limestones described in southwestern Europe.
authors: Vennin, E., Alvaro, J.J. & Villas, E.
title: High-latitude pelmatozoan-bryozoan mud-mounds from the late Ordovician northern Gondwana platform. -

name: Hawker Bay, Grinell Peninsula, Nunavut
remarks: Inner shelf-margin buildups composed of thrombolitic limestone. Largest is at least 100 m thick and 2-3 km in diameter. Zonation: Lowest are 1 mud mounds with composed thromboids and Conophyton-like stromatolites, then 2 cerebroform stromatolite facies, then 3 thrombolite facies with clotted core and stromatolitic margin, locally encrusted by lithistid sponges 4 large thrombolite facies with a columnar stromatolitic core. Outer shelf interior buildups also present (reef. 2347).
title: Kilometre-scale microbial buildups in a rimmed carbonate platform succession, Arctic Canada: new insight on Lower Ordovician reef facies. -

name: Bulleys Lump, Judge Daly Promot., Nunavut
remarks: Member A Outer Shelf edge buildup. Together with upper Member B about 1.5 km syndepositional relief. Fenestral pelmicrite and fenestral pelsparite predominate. Calcimicrobes associated: Halysis, cf. Hedstroemia, Epiphyton, Renalcis, Girvanella. Up to 30 % early marine cement. Abstract of ref. 1574: Four Lower Ordovician buildup categories occur in carbonate platform strata in the Canadian Arctic Islands: outer and inner shelf-margin buildups and outer and inner shelf-interior buildups. The outer shelf-margin buildup in the Bulleys Lump Formation consists mainly of calcirnicrobial biolithite and early marine cement, forming a structure that probably had a depositional relief of more than 1.5 km over contiguous basinal chert and mudrock. The length of the outer shelf-margin buildup is probably more than 1400 km, although it is discontinuously exposed. Inner shelf-margin buildups are smaller, mounded structures, attaining thicknesses in excess of 100 m and widths of several kilometres. A representative inner shelf-margin buildup comprises four distinct microbial facies; the stratigraphically lowest and deepest water facies contains up to 4 m-thick thrombolite mounds surrounded by Conophyton-like stromatolitic pinnacles. The two middle facies consist of numerous, aligned ovoidal thrombolites with thromboidal or columnar stromatolitic interiors and stromatolitic margins. Thrombolites were built mainly by benthic microbial communities, but fleshy and locally well-sclerotized sponges were probably important constructors as well. These thrombolites are overlain by the shallowest water and youngest buildup facies, consisting of cerebroform stromatolites and thrombolites, but which lack the distinctive ovoidal thrombolites of the underlying facies. Zoned inner shelf-margin microbial buildups such as these are previously undocumented. Shelf-interior buildups are composed of thrombolites and stromatolites, forming isolated, I to 5 m-high mounds and coalesced mounds in buildups more than 2.0 km wide. The distribution of the four buildup categories implies a shelf-margin embayment in the central part of the Arctic Islands.
title: Kilometre-scale microbial buildups in a rimmed carbonate platform succession, Arctic Canada: new insight on Lower Ordovician reef facies. -

name: Boonderoo, N.S.W.
remarks: Dunhill Bluff Limestone Member of Fossil Hill Limestone. 2.6 m thick coral/stromatoporoid biohermal mass. 85 % of biovolume formed by Tetradium cribriforme (up to 40x30 cm diameter) at base. Takeover by stromatoporoids up section reaching 50 % of biovolume at top. Other corals: Nycropora, Bajgolia, encrusting Dualites, cerioid Eofletcheria, solitary Hillophyllum. Stromatoporoids: Cystistroma, Labechia, Stratodictyon, Rosenella. Skeletal wackestone matrix, although sediments above and below are grainstones. Additional mound occur in Taplow limestone member, Transmission limestone member.
authors: Webby, B.D., Zhen, Y.Y. & Percival, I.G.
title: Ordovician coral- and sponge-bearing associations: Distribution and significance in volcanic island shelf to slope habitats, eastern Australia. -
paper: Boletín de la Real Sociedad Española de Historia Natural, Sección Geológica

name: Cliefden Caves, N.S.W.
remarks: Kalimna Limestone Member of Fossil Hill Limestone. 1.2 m thick sheet-like biostrome. Large (60x30 cm) Tetradium cribiforme colonies (Tabulate). 3 % of biovolume composed of Nycropora (T) and Cystistroma (S). 1.5 % composed of Bajgolia (T), Hillophyllum (R) and encrusting Dualites (T). 1 % are bryzoans. Collection of Miller Abstract ref. 1597: The Cliefden Caves area of central New South Wales has a well preserved Late Ordovician sedimentary succession that formed in an offshore, near-equatorial, volcanic island setting. Initially fringing deposits (the Fossil Hill Limestone) accumulated, with occurrences of corals such as Tetradium cribriforme, Nyctopora, Bajgolia, Dualites, Hillophyllum, and stromatoporoids like Cystistroma, Rosenella and Stratodictyon. These were particularly characteristic of the shoal-type, mid-shelf T. cribriforme biofacies, and were contributors to a number of bioherms and biostromes. The succeeding, massive Belubula Limestone accumulated mainly in shallow lagoonal phases of the planated island with only sparse heliolitine corals, Aulopora, Bajgolia?, the stromatoporoids Cystostroma and Alleynodictyon? and the sphinctozoan sponge Belubulaia. The overlying deeper platform carbonates of the Vandon Limestone have a more diverse fauna with T. cribriforme, numerous heliolitines, Palaeophyllum, the sphinctozoan Cliefdenella, and stromatoporoids (Ecclimadictyon, Clathrodictyon), but no indubitable 'reefs'. Deep water assemblages of the overlying Malongulli Formation include reworked and in situ siliceous sponge associations. Limestone breccias include: (1) clasts with corals (Favistina and favositids) and rare silicified sphinctozoans, presumed to be derived from the adjacent shallow platform; and (2) clasts eroded from the slopes, with a diverse assemblage of demosponges, hexactinellids and discrete spicules. The in situ Malongulli assemblage occupied a lower slope/basin position, and includes undescribed hexactinellids and abundant spicules. A striking onshore-offshore faunal differentiation exists, with (1) the corals and stromatoporoids, most diversified and abundant in the mid-shelf island settings above wave base, (2) the sphinctozoans, rare constituents of lagoonal to subtidal 'level bottom' carbonate platform habitats, (3) the demosponges, most common and diversified in the upper slope, and (4) the hexactinellids, well represented in both upper and lower slope /basin habitats.
authors: Webby, B.D., Zhen, Y.Y. & Percival, I.G.
title: Ordovician coral- and sponge-bearing associations: Distribution and significance in volcanic island shelf to slope habitats, eastern Australia. -
paper: Boletín de la Real Sociedad Española de Historia Natural, Sección Geológica

name: Upper Keg River, NE British Columbia
remarks: Pinnacle reefs seaward of Presqu'ile Barrier. Varaibly dolomitized. Dominated by bulbous and tabular stromatoporoids. Rugose corals represent by small branching forms (particaularly Dendrostella trigemme) enlosed in stromatop. Abstract of ref. 1600: Rugose corals of mid-late Eifelian age are diverse and relatively abundant in widespread open shelf carbonates of Northeastern British Columbia (lower Keg River and Dunedin formations) and District of Mackenzie (Lonely Bay, Nahanni, Headless and Hume formations). The overlying Givetian carbonate complex of northeastern British Columbia and southern District of Mackenzie (Presqu'ile Barrier) has only sparsely developed rugosans, but beds flanking the barrier (upper Dunedin, Pine Point, Sulphur Point formations) locally develop more diverse faunas of early-mid Givetian age. Downslope from the barrier complex, numerous early-mid Givetian pinnacle reefs (upper Keg River, Hom Plateau formations) bear particularly diverse and abundant rugose coral assemblages. In the lower Mackenzie River valley of northern District of Mackenzie a series of reefal complexes of mid-late Givetian age (Ramparts Formation) carries significant rugosan faunas, especially in platform and flanking beds.
title: Middle Devonian rugose coral faunas in northeastern British Columbia and District of Mackenzie, western Canada. -
paper: Boletín de la Real Sociedad Española de Historia Natural, Sección Geológica

name: Landry Creek, Mackenzie Mountains
remarks: stromatoporoid-dominated reef but only corals described
title: Middle Devonian rugose coral faunas in northeastern British Columbia and District of Mackenzie, western Canada. -
paper: Boletín de la Real Sociedad Española de Historia Natural, Sección Geológica

name: Horn Plateau, NWT
remarks: One of 13 drilled subsurface reefs from Horn Plateau. Dominated by large bulbous and tabulate stromatoporoids and scarce branching rugosans.
title: Middle Devonian coelenterates from the Nahanni Formation of H.B. Amerada Camsell A-37 well, District of Mackenzie. -

name: Gipsdalen, Pyefjellet, Spitzbergen
remarks: Phylloid algal buildups and banks. Some rugose corals.
title: Biostratigraphy and biofacies of Upper Carboniferous-Lower Permian rugose coral assemblages from the Isfjorden area, central Spitsbergen. -
paper: Boletín de la Real Sociedad Española de Historia Natural, Sección Geológica

name: Seewarte, Carnic Alps
remarks: Diverse brachiopods associated. Abstract ref. 1606. In the following 31 brachiopod genera and 56 species from the Heller Crinoidenschutt- und Riffkalk of the Seewarte Mt. are described. They belong to the superfamilies Pentameracea, Rhynchonellacea, Atrypacea, Retziacea, Athyridacea, Cyrtiacea, Spiriferacea, Crytinacea and Reticulariacea. Pugnax ? scupini is erected as a new species. Uncinulus sp., Parapugnax sp., Stenorhynchia aff. nympha, Atrypa (Planatrypa) n. sp., Carinatina n. sp., Rhynchatrypa aff. thetis and Striispirifer sp. are listed under open nomenclature because they require a future more complete investigation based on additional material. The brachiopod-fauna of the Carnic Alps is closely related to that of the Barandian area. This relation becomes most obvious when compared to the brachiopod community of the Pragian Koneprusy Limestones of Central Bohemia. Furthermore the connections to Lower Devonian brachiopod assemblages of the Ural, Altai and Salair (USSR) can be demonstrated. The faunas of the Armorican Massiv (Limestones of Erbray, Trench of La Lezais), Marokko (Limestones of the Tafilalt) and the Harz Mts. (Princeps-Limestone) are also comparable to that of the Carnic Alps.
title: Korallen aus dem Unterdevon der karnischen Alpen. -

name: Cerro La Silla, Jáchal, Argentina
remarks: Collection of Miller Shallow subtidal intrashelf. Reef-mounds with lithistid sponges, receptaculids (Calathium) and microbialite. Girvanella dominant 20-30 % (up to 70 %) of mound volume. 4 sponge species are common. 4 m thick complex of domal bioherms. Distinct flanking beds. Two facies types: Bio-lithoclastic wackestone/packstone Microbial boundstone. Borings present in cryptomicrobial structures (early lithification).
title: Early Ordovician microbial-sponge-receptaculid bioherms of the Precordillera, western Argentina. -

name: Cow Head, Newfoundland
remarks: Cow head Group. Beds 10 and 12. Redeposited reefal blocks in deep water limestone. Shelf margin boundstones, grainstones, packstones, wackestones. Boundstones dominated by microbes (Renalcis, Epiphyton, Girvanella) together with archeoscyphid sponges. Alga Halysis, some Pulchrilamina-like organisms, Wetheredella-like tubules also present.
title: Reconstruction of a lower/Middle Ordovician carbonate shelfmargin: Cow Head Group, western Newfoundland. -

name: Cow Head, Newfoundland
remarks: Cow Head Group. Bed 14 reefal clasts. Tube-work dominated clasts are also present.
title: Reconstruction of a lower/Middle Ordovician carbonate shelfmargin: Cow Head Group, western Newfoundland. -

name: Onoura, Amakusa-Shimo-shima
remarks: Oyster reef Abstract of ref. 1610: The Member U-III a of the Upper Himenoura Subgroup distributed in Kumamoto and Kagoshima Prefectures is composed mainly of cross-bedded sandstone, which yields two oyster beds. Autochthonous oyster reefs can be observed at two outcrops exposed at Onoura in Amakusa-Shimojima and Hirasezaki in Shimokoshikijima (Fig.1). These oysters are 'mudstickers' (Seilacher et al., 1985), and are assigned to one of the Crosssostrea species. They are divided into two distinct morphotypes, namely, a stocky form (Onoura type; about 30 cm in shell height) and a stick-like elongated form (Hirasezaki type; less than 100 cm in height). The Onoura type seems to adopt 'relay-strategy', and one clump usually consists of three or four generations. On the other hand, the Hirasezaki type resembles morphologically solitary mudstickers such as Konbostrea. However, this Hirasezaki type also make the clump composed of three or four generations. The Hirasezaki type may, therefore, adopt not only 'elongated-strategy' but also 'relay-strategy'. This is an intermediate mode of life between Crassotrea and Konbostrea. Sedimentological analysis suggests that the Cretaceous strata exposed at Onoura represent more nearshore facies than those at Hirasezaki. The Onoura type might be adapted to nearshore, lagoonal environments, while the Hirasezaki type might be an adaptive form to offshore bar in open marine environments. Cretaceous gigantic oyster beds are confined to three stages in Japan: middle Cenomanian, upper Turonian to lowest Santonian, and upper Campanian.
authors: Toshimitsu, S., Kano, M. & Tashiro, M.
title: Oyster reefs from the Upper Himenoura Subgroup Upper Cretaceous Kyushu Japan. -

name: Hirasezaki, Shimo-koshiki-shima
remarks: Open marine oyster (Crassostrea) reef. Large elongate oysters (almost 100 cm). See reef 2459 for more remarks.
authors: Toshimitsu, S., Kano, M. & Tashiro, M.
title: Oyster reefs from the Upper Himenoura Subgroup Upper Cretaceous Kyushu Japan. -

name: Bjärsjölagård, Scania
remarks: 1m thick, 7 m long stromatoporoid biostrome. Stromatoporoids in marly matrix. Three stromatoporoid species. Girvanella. Some favositid, syringoporid and solitary rugosan corals.
title: Stromatoporoids from the Upper Silurian of Scania, Sweden. -

name: N-Saarema
remarks: Jaagarahu stage. Width of reef belt 10 km. Vikingia tenuis and stromatolites as main builders. Additionally Favosites, Coenites and colonial rugosans

paper: Ecostratigraphy of the east Baltic Silurian. - Academy of Science of the Estonian SSR Institute of Geology

name: Deane Quarry + Alcoa Highway, Knoxville, Tennessee
remarks: Bryozoan biolithite rare stromatactis micrite. Total reef mass almost 100 m thick. Lithification by binding activity on encrusting bryozoans. Up to 6 m syndepositional relief. Batostoma dominant. Monotrypa and Mesotrypa subdominant. 18 genera in reef core, 18 in reef flank (4 missing, 4 additional). Flank beds important (75 % of reef mass), but containing mostly pelmatozoan debris and virtually no enrusters.
title: Major Middle Ordovician reef tract in east Tennessee. -

name: Los Navalucillos-Pena Hueca, Toledo
remarks: Abstract ref. 1614: We have studied the carbonates with Archaeocyatha in the outcrop of Los Navalucillos-Pena Hueca (Montes de Toledo occidentales), that belong to Los Navalucillos Limestone. These organic carbonates are, for the most part, of algae activity, and to a smaller extent to that of other organisms. Archaeocyatha and Trilobites. On the whole it is a trans-reef area with small mounds of algae and archaeocyatha, and levels with cups and organic debris accumulations. We described the species: Rotundocyathus salebrosus (Vologdin, 1931); Sibirecyathus disepimentalis Vologdin, 1940b; Afiacyathus alloiteaui Debrenne, 1964; Rasetticyathus iglesiensis DebrenneE, 1971; Inessocyathus spatiosus (Bornemann, 1887); Protopharetra polymorpha Bornemann, 1887; Pycnoidocyathus toledani Perejon, 1976, and Anthomorpha sisovae (Vologdin, 1940a); this association is characteristic of the Upper Ovetiense.
title: Archaeocyatha and sedimentological aspects of Pena Hueca Limestones, Los Navalucillos, Montes De Toledo, Spain. -

name: Lander Co., Nevada
remarks: Nevadella zone. One meter thick and 200 m long Spygoria biostromes (problematic organism, probably metazoan). Short lived experiment in metazoan reefs according to ref. 1616 Probably aragonite
title: An unusual new biostromal metazoan form the Lower Cambrian of central Nevada
paper: Geological Society of America Abstracts with Programs

name: Cheyne Point, Griffith Is., Nunavut
remarks: Abundant heliotids in mud mound flanking beds. Collection of Alroy with only 2 coral species indicated. Abstract of ref. 1617: Heliolitine corals occur in Upper Silurian strata of the topmost Douro, lower Barlow Inlet, and lower Somerset Island formations in the Boothia Uplift region. The fauna includes Heliolites (nine species), Propora (two species), the stelliporellid genera Ponollites (three species) and Stelliporella (one species), and the plasmoporid Squameolites (one species). Species present but not previously reported from the region include Heliolites arcuatus Bondarenko, Heliolites uksunayensis Mironova, Stelliporella ilensis Bondarenko, Podollites assitus new species, Podollites parryi new species, Podollites plectilis new species, Propora tubulata (Lonsdale) and an unidentified species of Propora. All species occur in reef and reef-associated facies of open carbonate shelf and ramp settings. In restricted nonreefal carbonate shelf settings, diversity attenuates to a minimum, exemplified by numerically abundant monospecific assemblages of Heliolites uksunayensis. Six of the 16 morphotaxonomic units recognized compare with species reported previously in Silurian faunas of Kazakhstan and Mongolia. Combinations of characters in the species attributed to Podollites support revision of the genus, possibly to include Derivatolites and Tarbagatailites, in a group morphologically intermediate between Stelliporella and Heliolites.
title: Heliolitine corals of the topmost Douro and overlying formations (Upper Silurian), Canadian Arctic islands. -

name: Trinidad
remarks: Sr age: 11.2-15 Ma 50 coral species recorded in total. Contrasting earlier statements diversity and fanal tunover rates high in the middle Miocene. Ref. 1902 recorded only 5 genera and 8 species of corals. Abstract of ref. 1862: Caribbean coral reefs were widespread, well developed, and highly diverse during the Late Oligocene. In contrast, the Early Miocene was marked by decline in both reef building and reef-coral diversity. Increasing planktonic productivity has been implicated in this regional collapse of the coral reef ecosystem. Reduction of extensive reef development makes it difficult to find early Neogene corals to sample, but the abundant and well preserved corals from the Tamana Fm. of Trinidad are one exception. The goal of this study was to more fully document this important fauna and better constrain the timing and effects of the Oligocene/Miocene biotic transition. Large new collections from the Tamana Fm. indicate that extinction was nearly complete and that recovery of coral species diversity was well under way by the beginning of the Middle Miocene. A total of 33 species were recovered from the Tamana Fm. Thirteen of these species are first occurrences (40 percent), but only four are last occurrences (12 percent). Three of the four last occurrences have only been recognized from the Tamana Fm., and may represent taxonomic uncertainty. The first occurrences include taxa destined to be major constituents of Miocene and Pliocene coral communities, including several species of Montastraea, Caulastraea portoricensis, Agaricia undata, and Siderastrea siderea. In spite of this increasing diversity, significant reef tract development did not return to the Caribbean until after a major episode of extinction during Plio/Pleistocene time. This second extinction decimated the diverse Late Pliocene fauna, and is associated with oceanographic changes caused by the emergence of the Isthmus of Panama and intensification of northern hemisphere glaciation. Therefore the Oligocene/Miocene transition was characterized by a decline in both reef building and reef-coral diversity but the Plio/Pleistocene transition was associated with decreasing diversity and increasing reef development. Both reef coral diversity and reef-tract development are strongly influenced by oceanographic conditions, but their responses are not in phase.
title: Miocene diversification of the Caribbean reef-coral fauna: new data from the Tamana Formation, Trinidad. -
paper: Geological Society of America Abstracts with Programs

name: Fourth Chute, Ottawa Valley, Ontario
remarks: Small (1 m long, 15 cm thick mounds) composed of strophomenid brachiopods and/or bryozoans. Anoxic conditions prevail in surrounding carbonate sediments.
title: Sedimentary mounds and washout depressions from the Middle Ordovician limestone, Ottawa Valley, Canada. -

name: Podeni, Cluj
remarks: Rhodalgal reefs with some corals.
title: Mid-Ordovician bryozoans reefs in western Newfoundland
paper: Geol. Soc. America Abstracts with Program

name: Maumee, Ohio
remarks: Lockport dolomite. Microbialite-coral reef. Only microbes and small Favosites. Favosites showing evidence of stress (stress bands, small size). High sedimentation rates indicated by growth form and in situ preservation. Nutrient-rich setting.
title: Corals as indicators of environmental stress: examples from a Silurian microbialite-coral reef
paper: Geological Society of America Abstracts with Programs

name: Lawrence Co., Alabama
remarks: Bangor Limestone Pennington group Fenestrate bryozoan buildup. Bryozoans together with rugose corals, stalked echinoderms, soft-bodied organisms encrusted by foraminifera. Biodetrital mound Mound resting on bored oolitic shoals. 25 m wide, 1.6 m thick, roughly circular.
title: A baffling Chesterian mud mound in north Alabama
paper: Geological Society of America Abstracts with Programs

name: Rambla Quebrada, Almeria
remarks: Coral banks on debris flow conglomerates. Banks of ahermatypic zooxanthellate Cladocora caespitosa. Oysters cemented on corals. Guild overlap (constuctor and baffler). Most reef builders in situ. Macroborings rare, no evidence for microborings. Abstract of ref. 1628: Cladocora caespitosa is a common zooxanthellate, ahermatypic, constructional scleractinian coral in shallow waters of the present-day Mediterranean. Extensive coral banks in Upper Pliocene shallow marine deposits of the Almería-Níjar Basin (SE Spain) contain the same species. These banks occur on debris-flow conglomerates deposited in a fan delta, or on bioclastic accumulations interpreted as storm deposits. Direct relationships of coral beds with coastal facies indicate that C. caespitosa colonized shallow settings near the paleocoast, probably not deeper than 20-30 m. Low turbulence allowed corals to colonize substrates, which remained stable for long periods. Activity of organisms in the coral community, storms, and detritic discharges from the fan delta were the most significant mechanisms disturbing the coral development. The hard substrata provided by coral banks promoted colonization by cemented and epibyssate organisms. Coral banks marked maximum flooding surfaces at the end of transgressive systems tracks. They were suddenly buried by sediment input into the basin. Taphonomic signatures measured on components of the coral bank communities indicate a low turbulence environment, probably a bay. The low hydraulic energy further inhibited post-burial reworking, thus promoting the in situ preservation of a great part of the organisms inhabiting the bioconstructions.
title: Fossil analogues of present-day Cladocora caespitosa coral banks: Sedimentary setting, dwelling community, and taphonomy (Late Pliocene, W Mediterranean). -

name: Indian Creek Field, Fentress Co., Tennessee
remarks: 18-30 m thick. 3 km long. Above storm wave base with periodic subaerial exposure.
title: Stratigraphy and petrology of petroleum-producing Waulsortian-type carbonate mounds in Fort Payne Formation (Lower Mississippian) of north-central Tennessee. -

name: Lawrence Co., Indiana
remarks: Echinoderms and fenestrate bryozoans as main constituents. Common only at basal lense core. 85 % micrite in central lense core. Lenses developed at or above fair-weather wave base on a relatively shallow carbonate platform.
title: Carbonate mud bodies in Middle Mississippian strata of southern Indiana and northern Kentucky: end members of a Middle Mississippian mud mound spectrum?

remarks: Micrite-rich bioherms with pseudo-algae and bryozoans, well below wave base,

name: Belaya River, Urals
remarks: Mid ramp position. m-scale patch reefs. Smaller biostromes. Reef debris slightly micritized. Boundstones with corals, bryozoans, pseudo-algae, Syringopora. Framestone with corals and bryozoans, framestone with Syringopora and pseudo-algae, bindstone and bafflestone with pseudo-algae and bryozoans. Biohermal bafflestones also present.
authors: Proust, J.N., Chuvashov, B.I., Vennin, E. & Boisseau,T.
title: Carbonate platform drowning in a foreland setting: the mid-Carboniferous platform in western Urals (Russia)

name: Penedés, Barcelona
remarks: 24 coral species in total (4 ahermatypic). Porites dominant. Other corals are Heliastrea, Tarbellastaea, Mussidae, Faviidae. Fringing reefs up to 50 m thick and 3-7 km long with well developed prograding reef slopes. Large reef with greatest diversity (12-16 species).
title: Le couple récif-mangrove à Sant Pau d'Ordal (Vallès-Pénédès, Espagne), témoin du maximum transgressif en Méditerranée nord occidentale (Burdigalian supérieur - Langhien inférieur). -

name: Deh Sorkh, Esfahan
remarks: Toucasiids, Eoradiolites, Caprotinids. Corals and rudists at the base (± in situ). Rudist debris at the top.

name: Mokrá, Moravia
remarks: Originally assigned to the Famennian, but dating from fissure fills. Reef is Frasnian (Joachimski, pers. comm. 2000). Ref. 1635: Vilémovice Limestone Upper part of Palmatolepis crepida zone. Reefoid limestone as continuation of Frasnian reef. Stromatoporoids and tabulate corals Stromatop. similar to Frasnian Some change in tabulates. Rugose corals with pronounced changes.
authors: Friákova, O., Galle, A., Hladil, J. & Kaldova, J.
title: A lower Famennian fauna from the top of the reefoid limestones at Mokrá (Moravia, Czechoslovakia). -
