name: Badila
remarks: Abstract ref. 1646: Analysis of the Badila exotic limestone blocks (Upper Jurassic) showed different microfacies: reefal, coral, algal, reef-slope, lagoonal pelagic, oolitic and basin. Bioclasts and intraclasts can be found reworked in the younger rocks (Miocene). The large limestone blocks are the only evidence in the Outer Carpathian Zone of a reefal barrier in the Upper Jurassic.
title: The limestones from Badila Romania: macropaleontological and micropaleontological study

name: Gor Uein Terguet, Tindouf Basin, Western Sahara
remarks: Two reef cycles: Lower Stromatactis mud mound with stromatoporoids on top seperated by Calceola marls from second/third reef cycle with: Top coral-stromatopora biostrome Stromatoporoid bindstone Tabulate (platy and stick) and rugose coral framestone Stromatoporoid bindstone Base From Copper: A spectacular Middle and late Givetian coral- stromatoporoid patch reef belt, paralleling the Precambrian basement some 50-100km to the south, is known to extend for c. 300km in the Tindouf basin of northern Saharawi Arab Democratic Republic (='Spanish Sahara': Hazzard,1961; Dumestre & Illing,1967), These tabular to mounded reefs were up to c. 2km across, and tens of meters thick, capped by a rich shallow water coral and stromatoporoid fauna, in the region from Uein Terguet to Gor Loutad. Stromatactis mudmounds with auloporids and thamnoporids, like those of the Kess-Kess of the Tafilalt, are also known at Uein Terguet, where they appear to initiate reef growth in the 'first cycle' (Dumestre & Illing, 1967).
title: Middle Devonian reefs in Spanish Sahara
editors: Oswald, D.H.
paper: International Symposium on the Devonian System

(?Caradoc-Ashgill) which are illustrated by Myagkova et al. (1977): such reefs appear to be endemic to this area.

Inozoans 10 % of framework. Peronidella, Intratubospongia, Radicanalospongia, Stellispongia, Corynella, Grossotubenella, Cavusonella. Two types of chaetetids. Palaeoaplysina (!) abundant. Archaeolithoporella Tubiphytes. Baffle- and Framestones.

Mounds nucleated on structural highs.

name: Putilovo quarry, St. Petersburg
remarks: Mud mounds, described from the Volkhovian (earliest Middle Ordovician), east of St Petersburg (Dronov and Federov 1994), are 4 to 5 m high, 30 to 50 m across, dome-shaped, and with a mud core and micritic crust facies; no reported calcimicrobes. A Trypanites-bored discontinuity surface separates the micritic crust from flanking pelmatozoan bioclastic limestones. Pelmatozoans are thought by Dronov and Federov to have grown on the atoll-like micritic rim, as baffles to the inner lagoonal mud core. Palaeomagnetic drift paths (Torsvik et al 1992) suggest the mud mounds grew in cooler temperate shallow seas.

name: Ullerntangen, Ringerike
remarks: Middle Hirnantian At Ullerntangen the bioclastic limestone sequence with its small mud mounds is overlain by a very much larger, lens-shaped buildup, at least 350 m in length, 100 m in width, and up to 12 m in thickness. It was originally interpreted as a reef by Kiaer (1897) but Hanken (1974) has argued that it lacks an organic framework, being largely composed of reworked material. Nevertheless a remarkably diverse biota is recorded from this structure, including the stromatoporoid Pachystylostroma, rugoans Palaeophyllum, Cyathophylloides, Tryplasma, tabulatans Saffordophyllum, Rhabdotetradium, Lyopora, Reuschia, Catenipora, Proheliolites and Plasmpora as well as exhibiting pockets with clusters of cystoids and trimerellid brachiopod specimens. The comparatively random directions of orientation of many of the coral and stromatoporoid specimens on the present exposed, slightly inclined, surface are not by themselves a certain basis for claiming that these organisms, or a substantial number of them, were not part of an in situ framework. Almost half the muddy matrix is composed of skeletal bioclasts - predominantly representatives of pelmatozoans, brachiopods, bryozoans, algae (Vermiporella, Hedstroemia) and the cyanobacterieum Girvanella. The upper surface of the mound is cut by deep fissures up to 6 m deep, that imply a period of significant erosion possibly under subaerial conditions, and then they were infilled by sandy pelmatozoan-dominated bioclastic limestone in a subsequent depositional phase. Finally a further sandstone unit overlaps the mound on its northern margin, and exhibits a very rich brachiopod, bryozoan and gastropod fauna near the mound. This unit represents the uppermost part of the unnamed formation, and appears to be bounded at its top by a significant unconformity (hiatus) to the overlying Silurian Saelabonn Formation.
title: Pers. comm.

name: Tiewadian, Xian, Shaanxi
remarks: Webby, 2002: A series of reef complexes, reefs, and biostromes have been reported through a carbonate succession 600 m thick at Tiewadian (Fig. 5) and equivalent sequences of adjoining areas, north of the Wei River, Shaanxi Province (Ye et al., 1995, Ye et al., 1996). They occur on topographic highs of the rifted, southwestern margin of the Ordos Platform (North China Block). At Tiewadian the sequence includes a composite, 150-m-thick reef complex composed of superposed biostromes and reef mounds, a 30-m-thick biostrome, and discrete, large to small, lens-shaped reefs, from 5 to 35 m thick. A wide range of frame-builders and binders are recorded, though seldom all groups in a single reef or biostrome. Stromatoporoid Forolinia (probably Labechia), and microbes Phacelophyton, Renalcis, Epiphyton, Trichophyton, and Girvanella, are the main contributors. Less important are algae Solenopora, Vermiporella, and the corals Lichenaria, Cryptolichenaria, Amsassia, and Eofletcheria. Some larger reefs exhibit a generalized framework succession: substrate stablization of bioclasts by microbial (stromatolitic) growth, in places associated with corals or succeeded by them, and then dominant Forolinia, and/or less common Phacelophyton, towards the top. Smaller reefs are mainly stromatolitic. Vermiporella, though recorded by Ye et al. (1996) as a major reef builder, may have had a more limited role in sediment production.

name: Voskhod and Rodnoye, Chornaya River Basin, Crimea
remarks: Lower part of boissieri zone of the Berriasian. Small bioherms (3-5 m thick, 4 m wide) of hermatypic corals and algae. Maximum 6 m thick. Intermound areas filled with bioclastic grainstones and packstones with fragments of corals and others. Framework of massive colonial (massive platy and pacheloid/ramose) corals and Lithocodium. Abstract ref. 1764: A section of Berriasian deposits from the River Belbek area (Southwestern Crimea) containing coral-algal bioherms is described. A detailed lithological and palaeontological description of one of these bioherms is given. Lithological features of Berriasian carbonate rocks are discussed, microfacies analysis of these rocks with there palaeontological remains are carried out. The history of the Berriasian development of the territory will be reconstructed.
title: Facies of the Cretaceous (Berriasian) deposits from the River Belbek Area (Southwestern Crimea). -

name: Ayton Farm, North Yorkshire, England
remarks: Solenopora-gastropod facies as pre- and inter-reef sediments. Reefs as a series of 2m thick isolated structures. Coral skeletal volume very high (90%). Highly micritized carbonate grains, and high bioerosion through bivalves. Effectively monospecific buildup dominated by Thamnasteria concinna. 30-40 cm sized colonies.
title: Facies and palaeoecology of Upper Jurassic (middle Oxfordian) coral reefs in England. -

name: Portopalo, Pachino, Sicily
remarks: Massive rudist lithosome with prominent domal shape (4 m high, 5 m wide). Highly dispersed cylindrical elevator rudists (Hippurites) in an micritic sandy matrix. Vocanoclastic setting. Abstract ref. 1770: Maastrichtian strata from the Pachino area (SE Sicily) provide a model of association between rudist-coral frameworks and submarine volcanic activity. Two successive carbonate units are distinguished: (a) Coral- rudist bioherms and biostromes developed in a high-energy environment. (b) Hippuritid build-ups and banks overlain by rudist-coral clusters which grew under harsher ecological conditions, in a weaker current regime. At the top of the Maastrichtian sequence, the growth of rudist-coral frameworks ceased as ecological conditions shifted toward restricted environments. The inferred succession reflects a gradual decrease in current strengths and water depths, related to the Maastrichtian regression phase. The frameworks display consistent evolutionary sequences reflecting progressive changes in their biota, structure, and size and shape. Occurrences of rudist-coral frameworks are clearly linked with submarine volcanoes which provided opportunities for their development; they sometimes grew in the vicinity of active-vent centers, a feature reported for the first time in the Upper Cretaceous.
authors: Camoin, G., Bernet-Rollande, M.C. & Philip, J.
title: Rudist-coral frameworks associated with submarine volcanism in the Maastrichtian of the Pachino area (Sicily). -

name: Mecsek Mountains II
remarks: At least 26 coral species. Additionally stromatoporoids and coralline algae. Abstract ref. 1786: Macro- and microfossils and microfacies of a few Lower Cretaceous sections in the Mecsek Mountains have been studied . Twenty five species of corals are reported for the time first from the Hungarian Cretaceous . Fossils derived from the carbonate platform are often found together with those of pelagic origin and monomictic volcanoclastics , indicating a special sedimentary environment . Based on this study the following model is proposed for the Early Cretaceous geological history of the Mecsek Mountains : instead of overall uplift and erosion giant basalt volcanoes grew above sea level until the Valanginian , whilst bathyal conditions were preserved between them . The volcanoes were bordered by gravel beaches , then sandy and silty lagoons , and the edge , of submarine slopes were crowned by atoll-type build-ups . Fossils and rocks of dif ferent environments were transported down the slopes of the volcanoes and mixed . As a result of widespread erosion during the Late Cretaceous or Palaeogene only the basal parts of a few volcanoes are preserved .
title: Vestiges of atoll-like formations in the Lower Cretaceous of the Mecsek Mountains , Hungary

name: Mecsek Mountains III
title: Vestiges of atoll-like formations in the Lower Cretaceous of the Mecsek Mountains , Hungary

name: Vanderbeek, Leon Co., Texas
remarks: Amoco well Outboard reef trend on distally steepened ramp. Two major types of reefs may occur both in an outboard an inboard position during latest Kimmeridgian and earliest Tithonian, resp. Vanderbeck is an outboard reef, Reef is coral dominated at base but rich in siliceous sponges and microbial crust at top. Data refer to cement-rich coral-sponge-microbial boundstones and skeletal pack-/grainstones. Best reservoir quality in shoal grainstone with reefal debris. Ideal sequence in area Top marine shlae marl shallow lagoon debris flow coral-calcareous sponge microbiolite reef reefal debris debris fan shallow outer ramp sponge-thrombolite reef upper deep marine ramp coral-calcareous algal reef with washover fan lagoon.
authors: Montgomery, S.L., Walker, T.H., Wahlman, G.P., Tobin, R.C. & Ziegler, D.
title: Upper Jurassic 'Reef' play, east Texas basin: an updated overview: part 1 - background and outboard trend

name: Mohawk Valley, New York
remarks: Abstract ref. 1800: Tribes Hill domal thrombolites, termed here microbial reef mounds, occupied the basal part of meter-scale shallowing-upward cycles. They are part of a high-energy facies that a sharp, transgressive surface separates from an underlying low-energy peritidal setting. This erosional surface served as the surface on which one of the reef mounds established itself during initial transgression before further deepening. The others overlie a floor of skeletal grainstone reflecting a high-stand sea-level facies tract. Skeletal grainstone composes the fill between the mounds. One channel and several aggrading hummocks occupy inter-reef mound areas resulting from storm events in a subtidal setting.
title: Early Ordovician microbial reef mounds of the Tribes Hill Formation, Mohawk Valley, New-York. -

name: N-Friuli Platform
remarks: Abstract of ref. 1801: This paper deals with the stratigraphy of well SPAN 1 (San Pietro al Natisone, Eastern Friuli). The stratigraphic sequence is composed by Paleocenic flysch deposits (from 69 m to 748 m), Maastrichtian resedimented carbonates (from 748 m to 940 m) and Late Jurassic reef deposits (from 940 m to 1397 m, total depth). The tectonic and sedimentary evolution of the Valle del Natisone, from the Oxfordian to the Early Eocene, is outlined (Taxa discussed include Foraminifera and corals).
authors: Sartorio, D., Tunis, G., Venturini, S.
title: New contributions to the geological and paleogeographic interpretation of the Julian Prealps eastern Friuli Italy the well SPAN 1. -

name: Mt. Medvednica
remarks: Abstract of ref. 1802: The biolithitic complex with a barrier reef in NE Mt. Medvednica shows the continuity of sedimentation of the Maestrichtian-Palaeocene. The lower part of the reef, which is built up mainly of rudistids, is of Maestrichtian age. The Palaeocene part of the reef is built up mainly of hermatypic corals and solenoporacean algae. The described biolithitic complex belongs to the sedimentation model characteristic for the subduction zone with an island arc system. The boundary Cretaceous-Tertiary is found everywhere in the Dinarides marked by a significant biostratigraphic discontinuity, and in terms of lithostratigraphy, by a continuity or discontinuity depending on geotectonical events. The facies migration occurred in transgressive succession in direction opposite to the subduction.
title: The boundary between the Cretaceous and Tertiary in terms of the stratigraphy and sedimentology of the biolithitic complex in Mount Medvednica northern Croatia Yugoslavia. -

name: Vapenkova skala, Rozbehy
remarks: Abstract of ref. 1803: The 1st paleontologically confirmed occurrence of Upper Cretaceous sediments in the Little Carpathians was described. A series of strata of carbonate-sandstones through fine grained conglomerates of the Campanian with large Foraminifera of the genera Orbitoides, Pseudosidlerites and Lepidorbitoides was exposed on the southern slope of Vapenkova skala near Rozbehy. Bodies of biohermal reef limestone with corals and Dasycladaceae, probably of the Maastrichtian, were found on the walls of the Campanian strata. The find represents an important connecting link between the Brezova development of the Upper Cretaceous and Senonian sediments found to exist on the floor of the Vienna basin in drillings in the area of Zavod and Studienka. O. tissoti, O. media, P. vidali and L. minima are discussed in detail.
title: The Upper Cretaceous with orbitoids in the Little Carpathians, Czechoslovakia. -

name: Mesaoria Plain
remarks: 40 m water depth inferred. Dominated by ramose Cladocora, but diverse molluscan fauna 38 species in total. Reef builders Cladocora, Ostrea and serpulids 9 m thick, 50 m wide. Base with Ostrea domination. Reef resting on calcareous silts, sandstones and conglomerates. Similar structure as Tortonian reefs. Abstract of Ref. 1821: Paleocological analysis of the reef community shows that, apart from corals, it was dominated by epifaunal molluscs. It represents one of the most diverse fossil communities found on Cyprus following the Messinian Salinity Crisis (MSC), with 38 identified species of macrofossils and 8 species of foraminifera. When compared to patch reefs on Cyprus formed just prior to the MSG, this Pliocene reef shows both the biological devastation of the event and the quick and complete recovery of the reefal biodiversity.
title: Paleoecology of a Pliocene coral reef in Cyprus: recovery of a marine community from the Messinian Salinity Crisis
paper: Neues Jahrbuch für Geologie und Paläontologie Abhandlungen

name: Lampazos, Sonora
remarks: Bisbee Group Thick massive biohermal limestones mentioned at base and top of Espinazo del Diablo Fm. 12 Coral species described. Age assignment corrected by ref. 2005, abstract: The stratigraphy and structure of the Lower Cretaceous (Aptian-Albian) rocks exposed in the area of Lampazos, Sonora, are redefined and correlated to well-known stratigraphic successions of Chihuahua and northeast Mexico (Coahuila and Nuevo Leon). Originally, seven stratigraphic units were proposed for the Cretaceous rocks exposed in the Lampazos area, but in this article only five units (El Aliso, Agua Salada, Lampazos, Espinazo del Diablo, and Los Picachos formations) have been used, and we propose herein to discontinue usage of the other two (Nogal and La Mesa formations). This Aptian-Albian succession of east-central Sonora yields facies and fossil content remarkably similar to coeval sequences in the Gulf of Mexico realm (Chihuahua, Coahuila, and Nuevo Leon). These sections contain abundant microfossils (benthic and planktonic foraminifera, colomiellids, nannoconids, and radiolarians) that permit detailed biostratigraphic determinations. A complete Aptian-lower Albian section (base of K-6 through top of K-15 of the biochronologic scheme of Longoria, 1984) was identified. Abrupt lithic changes through the Aptian-Albian section of Lampazos revealed three major paleoceanographic events having an overall regional marine transgression, including an early Aptian (K-6 to K-7) event, a late Aptian (K-10 to K-11) event, and an early Albian (K-13 to K-14) maximum flooding phase. We used physical and biochronologic data to tie the aforementioned events to geochemically constrained Aptian-Albian oceanic anoxic events (OAEs) in Santa Rosa Canyon of Nuevo Leon. The close correlation between the oceanic events in east Sonora (northwest Mexico) and central Nuevo Leon (northeast Mexico) invokes the closer paleogeographic development of the two regions (Begin page 1812) and undoubtedly links the area of Lampazos to a rapid encroachment of the paleo-Gulf of Mexico through north-central Mexico (the Mexican Sea) into northwestern Mexico (Chihuahua trough and Sonoran basin). The early Aptian (biozones K-6 to K-7) transgression has its maximum extension during the early Albian (biozones K-13 to K-14), culminating with the drowning of the carbonate platforms. The Lower Cretaceous rocks exposed in the Lampazos area are complexly folded and faulted. The more conspicuous structures are isoclinal and box-shaped folds and thrust faults, mostly oriented north-south and northwest-southeast, having vergences to both the northeast and southwest. A very conspicuous feature is the opposite vergence of thrust faults, either converging or diverging. Two dextral strike-slip faults (northeast-southwest and east-west) separate the area into three large blocks that have different patterns of folds and thrust faults. Also, it is evident that the area was affected by at least two episodes of normal faulting. Furthermore, the structural style of deformation present in the Lampazos succession is remarkably similar to the style of deformation of coeval rocks in northeastern Mexico, especially to the structure of the Chihuahua tectonic belt. The Lampazos succession is paleogeographically and tectonically related to the Chihuahua tectonic belt, and it is considered to be the westernmost extension of the ancestral Gulf of Mexico. The fact that the Lampazos succession can be lithocorrelated to known sequences in northeastern Chihuahua (Lucero, Ahumada, and Loma Plata formations) and northeast Mexico (Cupido, San Angel, La Pe±a, and Tamaulipas formations), which are know to be source rocks in exploration wells in Nuevo Leon and Coahuila, makes the Lampazos area of Sonora potentially attractive as an exploration target.
title: Lower Cretaceous corals and stratigraphy of the Bisbee Group (Cerro de Oro and Lampazos areas), Sonora, Mexico

remarks: 5-6 m thick patch reefs, lateral extension up to 30 m in shallowing upward sequence of first cycle. Porites-Faviidae assemblage. 10 m thick and 200 m long reefs in next cycle. Porites-Faviidae assemblage but Porites less abundant than in lower reef. Heavily encrusted by coralline algae. 80-90 % coral coverage. 20 species indicated (Genera: Acanthastrea, Acropora, Agathiphyllia, Antiguastrea, Astreopora, Astrocoenia, Caulastrea, Diploastrea, Favites, Goniopora, Hydnophora, Leptoria, Montastrea, Porites, Stylocoenia, Stylophora). name: Lacon, Alabama
remarks: Stromatolitic biostrome. See also reef 2710
title: Diverse carbonate mounds in the Bangor Limestone
paper: Geological Society of America Abstracts with Programs

name: Haletown, Tennessee
remarks: Microbial mound growing on grainstones and buried by grainstones. Abstract 1835: Carbonate mounds within the Chesterian (Mississippian) Bangor Limestone in north Alabama and east Tennessee are few in number, but diverse in character. Fourteen known mounds in this area can be assigned to five categories: 1) stromatolitic, 2) mud, 3) bryozoan-crinoid-coral, 4) bryozoan-crinoid, and 5) coral. Stromatolitic and mud mounds are microbial, bryozoan-crinoid-coral mounds are biodetrital, and coral mounds and some bryozoan-crinoid mounds are biohermal (reefal). Three lensoid stromatolites within crinkly-laminated dolomudstone comprise a single mound horizon about 0.5 m thick east of Monteagle, Tennessee. Near Haletown, Tennessee, the Bangor Limestone contains two mud mounds. The largest measures 8.2 m across and contains articulated bivalves and brachiopods, and intact fenestrate bryozoans. The mound's upper surface is bored. The mud matrix appears to contain tubular microfossils resembling Renalcis. A single bryozoan-crinoid-coral mound has been identified in Lawrence County, Alabama. It is approximately 25 m wide, up to 1.6 m thick, and had a maximum of 45 cm of synoptic relief. This mound is dominated by in situ colonies of the large rugosan Caninia sp. in a matrix of fenestrate bryozoan and echinoderm debris. A bryozoan-crinoid mound about 0.7 m thick and 1.5 m wide near Blount Springs, Alabama, contains a framework of fenestrate bryozoans and serpulids, spar-filled voids, and skeletal debris dominated by echinoderm ossicles. Bryozoan-crinoid mounds about 2 m thick have been reported from the Bangor-Pennington transition zone east of Monteagle. Five mounds up to 15 m wide and up to 1.5 m thick that are constructed entirely by Caninia sp. are known near Blount Springs and Lacon, Alabama. Bangor mounds are relatively rare and small, suggesting environmental stress. The mounds we examined are mostly underlain by packstone/grainstone, which suggests that the principal stressor might have been a mobile substrate coupled with periodic smothering. However, the Lawrence County mound is underlain by oolitic grainstone that had first been indurated during a period of early subaerial exposure. Early diagenesis or other stabilization mechanisms probably occurred at the other mound sites as well.
title: Diverse carbonate mounds in the Bangor Limestone
paper: Geological Society of America Abstracts with Programs

name: Peace Reach, Williston Lake, B.C.
remarks: Terebratulid-echinoderm biostromes. Abstract ref. 1836: Abstract: Mesozoic carbonate accumulations are rare in northwestern Pangea. This is due, initially to the demise of many carbonate secreting organisms during the terminal Permian biotic crisis and subsequently, to increased clastic sedimentation resulting from the tectonic development of western North America. Ecological voids resulting from the extinction however resulted in new opportunities for surviving taxa. Terebratulid brachiopod-echinoderm dominated biostromes within the primarily siliciclastic Liard Formation ( Middle Triassic, Ladinian) of northeastern British Columbia provide an example of this. The Liard biostromes are composed primarily of whole and unabraded terebratulid brachiopods, articulate crinoid elements and cidaroid echinoid spines and interambulacral plates. Many of the terebratulid brachiopods are characterized by the pedicle attachment trace fossil Podichnus. Other organisms which occupied the biostromes include acrotretid and spiriferid brachiopods, bivalves, and gastropods, as well as rare bryozoans, oysters and possibly scleractinian corals. Sedimentary units deposited on the margins of the biostromes are characterized by an abundance of body fossils (decapod crustaceans, bivalves and ophiuroids) and trace fossils (i.e. Asterosoma, Cylindrichnus, Palaeophycus, Rosselia, Teichichnus and Thalassinoides). This trace fossil assemblage contains a mix of horizontal and vertical deposit feeding organisms, consistent with deposition in a lower shoreface setting. Hiatal surfaces and laterally restricted bioclastic sandstone layers and lenses within these features suggests that frequent turnover of infaunal and epifaunal communities occurred at the edges of the Liard brachiopod-echinoderm biostromes. Environmental/ecological criteria essential for the development of the Liard biostromes include: a) initial storm-induced concentration of shell material to create islands or zones of comparably stable substrate, thus promoting colonization by crinoids, terebratulid brachiopods, and cidaroid echinoids; b) a temporary decrease in siliciclastic input to the shoreface, allowing biostrome building organisms the chance to colonize these patches of stable substrate, and dominate deposition within the lower shoreface, and c) aerobic conditions in the lower shoreface allowing for a healthy and robust biostrome fauna.
title: Paleoecological succession of Middle Triassic (Ladinian) brachiopod-echinoderm biostromes, Liard Formation, northeastern British Columbia, Canada
paper: Geological Society of America Abstracts with Programs

name: New York Route 67, Amsterdam, New York
remarks: Wolf Hollow Member Pillow- to dome shaped and biostromal thrombolites in intraclast-echinoderm pack- to grainstone matrix. Scour-and fill structures. Tribes Hill microbial reef mounds, occupied the basal part of meter-scale shallowing-upward cycles. They are part of a high-energy facies that a sharp, transgressive surface separates from an underlying low-energy peritidal setting. This erosional surface served as the surface on which one of the reef mounds established itself during initial transgression before further deepening. The others overlie a floor of skeletal grainstone reflecting a high-stand sea-level facies tract. Skeletal grainstone composes the fill between the mounds. One channel and several aggrading hummocks occupy inter-reef mound areas resulting from storm events in a subtidal setting. This study is part of a continuing program of Tribes Hill sedimentology.
authors: Landing, E., Westrop, S.R., Knox, L.A.
title: Conodonts, stratigraphy, and relative sea level changes of the Tribes Hill Formation (Lower Ordovician, east-central New York)

Coral hoizons also in Waynesville (below) and Whitewater (above) Fms.
title: The coral horizons and stratigraphy of the upper Richmond Group in Kentucky west of the Cincinnati Arch

name: Sortan-Manai, Betpak-Dala, Kazachstan
remarks: Microbial mudmound reef tract with dasyclad green algae. Island arc carbonate sequence. Mound core lense-like bodies of massive micritic limestone with numerous remains of dasyclad algae. No stromatactis. Flank beds with nodular algal limestone and some tabulate corals From Copper a late Caradoc, possibly also (?) Ashgill microbial mudmound reef tract from the Anderken Fm., with dasyclad green algae, is described (Nikitin, 1973; Nikitin et al., 1974; Nikitin et al, 1996). One reef is c.150m thick and about1500m across. Such reefs have physical similarities with those of the Boda Limestone of Sweden. The age of some of these mounds is not firmly established for some of the Caradoc mounds may be partly of Ashgill age. The Betpak-Dala locality is the central part of the arcuate Ordovician reef tract, with a southern extension for 600km to southern Kazakhstan, at the northern Tyan Shan range (Chon-Kemi River, N of Issuk-Kul Lake, near Alma-Ata). The other half reaches north to Stepnyak in northern Kazakhstan, W of the Irtysh River: total length of this island arc carbonate sequence is over 1500km (Zadoroshnaya & Nikitin, 1990)
title: Strophomerid and triplesiid brachiopods from an Upper Ordovician carbonate mound in central Kazakhstan

name: Montmorency river, Quebec City, Quebec
remarks: Tenton group Bryozoan bafflestone mound Up to 1.2 m high and 5.8 m wide No evidence for asymmetry or mechanical breakdown. 30 % bryozoan coverage No encrusters, no zonation. Matrix burrowed and bored, sometimes affecting bryozoans (evident from fig. 8d in ref. 1840)
title: A Late Ordovician high-energy temperate-water carbonate ramp, southern Quebec, Canada: implications for Late Ordovician oceanography

name: Amgar River, S Siberia
remarks: Epiphyton reefs. Coalescing small bioherms 0.5-1 m in diameter over at least 50 m extension.
title: Reef Evolution

name: Reed North Quarry, Fairborn, Green Co., Ohio
remarks: Stromatoporpoids more common on leeward side Ref. 1843: The Early Silurian is a critical time for understanding the evolution of corals and their role as reef-builders. By the middle Early Silurian, corals and stromatoporoids were the primary reef-building organisms. The Brassfield Formation (Llandoverian) in southwestern Ohio consists principally of nearshore bioclastic grainstones and packstones with occasional boundstones and minor shale intervals. Numerous coral-stromatoporoid patch reefs reported from the Brassfield are among the oldest known in the United States. Unlike other Silurian reefs in the U.S., Brassfield reefs are undolomitized and well-preserved. These conditions allow observation of fine-scale morphological details and permit a detailed taxonomic and paleoecologic comparison with other Silurian reef communities. Fossil material (in situ and from float) was collected from a Brassfield patch reef exposed in the Reed North Quarry, Fairborn, Greene County, Ohio. Approximately 350 fossil specimens were identified during preliminary mapping of at least 72 square meters of the patch reef. In order of abundance, the reef-building organisms include favositids (176 colonies), stromatoporoids (109 specimens), colonial rugosans (37 specimens), halysitids (16 colonies), and solitary rugosans (9 specimens). A few specimens have encrusting crinoid or bryozoan holdfasts. Initial observations indicate that this Brassfield patch reef is consistent with the model of a typical Early Silurian reef.
authors: Schneider, K. A., Ausich, W. I.
title: Paleoecology and taxonomy of frame-building organisms in the Brassfield formation, (Llandoverian, Lower Silurian), Fairborn, Ohio
paper: Geological Society of America Abstracts with Program

name: Guerrero
remarks: Ref. 1844: The Upper Permian in South Mexico includes the Olinala Formation in the state of Guerrero. This formation is the youngest Paleozoic sedimentary cover of the Mixteco Terrane. This formation contains the youngest Permian beds reported in Mexico (Woardian, Capitanian). The lower and middle part, containg fosilss of goniatits, of Woardian age, consists of silisiclastic rocks, while the upper part is a carbonate sequence of Late Guadalupean age. The carbonate sequence overlies the siliciclastic sequence by erosional contact. This carbonate sequence is a ramp deposit, the inner shallow ramp deposits are mainly composed of echinoderm debris grainstone-packstones, in which are found, crinoids, pelecypods, gastropods, as well as microfossils such as Parachaetes sp, seaweed (Tubhyfites sp; Tubhyfites obscurus Maslov 1956), boundstones type LLH(C), and organic bank crinoids boundstones and shoal bioclastic grainstones. The middle ramp is characterized by interbeded finegrained limestones and sandstones. The limestones are bioclastic packstone-wackestones with echinoid fragments (crinoids mainly), bryozoa, pelecypod shells of, brachiopod spines, small Foraminifera (Abadehella ex gr.coniformis) and fusulinids (Codonofusiela extensa Skinner& Wilde, 1955; Rauserella errática, Dumbar 1944, Condofusiella extensa Skinner & Wilde 1955) of Woardian-Capitanian age. The sanstones are litarenites and sub litarenites. The deep ramp deposits consist of carbonate mud mount of cyanobacterium (Tubiphytes, Aelisaccus), calcareous sponges, Prorichtofenids, and bryozoa, that trap the calcareous mudstone, forming typical stromatactitis.
authors: Flores de Dios, A., Vachard, D., Buitron, B.
title: The Late Permian lime mound mount in Olinala-Guerrero state Mexico
paper: Geological Society of America Abstracts with Program

name: Krzeszowice, Krakow
remarks: 'Reef' series above brachiopod limestones. Stromatoporoid beds (partly dolomitic) with prevailing Atelodictyon cracoviensis. Tn 1a

remarks: Silicified worm tubes of new species: Serpula helicalis form 0.5 m thick bioherm. Densely packed helical worm tubes. Bioherm overlain by dolomitic algal laminites.
title: Devonian serpulid bioherms in Arizona

name: Nagornij-Karabach, Azerbaidzhan

name: Doberlug, Brandenburg
remarks: Epiphyton predominates. Domal in lower parts, columnar in upper part. Some Renalcis, Botomaella and Kordephyton. Irregular archaecyaths also important. Shallow subtidal ramp Dimensions not given but probably nearly 20 m thick. Abstract of ref. 1849: The palaeoecology of calcimicrobial communities from the only Gondwana-related Lower Cambrian in Central Europe (eastern Germany, carbonates and siliciclastics) has been studied. Six morphological groups of calcimicrobes are described. Some of them show a significant ability for sediment stabilization and construction of biohermal reef mounds. Other types of calcimicrobes were more common in biostromal thickets. Some of them were capable of populating different environments, growing in different modes and on different substrates. An Epiphyton-archaeocyathan reef mound is described, illustrating the importance of calcimicrobes for mound formation. The fossil communities together with a complex of sedimentary features allow a reconstruction of the depositional history of the environment. Based on comparison with similar Gondwanan Lower Cambrian successions (Sardinia/Italy, Spain) and facies development a model is proposed describing the sedimentary history. Three depositional stages are distinguished: (1) deep subtidal ramp, (2) shallow subtidal ramp, (3) shallow subtidal to intertidal mixed siliciclastic-carbonate ramp with migrating oolitic shoals. In spite of similarities with the deposits in southern Europe, some distinct differences exist with respect to the succession of facies, the completeness of the sections, the fossil spectrum, and the nature of the siliciclastic sediments. For the German Lower Cambrian, a facies development from a low energy deep environment to a high energy shallow environment (partly restricted and with some evaporites) can be reconstructed. As compared with Sardinia and Spain, the depositional environment of the eastern German Lower Cambrian successions was predominantly characterized by low-energy conditions.
title: Palaeoecological significance of calcimicrobial communities during ramp evolution: an example from the Lower Cambrian of Germany

name: Last Chance Range, California
remarks: Marjumid Biomere Platform margin slope with Girvanella and Epiphyton boundstone clasts (up to 6 m) stemming from thrombolite mounds on platform edge. Micritized grains. 'Algal' boundstones also figured from platform interior but not described.
title: Contrasting sequence boundary zones developed within cyclic carbonates of the Bonanza King Formation, Middle to Late Cambrian, southern Great Basin

name: Monte Sant'Angelo, Gargano
remarks: Matese group. Bioherms with radiolitids, hippuritids and corals Redeposited in slope deposits. Ref. 1859: 'Organogenic structures are present in which rudists are unbroken and partially preserved in growth position. In these structures, mollusc rudstone-bafflestones and mollusc floatstones are arranged in a complex way to form lens-shaped bodies.'
authors: Carannante, G., Graziano, R., Ruberti, D., Simone, L.

name: Grand Cayman, Cayman Islands
remarks: Heavily bioeroded by Entobia, Trypanites, Gastrochaenolites, Maeandropolydora, Talpina and Caulostrpsis. Algae significantly less affected than corals and bivalves. Also difference among corals: Stylophora most extensively affected. 38 % average boring in corals
title: Boring of various faunal elements in the Oligocene-Miocene Bluff formation of Grand Cayman, British West Indies

name: Eastern Ellesmere Island
remarks: Coral-microbial shelf margin reef tract 500 m thickness exposed (base covered by glacier). New genus of branching rugose corals prevails (up to 1 m in diameter). Additionally cf. Halysites (up to 50 cm in diameter) Corals encrusted by microbialites and lesser radiacial calcite. Up to 50 % marine cement locally. Microbialites: clotted or vaguelly laminated micrites, 3-5% calcimicrobes (Renalcis, Epiphyton', cf. Gammia). Stromatoporoids, brachiopods, megalodont bivalves and lithistid sponges are accessorial. Abstract or ref. 1861: A recently discovered Silurian reef tract in the high Canadian Arctic has an exposed length of more than 150 km and is locally more than 500 m thick. The reefs occur within a Silurian ramp and rimmed shelf-margin sequence about 2 km thick. Conodont biostratigraphic data indicate that the reefal strata are late Llandovery to Ludlow in age, and reefs are composed largely of coral-microbial boundstone, The corals are mainly digitate rugosans and large halysitids, associated with fewer stromatoporoids and lithistid sponges. However, most of the reefal strata consist of microbialite, which encrusts skeletal metazoans or is massive or thromboidal. Microbialite microstructure consists mainly of clotted micrite or laminated micrite associated with common Renalcis, other calcimicrobes, and locally abundant early marine cements. Other reef rock types include stromatactis-rich lime mudstone, cementstone, zebroid stromatactis-bearing lime mud-stone, crinoidal grainstone, and, rarely, stromatoporoid boundstone. The reefs formed on the shelf margin and prograded basinward in three distinct phases during Wenlock and Ludlow time. Underlying Llandovery, shelf-margin facies are highly dolomitized and may represent an original stromatoporoid boundstone. Overlying late Ludlow to Pridoli carbonates were deposited on a prograding carbonate ramp, dotted with small coral-stromatoporoid and other biostromes, Three periods of Silurian reef growth can be recognized in the Arctic: Llandovery, latest Llandovery-late Ludlow, and late Ludlow-Pridoli. The Llandovery phase was widespread, and large stromatoporoid-coral reefs occupied a variety of depositional settings, including shelf-edge, intrashelf, drowned shelf, and slope. Late Llandovery to late Ludlow reefs were also regionally extensive, but were predominantly coral-microbial boundstone and locally grainstone-rich structures containing accessory metazoan (stromatoporoid-coral) framestone and boundstone. These formed high-relief structures with coarse allochthonous debris aprons. Large stromatoporoid-coral reefs were also present, but these were confined to areas characterized by high rates of siliciclastic sedimentation or to intrashelf areas. Another regional change in reef composition occurred in the latest Ludlow. Initially, reefs were rare and dominated by lithistid sponges and microbialites, but in Pridoli time, they became widespread and were constructed by corals and stromatoporoids, as were their Llandovery ancestors. In addition, the Pridoli reefs did not attain the large sizes of reefs in the two older sequences. The three phases of reef development can be related to important, basinwide sequence boundaries. Microbialite-rich reefs have also been described from northwestern Russia, Alaska, and eastern Canada and are some of the largest reef structures known. Their large size reveals a need to reconsider popular reef evolutionary models, in which skeletal metazoans are regarded as the predominant constructors. Large reef size is implied in these evolutionary models, but, based on this and other reef studies, microbialite-rich reefs equal, and commonly surpass, the dimensions exhibited by coral-stromatoporoid reefs. Considering the microbialite-rich reefs, now known from both the Ordovician acid Silurian, it is clear that benthic microbial communities played a very important role in reef construction through the lower Paleozoic.
title: A new, major Silurian reef tract and overview of regional Silurian reef development, Canadian Arctic and north Greenland

name: Dongzhuang, Liquan, Shaanxi
remarks: Late Caradoc early Ashgill algal reef mounds. 11 identified reef building genera Also Webby, pers. comm.: The 80-m thick reef-bearing interval at Dongzhuang comprises six superposed reefs, the lower, a large, 30 m-high, wedge-shaped shelf-edge reef, bounded top and bottom by massively bedded, calcarenitic, bank-type deposits, and dominated by 'algal' constituents (Solenopora, Palaeoporella, Ajakmalajsoria), and cyanophytes (Hedstroemia, Girvanella) that contributed mainly a bafflestone facies. Basin-facing, outer flanks of this reef show wedge-shaped talus, up to 30 m thick, with clasts up to 80 mm across. The rest of the reefal series comprises back-stepping, partially stacked, patch reefs, dominantly of coral, stromatoporoid and stromatolitic contributors. They have an overall thickness of 40 m and a width of more than 100 m. Corals include rugosan Favistina, and tabulates Paleofavosites, Syringoporella and Halysites. The stromatoporoids are Ecclimadictyon and Clathrodictyon, characteristically sheet-like to more massive. The flanking bioclastic limestones include clasts with pelmatozoan debris, brachiopod fragments, gastropods, bryozoans and 'algae'. All these reefs, except the first which is small (2 m high) and stromatolitic, include corals and stromatoporoids, and they are 3 to 4 m high, with flanking (and enveloping) rudstones. The series appears to represent a shelf-edge complex with back-stepping, asymmetrical form, between a thick rudstone blanket on-shelf, and a narrow rudstone halo to the deeper transgressing shales of slope and basin.

name: Tuosuo Lake - Huashixia, Kunlun Mts., Qinghai
remarks: Stratigraphy according to ref. 2220 Reef growth starting in Longlinian with Tubiphytes-Archaeolithoporella frame and crinoid bryozoan baffle frame. Abstract of ref. 1915: The early Permian reef belt is distributed in the southern side of eastern Kunlun, north area of Qinghai-Tiber Plateau. The core-reef facies of the reef extends from Tuosuo Lake to Huashixia. Lots of reef breccia was found at the southern slope of the core-reef belt, and to the north of the reef belt there is back-reef limestone. Calcisponges, hydrozoa, bryozoa, Tabulozoa, Tubiphytes and red algae are the main frame-building organisms. Archaeolithoporella, laminated blue-green algaes, Tabulozoa and Tubiphytes played a role of binding or encrustating. There are many kinds of epibiont in the reef, including brachiopod, gasteropod, foraminifera, echinoderm and simple coral. The type and the characteristics of the reef- building organisms in eastern Kunlun and Animaqing are basically the same as those in the south of China.
authors: Wang, Y. B., Zhang, K. X., Gong, Y. M., Zhang, Z., Luo, M. S.
title: The discovery of Early Permian reef belt in east Kunlun and its significance

name: NMA-1 well, Male
remarks: Abstract of ref. 1928: As documented by industrial seismic reflection profiles and well data, the Cenozoic stratigraphic evolution of the Maldive carbonate system shows three distinct intervals characterised by their own specific depositional signatures. Late Palaeocene volcanics generated by the Reunion hotspot filled deeper pull-apart structures and created a flat topography that promoted the onset of the Maldive carbonate system in the early Eocene. Some of the initial structural depressions remained as deep internal seaways surrounded by reefal margins until the late Oligocene. The Eocene-Early Oligocene stratigraphic signature is essentially aggradational and corresponds to a transgressive cycle associated with a second-order sea-level rise. In the mid-Oligocene, a major sea-level fall exposed the neritic carbonate system and restricted sedimentation to the former deep internal basins. During the next transgression, a neritic carbonate system re-established itself on the newly flooded platform and was finally drowned near the Oligocene- Miocene boundary. The main effect of this second-order transgressive cycle was the transformation of the central troughs into one single deep basin in the Neogene, the palaeo- Maldive Inner Sea. When a reef framework was established in the early Miocene near the present location of the platform edge, systematic bank margin progradation toward the central Inner Sea basin became enhanced. This Neogene progradational phase is explained as the response to a long-term sealevel fall associated with a second- order regressive cycle. Finally, the late Pliocene-Pleistocene depositional signature is mainly aggradational and corresponds to the regional modification from flat-topped carbonate banks to atoll physiographies. The 'antecedent karst theory' suggests that increased karstification was triggered by high-frequency eustatic and climatic changes in the last 3.0 Ma.
title: Seismic stratigraphy and depositional signatures of the Maldive carbonate system (Indian Ocean)

name: Bandung, Java
remarks: Abstract ref. 1943: Outcrops of the Rajamandala Formation limestone near Bandung offer an excellent opportunity to study the facies -relationships of an Early Tertiary reef, which may serve as a model for Tertiary reef exploration in Indonesia. The limestones are exposed along quarries and natural Outcrops along the road from Bandung to Jakarta. These limestones with thicknesses of approximately 600 meters are dipping 40 to 60 degrees toward the south and are involved in asymmetric folding and thrusting towards the north. Along its ENE-WSW trending strike the limestone exhibits a graded granular limestone facies representing turbidites at the toe of the basin-slope facies, a foraminiferal algal facies with rudstone facies representing a fore-reef facies, a coral-algal baffiestone to boundstone facies (locally quarried and slabbe as commercial marble), representing, reef ramparts, and a possible milliolid limestone facies with isolated patch reefs, representing the lagoonal back reef facies. CORAL DEBRIS RUDSTONE FACIES: This facies consists of angular fragments of corals and other limestones, mostly dark grey, embedded in a limemud matrix, which is generally lighter in color. Fragments, poorly sorted, vary in size up to 30 cm. Matrix contains considerable amounts of large foraminifera mainly Lepidocyclina. This facies represents talus-slope debris of coral fragments from the main reef CORAL BOUNDSTONE FACIES: In general this consists of corals in growth position in which the spaces among the coral framework are filled up with muds containing coral debris, large foraminifera, etc. often bound with encrusting red algae. The rocks are light colored and are usually dense, massive, nonbedded to poorly bedded, with no primary porosity. The following sub-facies can be recognized based on the type of corals: Massive Head Corals Boundstone: This facies consists mainly of colonies of massive head corals, such as brain-corals, Meandrina etc. with encrusting red algae. A pack-stone facies, rich in foraminifera, is common in between the coral colonies. Worm tubes are very common in this facies, as well as large shells of gastropods and lamelli-branchia. These rocks are very massive, dense and usually white in color. The carbonates are very pure, containing over 95% calcium carbonate. Recrystallization is fairly. This rock is polished into commercial marble, common. This facies presumably represents the reef crest or reef flat. Platy Coral Boundstone: This facies consists of platy corals, which are aligned parallel to bedding. Within the framework of these boundstone are pockets of foraminiferal packstone to wackestone. These rocks are mostly massive and poorly bedded, but occasionally show wavy bedding. This facies presumably represents the deeper environment of the reef front. Branching Coral Bafflestone: This facies consists primarily of branching corals, mostly in growth position, some as broken fragments ' , embedded in a limemud matrix. Typical corals are Porites, Acropora, -RhabdophyIlia etc. (Gerth, 1933). Branching coral facies presumably represent sub-wayebase environments of the reef front. These three sub-facies are usually intermixed together and cannot be differentiated, but often the platy coral boundstone and especially branching corals bafflestone form' definite facies development, such as G. Pawon and G. Manik. REEF DEPOSITIONAL ENVIRONMENTS Measured sections at several localities and their lateral correlations indicates that depositional environments of the reef related sediments can be identified, based on the lateral facies developments, as well as each individual facies. The following depositional environments can be recognized:

Biodetrital grainstone mounds Mound growth from texanus-zone to bilineatus-zone (Asbian-Brigantian)
title: Die unterkarbonischen Mud Mounds des östlichen Anti-Atlas (Marokko)

remarks: Paucispecific crustose microsolenid biostromes with a remarkable amount of encrusting algae and adherent foraminifera (about 10 m in extension) colonized the outer platform margin . In places they are replaced by microsolenid-dominated patch reefs of biohermal character (up to 7 m in diameter) built by crustose and ramose coral morphotypes. The coral bioherms are overlain by requieniid rudist beds in micritic matrix. Upper reef of ref. 2412 and 2554

name: Snäckgärdsbaden-Ireviken, Gotland
remarks: Position refers to Ireviken Large composite reef. Layered stromatopores dominate (Coenostroma, Clathrodictyon, Labechia). Others are mostly tabulate corals. Visby-Series. Ref. 1893: 25 % of matrix is sparite 20 % micrite 45 % skeletal sand and debris. Calcimicrobes common Abstract of ref. 1971: Patch reefs up to 35 m thick and generally 100-150 m wide, separated by bedded inter-reef sediment, dominate the Högklint Formation (Lower Wenlock) of north-west Gotland. The spacing between adjacent patch reefs is variable, but is commonly 150-350 m. The Högklint is a shallowing sequence, and the patch reefs exhibit a well-developed vertical succession: (1) Axelsro-type patch reefs developed in the underlying Visby Formation; (2) halysitid tabulates capped by laminar stromatoporoids; (3) domical and bulbous stromatoporoids and red algae; (4) cyanobacterial-algal reef crest. The patch reefs expand upwards from an initial bioherm phase with a small base to a laterally extensive biostrome phase. This gives them a thumb-tack appearance. In stage 2 of the bioherm phase, rigid framework development and high reef relief resulted in breakage of angular blocks up to 15 m long, which were incorporated into the reefs or fell into adjacent sediments. Poorly sorted talus haloes (Millingsklint Member) also developed adjacent to stage 2 of the bioherm phase. These include angular blocks and exhibit depositional slopes up to 40° away from the reefs. Stage 3 biostrome development was mainly non-rigid cluster reef, which shed skeletal debris (Domkyrka Member) but few lithified blocks. Stage 4 biostrome development was a reef crest with open to closed frame structure. Storm breakage and overturning produced large blocks with complex cavity fill sequences including double geopetals. Relief during the bioherm phase, indicated by fallen blocks and talus slopes, was up to at least 15 m; during the biostrome phase, it was up to 10 m.
title: Growth of rigid high-relief patch reefs, Mid-Silurian, Gotland, Sweden

name: Cap Guir, Agadir, Maghreb
remarks: reef mostly built by stromatoporoids (30%), corals (20%) (Stylina tubilifera, Thecosmilia) and chaetetids, rare mollusks and bryozoans. Abundant internal reef debris (50%). Microbialites especially abundant in colonisation stage approaching 40%. Stromatolites associated with abundant microencrusters: Tubiphytes, Bacinella and Lithocodium. Very pronounced succession with stabilisation, colonisation, diversification and domination indicated.
authors: Ourribane, M., Chellai, E. H., Zaghbib-Turki, D.
title: Microbialites and micro-encrusters role in the reefs lithification: examples of the Maghrebian Atlas reefs during the Upper Jurassic
paper: Comptes Rendus de l Academie des Sciences Serie II Fascicule A-Sciences de la Terre et des Planetes

name: Cap Guir, Agadir, Maghreb
remarks: Peninsula north of Agadir Coral reef with 70% massive and rare branching corals. Other reef builders are stromatoporoids, bryozoans, mollusks and microbialites (laminated stromatolites and peloidal thrombolites) and microencrusters (Bacinella, Tubiphytes, Lithocodium, encrusting forams), rare solenoporeaceans. Microbialites approaching 25% or reef volume.
authors: Ourribane, M., Chellai, E. H., Zaghbib-Turki, D.
title: Microbialites and micro-encrusters role in the reefs lithification: examples of the Maghrebian Atlas reefs during the Upper Jurassic

name: Daluokeng, Gaofeng, Cili Co., Hunan
remarks: lower Daluokeng Fm.: Greyish white massive sponge-algal-microbial framestone, intercalated lenticular beds of wackestones, shell beds containing corals, sponges, forams, calcareous algae and the brachiopods Uncinunellina multicostioidea, Spirigerell ovalioides, S. shuizhtangensis, Ladoliplica zigzagiformis, L. platformia. Brachiopds much rarer in underlying coral limestones of the Xiamidong Fm. Reef overlain by thick-bedded wackestones with intraclasts (Member 2) and oolitic limestone (Member 3). Abstract ref. 2128: Bafflestones, framestones as well as bindstones are described. According to the function of reef-building, the organisms are classified to frame-builder, bind organisms and clastic-builder, in which main frame-builders are Sphictozoa, Inozoa, Tabulozoa and Hydrozoan, the bind organisms are Archaeolithiporella, Tubiphytes, Tabulozoa and blue-green algae. Four developing stages of the reefs have been distinguished.
title: Reef-dwelling brachiopods from the Late Permian of the central Yangtze river area, China
editors: Copper, P., Jin, J.

name: Blue Pool Bay, Wales
remarks: Abstract of ref. 1976: Buildups with a rigid coral framework are generally rare in Lower Carboniferous time. An exception was found in the Hunts Bay Oolite-Formation at Blue Pool Bay (Gower Peninsula). This bioherm is intercalated in well-bedded oolitic limestones. It is about 25 meters in width and rises up to 10 meters in thickness. The coral association indicates an Asbian age of the bioherm. The core of the structure consists of large massive colonies of Lithostrotion and a small number of dendroid colonies (Siphonodendron and Syringopora). Most of the corals are preserved in living position. The density of the colonies is high, in many cases they grow upon eachother. Dendroid corals become more common in the outer core. An increase of colonies, which are upside-down orientated, together with broken colonies and coarse debris describe the facies of the flanks. The general decrease of the amount of corals and the gradual increase of fragments of colonies in bioclastic rudstones to wackestones at the top of the structure characterize the end of the biohermal development. Due to the appearance of a coral framework and its thickness, the bioherm is wave resistant. It is described as the first ecological coral-reef of the Lower Carboniferous of South Wales.
title: Coral-rich bioconstructions in the Viséan (Late Mississippian) of southern Wales (Gower Peninsula, UK)

name: Jinan, Shandong
remarks: Thrombolite microframes Abstract ref. 1979: Mid Cambrian reefs with microframe structure built by calcified microbes, probably cyanobacteria, are well-exposed in the Zhangxia Formation near Jinan in Shandong Province. Members of the Epiphyton, Renalcis and Girvanella groups are almost solely responsible for a series of extensive biostromes, individually up to 15 m thick, in which metazoans are scarce. These reefs are surrounded by coarse cross-bedded oolite-pisolite, reflecting rapid growth in a high-energy environment. The two main reef lithotypes present are: (1) matrix-rich Tarthinia-Tubomorphophyton thrombolite-dendrolite microclusters, and (2) Gordonophyton-Razumovskia thrombolite microframes. The latter were created by rectilinear arrangement of prostrate and vertical microbial filaments, and the small (millimetric) size of the cavities contributed to framework strength. Similar, but usually less well-preserved, mid-late Cambrian reefs appear to be widespread in Asia and North America. These North China examples establish microbial microframes as a distinctive reef-structure, and show that frame-building continued during the Cambrian despite archaeocyath demise.
authors: Robert Riding, Huiming Bao, Xinan Mu
title: Microframe reefs built by calcified microbes, middle Cambrian, Jinan, North China

All reef periods associated with transgression.
title: Structure and oil-gas potential of zones of upper Frasnian barrier reefs of Tebuk-Visov area of Timan-Pechora province

name: Inangahua Outlier, Reefton
remarks: Buller Terrane. Horizons of bio-rudite in places exceptionally rich in largely transported coral and stromatoporoid colonies. Near coastal environment. Abstract of ref. 2236: Study of 35 systematically collected and 10 semi-random samples (about 100 cm(2) each) from one outcrop of the Lankey Limestone (Emsian) near Reefton, New Zealand indicates that it is a reef framestone built by tabulate (4? spp.) and clonal rugose (one sp.) corals, two species of stromatoporoids, a few bryozoans (2? spp.) and crinoids. The guild structure of the reef community and data on skeleton orientation and growth direction further indicate that there was relatively minor biostratonomic alteration of the original community. Skeletons are either in growth position or tipped, toppled or even overturned, but they have remained in situ. Other clone-rich Lankey Limestone outcrops in the Reefton area support the notion of an upper shelf reef system and stratigraphic and sedimentologic data suggest that it was located near the Gondwana margin at a paleolatitude of about 35 degreesS.
title: New studies on the Devonian of New Zealand
editors: McMillan, N.J., Embry, A.F., Embry, A.F.

name: Manchester Plateau, central Jamaica
remarks: About 20 genera and >30 coral species 5-8 M thick. Age was Lower Miocene. Revised to latest Oligocene in ref. 2574 Abstract of ref. 1993: During the middle Tertiary, the island of Jamaica was part of a large system of shallow carbonate platforms extending northeast along the Nicaraguan Rise. Although these platforms undoubtedly supported a rich fauna of marine benthos, the coral communities of this region are poorly known. New exposures in Jamaica, however, provide a clearer picture of the development of these Tertiary reefs, especially those spanning the Oligocene/Miocene transition, a time of significant taxonomic turnover in Caribbean corals. Recent bauxite mining on the Manchester Plateau of central Jamaica exposed well-developed (5 - 8 m thick) patch reefs in the Lower Miocene of the Newport Formation. Sections through these coral build-ups have been logged and extensively sampled. This material was compared with new data from similarly exposed reefs in the Upper Oligocene Brown's Town Formation of north central Jamaica. Cluster analysis and ordination of coral occurrences has revealed similarities as well as distinct differences between Oligocene and Miocene assemblages. Both units contain coral assemblages dominated by massive, branching, or plate-shaped colonies. Coral diversity is also roughly the same in each formation (approximately 20 genera and >30 species). There is some turnover of species between the late Oligocene and early Miocene, but perhaps the most significant difference between the sampled assemblages is a change in the relative abundance of certain key taxa. Antiguastrea cellulosa, for instance, is the dominant massive coral in the Upper Oligocene assemblages but is much less common in Lower Miocene faunas. Ecologically and sedimentologically, there appears to be little difference between the coral build-ups in the Brown's Town and Newport Formations. This suggests that, in contrast to some other regions in the Caribbean, patch reef communities in Jamaica thrived throughout the Oligocene/Miocene transition. Changes in dominant coral taxa, however, could suggest a complex shift in community structure during this turnover interval.
title: Changing patterns of raxon dominance in patch reef assemblages from the Oligocene and Miocene of Jamaica
paper: Geological Society of America, Abstracts with Programs

name: Monte San Angelo, Gargano
remarks: From ref. 2006: Formed by rudist framestones and bafflestones, the shelf edge-related rudist complexes, unlike the rudist banks, are commonly not well preserved in situ as the main source of the bioclastic sediments (Figure 10). In the Murge region they are clearly associated with (Begin page 1569) the fault systems that form the eastern shelf edge (Borgomano and Philip, 1987), and in the Gargano they occur as megablocks (>103 m3) in base-slope deposits (Figure 11). A detail study of the biogenic components of those bioclastic sands and blocks has shown that they were mainly sourced from rudist associations not found in the inner platform. Combined analyses of a few preserved shelf edge-related rudist complexes and the associated deeper marine sediments have allowed some of their characteristics to be established. They were dominated by recumbents rudists, including caprinids and Sabinia. The diversity, size, and shape of those rudists, commonly associated with rounded and well-sorted bioclastic gravels, suggest that they lived in a high-energy subtidal setting (Figure 10). These shelf edge-related rudist complexes could be considered as reefs (Longman, 1981), defined as carbonate buildups, influenced by organisms, that controlled depositional processes in adjacent zones and were situated on a topographic high.
title: The Upper Cretaceous carbonates of the Gargano-Murge region, southern Italy: A model of platform-to-basin transition

name: Murge Area
remarks: From ref. 2006: Tidal channel-related rudist consist of meter-thick lenses or (Cummings, 1932) dominated by rudists, overlying algal-mud banks having an erosive contact (Figures 7a, 8). The horizontal dimensions of the rudist are less than 10 m. They are stacked in a progradational system and are overlain by algal-mud banks. The rudist communities are monospecific and have bafflestone-framestone structures (Embry and Klovan, 1971). The have filled preexisting depressions cut through the algal-mud banks. It is plausible that they have affinities with tidal channels because (1) they occur in a zone dominated by cryptalgal laminites inferred to have formed in intertidal environments, (2) they have the character of submarine deposits, and (3) they have prograded in depressions over a lag breccia rich in mud and stromatolitic clasts.
title: The Upper Cretaceous carbonates of the Gargano-Murge region, southern Italy: A model of platform-to-basin transition

name: Ouachita Thrust Belt, Oklahoma
remarks: The calcareous alga Donezella is composed of thin (typically 70-160 micrometer in diameter) branching segmented tubes, which bifurcate at an angle of 45-90 degrees. This calcareous alga is known to baffle sediment and build small (~6 m thick) to large (30-100 m thick) bioherms. Examples of Donezella-dominated bioherms are reported from Middle Carboniferous strata of Algeria, the Canadian Arctic Archipelago, Spain, and West Texas. A 5 m thick Donezella - siliceous sponge bioherm from the Wapanucka Formation was studied in detail by microfacies analysis. Due to high dip of the beds, the lateral dimension of the bioherm is not known. The bioherm overlies thin (20 cm), cross-bedded crinoidal-bioclastic packstone to grainstone, and is capped by peloidal packstone to grainstone The bioherm is primarily composed of Donezella boundstone-bafflestone and peloidal wackestone. In situ siliceous sponge bodies are locally preserved in the lower part of the buildup, by encrustation of micritic crusts and the red alga Archaeolithophyllum. Siliceous sponge spicules are common in the lower half of the bioherm and are rare to present throughout the upper half of the bioherm. The presence of siliceous sponge bodies in the lowest part of the buildup strongly suggests that they played a significant role in initial mound accretion. The green calcareous alga Donezella is common to abundant throughout the bioherm. Donezella builds a delicate framework or colony of thalli enclosing constructional pores. These pores are filled with internal sediments, burial calcite cements, dark micritic crusts and peloids with fuzzy outlines. Toward the top of the bioherm Donezella is increasingly surrounded by carbonate mud. Worm tubes with dark, micritic, encrustations are common in Donezella colonies. The calcareous alga Berestovia (or Claracrusta) is present mainly in the lower half of the bioherm, acting as the primary and secondary encruster of siliceous sponges. Berestovia is also the primary encruster of Donezella colonies. The red alga Archaeolithophyllum is locally present as the secondary and tertiary encruster of siliceous sponges in lower part of the bioherm. Broken segments of Archaeolithophyllum and other phylloid algae are increasingly present toward the top of the bioherm, often encrusted by encrusting foraminifera. Ostracod, benthonic, and encrusting foraminifera are rare to present, but are increasingly present toward the top of the bioherm. Brachiopods, ramose bryozoans, crinoids and corals are rare to present, and are scattered irregularly throughout the bioherm. The bioherm shows a subtle vertical community succession from Donezella boundstone to peloidal wackestone in the lower 5/6 of the bioherm to wackestone with scattered Donezella, fragments of phylloid algae, ostracodes and foraminifera toward the top. This succession is interpreted as being due to shallowing. The presence of siliceous sponge bodies, the abundance of siliceous sponge spicules, and the lack of high-energy microfacies in this bioherm indicates initiation and growth in a quiet-water environment below storm-wave base in the open-marine / slope environment seaward of the platform-margin grainstone belt.
title: Microfacies, Biota, and Depositional Environment of an Early Pennsylvanian (Morrowan) Donezella - Siliceous Sponge Dominated Bioherm, Frontal Ouachita Thrust Belt, Oklahoma, USA
paper: SEPM/IAS Research Conference: Permo-Carboniferous Carbonate Platforms and Reefs, Abstracts

name: Sierra de la Estrella, Guadiato
remarks: Microbial mud mounds between inner and outer ramp setting. Asbian-Brigantian Abstract ref. 2010: In the Guadiato Area sedimentation occurred during the upper Viséan to form the Sierra de la Estrella outcrops which belong to the Sierra del Castillo Unit The Guadiato Area is located on the boundary between the Ossa-Morena and Central-Iberian zones, in the south-western Iberian Peninsula, where Lower Carboniferous outcrops are numerous. Buildups development has been recognised in most outcrops of the Sierra del Castillo Unit, and they are located at La Casa de la Calera, Peñarroya, Sierra Boyera and Sierra de la Estrella. Although the stratigraphical setting of the first three sections has been previously described, their buildup development and morphologies are different to those of Sierra de la Estrella, whose buildups are thicker and more abundant. The stratigraphic succession from Sierra de la Estrella is dated precisely as upper Viséan by means of foraminifers (Zone 15 of Mamet). The main guide taxa are: Palaeotextularia (bilaminar), Cribrostomum, Vissariotaxis compressa, Howchinia, 'Monotaxinoides' sp., Endothyranopsis crassa, and the Microproblematicum Saccamminopsis fusulinaeformis. Sediments at Sierra de la Estrella show characteristics of a storm-dominated transitional zone between outer and inner ramp. The outstanding feature of this ramp is the development of microbial buildups. They may be called mud-dominated buildups or mud-mounds because they are mud-dominated (they show more than 50% of mud). They are regarded as microbial mounds because they are mainly composed of organomicrite and show common stromatactoid cavities. Two main morphologies have been identified: 1. Tabular mud-banks; they extend laterally for 1000 m to 1300 m, and are 35-60 m in thickness. 2. Domal mud-mounds; they have variable size; they are 2-25 m in thickness and 4- 40 m in diameter. Buildup types were related to sedimentological conditions; domical mud-mounds were developed in transitional facies between the inner and outer ramp, with variations in the environmental conditions, while tabular mud-banks were developed in more stable conditions in an outer ramp setting. Microbial buildups are interbedded with tempestites and marls. Some siliciclastic beds showing erosion surfaces and hummocky cross-bedding also occur The sedimentological and paleontological characteristics of the Sierra de la Estrella section allow us to recognise two deepening-upward sequences (probably of 4th order), which are integrated into a major transgressive sequence (belonging to a 3rd order cycle). This glacio-eustatic cycle is recognised in upper Viséan throughout the Guadiato Area, so it could be envisaged that it will influence all outcrops from this epoch within the Ossa-Morena and Central Iberian zones.
authors: Cózar, P.; Rodríguez-Martínez; M.; Falces, S.; Mas, R.; Rodríguez, S.
title: Stratigraphical setting in the development of upper Viséan (Lower Carboniferous) microbial buildups of the Sierra de la Estrella (Guadiato Area, SW Spain)
paper: SEPM/IAS Research Conference: Permo-Carboniferous Carbonate Platforms and Reefs, Abstracts

name: Koscian
remarks: Gas reservoirs Abstract ref. 2011: The gas saturated Zechstain Limestone Reefs within western and south western direction from Poznan have been recently discovered. These are Papro W reef nearby Nowy Tomy l Town and Koscian - Bonikowo Kokorzyn reefs located nearby Koscian Town. Koscian and Papro reefs and Bonikowo Kokorzyn reefs were discovered with 2D and 3D seismic respectively. The reefs were formed in the inner part of Zechstein See about 60-80 km north from the off shore carbonate platform. The genesis of the reefs is strongly connected with a local Carboniferous paleo highs called Wolsztyn High (Fig 1). The paleo-highs are formed with carboniferous sandstone (Koscian area) or Autunian volcanic rocks (Paproc_W area) and they were covered by shallow see. In this shallows there were mainly bryozoan reefs and oolitic-oncoidic carbonates deposited. Additionally, mostly at the top of the reef the stromatolite occurs. Porous reef body, characterised by thickness of up to 90 m is surrounded by deep basin limestone facie which is deposited as thin (up to 5m thickness) tight mudstone. Below this the most important parameters of the reefs are presented: Porosity very good up to 35 % Permeability variable 0.1 3000 mD Paproc-W Reef, area 4 sqkm, top depth 2450m TVDSS, thickness 50-80 m -The first discovered by 2D seismic Zechstein Limestone Reef in Poland. All its thickness is gas saturated. The accumulated gas contains 40 % of hydrocarbons. Koscian Reef , area 20 sqkm, top depth 2100m TVDSS, thickness 60 m. Koscian Reef is the largest of all discovered reefs body (Fig.3). There is gas-water contact at the depth of 2208m.The resent discoveries allowed to located new Wielichowo and Ruchocice Reefs at NE from Koscian Reef. Bonikowo Reef, area 9 sqkm, top depth 2260m TVDSS, thickness 90 m. In 1999 several new reefs was discovered i.e. Rensko-Kokorzyn-Bronsko and it seems to be the largest discovered reef, however shape of the reef was interpreted from 3D seismic and wait for the wells drilling. The reefs saturated gas contains 81 % of hydrocarbons (80.5 % of methane) and 18 % of nitrogen. It is very important to notice that the efficient reef prospecting is possible thanks to 3D seismic survey. Both 2D and 3D seismic was shot by GEOFIZYKA Toru. Especially it is worth emphasising that final success is a result of a co-work of many people; geophysicists, geologists and engineers. Presently, thanks to excellent co-operation between POGC - Oil and Gas Zielona Góra and GEOFIZYKA Toru S.A. the exploration of the Zechstein Limestone reefs has become the priority task for the companies operating in the western Poland
title: The Gas Saturated Zechstein Limestone Reefs in the Western Poland

name: Black Nose, ODP 171B, West Atlantic
remarks: Abstract ref. By Barremian-Aptian time, the reef stepped back 40-50 km from the lower Cretaceous margin and formed a long tract of coral-rudist reefs such as the one evident in seismic profiles in the shallow subsurface at the head of Blake Nose (Fig. 3). The Aptian reef tract ceased growth during the late Aptian, at which time periplatform debris was no longer delivered to the outer edge of Blake Nose, and the deposition of green and red variegated clays began.

name: Argentara Massif, Maritime Alps, France-Italian bor
remarks: Abstract ref. 2024: A finding of a Nerineae fauna in the southeast part of the Argentera massif and in the Tenda pass (Franco-Italian Alps) is reported. The formation is a reef facies of Kimmeridgian-Tithonian age (upper Jurassic). The following forms are represented in the fauna: an unidentified species of Nerinea, Ptygmatis cf. pseudobruntrutana, Phaneroptyxis moreana, and Cryptoplochus cf. subpyramidalis.
title: Sur quelques nerinees du malm des Alpes Maritimes (couverture sedimentaire de l'Argentera et ecailles charriees du col de Tende)

name: Malleval, Vercors
remarks: Abstract ref. 2025 (not seen): Sedimentary rocks exposed in the vicinity of Malleval (southeast France) include Tithonian (Jurassic), Berriasian, Valanginian, Hauterivian, and Urgonian (all lower Cretaceous) formations. A new outcrop of the upper Valanginian reef facies is reported. The Nant and Gerlette anticlines and the Picotiere syncline, all oriented north-south, are cut by three previously undescribed fracture systems: north-south, north-northwest-south-southeast, and west-southwest-east-northeast. The late phase of tangential movements in the Subalpine region is probably responsible for westward thrusting along the fractures.
title: Les environs de Malleval (Vercors occidental); etude stratigraphique et structurale
paper: Bulletin du Service de la Carte Geologique de la France

name: Siniscola-Posada, Sardegna
remarks: Abstract ref. 2026: On the eastern coast of Sardinia, in the Siniscola-Posada area, Jurassic rocks are transgressive on the Hercynic basement. The sequence begins with 15 to 50 metres of dolomitic limestones and dolostones, yielding Bathonian and Callovian ammonites. Oxfordian is probably missing. The middle Jurassic dolostones are directly overlaid by Kimmeridgian limestones, 100 m thick. The Beckeri zone is well represented in their upper half, with the index form and several other ammonites and aptichi. The Jurassic sequence ends with Tithonian limestones in reef facies.
authors: Dieni, Iginio, Massari, Francesco, Sturani, Carlo
title: Segnalazione di ammoniti nel giurese della Sardegna orientale
paper: Atti Accademia Nazionale dei Lincei, Classe di Scienze Fisiche Matematiche e Naturali, Rendiconti

name: Suva Planina, Serbia
remarks: Abstract ref. 2029: Reef limestones of the Suva Planina region and similar organic limestones of eastern Serbia, Yugoslavia, represent continuous sedimentation from Tithonian (Jurassic) to Valanginian (Cretaceous) time. Two types can be distinguished--reef deposits and lateral equivalents formed in deeper waters. Transgression was widespread, and deposition of thick sequences of limestone was due to gradual subsidence of the depositional basin during epeirogenic crustal movements.
title: Titon-valanzinien u istocnoj Srbiji; I, Problem starosti i mocnosti zoogenih sprudnih krecnjaka Suve Planine i njima slicnih tvorevina u istocnoj Srbiji

name: Crimea Mountains
remarks: algal-coral bioherms, 2.5-8 m thick, 2.5-6 m across, 3-10 m distance between bioherms Abstract ref. 2031: Biostromal structures have been identified in the upper Valanginian and lower Hauterivian (lower Cretaceous) deposits along the Crimean mountains (USSR). The structures have been formed by scleractinians, algae, and rarely by hydrozoans. Reef facies first appeared during the upper Oxfordian (upper Jurassic) and northward migration of some 25-30 km continued until the Hauterivian. The migration was influenced by tectonic movements and uplift of Kimmerian massifs.
title: Coral facies in lower Cretaceous deposits of the Crimean mountains

name: Sabana Grande, SW Puerto Rico
remarks: Part of abstract of ref. 2032: The structurally low Yauco basin began to receive volcanic rocks, clastic rocks, olistostromes, and olistoliths in Maastrichtian time. Campanian reefs which had grown on the uplifted Jurassic crust slid northward into the basin. Emplacement of reefal debris and olistoliths was synchronous with volcanism and uplift. These processes suggest proximity to submarine volcanoes, possibly in a deforming forearc basin. Surficial exposures of mantle rocks are probably the result of structural inversion of the basin in response to contraction in the currently active east-trending left-lateral fault system.
authors: Anderson, T.H., Jolly, W.T., Lidiak, E.G., Ruskin, B.
title: Tectonostratigraphic evolution of the Bermeja Complex, Puerto Rico
paper: Geological Society of America, Abstracts with Programs

name: Porcupine Basin, offshore Ireland, Atlantic
remarks: Reefs buried under 30 m of sediment. No age control. Abstract ref. 2033: During a recent cruise in the Porcupine Basin, off southwest Ireland, we discovered two extensive and hitherto largely unsuspected deep-water reef provinces, including a giant cluster of hundreds of buried mounds. The ring shapes of many reefs suggest that they are caused by an axial fluid expulsion at the sea bed, a transient flow well confined in space and time. We are exploring various hypotheses, but a stimulating avenue for research is opened by a glacially controlled growth pulse and subsequent decay of a shallow layer of gas hydrates as a methane buffer and probably indirectly as a ground for overlying biological communities.
authors: J. P. Henriet, B. de Mol, S. Pillen, M. Vanneste, D. van Rooij, W. Versteeg
title: Gas hydrate crystals may help build reefs
