name: Drake Island, Glacier Bay National Park, Alaska
remarks: Platform margin reef Abstract ref. 2036: In Glacier Bay, Alaska, Silurian limestones record the development and demise of a stromatolite reef complex in the Alexander terrane. These microbial deposits are of regional and paleontological significance because they contain paleogeographically distinctive biotas and yield important insights into Phanerozoic stromatolites that inhabited normal-marine subtidal environments. Willoughby limestones exposed on Drake Island reveal that stromatolite growth at the platform margin influenced platform dynamics with the protection of peritidal and lagoonal habitats behind a reef-fringed rim, which experienced early lithification by the precipitation of synsedimentary marine cements. Relatively low-energy subtidal conditions in a restricted, shallow-marine lagoon are implied by the peloidal and mollusk-rich wackestones, packstones, and grainstones. At the platform margin, stromatolite boundstones and cementstones capped a reef-like mound by forming a thick microbial-cement crust on a core of outer lagoonal sediments. Well laminated, fenestral mudstones and peloidal wackestones-grainstones have an abrupt lateral contact with the microbial boundstones, indicating their formation in peritidal flats adjacent to the stromatolite reefs. Foreslope breccias consist of clasts derived from shallow subtidal environments on the shelf and at its rim. Cyclic repetition of these deposits indicate that sea level fluctuations and tectonic instability in the Alexander terrane contributed to periodic shedding of shallow-marine detritus to the upper slope, followed by the rebuilding of stromatolite reefs at the platform margin. Culminating stages in the Klakas orogeny induced large-scale, catastrophic collapse of the carbonate platform. Silurian stromatolites characterized by similar habitats and microbial-sponge biotas in southwestern Alaska and the Ural Mountains, Russia, together with paleomagnetic data, detrital zircon evidence, and the timing of late-stage Caledonide events, firmly establish genetic and temporal links of the Alexander terrane with other areas along the Uralian Seaway.
authors: Soja, C.M., White, B., Antoshkina, A., Joyce, S., Mayhew, L., Flynn, B., Gleason, A.
title: Development and decline of a Silurian stromatolite reef complex, Glacier Bay National Park, Alaska

name: Lakeside Mountains, Utah
remarks: Thrombolitic and stromatolitic mounds (pinch and swell structures). Abstract ref. 2040: Stromatolites have been recognized as opportunistic disaster forms following the end-Permian mass extinction. This occurrence was attributed to the partial relaxation of ecological constraints in the aftermath of the mass extinction. A similar pattern occurs in the Great Basin following the Late Ordovician mass extinction in association with a shift to low-diversity, generalized faunas. Most Late Ordovician-Silurian faunal communities in the Great Basin are diverse and limited to relatively narrow environmental zones. Thin (10-20 cm thick) stromatolites occur throughout the section within inner-shelf tidal-flat facies. After the mass extinction, earliest Silurian (Rhuddanian) communities are broadly distributed with low diversity. Associated stromatolitic and thrombolitic mounds increase in abundance and reach a thickness of 2.5 meters. Bootstrapping analysis suggests the restriction of thick mounds to the post-extinction interval is non-random (probability <0.5%). The widespread shelf stromatolites and thrombolites of the early Paleozoic declined, probably because their habitat was disrupted by the evolving Paleozoic Evolutionary Fauna. By mid-Ordovician, stromatolites and thrombolites were small and restricted to marginal, inner-shelf environments. They temporarily regained prominence in the aftermath of the Late Ordovician and end-Permian mass extinctions. In the earliest Silurian, shelf communities were undifferentiated in the long (3-4 MY) aftermath of the mass extinction. Thick stromatolites and thrombolites disappeared when diversity increased and differentiated communities were re-established. This patterns suggests animals that were suppressing stromatolites and thrombolites were reduced or absent after mass extinctions.
title: Early Silurian stromatolites and thrombolities: successful disaster forms after the Late Ordovician mass extinction
paper: Geological Society of America Abstracts with Programs

name: Lost Springs, Nevada
remarks: Stromatolitic bioherms. No bioherms in shallow water. Abstract of ref. 2041: Most of what is known about the biotic recovery from the end-Permian mass extinction has been recovered from strata deposited in shallow-water environments. Yet, properties of the deep-ocean have been invoked as causes for the mass extinction as well as the unusually prolonged biotic recovery from this crisis. A nearshore to shelf transect of the Lower Triassic Virgin/Schnabkaib Limestones of the Moenkopi Formation (southern Nevada) was studied for changes in facies types and biofabrics as well as comparison with the coeval outer slope to deep basin Union Wash Formation (eastern California). A number of biofabric trends were documented across this transect. Vertical burrows are common in nearshore strata, while horizontal burrows are prevalent in shelf strata. Intervals with relatively high ichnofabric indices (ii 4-5) are more common in shelf than nearshore strata. The most intriguing biofabric trend is the lack of microbial structures, such as stromatolites, in the most nearshore section, with their greatest occurrence found in shelf strata. This anachronistic onshore-offshore trend of stromatolitic development points to offshore and oceanic environments as a likely influence on their formation. Presence of seafloor carbonate cements in coeval slope and deep basin Union Wash strata, implying an offshore presence of water masses supersaturated in calcium carbonate, suggests that unusual ocean chemistry may have played a significant role in the development of Early Triassic shelfal stromatolites.
title: Early Triassic onshore-offshore biofabric trends: implications for the end-Permian mass extinction and biotic recovery
paper: Geological Society of America Abstracts with Programs

name: Admiral Bay Fault, Canning Basin
remarks: Primary reef framework of domical and digitate stromatolites. Flanking deposits are bryozoan and palmatozoan grainstones and packstones. From Webby: Localized stratigraphically within the Goldwyer Formation, of probable early-mid Darriwilian age, and occupy restricted sites immediately adjacent to a major, intra-basinal fault zone (Admiral Bay Fault Zone). Four separate occurrences of these linear-shaped, microbial-dominated reefs are recorded along the main Admiral Bay fault line over a distance of 16 km. They vary from 500 m wide and 330 m thick to 200 m wide and 25 m thick, and at least one is more than 1 km in length. The reefs exhibit a primary reef framework of domical and digitate stromatolites. Flanking deposits are bryozoan and pelmatozoan grainstones, and packstones. The fault system which defines the northeastern margin of the Willara Sub-basin, was apparently active intermittently through Early-Middle Ordovician time. McCracken et al. (1996) suggested that uplift of the footwall side of the main fault produced a narrow, raised, linear belt along the line of the fault, providing suitable shallower depositional conditions for localized reefal growth. The timing of uplift is possibly early Darriwilian. These reefal masses were subsequently fractured by renewed phases of faulting that facilitated movement of mineralizing solutions and extensive alternation of the host rocks, with the emplacement of the Mississippi Valley-type, lead-zinc mineralization.
authors: McCracken S.R., Etminan, H., Connor, A.G., Williams, V.A.
title: Geology of the Admiral Bay Carbonate-hosted zinc-lead deposit, Canning Basin, Western Australia
paper: Society of Economic Geologists, Special Publication

Abstract of re. 2094: Carnian reef biota and brachiopods of the Misfah Formation (Hawasina complex) from a locality near the town of Al Aqil in Oman are described. A new brachiopod species, Oxycolpella arabica n. sp. is described. The composition of the Carnian reef biota in Oman is similar to those known from the Alpine-Mediterranean region. However, differences exist in the microfauna of reef dwellers, e.g. foraminifers. New stratigraphic data based on reef organisms and conodonts are presented.
authors: Senowbari-Daryan, B., Bernecker, M., Krystyn, L., Siblik, M.

name: Erd-Diosd, Budapest
remarks: Corals, coralline algae, diverse bryozoans, microbes. Bioclastic debris without corals and algae The first visible level of the reefal unit is formed by coralline algal thickets associated with a number of coral colonies belonging to the scleractinian genera Porites and Tarbellastraea. The overlying unit exhibits more distinctive reef features through the presence of metric-sized coral patches and scattered coral colonies. Two different growth forms of Porites occur (possibly two species): one with densely packed finger-thick branches, the other partly massive, partly ramose (often within the same colony), with branches about 5-10 cm thick. Coral constructions also contain globular to ramose colonies of Tarbellastraea with frequent Lithophaga borings. Thin Porites colonies domi-nate near the top of the reefal unit. Scleractinian colonies and mollusc shells (especially bivalves) are often invaded by a network of boring sponges corresponding to the ichnogenus Entobia. Among the samples from Dio'sd, Oosterbaan (1990) identified the following scleractinian species: Porites collegniana, Tarbellastraea reussiana, and Siderastraea crenulata. Coralline algae also play a major role in the construction of the framework. They encrust the surface of coral colonies with up to centimetre- thick sheaths around thin Porites colonies, or give rise to bushy outgrowths. Coralline algae are some- times also associated with bryozoan crusts. 1 The amount of siliciclastic material decreases upward, and at a distinct masses of red algae appear as encrustations covering an area of some 100 m2, possibly a hardground (which is not exposed). Upon parts of this algal build-up coral colonies occur, and locally become dominant (Müller, 1984). The algal-coral build-up is capped by a pebbly horizon and no further beds are exposed here. Further to the NW, a possibly coeval slightly clayey limestone contains abundant Turritella moulds, probably deposited in a sublittoral setting. The transition zone between the build-up and clayey limestone is not exposed. The clayey limestone is covered by a calcarenite ( Müller, 1984),partly grainstone, partly wackestone,with some faunal evidence for slightly decreased salinity.
authors: Saint Martin, J.-P., Müller, P., Moissette, P., Dulai, A.
title: Coral microbialite environment in a Middle Miocene reef of Hungary

name: Wangjiaping, Yichang, Hubei
remarks: Tianheban epoch 33% archaeocyaths but only one genus Abstract of ref. 2127: The limestone of the Tianheban Formation on the Yangtze Gorges belongs to open shelf marine deposit in middle Early Cambrian age. Two distinct types of archaeocyath reefs are preserved - an isolated archaeocyath mud mound, and a patch reef. The reefs are composed of irregular archaeocyathids and calcified microbial microfossils such as Epiphyton, Renalcis, Givanella, etc., belonging to baffling reef mounds. The patch reef succession shows the hydrodynamic changing from low energy to moderately high energy, and then to a low energy environment.
title: Archaeocyath reefs from the Lower Cambrian Tianheban Formation at Wangjiaping, Yichang, Hubei and their diagenesis

name: NE Amadeus Basin, Northern Territory

title: Lower Cambrian archaeocyathan buildups, Todd River Dolomite, northeast Amadeus Basin, central Australia: sedimentology and diagenesis
paper: Bulletin - Bureau of Mineral Resources, Geology & Geophysics, Australia

name: NE Amadeus Basin, Northern Territory
remarks: Abstract or ref. 2129: Two distinct types of archaeocyathan buildups occur within the Lower Cambrian Todd River Dolomite: a high energy, intemittently emergent, bioherm and grainstone reef-shoal (30-50m thick), and low energy open-shelf bioherms and patch reefs up to 8m thick and 20m across. The primary fabric of these buildups has been largely destroyed by dolomitisation. Facies relationships indicate that high and low energy buildups are temporal equivalents, and that the high energy reef-shoal now present in the N'Dhala Thrust Sheet was flanked to the east and south by a low energy shelf studded with bioherms and patch reefs. The reef-shoal was capped locally by microbial mudflats. The best potential for hydrocarbon accumulations appears to be local open-shelf buildups draped by thick halite deposits in autochthonous and para-autochthonous areas.
title: Lower Cambrian archaeocyathan buildups, Todd River Dolomite, northeast Amadeus Basin, central Australia: sedimentology and diagenesis
paper: Bulletin - Bureau of Mineral Resources, Geology & Geophysics, Australia

name: Lost Cabin, Spring Mountains, Nevada
remarks: Stromatolitic mounds in normal marine environment. Maximum thickness 2 m (= syndepositional relief). Virgin Member of Moenkopi Fm. Ref 2184: These microbial structures from the Virgin Limestone Member of the Moenkopi Formation have been recently reinvestigated to determine if they represent true reefs. In places microbial mounds occur as isolated patch reefs, although elsewhere they coalesce to form tabular biostromes. These mounds are an agglomeration of smaller subunits that have wavy laminations and thrombolitic textures. Measurements on isolated mounds show that they attained a relief of 1-2 meters above the seafloor.
title: Stromatolite beds from the Lower Triassic Virgin Formation, Spring Mountains, Nevada
editors: Cooper, J.D.
paper: Cavalcade of Carbonates - Volume & Guidebook, Ann. Meet. Pacific Section AAPG and SEPM

name: June Canyon, Toquima Range, Nye Co., Nevada

Rugose corals encrusted by Renalcis Mudstones with abundant calicmicrobes: Renalcis, Girvanella, Sphaerocodium associated with some heliolitid corals. Some crinoids as bafflers
title: A Lower Devonian reef and associated facies in the Tor Limestone, Toquima Range, central Nevada

name: Omi River, Nishiyama
remarks: Bryozoan-coral boundstones in Miodiocris breviscula zone. (with crinoids) Corals: Cyathaxonia, Clisiophyllum, Akiyoshiphyllum, Carcinophyllum, Hiroshimaphyllum (dominant), Amygdalophylloides. 22 bryozoan species in whole Carboniferous succession. Partial abstract of ref. 2181: Sedimentary facies in the Carboniferous part of the Omi Limestone are generally highly diverse, but their diversity varies in each age. The Upper Carboniferous part consists of highly diversified facies including fore reef, reef front, reef crest, sand shoal, and lagoon facies, while a simple facies assemblage, composed only of fore reef, reef front, and sand shoal facies, occurs in the Lower Carboniferous. The first phase, comprising the coral-bryozoan-crinoid community, occurs in the Endothyra spp. Zone to the Eostaffella kanmerai Zone (Visean to Serpukhovian).
title: Carboniferous reef succession of the Panthalassan open-ocean setting: Example from Omi Limestone, Central Japan

name: Souther Higashiyama, Omi River
remarks: Coral-chaetetid and chaetetid boundstones in Fusulinella biconica Zone.
title: Carboniferous reef succession of the Panthalassan open-ocean setting: Example from Omi Limestone, Central Japan

name: Fukugakuchi, Tomi River
remarks: Coral-bryozoan-microencruster boundstone in Millerella sp. Zone (lower Bashkirian) and in Profusulinella daiyamensis Zone (upper Bashkirian). Highly diverse reef-building community including rugose and auloporidid corals, bryozoans and microencrusters. Also associates with some chaetetids and other sponges (sphinctozoans/inozoans). Taisyakphyllum and Pseudopavona dominant Second reef phase in Omi Limestone, represented by the problematic skeletal organism-microencruster community, is developed in the Millerella sp. Zone to the Akiyoshiella ozawai Zone (Bashkirian to lowermost Moscovian),
title: Carboniferous reef succession of the Panthalassan open-ocean setting: Example from Omi Limestone, Central Japan

name: Souther Higashiyama, Omi River
remarks: Phylloid algal boundstones in Fusulinella biconica Zone. Marine cements common. Solenoparacean boundstones also present.
title: Carboniferous reef succession of the Panthalassan open-ocean setting: Example from Omi Limestone, Central Japan

name: Southern Nishiyama
remarks: Stromatolite-like laminar boundstones interpreted as reef-crest boundstone. Skeletal microbes? Microbial bindstones with Donezella in lagoonal facies.
title: Carboniferous reef succession of the Panthalassan open-ocean setting: Example from Omi Limestone, Central Japan

name: Elsa Nappe, Cantabrian Mts.
remarks: Back-shoal patch reefs in latest Early Cambrian (local stages Bilbilian to Leonian). boundstones predominantly composed of archaeocyaths (branching colonies of Archaeocyathus and solitary Pycnoidocyathus) in growth position overgrown by a framework of Epiphyton, Renalcis and Girvanella. Reefal debris with quartz silt. Some archaecyathan floatstones with up to 20% of terrigeneous material.
authors: Alvaro, J. J., Vennin, E., Moreno-Eiris, E., Perejon, A., Bechstadt, T.
title: Sedimentary patterns across the Lower-Middle Cambrian transition in the Esla nappe (Cantabrian Mountains, northern Spain)

name: La Cadiere
remarks: Peri-deltaic environment Rudist baffestone buildups. relatively diverse fauna of hippuritids, radiolitids and caprinids (7 species).
title: Dynamique biosédimentaire de bancs à rudists dans un environment pérideltaique: la formation de La Cadière d'Azur (Santonien, SE France)

name: Macon Co., Alabama
remarks: See reef 3089
title: New Ostracoda species from an Upper Cretaceous oyster reef, northern Gulf Coastal Plain, USA

name: Russell. Co., Alabama
remarks: Several biostromal horizons. Total thickness 30m. Only one oyster species strongly predominant (Ostrea cretacea). Other bivalves are: Exogyra upatoiensis, Lopha ucheensis, Anomia preolmstedi Micrfosossils: Only ostracods. Naticid gastropod drillholes in oysters up to 2 mm in diameter. Brackish environment with low sedimentation rate.
title: New Ostracoda species from an Upper Cretaceous oyster reef, northern Gulf Coastal Plain, USA

remarks: Upper Taqa porous limestone with bivalves, gastropods and colonial corals. Seismic evidence for
authors: Brannan, J., Gerdes, K. D., Newth, I. R.

name: Jumilla-Yecla Altiplano, SE Spain
remarks: Reef-shoal complex at margin of carbonate platform. Robust branching corals, red algae, stromatoporoids, and some rudists. Elevator hippuritids in back-reef.
authors: Martín-Chivelet, J., J. Ramírez del Pozo, G. Tronchetti, J.F. Babinot
title: Palaeoenvironments and evolution of the upper Maastrichtian platform in the Betic continental margin, SE Spain

name: SW Virginia
remarks: Bioherms are 30 cm to 1.5 m high and range from club-shaped heads 30 cm to 2 m in diameter to coalescent forms 10 m wide. Bioherms consist of branching digitate stromatolite columns (1 cm wide, 2 to 4 cm high), lesser sponge and calcareous algae, and interstitial carbonate mudstone and skeletal wackestone. Bioherms overlie flat-pebble breccias that are underlain by ripple-laminated shaly-pellet limestone and interbedded breccia lenses and sheets. Shaly limestones locally overlie fossiliferous marine shale. Bioherms are overlain by ripple-laminated shaly-pellet limestone that also fills interbioherm depressions, and locally by ooid grainstone sheets (up to 8 m thick).
title: Digitate stromatolitic bioherms and associated facies, Nolichucky Formation (Upper Cambrian), southwest Virginia

name: Maliri, Watwaro Range, Sind
remarks: Reefal nature uncertain but many reef building corals Age assignment based on stratigraphic correlation with NE India: Jauhri, A.K., and Agarwal, K.K., 2001
title: Sind fossil corals and Alcyonaria
paper: Memoirs of the Geological Survey of India, Palaeontologica Indica, Ser. 7 and 14

name: Jhirk, Sind
remarks: Reefal nature unknow and mostly ahermatypic corals described. However 23 hermatypic corals in fauna suggest some patch reefs
title: Sind fossil corals and Alcyonaria
paper: Memoirs of the Geological Survey of India, Palaeontologica Indica, Ser. 7 and 14

name: Magar Pir, Karachi, Sind
remarks: 41 species of corals (many reef building) from whole Sind area.

paper: Memoirs of the Geological Survey of India, Palaeontologica Indica, Ser. 7 and 14

title: Facies distribution in upper Jurassic coral reefs of the Dnieper-Donets basin (in Russian)

name: Donetz River
remarks: Outcrops of Donetz basin reefs with corals and algae (no bryozoans). Somewhat shallower deposits than NW Donetz reefs. Corals: Thamnasteria sp., Stylina aff. girodi Efallon and Stylina sp.

name: Caigudaogou, Rutog, Tibet
remarks: Age of formation given as Albia-Turonian. Reef horizons at several levels. Base: Thin-bedded orbitolinid wackestones Reef: Rudists, orbitolinids, stromatoporoids, algae, corals. Reef apex and edge: brecciated limestone. Tope: Orbitolinid wackestones interbedded with sandy limestones
authors: Kollmann, H.A., Lupu, D., Velitzelos, E.

remarks: Stylophora minutissima (small branching) coral bioherms in Terramar backreef lagoon

name: Central Pasco Co., Florida
remarks: Barrier reef tract in front of Terramar lagoonal environment inferred from massive corals and reef bivalves
title: A new gastropod fauna from an Oligocene back-reef lagoonal environment in West Central Florida

name: Russell Spring, Bainbridge, Georgia
remarks: Formerly assigned to Rupelian Very diverse coral fauna (25-30 species estimated)
title: A Tertiary coral reef near Bainbridge, Georgia

name: S. Cesarea, Apulia
remarks: Platform edge rudist biostrome Small Meandrina corals in addition late Campanian or Maastrichtian
title: Rudist fauna in the Maastrichtian deposits of southern Salento (southern Italy)

name: St. Corneli, Tremp, Cataluna
remarks: 25 rudist species listed. Corals mentioned but not described
authors: Gallemi, J., Martinez, R., Pons, J. M.

name: Karlovac
remarks: latest Kimmeridgian to Tithonian barrier reef with 'Hyrdozoans' (Ellipsactinia, Sphaeractinia), bryozoans (Bauneia), chaetetids, sponges, corals (Thecosmilia, Montlivaltia), gastropods, bivalves and brachiopods

name: SE Sarajevo, Bosnia
remarks: See reef 3117

name: Strojice, Bosnia
remarks: Reworked reef debris prevailing
title: Stratigraphical position and significance of reef facies at the northern margin of the Dinaric carbonate platform during the Late Jurassic and Cretaceous

name: Lakhpat, Kutch
remarks: Corals up to 2.5 m in size - with borings. Coralline algal, serpulid, oyster and bryozoan encrustations. Astrocoenia, Actinastrea, Stylophora, Hydnophora, Leptoria, and other faviids and poritids and some single corals
title: Oligocene reefal environment of Kutch Basin (western India) with implications of the Mediterranean connection

name: Akros Massif, Argolis
remarks: Three succeeding biostromes during Turonian in 37 m thick series: 1. Hippuritid-radiolitid biostrome with corals, chaetetids, coralline algae, and cyanophycean filaments. Radiolarite breccia horizon 2. Similar but with Bacinella 3. Like 2
title: Bioconstructions et plates-formes carbonates à Rudistes du Crétacé supérieur des zones ophiolitiques: le Massif de l'Akros (Argolide, Grèce

name: Dzykhra, N-Caucasus
remarks: Akhtsu-Dzykhra barrier reef
title: Nappe structure of the Greater Caucasus range

name: Tarlton Island, Isla Madre de Dios
remarks: Some poorly preserved colonial corals, pure character of limestones and massive bedding suggest shallow-water reef-affiliated depositional environment.
title: Stratigraphy and geochemistry of accreted fragments of the ancestral Pacific floor in southern South America

name: Alvrekdalen, Spitzbergen
remarks: Palaeoaplysina mounds in Tyrrellfjellet Member. Dated by conodonts and fusulinids Palaeoaplysina, Epimastopora, bryozoans, rare corals and peloids. Middle ramp position between fair weather and storm wave base.
authors: Hüneke, H., Joachimski, M., Buggisch, W., Lützner, H.
title: Marine Carbonate Facies in Response to Climate and Nutrient Level: The Upper Carboniferous and Permian of Central Spitsbergen (Svalbard)

name: Langenberg, Oker, Lower Saxony
remarks: 'Lowest Kimmeridgina oyster (Nanogyra nana) patch reef with cryptic sponges. Serpulid and microbial encrustations present. Oxfordian coral occurrences for this locality included in $ Div. set to 1 because Nanogyra extremely dominant'
authors: Delecat, S., Peckmann, J., Reitner, J.
title: Non-Rigid Cryptic Sponges in Oyster Patch Reefs (Lower Kimmeridgian, Langenberg/Oker, Germany)

name: Hanwang, Sichuan
remarks: > 90% micrite. Microbial origin of micrite suspeceted due to cloudy, clotted and peloidal textures. Thickness ratio of mounds to inter-mound sediments about 5:1.
title: Upper Triassic (Carnian) mud mounds from northern Sichuan (China)

name: Niggemann Quarry, Crawford Co., Kansas
remarks: Chaetetid buildups in Higginsville Limestone Member. Chaetetid masses up to 6 m across. 30-45 cm syndepositional relief. Chaetetids and tabulate corals (Multithecopora, Lophophyllidium) as encrusters in fusulinid wackestone matrix. Some bryozoans and algae >95 % of reef builders in situ
title: Chaetetid buildups in a Westphalian (Desmoinesian) cyclothem in southeastern Kansas

name: Stranice
remarks: 17 species of reef corals described. Some rudists (radiolitids, hippuritids) associated. Corals in three levels. Collection 23071-23073
title: Upper Cretaceous reef building colonial corals of Gosau facies from Stranice near Slovenske Konjice (Slovenia)

name: Skaz, Nizhnyaya Shemakha River, Urals
remarks: Ivdelinia acutolobalta zone (=costatus to kockelianus zones). Massive reefal limestones bordered by deep-water cherts (tectonic boundary).
authors: Sapelnikov, V.P., Snigireva, M.P., Bikbayev, A.Z., Mizens, L.I.
title: Zonal subdivision of Early-Middle Devonian reef deposits of the Urals based on conodonts and brachiopods

name: Tabuska River-Ufa River
remarks: Position not clear. 'Algal'-bryozoan reefs from uppermost Lochkovian (pesavis zone) to lower Pragian (sulcatus-kindley) zone. High brachiopod diversity. See reef 3130 for Pragian part.
authors: Sapelnikov, V.P., Snigireva, M.P., Bikbayev, A.Z., Mizens, L.I.
title: Zonal subdivision of Early-Middle Devonian reef deposits of the Urals based on conodonts and brachiopods

authors: Sapelnikov, V.P., Snigireva, M.P., Bikbayev, A.Z., Mizens, L.I.

remarks: Example of separate knoll reef on tidal-bank facies. Tubiphytes-Archaeolithoporella frame and crinoid-bryozoan baffle frame subdivided . 15-20% sparite cements, less than 15% sediment.

remarks: Platform-margin wall-reef Position unclear From base to top Phylloid algal frame Sponge-bryozoan frame Sponge frame Tubiphytes-Archaeolithoporella frame. Sponges frame with 60-70% sponges and minor amounts fo Trepostomata, Fenestella, Tubiphytes etc.

Sponges: Inozoans (Peronidella, Grossotubenella), spinctozoans (Amlysiphonella, Colospongia, Sollasia ...), calcareous algae, Tubiphytes, crinoids, Archaeolithoporella, 'hydrozoans' and bryozoans (Fistulipora, Fenestella) as reef builders

title: Early-Middle Permian reef frameworks and reef-building models in the eastern Kunlun Mountains

name: Chironäa, Boetia
remarks: Cited as a big rudist reef with: Radiolites (1 sp.), Medeella (3 sp.), Biradiolites (1 sp), Hippurites ( 1 sp.), Plagioptychus (1 sp.), gastropods, and boring bivalves
title: Das geologische Alter des großen Rudistenriffes vom 'Hönerberg' bei Chironäa unweit Livadia in Böotien (Griechenland)

name: China Echada, Malargüe,
remarks: Ramose and branching corals in pelecypod-rich matrix. Packstone with Columastrea and Placocoenia neuquensis (Up to 30 cm long). Coral incrusted by colonial worms. Rare gastropods and pellets. Boundstones with Amphiastrea with up to 1.2 m in diameter and 1 m height. Some bryozoans. Bioerosion locally intense, including micrite envelopes
title: Estratigrafia y sedimentologia de la formacion Chachao, Provincia de Mendoza

name: Balki, Sarysu River, Crimea
remarks: Bryozoan mounds with rich brachiopod fauna
title: Scanning electron microscopy study of Cretaceous brachiopods of the new family Praeargyrothecidae: implications for megathyroid systematics and terebratulide phylogeny

name: Bol'shaya Nadota Carbonate Complex
authors: Skompski, S., Paszowski, M., Krobicki, M., Kokovin, K., Korn, D., Tomas, A., Wrzolek, T.
title: Depositional setting of the Devonian/Carboniferous biohermal Bol'shaya Nadota carbonate complex, Subpolar Urals

name: Bol'shaya Nadota Carbonate Complex
remarks: Description refers to localites 9 and 8 of Skompski et al. (2001). Givetian to lower Frasnian conodonts. Stromatoporoid-amphiporoid(?) biolithite with numerous tabulate corals and cement-filled cavities, partial dolomitization. Corals are Thamnopora, and Natalophyllum. Overlain by late Frasnian crinoidal organodetrital calcarenites.
authors: Skompski, S., Paszowski, M., Krobicki, M., Kokovin, K., Korn, D., Tomas, A., Wrzolek, T.
title: Depositional setting of the Devonian/Carboniferous biohermal Bol'shaya Nadota carbonate complex, Subpolar Urals

name: Nixon Gulch, Horseshoe Hills, Montana
remarks: = Dresbachian Thrombolitic boundstone colums composed of micritic limestone with clotted fabric and colonies of Epiphyton. Linear structure parallel to shoreline in intrashelf basin below fair weather wave base, aboutn 50 km wide and 250 km long
title: Upper Cambrian carbonate platform evolution, Elvinia and Taenicephalus zones (Pterocephalid--Ptychaspid biomere boundary), northwestern Wyoming

name: Swamp Lake, Absaroka Range, Wyoming
remarks: See reef 3146

name: Eagle Mountain, California
remarks: Thrombolite bioherms in Jangle Limestone Member. Some probalbe Renalcis
title: Lateral continuity of facies and parasequences in Middle Cambrian platform carbonates, Carrara Formation, southeastern California, U.S.A.

name: Hvitland Peninsula, Ellesmere Island, Nunavut
remarks: Palaeoaplysina, phylloid algae and dasycladaceans form buildups up to 1 km in thickness.

editors: James, N.P., Clarke, J.A.D.

name: Apuane Alps, Tuscany
remarks: Small microbial(?) mounds with corals and crinoids within shoal complexes.

name: Kita-daito-jima, Philippine Sea
remarks: Unit C3 of well. Locally dolomitic rudstone associated with grainstone and packstone. Some in-situ corals and coralline algae.
title: Biogeochemical contrasts between mid-Cretaceous carbonate platforms and Cenozoic reefs

name: Kita-daito-jima, Philippine Sea
remarks: Upper Miocene part (C2) with prevailing bafflestones and less dominant framestones. Acropora abundant.
title: Biogeochemical contrasts between mid-Cretaceous carbonate platforms and Cenozoic reefs

name: Kita-daito-jima, Philippine Sea
remarks: Unit C1 of well is Pliocene: Coral framestone overlying rudstones with algal-encrusted coral branches. Pervasiv dolomitization. In-situ hermatypic corals and non-geniculate coralline algae throughout.
title: Biogeochemical contrasts between mid-Cretaceous carbonate platforms and Cenozoic reefs

name: Taebek, East South Korea
remarks: Mud-mounds in shallow ramp facies. Mound core micritic with scattered bioclasts. Micritic homogenous but locally clotted. Surrounded by echinoderm-rich skeletal packstones and grainstones. Sparse and small sparite-filled cavities in mound core. Time slice change (was 4) Lithistid sponges and Calathium
authors: Jeong Chan Kim , Yong Il Lee
title: Marine diagenesis of Lower Ordovician carbonate sediments (Dumugol Formation), Korea: cementation in a calcite sea

name: Koroviko, Viti Levu
remarks: Mainly coral rudstones and algal-coral-larger foram grainstones and packstones. Corals stongly bored. Borings and interseptal spaces in coral filled wither by fibrous finging cements or micrite
title: Deposition and diagenesis of Miocene arc-fringing platform and debris-apron carbonates, southwestern Viti Levu, Fiji

name: Koroviko, Viti Levu
remarks: See reef 3155.
title: Deposition and diagenesis of Miocene arc-fringing platform and debris-apron carbonates, southwestern Viti Levu, Fiji

name: Qaraqara Creek, Viti Levu
remarks: Qaraqara Member. Coral debris commonly encrusted by foraminifera and coralline algae, strongly bored. Associated with volcanic clasts
title: Deposition and diagenesis of Miocene arc-fringing platform and debris-apron carbonates, southwestern Viti Levu, Fiji

name: Borova draga, Jurjevo
remarks: One species of Milleporids, two chaetetids, corals and thick-shelled diceratids
title: Facijelni odnosi i hidrozoa malma - primorskog dijela sjevernog Velebita i Velike Kapele

name: Murva, Sibinji
remarks: 11 species of 'hydrozoans' from reefs, 2 from subreef beds and 2 assumed for corals and algae. Additional taxa in close-by Draga Kozica reef and Omar (collections 21191 and 21189 in Paleodb)

name: Waukesha County, Wisconsin
remarks: Very fossiliferous. This is a typical Wenlockian carbonate mud mound community, in which the core contains mostly carbonate mud, sometimes with Stromatactis-like structures, and echinoderm debris and the flank beds are echinoderm-dominated. Skeletal grains in the flank beds which contain this community can be either moldic or dolomite-replaced, and the texture ranges from non-cherty, porous dolowackestone to dolopackstone, with some grainstone present also in the flank facies, to crystalline dolomudstones and sparse dolowaxkestone to dolopackstone, with some grainstone present also in the flank facies, to crystalline dolomudstones and sparse dolowackestones in the cores. Skeletal grains show the full range from well to poorly sorted, and some graded bedding is present in the inclined beds of the echinoderm facies. Corals, which tend to surround the mound core, are sometimes overturned (Philcox, 1970), and in any case, are not abundant enough to form an organic framework. As noted by Witzke (1981b, 1987b), the general absence of skeletal boundstone fabrics precludes interpretation as an organic-framework reef, but the presence of apparent penecontemporaneous cave and fissure-fills in the core, often with thick trilobite or nautiloid concentrations, plus wedge-shaped debris flows in some facies, suggests that the mounds were rigid features, possibly resulting from submarine cementation processes (Witzke, 1987a). Dolomitized botryoidal and fibrous marine cembents are present. Sedimentary features are consistent with episodic high-energy conditions, such as would result from storm action in depths generally at or slightly below fair weather wave base.
authors: Frest, T. J., Brett, C. E., and Witzke, B. J.
title: Caradocian-Gedinnian echinoderm associations of Central and Eastern North America

name: Central Carnic Alps
remarks: Mounds with cystoid crinozoans and trepostome bryozoans. Position unclear. Normalograptus extraordinarius graptolite zone Abstract of ref. 2275: The Late Ordovician stratal succession in the Carnic Alps, an area that lay at about 50 degrees south latitude in the Ordovician, includes bioclastic carbonates derived from reefs. Two distinct facies have been distinguished in the Carnic Alps Late Ordovician succession: an inner shelf, Wolayer, facies and an outer shelf-upper slope, Uggwa, facies. Wolayer facies carbonates are massive, structureless, and accumulated as reefs which developed as thickets of crinozoans, primarily cystoids, and trepostome bryozoans. Cystoid calices are common at some sites. Conodonts, chitinozoans and trilobites are present in the reef rocks. These crinozoan-bryozoan reefs developed in relatively shallow-shelf, subtidal environments. Reef-derived detritus was swept downslope from time to time to accumulate in a sequence of graded debris flows in deep shelf-upper slope settings. These carbonate clast debris flows are a characteristic component of the Uggwa facies. Siliclastics subjacent to the Uggwa carbonates bear Rawtheyian shelly faunas. Blocks within cross-bedded sandstones and siltstones superjacent to Uggwa carbonates bear Hirnantia faunas. Persculptograptus persculptus and Mucronaspis occur in interbedded silty shales. Correlations based on faunas in strata subjacent and superjacent to the carbonates indicate that the reefs developed during the Normalograptus extraordinarius graptolite zone. Late Ordovician glaciation on Gondwana occurred during that zone. Siliclastics are absent from the reefs and reef-derived carbonates. If the source for the siliclastics was a portion of Gondwana, then reef development during glaciation suggests that the reef-building organisms were permitted to grow because the reef sites were not impacted by fluxes of siliclastics. The abundance of crinozoans and bryozoans suggests that small plankton were plentiful and nutrient availability high.
title: Late Ordovician crinozoan-bryozoan reefs in the Carnic Alps

name: Cody, Indian Pass Triangle, Wyoming
remarks: Thrombolite patch reefs in mixed carbonate-evaporitic sequence (restricted inner ramp setting). Part of abstract of ref. 2353: The observed buildups are approximately 3 meters across and 1 meter thick. Each buildup is composed of circular 'heads' of layered microbialite with an internal clotted texture (i.e. thrombolite). Individual heads are approximately 0.5 meters in diameter and 0.25 meters thick. Environmental interpretations of these microbial buildups suggest that they developed in shallow water (< 1 meter water depth). As many Jurassic thrombolite reefs discussed in the literature have been interpreted to have developed in deep-water settings, examination of these well-exposed Wyoming reefs provides important contributions to extend the distribution of thrombolite reefs into shallow-water environments.
authors: Parcell, W.C., Kastern, L., Minks, K., Williams, M.K.

name: Arrow Canyon Range, Clark Co., Nevada
remarks: Reef from old Trempelauan A sponge-microbialite reef horizon occurs in the upper Cambrian (Millardan) strata of the Arrow Canyon Range, Clark County, Nevada. This horizon represents one of the few metazoan reefs occurring between the extinction of the Archaeocyathids at the end of the early Cambrian and the proliferation of Calathium-sponge-microbialite reefs in the late early Ordovician. Good exposures of the reefs occur discontinuously on the western slopes of the Arrow Canyon Range. Uneven dolomitization obscures some reef structures while creating patches of well-preserved reef rock that are up to 15 m thick by 50 m wide. Some dolomitic intervals between reef mounds reveal faint reef-like textures and structures, therefore the shape and extent of the original reef(s) is uncertain. The interval may have extended into the overlying dolostone and the original reef may have formed distinct mounds larger than 50 m wide, or a single continuous biostrome over the 8 km exposure. The reef(s) show an ecological succession from basal-domal stromatolites (0.5 m wide, 1 m tall) to digitate stromatolites (5-20 cm wide, 10-20 cm high), a core of sponge-thromolite reef (3-7 m thick), and a cap layer of columnar stromatolites (20 cm w., 1-2 m h.) with attached and detrital sponges between the columns. Sponges in the core have thin walls (1-2 mm), and are broadly conical to bowl-like in shape, (5-10 cm w/h). They form a closely packed framework that is in-situ with pendent microbialites; Renalcis and Epiphyton. Age determination is currently supported by 4 conodont collections from strata underlying the reef through the reef core. Strata below the reef have Proconodontus muelleri and are assigned to that zone. Eoconodontus notchpeakensis occurs in the stromatolitic base and indicates the E. notchpeakensis Subzone of the Eoconodontus Zone. Palaeobotryllus taylori, also from the Eoconodontus Zone, occurs in the core.
authors: Mrozek, S., Dattilo, B.F., Hicks, M., Miller J.F.
title: Metazoan reefs from the Upper Cambrian of the Arrow Canyon Range, Clark County, Nevada
paper: GSA Annual Meeting, Abstracts with Programs

name: Gavu Fm., Mushgai
remarks: For the Silurian, four reef-complexes were investigated. They are situated as lens bodies within crinoid limestones. The lenses are 150-250 cm long and 80-150 cm tall. The composition of fossils is repeated in each lens: Stromatoporoidea, Tabulatoidea, Favositida, Thamnoporida, Bryozoa, Crinoidea, Algae, rare Heliolitoidea, solitary Rugosa and Brachiopoda. The dominate taxa are Stromatoporoidea and Tabulatoidea (Favositida) with a variety of colonies: laminar, hemispheric, spheric, massive. The dimensions of the colonies varied from 2-3 to 20-30 cm across. The laminar and incrusting colonies dominated the periphery of the reef-complexes; the hemispheric, spheric and columnar dominated the central parts, where the colonies were large in size.
authors: Minjin, C., Bondarenko, O.B., Bol'shakova, L.N., Ulitina, L.M., Sharkova, T.T.
title: Paleozoic reefs of Mongolia

name: Orgol Fm., Mushgai
remarks: It forms a biostrome that is 5 m height and 1000 m long. The bottom 1.5 m consists of small lenses of crowding Thamnoporida. Some of lenses are 10 m long, and they rise up to 20-40 cm in the center. The upper 1.5 m of the biostrome consists of lenses full of Thamnoporida as well. In the middle part of the biostrome, there are massive colonies of Stromatoporoidea and Favositida with Thamnoporoida in the interstices. The following taxa were also found in the biostrome: brachiopods, single trilobites, solitary and fragments of massive colonies of Rugose, Crinoidea and Algae.
authors: Minjin, C., Bondarenko, O.B., Bol'shakova, L.N., Ulitina, L.M., Sharkova, T.T.

The dominant fossils are Stromatoporoidea, Heliolitoidea, Tabulatoidea and Rugosa. Other taxa found in this complex include Brachiopoda, Crinoidea, Bryozoa and Algae. Details from poster at exhibit.

name: South central Pennsylvania
remarks: Abstract ref. 1994: Laurentian shelf margin deposits typically are dolomitized or metamorphosed, but the Ledger Fm. contains an exceptionally well preserved microbialite reef complex, riddled with large submarine cavities. The microbialite consists of Renalcis-like shrubs, centimeter-scale domal stromatolites, dense fronds and laminated fabrics. Petrographically, the microbialite is expressed as clots of spherulites, stringers, arborescent garlands, and dendritic shrubs. Microbial processes dominated all ecological niches; forming the substrate, colonizing cryptic spaces, coating and encrusting other algae. Cavities within the microbialite formed through a number of previously undescribed processes, at least on the large scale reported here. Organic decay led to the development of stromatactis-like voids on a meter-scale, while syn-depositional slumping and channel formation led to microbial props and folds which resulted in further void generation. These large cavities were stabilized with multiple generations of radiaxial fibrous and herringbone calcite cements, intercalated with internal sediment. The herringbone calcite cement has depleted carbon isotopic values relative to the radiaxial fibrous cement, even those within the same cavity. This suggests that the herringbone morphology is related to unusual porewater conditions. In this instance I interpret that the herringbone calcite reflects near anoxic porewaters due to large quantities of decaying microbial material nearby. Marine cement stratigraphy, based on petrography, CL, stable isotopes, and trace element geochemistry, demonstrate that the cavities did not fill simultaneously. Rather, even adjacent cavities exhibit complex patterns of cementation, encrustation, and cement breakage, indicating that the reef's location was in a high energy, shelf margin setting where storms and local events impacted each cavity differently.
authors: de Wet, C., Frey, H. M., Gasworth, S. B., Moore, C. I., Rahnis, M., Bruno, C. R.
title: Origin of meter-sclae submarine cavities, herringbone calcite, and radiaxial fibrous cement infills within a microbial reef, Cambrian Ledger Formation, York, Pennsylvania, U.S.A.

name: La Serre, Montagne Noire
remarks: Abstract ref. 2009: During the Early and Middle Viséan rugose corals again occurred widespread within shallow water marine environments. To some extent they accumulated to form reefal structures. The significance and function of related rugose corals were highly variable. In order to achieve a systematic approach Lower Carboniferous biostromes and biohermes were examined in different geotectonic settings north (Belgium) and south (France: Montagne Noire) of the European Variscian orogenic belt. In the Montagne Noire the Viséan to Namurian sequence is part of large olistoliths originating from an active continental margin. Limestone olistoliths yield different shallow-water communities. Bioherms show a community consisting of calcareous algae, cyanobacteria (e.g. Orthonella), and bryozoans. Accessory brachiopods, corals, molluscs, siliceous sponges, and foraminifers occur. Sporadically there are intercalations of dark, well-bedded pack- and grainstones (part of peri-biohermal facies). Some of the olistoliths yield a rich coral fauna. Most abundant are solitary corals (e.g. Axophyllum), but in some cases colonial forms contributed to the formation of biostromes and small bioherms. They were dominated in changing compositions by Lithostrotionidae, Lonsdaleia and Axophyllum. These small structures seem to be bound to lagoonal or inter-biohermal settings. In Belgium coral biostromes occur throughout the Viséan. Siphonodendron martini occurs in the capping-beds of the cryptalgal-bryozoan Buildup of Bomal (Middle Viséan). During the Late Viséan a diverse coral fauna inhabited the microbial mounds of the Campine Basin. From the same interval two biostromes are known form Royseux (northern limb of the Dinant Syncline). These biostromes show important contributions by Lithostrotionidae. In general Late Viséan and Early Namurian coral biostromes and bioherms appear to represent local niches. The reef-building potential seems to be relatively high if rugose corals and encrusting organisms co-occur.
title: Contribution of rugose corals to late Viséan and Serpukhovian bioconstructions in the Montagne Noire (southern France)
editors: Ahr, W.M., Harris, P.M., Morgan, W.A., and Somerville, I.D

title: Growth forms and palaeoenvironmental interpretation of stromatoporoids in a Middle Devonian reef, southern Morocco (west Sahara)

name: Gavdos Island, South Greece
remarks: 11 coral species from 6 small outcrops. Corals from marls, thought to be inner part of atoll reef structure. Minor bioerosion evident on pictures.

name: Ai-Petri, Crimea
remarks: 650 m thick reefal complex with coral-stromatoporoid patch reefs, stromatoporoid-Lithocodium patch reefs, packstones, grainstones, calcareous sponges, Tubiphytes and foraminifera. Age poorly constrained between late Kimmeridgian and Berriasian. Bulk of reef is probably Tithonian. Two reefs added to give double weight to Tithonian.

remarks: lack, massive limestone reefs, formed by lamellibranchs Myalina ramanensis = Ramonalina ramanensis
title: Stratigraphical studies on the Triassic vertebrate fossils from Wadi Raman, Israel

name: Rottnest Island
remarks: coral-reef limestone and associated shelly limestone. Accumulated in a reefal setting in as many as a few metres of water depth. Coralline algae encrust most of the corals, and contributed significantly as binding organisms in the reef framework; some shells are heavily encrusted and bound into the reef framework by coralline algae. Dated by U/TH method as 132 ka
title: Guidebook to the geology of Rottnest Island
paper: Geological Society of Australia Western Australia Division Excursion Guidebook

name: Catombal, Back Creek, N.S.W.
remarks: Bioherms with stromatoporoids, tabulate corals (together 55% area), micobialites (13%). 32% are matrix and cements. Microborings common, but no macroborings reported
authors: Adachi, N., Ezaki, Y., Pickett, J. W.
title: Marked accumulation patterns characteristic of Lower Devonian stromatoporoid bindstone: Palaeoecological interactions between skeletal organisms and microbes

name: Yass area, Canberra, N.S.W.
remarks: Red algal-calcimicrobial-stromatoporoid bindstones. Stachyodes as main reef builder 20% stromatoporoids, Rothpletzella (5%), Renalcis (5%), Wetheredella (2%) and Graticula-like red algae ( 1%) as encrusters. Stromatolites and Girvanella (1%) present. The conodont fauna, obtained from the limestone lenses, includes Icriodus woschmidti and indicates an early Gedinnian age for the upper half of the formation (Link & Druce, 1972). The underlying Cowridge Siltstone is of Late Ludlovian to Pridolian age, suggesting that the Elmside Formation ranges in age from Late Pridolian to Early Gedinnian (Pickett, 1982).
authors: Adachi, N., Ezaki, Y., Pickett, J. W.
title: Interrelations between framework-building and encrusting skeletal organisms and microbes: more-refined growth history of Lower Devonian bindstones

name: Benicàssim, El Molto, Maestrat Basin
remarks: Microsolenid laminar framework reefs with stromatolitic crusts (with clotted micrite and microspar). Corals encrusted by coralline and peyssonneliacean red algae, encrusting foraminifers, and stromatolitic crusts. Microbes 20% of reef volume. Burrows in semi-consolidated stromatolites interpreted as borings by me. Microborings present
title: Stromatolite reef crusts, Early Cretaceous, Spain: bacterial origin of in situ-precipitated peloid microspar?

name: Shar'yu River section, Chernyshev Ridge
remarks: Microbial boundstone, stromatolite boundstone, peloidal limestone, interpreted to having formed under nutrient-rich conditions. Starts in upper Frasnian but largely Famennian

name: Aramda Reef Member
remarks: Late Pleistocene to Holocene coral reef with abundant rhodolites. 4 m thick. Radiocarbon ages are 41.2 and 18.3 ky. Four reef units: 1. Coral framestone 2. Algal framestone 3. Coral bafflestone with algal debris 4. Rudstone with algal debris
title: Record of rhodoliths from Aramda Reef Member (Late Pleistocene to Holocene) of Chaya Formation, Dwarka-Okha area, Gujarat and their paleoenvironmental significance

name: Estancia 25 de Mayo, Santa Cruz
remarks: Crassostrea? hatcheri reefs
title: The oyster Crassostrea? hatcheri (Ortmann, 1897), a physical ecosystem engineer from the upper Oligocene-lower Miocene of Patagonia, southern Argentina

name: Gran Bajo, Santa Cruz

title: The oyster Crassostrea? hatcheri (Ortmann, 1897), a physical ecosystem engineer from the upper Oligocene-lower Miocene of Patagonia, southern Argentina

name: Sicakbük reef bouldes, Karaburun
remarks: Solonepora and alga Aternasus seem to prevail. Additionally porostromate algae (=microbes), sponges and corals The reef boulders, found in Sicakbük locality (Fig. 1) are most probably Anisian in age. They contain different reef organisms (e.g., sponges, corals, etc.) associated with algae described in this paper. The samples were collected in an outcrop (Anisian Gerence Formation, Koyutepe Unit of Brinkmann et al. 1972, samples K1 and KAB) about 12.5 km south of Mordogan.
authors: Senowbari-Daryan, B., Link, M. & Isintek, I.
title: Calcareous algae from the Triassic (Anisian reef boulders and Norian reef limestones) of Karaburun, western Turkey

name: Tahta Iskele, Karaburun
remarks: Probably lower Norian reef of 150 m lateral extent. Abundant microbial crusts associated with coralline sponges and corals
authors: Senowbari-Daryan, B., Link, M. & Isintek, I.
title: Calcareous algae from the Triassic (Anisian reef boulders and Norian reef limestones) of Karaburun, western Turkey

name: Benicàssim, El Molto, Maestrat Basin
remarks: Platy coral reef with red algae (2%) and stromatolites. Could be same reef as 3536
authors: Tomás, S., Aguirre, J., Braga, J. C. & Martín-Closas, C.
title: Late Hauterivian coralline algae (Rhodophyta, Corallinales) from the Iberian Chain (E Spain). Taxonomy and the evolution of multisporangial reproductive structures

name: ENE of Xuyong, Sichuan Basin, Guizhou
remarks: Exact position unclear. Mud mounds with Stramatactis in open shelf environment, deeper water. Mound cores composed of clotter micrite. Individual mound small but composite up to 35 m. Mound tops dolomitized
authors: Zhao, W. Z., Yang, X. P., Kershaw, S., Zhang, B. M.
title: Reservoir potential of Silurian carbonate mud mounds in the southern Sichuan Basin, Central China

name: Longmenshan, Ganxi, Sichuan
remarks: Position unclear. Stromatoporoids, rugose corals and tabulate corals indicated as reef builders. 2 reef intervals, each 2-3 m thick in highstand systems tract. Distinct brachiopod community in reef (Clathrocoilona-Hexagonaria)
title: Paleocommunity replacements of benthic brachiopod in the Middle-Upper Devonian in the Longmenshan area, southwestern China: Responses to sea level fluctuations

name: Bianping, Houchang, Ziyun, Guizhou
remarks: Coral reef composed of rugose corals Fomichevella and microbes. Overlying phylloid algal reefs with Ivanovia cf. manchurica Two reef bodies laterally separated by a fault. Top of upper Carboniferous.
authors: Gong, E. P., Yang, H. Y., Guan, C. Q., Sun, B. L. & Yao, Y. Z.
title: Unique recovery stage of reef communities after F/F event in a huge coral reef of Carboniferous, Southern Guizhou, China
paper: Science in China Series D-Earth Sciences

name: Kudirka atoll structure, Vilkaviskis
remarks: Atoll-like reefal structure of 5 x 8 km in area and up to 88 m thickness. Described as stromatoporoid-crinoid reef. 60% of bulk rock are crinoids. Reservoir quality reduced due to calcite cementation. 2-14% porosity
authors: Stentoft, N., Lapinskas, P. & Musteikis, P.
title: Diagenesis of Silurian reefal carbonates, Kudirka oilfield, Lithuania

name: Camposilvano, Monti Lessini
remarks: age stated as Aalenian, but below middle Aalenian unconformity.
title: Brachiopods from the 'Calcari Oolitici di S. Vigilio' (Toarcian-Aalenian) and 'Rosso Ammonitico' (Upper Bajocian) in the central Lessinian Alps (Province of Verona, Italy): a preliminary note
editors: J. Palfy and A. Voros
paper: Mesozoic brachiopods of Alpine Europe. Hungarian Geological Society, Budapest

name: Muddy Mountains Overton locality
remarks: Placunopsis bioherms in Virgin Limestone Member The heights of the Placunopsis buildups range from 12 to 26 cm, with the majority of the bioherms attaining a height greater than 20 cm. The widths of the buildups range from about 0.5 to 1.5 m. Where exposure is continuous, distances between the centers of adjacent bioherms range from 1 to 1.5 m; adjacent bioherms do not appear to connect laterally.
authors: Pruss, S. B., Payne, J. L. & Bottjer, D. J.
title: Placunopsis bioherms: the first metazoan buildups following the end-Permian mass extinction

name: Prayon, Vesdre area
remarks: 6.7 m-thick biostrome composed of laminar Alveolites-stromatoporoid bindstone with some Frechastraea. The biostrome formed under or near the storm wave base and was subjected to an input of limestone sediments, perhaps triggered by storms (it will be discussed later in the section devoted to the biostromes).
title: Late Frasnian phillipsastreid biostromes in Belgium

name: La Mallieue
remarks: The second unit is a 3.7 (Engis) to 4 m-thick (La Mallieue) coral biostrome sensu stricto. The rugose coral colonies are laminar, discoid, of various sizes, from a few centimetres to 70-80 cm in diameter (and possibly more). The density of the frame builder can reach 90% of the rock; the matrix is a shale or a slightly argillaceous packstone more or less dolomitized.
title: Late Frasnian phillipsastreid biostromes in Belgium

name: Sierra Agua Verde, Sonora
remarks: Equivalent to early late Moscovian (Podolskian) and fusulinid biozone A3. Chaetetid reef mound with phylloid and other calcareous algae
authors: Almazan-Vazquezi, E., Buitron-Sanchez, B. E., Vachard, D., Mendoza-Madera, C. & Gomez-Espinosa, C.
title: The late Atokan (Moscovian, Pennsylvanian) chaetetid accumulations of Sierra Agua Verde, Sonora (NW Mexico): composition, facies and palaeoenvironmental signals

name: Microconch reef, S of Liege
remarks: The framework of these small domal-shaped reefs was owing to microconchids and calcimicrobes (Garwoodia, Mitcheldeania).
title: After the collapse of stromatoporid-coral reefs -- the Famennian and Dinantian reefs of Belgium: much more than Waulsortian mounds

name: Engihoul Quarry, Liege
remarks: Local stage Livian (approximately Holkerian). a massive lens (2 m high, 5 m across) composed of massive, dark grey limestone. Microscopically, the central part of the lens consists of microbe-bryozoan boundstones.
title: A microbe-bryozoan reef from the middle Visean of the Namur Syncline (Engihoul Quarry)

name: Kirchfidisch, Burgenland
remarks: huge amounts of accumulated serpulid tubes
title: Siluro-Devonian Alpine reefs and pavements

name: Hohe Warte, Carnic Alps
remarks: Microbial mounds are documented in the Lower Devonian Rauchkofel Limestone. Baffling organisms, especially calcareous green algae (Hubmann 1994) and ramose-branching tabulate corals, predominate. The dimension of the lensshaped body is about 60-80 m in length and 8-10m in height.
title: Siluro-Devonian Alpine reefs and pavements

name: Weiße Wand, Graz Paleozoic
remarks: Basally developed 'reef pioneer settlement', some 10m in thickness dominated by densely packed Stachyodes and auloporids in a black bituminous limestone matrix. This sequence passes into dark-grey fossil-rich limestones with special rugose coral consortia dominated by Mesophyllum and Stringophyllum. A thin horizon (approximately 30-50 cm) with small colonies of the phaceloid rugosan Thamnophyllum terminates the 'pioneer sequence', which is overlain by 20-30 m-thick, white and slightly dolomitized limestones. The latter contain accumulations of various reef-building organisms (stromatoporoids, rugose and tabulate corals).
title: Siluro-Devonian Alpine reefs and pavements

name: Pimento Hill near Beecher Town, St. Ann parish
remarks: Coral patch reef
title: Reef corals of the White Limestone Group of Jamaica

name: St. Ann and St. Andrew parish
title: Reef corals of the White Limestone Group of Jamaica

name: Rustrel, Massif de Vaucluse, Provence
remarks: Listed as coral biostromes with stromatoporoids, but mound geometry verified in the field. Low porosity in buildup, higher porosity in adjacent rudist limestones.
title: Les scléractiniaires du Barrémien-Aptien inférieur de Provence (SE de la France) [The Barremian-Early Aptian Scleractinia from Provence (SE France)]

name: San Luca area, Vicenza
remarks: San Luca Unit dated as 'middle Oligocene'. Assignment to late Oligocene herein. Very rich coral faunas in several levels.
title: Systematische und paläoökologische Untersuchungen an oligozänen Korallen der Umgebung von San Luca (Provinz Vicenza, Norditalien)

name: Crosara area, Crosara unit, Vicenza
remarks: Coral-rich marls and algal limestones,
title: Systematische und paläoökologische Untersuchungen an oligozänen Korallen der Umgebung von San Luca (Provinz Vicenza, Norditalien)

name: Kasal
remarks: Sponge-tabulozoan boundstones small discontinuous, lenticular reef knolls or banks on a muddy sea floor

name: Mesici, Dinarides
remarks: 'Reef facies'. Only forams described
authors: Zaninetti, L., Ciarapica, G., Cirilli , S., Cadet, S.P.
title: Miliolechina stellata, n. gen., n. sp. et Hirsutospirella pilosa, n. gen., n. sp. (Foraminiferes), dans le Trias Superieur (Norien) a facies recifal des Dinarides

name: Las Juntas, Sierra de Baza
remarks: Mounds consist of a core of bafflestone texture, with abundant sphinctozoans, hermatypic corals, inozoans, hydrozoans, solenoporaceans and dasycladaceans, covered on top by a boundstone formed by clusters of tubular organisms (serpulids) encrusted by Spongiostromata and with abundant interspace voids filled in by synsedimentary cements. At the top of the bioconstructions there exists a micrite facies with abundant fenestrae. The thickness of a single mound ranges from 1 to 10 m. The mounds developed at the edge of a platform seaward of a calcarenite barrier.
title: Bioconstrucciones del Anisiense-Ladiniense en el Trias Alpujarride

name: Sierra de la Joya, Lujar
remarks: Upper Anisian? Mounds in a lagoonal setting bafflestones containing dasycladaceans, gastropods, bivalves, echinoderms ... together with solitary corals and branching cyanophytes (core facies), which alternate with Spongiostromata crusts (cap facies)
title: Bioconstrucciones del Anisiense-Ladiniense en el Trias Alpujarride

name: Oued Zaafrane, Haddadah
remarks: Chaetetid sponges only. Previously dated as Oxfordian

The biohermal type of rudist buildups was uncommon. Diversity in PBDB list refers to large area of several biostromes combined.
title: On the Senonian rudist-bearing sediments in Yugoslavia

Dublin developed in a deeper ramp setting of the Dublin Basin.

It is 2 m thick.

name: July Lake area, British Columbia
remarks: Recent drilling in the Helmet and July Lake areas of northeastern British Columbia has found sizeable reserves of natural gas in the Upper Devonian (latest Frasnian) Jean Marie Formation. Patch reefs form a principal reservoir facies in this limestone. These reefs more closely resemble Carboniferous aged Phylloid-algal mounds than the more typical Givetian and Frasnian age buildups. The patch reefs attained a maximum thickness of 25 m and had a maximum relief above the sea floor of approximately 13 m. The dominant reef formers were platy stromatoporoids which grew in an upright, interconnected manner similar to that of phylloid algae. Renalcis typically grew on the underside of these stromatoporoids, partially filling the shelter cavities while finer sediment accumulated on the tops of these stromatoporoids in a geopetal fashion.
authors: Wendte, J.C., Cadenhead, D., Sturrock, D.L., Dawson, S.W.
title: Platy stromatoporoid reefs of the Upper Devonian Jean-Marie Formation of northeastern British Columbia

name: Pardonet Hill Patch Reef
remarks: Ref. 2751:Bioclastic accumulations composed of crinoids, brachiopods, molluscs, spongiomorphs and scleractinian corals at Pardonet Hill. These small buildups (~100 to 500 m3) have planar bases and broadly convex tops (3 small reefs). These mounds are interpreted as small patch reefs composed of packstone, bioclastic floatstone/rudstone and carbonate breccia intercalated with mixed siliciclastic carbonate sediments deposited in a shallow subtidal setting. RCM Edit in May 2015.

Non-coral taxa found within this bed include abundant Pecten roemeri Hill, 1889, Radiolites cf. R. costata Scott, 1990, large nerineids, Mexicaprina alata Filkorn, 2002a, and massive colonies of the stromatoporoid Actinostromaria sp.

name: Penaguila, Valencia
remarks: Coral reef developed in HST on top of deep shelf limestone sequence. Buried coral reef also inferred for between Ibi and Carrasqueta. coralgal buildups interfingering with miliolid-rotaliid limestones. The top shows a thickening-up bedding pattern and consists of packstones and grainstones with exclusively rotaliids and some coral debris. The unit of pebbly rotaliid limestones with coralgal reefs is considered to represent a highstand prograding barrier with fore-reef, reef and interreef subenvironments.
title: Recognition of stratigraphic sequences in carbonate platform and slope deposits: empirical models based on microfacies analysis of Palaeogene deposits in southeastern Spain

name: Minkowice, Lublin Basin
remarks: Waulsortian type mud mound with crinoids, fenestrate bryozoan debris and abundant stromatactis. Microbes probably important 35 m thick. in central part of Lublin Basin.
title: The Waulsortian-type mound in the Lower Namurian of the Lublin Basin (SE Poland)

name: Normandville II, Alberta
remarks: Described as Waulsortian-type mud mounds (bryozoan-crinoidal). Two facies in core: 1. fenestrate bryozoan facies with minor mud. 2. carbonate mud with minor bryozoans.
title: Waulsortian-like mounds of the Mississippian Pekisko Formation, Northwestern Alberta: Petrographic and chemical attributes

title: Carbonate platforms in wedge-top basins: An example from the Gunung Mulu National Park, Northern Sarawak (Malaysia)

name: Tazhong oil field, Tarim
remarks: age indicated as early late Ordovician. Corals, stromatoporoids, solenoporaceans and calcimicrobes as reef builders. Largest oil field in China. oil in reef-flat and grainstones. Reef facies in well Tazhong-30: Reef mounds are coral framestones coral bafflestones in 10-20 m thick horizons. Mud mounds are up to 30 m thick.
authors: Ivanova, R. M. & Bogush, O. I.
title: Algae as indicators of a biogeographical zonation in the early carboniferous of the Urals, Siberia and Northeast Russia

name: Goznitsa, Lovech
remarks: Small biostromes and patch reefs in lagoonal marls, siltstones and sandstones. They are built of colonial corals, faceloid and dendroid, adapted to a soft substratum (clayey bottom). They are preserved in the rock in situ, the dimensions of the colonies varying from several centimeters to several tens of centimeters. Massive colonies dominate the central parts, and dendroid corals, the peripheries.
title: axonomy of scleractinian corals from the Barremian-Lower Aptian of central north Bulgaria (Lovech Urgonian Group)

name: Amagour mound complex, Anti Atlas
remarks: Mound complex on grainstones. Mound cores exhibit microbial (mainly Epiphyton and Renalcis) patches, up to 0.8 m thick and 1 m long, surrounded by massive microsparite bearing scattered shelly debris. Archaeocyaths, both preserved in life position and forming parautochthonous accumulations, are dominated by simple forms. Abundant stromatactis
title: The Great Atlasian Reef Complex: An early Cambrian subtropical fringing belt that bordered West Gondwana

remarks: Reef complexes described from Aguerd (W), Tadakoust (middle) and Tamezrar (E). Aguerd member of Issafen Fm. Coordinates for Tadakoust

name: Pamyatno-Sasovskoye oilfield, Zhirnovsk
remarks: Intrabasin buildup. flat-topped, narrow, and extended reef steep (southeast) foreslope composed of relatively deep-water deposits and more gentle inner (north-west) slope represented by lagoonal deposits. Upward increase of the role of stromatoporoids, corals, crinoids, calcareous algae (green and red), and cyanobacteria. 8% porosity, 10% detritus (fossils), 32% algal, rest is spar (dolomite)
title: A lithofacies model for the Upper Devonian Pamyatno-Sasovskoye reef (oilfield) (Volgagradskoe Povolzhye, Russia)

name: NE Taebaek Basin
remarks: Described as siliceous-sponge microbial reefs. Epiphyton dominant, followed by Siliceous sponges, Renalcis and Epiphyton. 170 m thick section with several intervals. Described is only 14 m thick example. Ooids indicate shallow marine deposition. late Stage 5 to middle Guzhangian.

name: Lake Georgetown Spillway
remarks: Outcrops of rudist-bearing shallow water carbonates. Weakly cemented, circular, flat-topped radiolitid–caprinid–toucasid mounds developed above the toucasid mounds and low relief, often sucrosic-dolomitized mounds. Low diversity, with each biohermal stage being composed of one dominant species—caprinids, toucasids, or caprinid–toucasid– radiolitids, respectively.
title: Discovery of a Mississippian Reef in Turkey: The Upper Viséan Microbial-Sponge-Bryozoan-Coral Bioherm From Kongul Yayla (Taurides, S Turkey)

name: Zhangzhai
remarks: The small-scaled reefs are generally domical or lenticular in shape, ranging in height from tens of centimeters to several meters, and in width from less than a meter to more than 10 m. They are chiefly built by benthic microbes, lithistid sponges, the quasi-sponge fossils Calathium as well as bryozoans and are usually surrounded by skeletal/intraclastic grainstones and packstones. Skeletal fragments of ostracods, trilobites, gastropods, brachiopods, nautiloids, and echinoderms are found within the reefs and surrounding sediments. Three reefal types are recognized.
authors: Qijian Li, Yue Li and Wolfgang Kiessling
title: Early Ordovician sponge-Calathium-microbial reefs on the Yangtze Platform margin of the South China Block

In the top part of the reef thin-bedded micritic mudstones occur with rare bioclasts.

The reefs are Upper Toarcian and are from the Middle Atlas Mountains. They consist of bioherms, 1-12m. RCM Note: Unclear on exact location. Reef width and thickness estimated from figure 2 of Lathuiliere 2011, reefs are stacked patches 1-12m thick

name: Topuk Tepe, near Pinargözü

At the top of this sedimentation a reefal fauna is developed with similarities to the cipit fauna. The Topuk Tepe locality is surrounded by reef boulder bearing shales of Kasımlar Formation.

name: Vojsko Plateau
remarks: The major biostrome builders are medium-sized coralline sponges, Demospongea and Calcarea, encrusted by smaller sponges, tube worms, sessile foraminifera, calcareous algae - Archaeolithoporella - and Shamovella - Tubiphytes-, all of which are typically covered by microbial crusts. The biostromes are characteristically composed of bafflestone and bindstone, incorporating sporadic framestone. Narrowbelts of floatstone surround the buildups, and sponge debris is also present in lenseswithin the mud matrix between metazoan bafflestones

This fabric commonly grades intowellpreserved stromatoporoid skeletons, or rarely replace the bulk of each skeleton. Framework basically just Labechia, rare calcimicrobes and bryozoans

name: Precordillera
remarks: Stromatolites, and particularly thrombolites, are ubiquitous and very common components of the higher-frequency cycles. Calcarenites are mainly composed of peloids, well-rounded intraclasts, aggregate lime grains, micritized ooids, and a few bioclasts. Bioclasts are very scarce and include rare calcareous algae such as Nuia sp. and scattered fragments of gastropods, trilobites, and nautiloids within the cross-bedded subtidal grainstone-packstone intervals. Abundant in situ gas- tropods seem intimately related with domical thrombolites.

Carbonates of the Minija Regional Stage serve as a good example of a carbonate ramp system with a stromatoporoid-crinoid- brachiopod-dominated carbonate factory. According to the lithofacies distribution, the ramp can be subdivided into five main facies belts...

title: Sedimentary and environmental history of the Late Permian Bonikowo Reef (Zechstein Limestone, Wuchiapingian), western Poland

name: Tebaga of Medenine
remarks: the northern edge of the Saharan platform. The exposed Permian sequence at Jebel Tebaga of Medenine and Baten Beni Zid consists at least of 850m of marine strata grading to nonmarine red beds. It is made up of local biohermes, thin carbonate beds, bioclastic limestone, sandstone and shale. The main feature of Permian sequence is the abrupt and complex facies changes due to presence of obscure and inferred faults. Particularly, presence of the fusulinacean Yabeina at Oum el Afia section suggests that these rocks are younger than those outcropping at Baten Beni Zid.
authors: Adel Zaafouri, Sofiene Haddad, Beya Mannaî-Tayech
title: Subsurface Permian reef complexes of southern Tunisia: Shelf carbonate setting and paleogeographic implications

name: Penglaitan -Tieqiao
remarks: The overlying Heshan Formation, 150 m in thickness, is composed of black cherty limestone of basinal facies in the lower part and white bioclastic carbonate of sponge reef facies in the upper part. The Late Wuchiapingian reefal carbonates about 91 m in thickness at the Tieqiao Section are reduced to 10 m in thickness at the Penglaitan Section.
authors: Yugan Jin, Shuzhong Shen, Charles M. Henderson, Xiangdong Wang, Wei Wang, Yue Wang, Changqun Cao, Qinghua Shang
title: The Global Stratotype Section and Point (GSSP) for the boundary between the Capitanian and Wuchiapingian Stage (Permian)

name: Gundara valley
remarks: Our preferred palaeoenvironmental reconstruction is one of agglutinated microbial reefs to cluster reefs. The microbial reefs are formed by the cyanobacterial microbialites Tubiphytes and Archaeolithoporella, with a few large cavities filled by botryoidal cements and subordinate skeletal elements. The cluster reefs are made by in-place conical skeletons of Gundaria insolita n. gen. n. sp. that were adjacent but not always in contact with the substrate. The Gundaira insolita were also able to trap loose sediment, which indicates that the reefs are matrixsupported. In-place, pedicle-attached species contributed to the framework and helped trap the matrix. These reefs were likely laterally extensive despite their low topographic relief, which is consistent with the mostly bedded nature of the Gundara Formation. The abundance of matrix and the reduced cementation and bioerosion suggest muddy depositional environments, which were probably deeper and more turbid than those of the Safetdara Formation.
authors: Lucia Angiolini, Mark Campagna, Letizia Borlenghi, Tatiana Grunt, Daniel Vachard, Giovanni Vezzoli, Irene Vuolo, James Worthington, Alda Nicora, Andrea Zanchi
title: Brachiopods from the Cisuralian–Guadalupian of Darvaz, Tajikistan and implications for Permian stratigraphic correlations

name: Dugway
remarks: In the Dugway Range, the massive, cliff-forming, peloidal, stromatoporoid- bearing reef facies is intercalated between thick-bedded, carbonate-platform rocks of the lower Famennian, upper Guilmette Formation below and thin-bedded, upper-slope rocks of the Famennian West Range Limestone above. The carbonate facies in the Dugway Range represent the southernmost extension of carbonate bank that is equivalent to and continuous with the so-called False Birdbear unit of the upper Jefferson Formation in Idaho, the upper limestone unit of the Logan Gulch Member of the Three Forks Formation in Montana, and the Morro Member of the Palliser Formation in Alberta, Canada. Carbonate-bank facies deposition persisted in an extensive, north-south–trending belt from the northern Great Basin into southern Alberta for at least 3 myr until the middle Famennian lower Palmatolepis marginifera biozone.
title: Reef recovery following the Frasnian–Famennian (Late Devonian) mass extinction: evidence from the Dugway Range, west-central Utah

name: Agrio, Pilmatué Member, Loma Rayoso Area
remarks: The studied section belongs to the upper half of the Pilmatué. The coral bed is interpreted as a coral biostrome. It is composed by low ramose coral colonies that did not form a rigid barrier, lacking lateral coalescence and overgrowing.
authors: Ricardo M. Garberoglio, Darío G. Lazo, Ricardo M. Palma
title: An integrate analysis of an Hauterivian coral biostrome from the Agrio Formation, Neuquén Basin, west-central Argentina

name: Rietoog
remarks: Omkyk Member of the Kuibis Subgroup of the Nama Group, at the Driedoornvlagte pinnacle reef complex, near Rietoog. Reef-building by the earliest known skeletal metazoan, the globally distributed Cloudina
authors: A. M. Penny, R. Wood, A. Curtis, F. Bowyer, R. Tostevin, K.-H. Hoffman
title: Ediacaran metazoan reefs from the Nama Group, Namibia

name: Tangwangzhai
remarks: Two outcrop sections (Tangwangzhai and Laopozhuang sections) in Shandong Province. Microbial components comprise microstromatolites, calcified Girvanella filaments, and Renalcis-like botryoid forms. Microstromatolites, which are one of the most common components of the maze-like structures, mostly exhibit convex-up laminae composed of alternating micrite and microsparite
authors: Jeong-Hyun Lee, Jitao Chen, Suk-Joo Choh, Dong-jin Lee, Zuozhen Han, Sung Kwun Chough

name: Tangwangzhai
remarks: Two outcrop sections (Tangwangzhai and Laopozhuang sections, about 20 km distant) in Shandong Province. Microbial components comprise microstromatolites, calcified Girvanella filaments, and Renalcis-like botryoid forms. Microstromatolites, which are one of the most common components of the maze-like structures, mostly exhibit convex-up laminae composed of alternating micrite and microsparite
authors: Jeong-Hyun Lee, Jitao Chen, Suk-Joo Choh, Dong-jin Lee, Zuozhen Han, Sung Kwun Chough

name: Fox Cove
remarks: At the Fox Cove locality, a series of archaeocyathan patch reefs of the lower Forteau Formation. Common components of all thin sections include microbial fabrics, carbonate cement, echinoderms, brachiopods, archaeocyaths and trilobites. Grainstone samples often contain abraded and broken fossil material as well as detrital grains; reef samples are characterized by abundant microbial fabrics with archaeocyathans.
authors: S. B. Pruss, H. Clemente, M. Laflamme
title: Early (Series 2) Cambrian archaeocyathan reefs of southern Labrador as a locus for skeletal carbonate production

name: Herefordshire
remarks: The central part of the buildup is formed by coral bafflestone, partly overlain by brachiopod-rich facies III. The buildup is formed by several pillow-shaped units. The transition to surrounding bedded facies V is gradual. The buildup framework is formed by complete, in situ colonies of rugose and tabulate corals, stromatoporoids and branching bryozoans. The sediment baffled between the framework builders consists of very poorly sorted echinoderm ossicles, brachiopods and rare ?Dimorphosiphon fragments, but the buildup fabric is distinguished by a high (ca 50%) micritic matrix. Allonema and Rothpletzellaare present as crusts and Rothpletzella also as loose accumulations within the matrix. These are associated with mottled, peloidal-like structures containing structures tentatively identified as sponge spicules. The mottled fabrics contain multiple small (up to 0.4 cm wide) stromatactis-like cavities filled with spar, characterized by sharp basal parts and irregular undulating upper parts. In SEM images, oncoids and Rothpletzella accumulations floating in the matrix are built by tubes filled with sparitic cement. The tube walls are 5-6 µm thick, formed by regularly arranged needleshaped calcite crystals oriented perpendicular to the porostromate tube in longitudinal sections and radially in cross sections. In contrast, the mottled, peloidal matrix of facies IV is composed of chaotically arranged microcrystalline calcareous mud containing a high proportion of clay particles and scattered fragments of skeletal grains. The buildup is overlain by nodular wacke- to packstones composed of well-sorted echinoderm, brachiopod, gastropod, trilobite and coral fragments (facies V) and onlapping the units represented by facies II, III and IV.
authors: Jan-Filip Päßler, Emilia Jarochowska, David C. Ray, Axel Munnecke, Graham Worton
title: Aphanitic buildup from the onset of the Mulde Event (Homerian, middle Silurian) at Whitman's Hill, Herefordshire, UK: ultrastructural insights into proposed microbial fabrics

name: Saaremaa
remarks: Due to constant southwards regression and infilling of the BSB, the lagoonal-littoral facies became increasingly dominant all over Saaremaa towards the end of Wenlock. At that time, the shoal facies only reached Saaremaa during short transgressions. A series of upwards shallowing cycles with shoal to lagoonallittoral sediments, often bracketed by discontinuity surfaces, therefore characterizes the Jaagarahu and Rootsiküla stages on Saaremaa
title: Silurian reefs off Saaremaa and their extension towards Gotland, central Baltic Sea

name: Saraburi, Siam City Cement quarry along Highway 2
remarks: Peritidal zone deposits consist of dark carbonaceous mudstones-wackestones and dolomitised laminated algal boundstone beds.
