Secondary Fe-calcite camouflaged the original depositional texture in some parts. Fossils include Schubertella, Girvanella and Gyroporella algae, Hemigordius, Globivalvulina sp. along with other microscopic non-fusuline foraminifera. Peritidal settings were interpreted within Logs 1 and 4 with ages constrained between the late Murgabian to Midian. Platform interior contains three sub-environments: lagoon, the outer platform and the higher energy backreef. The low-energy lagoon is comprised of bioturbated skeletal and peloidal wackestones and packstones with localised interbedded shales. The fossil assemblage contained abundant algae including Girvanella, bivalves (including alatoconchids), fusulinids (N. simplex) and microscopic non-fusuline foraminifera (Globivalvulina, Schubertella, Cribogenerina and Textulariida). The lagoonal environment is interpreted for lower Log 4 and upper Log 6 and deposited in the Murgabian with possible extension into the Midian. The outer platform sub-environment is a non-parallel bedded bioclastic limestone grading from wackestone through to grainstone with boundstone interbeds. Isolated coral clumps were also observed within the grainstone sections. Inner platform settings were interpreted within Logs 1, 2, 5, 7 and 8. The age of the environment was constrained using the fusuline foraminifera (Neoschwagerina simplex, other Neoschwagerina sp., Neofusulinella, Nankinella, Kahlerina, Armenina). The fossil assemblages gave an age within the Murgabian Stage. The higher-energy backreef sub-environment is defined by parallel bedded wackestones and packstones. Backreef settings are interpreted within Logs 5, 6 and 8. Each major fossil group is present in the Highway 21 backreefs: crinoids, fusulinids (Nankinella, Schwagerina, Colania, Neoschwagerina and Gifuella), bivalves (Alatyoconda), non-fusuline foraminif
authors: Romana Dew, Alan Stephen Collins, Francesco Arboit
title: Stratigraphy of deformed Permian carbonate reefs in Saraburi Province of Thailand

name: Akiyoshi and Taishaku
remarks: Palaeoaplysina–microencruster reef community. In a reef-core area of the atoll, the alga Palaeoaplysina acted as a framebuilder and was associated with various binders (e.g., Tubiphytes,Archaeolithoporella, cystoporate bryozoans, and microbialites) and sediment-bafflers such as fenestrate and cryptostomate bryozoans and phylloid algae. In a subtidal environment of the back-reef area, Palaeoaplysina and phylloid algae flourished as sediment-bafflers. A microbial community, including Tubiphytes and sessile foraminifers, was predominant in a very shallow, peritidal environment of the back-reef area.
authors: Tsutomu Nakazawa, Katsumi Ueno, Hodaka Kawahata, Masayuki Fujikawa
title: Gzhelian – Asselian Palaeoaplysina – microencruster reef community in the Taishaku and Akiyoshi limestones, SW Japan: Implications for Late Paleozoic reef evolution on mid-Panthalassan atolls

name: Xinzhai and Longjiangdong Langping
remarks: Coral patch reef, whichis 15 m in width and 20 m in thickness, is composed mainly ofcolonial rugose corals: (Lonsdaleia and Antheria), and Syringo-pora with crinoids filling around them. Longjiangdong biostromal reef is about28 m wide and 15 m thick, grows on crinoidal banks, and hasthree cyclical growth stages. Diphyphyllumis abundant and accessory organisms are crinoids, brachiopods,calcareous algae, and foraminifers (Fig. 5B). The coral patchreef at Longjiangdong is about 20 m wide and 8 m thick. Themain reef-builders are Thysanophyllum and Lithostrotionella(Petalaxis) (colonial rugose coral) with Caninia (solitary rugosecoral) secondarily incorporated. Thysanophylum and Lithostro-tionella successively occur in the reefs in clusters, and Caniniarandomly grows near the clusters. Reef-dwellers are mainlycrinoids. TheLongjiangdong reefs were formed at shallow SW platform margin, and grew and demised due to relative sea-levelrise and fall, resulting from the increasing micrites and sparrycalcite in the reefs and their overlying limestones, respectively
title: Distribution and evolution of Carboniferous reefs in South China

name: Longdianshan Hill, Liuzhou
remarks: The mud banks are composed of a mixture of two basic micro-facies: (1) spiculitic wackestone with diverse fauna includingcryptostome and fenestellid bryozoans, crinoids, ostracodes, andbrachiopods; (2) fine-grained bioclastic wackestone and pack-stone containing crinoids, bryozoans, sponges, brachiopods,ostracodes, and corals. The mud banks developed during a rela-tive sea-level rise in an outer deep platform margin, and died asrelative sea-level fell evidenced from the bioclastic wackestoneand packstone overlying the banks. The mud banks at Longdian-shan are similar to typical Waulsortian mud mounds, as indicatedby the presence of bryozoans, crinoids, and sponges, mud gen-erations and spar-filled cavities
title: Distribution and evolution of Carboniferous reefs in South China

name: Beibuwan
remarks: One 300 m thick core of the late Bashkirian-middle Kasi-movian red algae reef crops out in the Dabu and Huanglongformations at Beibuwan. It is located at shallow SW plat-form margin. Themain constructors are the red algae Parachaetetes and Ung-darella. Reef-dwellers include crinoids and fusulinids. Fivesimilar growth stages, characterized by Parachaetetes and Ung-darella bindstone, can be identified, which are separated by fourgrowth intermissions dominated by dolostones, and the fifthgrowth stage also has some small growth intermissions.
title: Distribution and evolution of Carboniferous reefs in South China

name: Lianyuan and Lengshuijiang, Hunan Province
formation: upper Zimenqiao Formation to lower Dabu Formation
remarks: In Lianyuan and Lengshuijiang cities, HunanProvince, the Serpukhovian-middle Bashkirian massive lime-stones (about 5 m thick) from the upper Zimenqiao Formation tolower Dabu Formation contain abundant benthic fossils includ-ing fasciculate colonial rugose corals, fasciculate tabulate corals,and chaetetids. They locally form bounded frameworks whichresemble the contemporaneous reefs in Akiyoshi, Japan. Besides, stromatolites also occurred in Lianyuan-Lengshuijiang areas during this time
title: Distribution and evolution of Carboniferous reefs in South China

name: Yashui
remarks: The middle Viséan coral biostrome from the Shangsi For-mation at Yashui, which is variable from 2.5 m to 3.9 m inthickness and more than 500 m in width, is composed mainlyof Kueichouphyllum (solitary rugose coral), Syringopora,and Siphonodendron. Associated fossils include brachiopods,crinoids, foraminifers, calcareous algae, gastropods, bryozoans,and ostracodes. In the biostrome, three growthstages have been distinguished, which in ascending order areKueichouphyllum growth stage, Kueichouphyllum-Syringoporagrowth stage, and Siphonodendron growth stage. The biostromeoccurred at shallow DQGX platform margin with its growthand demise controlled by relative sea-level rise and fall, asevidenced from the increasing of micrites and sparry calcitein the biostrome and its overlying limestone, respectively. Compared with the coral reefs, the coral biostromelacks calcimicrobe encrustation and sparry calcite cementation
title: Distribution and evolution of Carboniferous reefs in South China

name: Mengcun and Helü
remarks: Morphologies of these stromatolites include laminar, wavy-laminar, domal or hemispheroidal, bulbous, and flabellate-growth columns. Individual stromatolites are generally 3–6 cm thick, which can grow upward upto 60 cm thick in the core facies. The core-facies of stromatolite mounds were formed by calcimicrobes, with initially horizontal laminar and tabular growthforms later becoming domal and bulbous forms, and finally flabellate columnar forms indicating a gradual relative sea-level rising. The occurrence of talus breccias under and above themounds suggests that they were located at a deep slope setting.
title: Distribution and evolution of Carboniferous reefs in South China

name: Gandongzi village and Xiadong village,, Langping, Guangxi
remarks: Built mainly by the colonial rugose coral Thysanophyllumand the bryozoan Fistulipora, and less frequently by Syringo-pora (tabulate coral) and Lithostrotion (colonial rugose coral). Reef-dwellers include crinoids, brachiopods,solitary rugose corals, cryptostome bryozoans, foraminifers, gastropods, ostracodes, and green algae.Reefal units show four growth stages with the predominantframeworks of Thysanophyllum, Fistulipora, Thysanophyllum,and Fistulipora-Thysanophyllum, intercalated with intraclastic-crinoidal or crinoidal bank facies. The reef-crest is composedof gray thick-bedded algal peloidal packstones, fine bioclasticwackestones interbedded with brachiopod grainstones and pack-stones. The reef was formed at shallow isolated platform marginand died resulting from relative sea-level fall and rise respec-tively, which may be caused by regional rift activities. At Xiadong village, Langping, reef is about 260 m wide and 50 m thick andthe major reef-builders are colonial rugose corals (Diphyphyl-lum, Siphonodendron, and Lithostrotion), and the tabulate coralSyringopora. Reef-dwellers are solitary rugose corals, crinoids,ostracodes, brachiopods, gastropods, bryozoans, and calcareousalgae.
title: Distribution and evolution of Carboniferous reefs in South China

name: Yashui
remarks: formed by in situ upright fasciculate colonial rugosecorals. Preliminary data indicate that dwellers of this coralboundstone include crinoids, brachiopods, foraminifers, ostra-codes, gastropods, bryozoans, calcareous algae, and solitaryrugose corals. This coral boundstone was located at shal-low SW platform margin during the early Bashkirian, and it grew and died as relative sea-level rose and fell respec-tively, evidenced from increasing micrites and sparry calcite inthe boundstone and its overlying limestone, respectively. Therefore, the Serpukhovian-middle Bashkirian has the poten-tial for reef development, and the discovery of reefs is to be made
title: Distribution and evolution of Carboniferous reefs in South China

name: Benxi Area, Liaoning
remarks: Benxi Area, Liaoning Chaetetes – coral reef. At the beginning of the Pennsylvanian, a massive south-north transgression occurred in this region. The sedimentary environment changed from fan delta to fiord coast and then into a carbonate platform, and thus several reefs with a nearly east-west trend were built on the nearshore side of the platform. These reefs are relatively small, with thickness of 2–4 m. There are abundant benthic organisms found in these reefs, and the biotic content is up to 60% of the reef volume. Arachnastraea manchurica and Chaetetes penchiensis are the dominant building organisms in these reefs. Their colonial skeletons are tabular in shape with varying thickness. Multithecopora penchiensis is the secondary building organism in the reefs of this region, and it mainly occur in the spaces between Chaetetes and Arachnastraea. There are also such binding organisms in the reef as Archaeolithoporella and Girvanella. The organisms associated with the Chaetetes coral reef are fusulinids, foraminiferans, brachiopods, ostracodas, bryozoans, gastropods and various genera of algae.
authors: Gong Enpu, Zhang Yongli, Guan Changqing, Chen Xiaohong
title: The Carboniferous reefs in China

name: Eastern Tianshan, Xinjiang
remarks: occurred in the Tianshan-Xingan active ocean trough. Coral pach reef, bryozoan-calcareous algae mound
authors: Gong Enpu, Zhang Yongli, Guan Changqing, Chen Xiaohong
title: The Carboniferous reefs in China

name: Beibuwan Area, Guangxi
remarks: Parachaetetes and Ungdarella are the main reef-building organisms. Calcareous green algae are also associated with these reefs
authors: Gong Enpu, Zhang Yongli, Guan Changqing, Chen Xiaohong
title: The Carboniferous reefs in China

name: Pahvant Range, Utah
remarks: the oldest reefs consist of small (ca. 5mm) sponges encrusting thin bivalve shell layers, which probably facilitated their settlement and enhanced their preservation. Although these sponges are preserved in life position, their initial essentially globular shape now seems compacted. The sponges are associated with small serpulids within a very abundant micritic matrix, and with common echinoderm plates (probably crinoids) locally reworked as bioclastic accumulations in storm-induced deposits. These biostromes, tens of centimetres thick, are formed by alternating gregarious settling and hydraulic reworking. The latter leads to multiple short-term events of hard-part concentrations in a low to moderate energy mid ramp environment. Isolated sponges are also found within overlying beds, identified only by sparse bundles of spicules. Sponges occur a few metres higher in recurrent large (ca. 50 m of lateral exposure) lenticular ca. 5- cm-thick layers, throughout a ca. 20 m-thick stratigraphic interval. These sponges are preserved in situ as lenticular reefs composed of small coalesced spheres (ca. 1 cm in diameter) that resemble lyssacine hexactinellids bound by submillimetre-scale biofilms. Within the lowermost Spathian PR beds, serpulids form small millimetre to centimetre-consortia with abundant ostracods, brachiopods and rare gastropods, alternating with tempestite deposits
authors: Arnaud Brayard, Emmanuelle Vennin, Nicolas Olivier, Kevin G. Bylund, Jim Jenks, Daniel A. Stephen, Hugo Bucher, Richard Hofmann, Nicolas Goudemand, Gilles Escarguel
title: Transient metazoan reefs in the aftermath of the end-Permian mass extinction

name: Mineral Mountains, Utah
remarks: Early Smithian reef deposits are characterized by more diverse sponge morphologies. The oldest sponges are embedded within microbialites forming reefs, tens of centimetres thick, distributed throughout a massive (up to 10m high) microbial carbonate unit. These microbialites are composed of centimetre-scale stromatolitic domes and thrombolites sealed off by micrite. Complete cup- to flat-shape and dendroid centimetre-scale sponges are preserved, resting on micrite matrix or encrusting microbialitic crusts. They show an internal re-crystallized spiculitic network and are often partially to completely dissolved and replaced by calcite-cemented cavities.
authors: Arnaud Brayard, Emmanuelle Vennin, Nicolas Olivier, Kevin G. Bylund, Jim Jenks, Daniel A. Stephen, Hugo Bucher, Richard Hofmann, Nicolas Goudemand, Gilles Escarguel
title: Transient metazoan reefs in the aftermath of the end-Permian mass extinction

name: Willow Spring locality, Olds Ferry terrane, Blue Mountains Province, northeastern Oregon
remarks: Upper member of the Huntington Formation (Olds Ferry terrane) at a locality. Corals at the site include a high-growing, dendroid-phaceloid species that acted as either framework or sediment baffles, and a lowgrowing, cerioid, encrusting coral and a sponge that acted as sediment herein named Willow Spring. binders. Together, these organisms produced at least a 10–50 cm high reef-like or reefal framework. Framework mineralogy of sandstones and clast types in the conglomerate suggest that the source of these Triassic coral-sponge reef faunas was intrabasinal. The occurrence of the same two coral taxa in the Wallowa and Olds Ferry terranes may support the proximity of these two regions in the late Triassic, but the presence of these taxa in other Cordilleran terranes suggests that they are probably cosmopolitan and therefore not good indicators of terrane proximity.
authors: Todd A. Lamaskin, George D. Stanley, Andrew H. Caruthers, Megan R. Rosenblatt
title: Detrital record of upper Triassic reefs in the olds ferry terrane, blue mountains province, northeastern Oregon, United States

name: Paluma Shoals, Halifax Bay
remarks: The palaeoecological assemblages of the PSRC are representative of inner-shelf reef communities across the central GBR, which are characterised by mixed assemblages of acroporids (Montipora, and locally abundant Acropora), dendrophyllids (Turbinaria), euphylliids (Euphyllia and Galaxea), and poritids (Goniopora and Porites). The composition of inner-shelf coral communities distinguishes them from those associated with mid- and outer-shelf reefs, which are predominantly characterised by assemblages of Acropora
authors: J. A. Johnson, C. T. Perry, S. G. Smithers, K. M. Morgan, N. Santodomingo, K. G. Johnson
title: Palaeoecological records of coral community development on a turbid, nearshore reef complex: baselines for assessing ecological change

name: Stadion locality
remarks: diverse assemblage that includes corals, foraminifers, coralline algae, bryozoans, and mollusks. In addition, some echinoid spines, serpulid tubes, small brachiopods, and crustacean chelae were found within the sediments or cemented to coral surfaces. low-relief patch reef
authors: Nadiezhda Santodomingo, Vibor Novak, Vedrana Pretković, Nathan Marshall, Emanuela Di Martino, Elena Lo Giudice Capelli, Anja Roesler, Sonja Reich, Juan Carlos Braga, Willem Renema, Kenneth G Johnson
title: A diverse patch reef from turbid habitats in the middle Miocene (East Kalimantan, Indonesia)

name: Jiulongshan, Laiwu
remarks: lower part of the Zhangxia Formation (Crepicephalina Zone: Drumian of Cambrian Series 3). The coralomorph-bearing lithistid demosponge-microbial reefs are intercalated within bioclastic wackestone beds. Thin veneers of stromatolites. In places, sheet-like micrite layers and knobshaped stromatolites consisting of vesicular and globular clots pave the underlying wackestone. The underlying wackestone was stabilized by microbial consolidation, which then provided suitable substrates for the microbial reefs. Bioclastic wackestone is thus conformably overlain by the basal parts of the microbial reefs.
authors: Ezaki, Y., Liu, J., Adachi, N., and Yan, Z.
title: Microbialite development during the protracted inhibition of skeletal-dominated reefs in the Zhangxia Formation (Cambrian Series 3) in Shandong Province, North China

name: South end of the Franklin Mountains at El Paso, Texas
remarks: Small metazoan-microbial reefs, massive, barrel- to lens-shaped bioherms a few meters high and 2–5 meters across. in situ biotic builders are microbialites (mainly thrombolites) and lithistid, calathid, and pulchrilaminid sponges; many are dominated by thrombolites, some are dominated by Calathium, and a few are dominated by lithistid sponges.
authors: Björn Kröger, André Desrochers, Andrej Ernst
title: The reengineering of reef habitats during the great ordovician biodiversification event

name: Ile de la Grosse Romaine
remarks: Mostly composed of peritidal and open-shelf carbonates. Well-developed thrombolite mounds occur in the middle part of the Romaine Formation either as small submeter isolated bioherms or as closely spaced buildups forming larger bioherm complexes up to 6 m high and several tens of meters wide.
authors: Björn Kröger, André Desrochers, Andrej Ernst
title: The reengineering of reef habitats during the great ordovician biodiversification event

name: Ile à la Chasse
remarks: Coalescent metersized thrombolite heads with a distinctive macroscopic clotted appearance exhibiting a cerebroid pattern in plan view and a digitate branching pattern in cross-section. They are flanked by a ripple-laminated to cross-bedded skeletal dolograinstone interpreted as coarse bioclastic haloes or channels separating individual bioherm complexes.
authors: Björn Kröger, André Desrochers, Andrej Ernst
title: The reengineering of reef habitats during the great ordovician biodiversification event

name: Hudson Platform on Southampton Island
remarks: At the northern end of the Hudson Bay, the massive cores have been loosely described in the past as micritic, algal, or microbial limestones with metazoans. The Red Head Rapids Formation mounds are locally partly dolomitized. The reefs contain large voids and vugs that are locally filled with bitumen and dead oil, composed of boundstone and cementstone with various proportions of early calcified sponge tissues, microbial encrusters, synsedimentary cement and small metazoans. The accretionary mechanisms of the Red Head Rapids Formation were mainly the result of frame building by early calcified sponges and small colonial corals and binding by calcimicrobial elements for the boundstone facies, and of marine cement precipitation near the seafloor for the cementstone facies.
authors: Denis Lavoie, Ariane Castagner, Omid Haeri Ardakani, André Desrochers
title: Upper Ordovician reefs in the Hudson Bay Basin: Porosity evolution and hydrocarbon charge

name: Bernatai
remarks: Reservoir oil. Limstone reef.
authors: Shengyu Yang, Hans-Martin Schulz, Niels Hemmingsen Schovsbo, and Jørgen A. Bojesen-Koefoed
title: Oil-source rock correlation of the Lower Palaeozoic petroleum system in the Baltic Basin (northern Europe)

name: Brattefors
remarks: Limstone reef. Oil samples from the Brattefors quarry are characterized by pyrene concentrations higher than phenanthrene. Oil samples from Brattefors quarry in south central Sweden were heated by volcanic intrusions with high pyrene/phenanthrene ratios and have C29 S/R sterane ratios significantly beyond the normal thermodynamic threshold.
authors: Shengyu Yang, Hans-Martin Schulz, Niels Hemmingsen Schovsbo, and Jørgen A. Bojesen-Koefoed
title: Oil-source rock correlation of the Lower Palaeozoic petroleum system in the Baltic Basin (northern Europe)

name: Rute-1
remarks: Limestone reef.
authors: Shengyu Yang, Hans-Martin Schulz, Niels Hemmingsen Schovsbo, and Jørgen A. Bojesen-Koefoed
title: Oil-source rock correlation of the Lower Palaeozoic petroleum system in the Baltic Basin (northern Europe)

name: Adze-6
remarks: Limstone reef.
authors: Shengyu Yang, Hans-Martin Schulz, Niels Hemmingsen Schovsbo, and Jørgen A. Bojesen-Koefoed
title: Oil-source rock correlation of the Lower Palaeozoic petroleum system in the Baltic Basin (northern Europe)

name: Jabal Al - Abakkayn
remarks: Coral facies-capped cycles with bioherms
title: Stratigraphic evolution of the Late Jurassic Hanifa Formation along the Tuwaiq Escarpment, Saudi Arabia: evidence for a carbonate ramp system

name: Raghbah
remarks: Coral buildups. Prominent bench formed by the cross-bedded peloidal-skeletal grainstone facies. Grainstone and bioherm facies that can be traced over relatively long distances
title: Stratigraphic evolution of the Late Jurassic Hanifa Formation along the Tuwaiq Escarpment, Saudi Arabia: evidence for a carbonate ramp system

name: Wadi Al-Ain 6
remarks: Carbonate ramp. Close (~150 km) to large commercial hydrocarbon fields in Saudi Arabia
title: Stratigraphic evolution of the Late Jurassic Hanifa Formation along the Tuwaiq Escarpment, Saudi Arabia: evidence for a carbonate ramp system

name: Wadi Dirab
remarks: Bioturbated spiculitic wackestone/mud-dominated packstone facies. The facies is characterized by crumbly appearance and nodular bedding produced by bioturbation. Hardground surface encrusted with oysters. Sponge spicules in a micritic matrix. Mud-dominated packstone with sponge spicules, echinoids, and the foraminifera species, Redmondoides lugeoni, Photomicrograph of wackestone with sponge spicules, echinoids and brachiopods
title: Stratigraphic evolution of the Late Jurassic Hanifa Formation along the Tuwaiq Escarpment, Saudi Arabia: evidence for a carbonate ramp system

name: Dalmiapuram limestone quarry
remarks: Ostracods, bryozoans, gastropod fragments. Grey shale with frequent interbeds of fossiliferous grey limestone (the thickness of which increases upwards) and to a minor extent it is composed of a significant admixture of silt-sized siliciclastics. Coral algal limestone.
title: Occurrence of Arctostrea: Existence of high nergy Paleoenvironment in Cauvery basin, India during Late Cretaceous.
paper: International Journal of Scientific & Engineering Research

name: Nanjiang, Shatan section
remarks: Microbial reefs containing archaeocyaths, up to 1.5 m thick, are composed of massive to lenticular thrombolites with densely distributed, millimeter- to centimeter-scale darker mesoclots and rare archaeocyaths. These microbial reefs are enclosed by wackestone–packstone, intraclast packstone– grainstone, ooid packstone–grainstone, calcareous shale, and fine sandstone. The thrombolites are composed mainly of Girvanella, micritic clumps, and subordinate Epiphyton.
authors: Meiqi Zhang, Jongsun Hong, Suk-Joo Choh, Dong-Jin Lee
title: Thrombolite reefs with archaeocyaths from the Xiannüdong Formation (Cambrian Series 2), Sichuan, China: implications for early Paleozoic bioconstruction

name: La Désirade Island, Lesser Antilles
remarks: The coral layers are dominated by either scattered domal and thick lamellar colonies of Diploria spp., in life position or elkhorn Acropora palmata represented by up to 2-m-thick coral patches or coral breccia. An irregular erosive surface incises up to 2 m depth into the top of Unit 1. Unit 2 consists of the three following layers. Scattered thick lamellar Diploria sp. and domal Orbicella colonies in life position, columnar Orbicella spp. patches up to 4 m thick and 100 m long, and rare, scattered Acropora palmata. Coral patches form bioherms and are surrounded and overlain by m-thick-bedded, coarse-grained calcarenites with clay, and by dm-to-m-thick-bedded and clayey, sand-supported red breccia. These breccia include pebbles from the substratum, dm-toover- m-sized coral fragments, and a few bioclasts.
authors: E. Vernhet, G. Conesa, P.-O. Bruna
title: Reworking processes and deposits in coral reefs during (very) high-energy events: Example from a Pleistocene coral formation (125 ka), La Désirade Island, Lesser Antilles

name: Kampung Lembah Tuwi, near Kangar
remarks: These dome-shaped microbialites grew directly on skeletal packstones and grainstones with abundant oncoids. Laterally, the massive microbial boundstone grades into surrounding bioclastic limestones. The microbial reefs are mainly composed of cylindrical columnar stromatolites (8- 35 cm wide and 30-105 cm high), with a distinct laminar texture present over the weathered surfaces. Several stromatolites usually occur alongside each other and are packed together, creating a frame-like cluster structure. Interspaces between stromatolites are often filled with Calathium. lithistid sponge-microbial bafflelbindstones that generally lack recognizable lamination and are characterized by in situ sponges
title: The first report of Ordovician reefs from Peninsular Malaysia
paper: Extended Summaries for the International Geoscience Programme (IGCP) Project 653 --Annual Meeting 2017

name: Mt. Ishidate1, Befu-Kito area
remarks: Massive limestone slab.sponge-dominated reefs during the Late Carnian–Norian to Rhaetian?. abundance of Chaetetids, and the presence of Galeanella sp., Microtubus communis, Decapoalina schaeferae, Alpinophragmium perforatum and Actinotubella gusici. significant reef framework (40–60% of the rock volume)
authors: Camille Peybernes, Jérôme Chablais, Tetsuji Onoue, Gilles Escarguel, Rossana Martini
title: Paleoecology, biogeography, and evolution of reef ecosystems in the Panthalassa Ocean during the Late Triassic: Insights from reef limestone of the Sambosan Accretionary Complex, Shikoku, Japan

name: Mt. Ishidate2, Befu-Kito area
remarks: Massive limestone slab. sponge-microbialite boundstones. Abundance of sponges. The reef framework represents a relatively low volume and does not exceed 33%. High abundances of Tubiphytes and peloidal and clotted micrite.
authors: Camille Peybernes, Jérôme Chablais, Tetsuji Onoue, Gilles Escarguel, Rossana Martini
title: Paleoecology, biogeography, and evolution of reef ecosystems in the Panthalassa Ocean during the Late Triassic: Insights from reef limestone of the Sambosan Accretionary Complex, Shikoku, Japan

name: Wajiki area, Anan, Tokushima prefecture
remarks: Reef limestone clasts crop out, along with basaltic clasts and limestone clasts of other facies, in a VCM breccia. This unit is in tectonic contact with recrystallized massive limestone slabs. Reef limestone crops out in VCM breccia. The reef framework volume is relatively low (approximately 30%) but sponges are comparatively abundant (21%) and Tubiphytes are rare. Sponge-dominated reefs.
authors: Camille Peybernes, Jérôme Chablais, Tetsuji Onoue, Gilles Escarguel, Rossana Martini
title: Paleoecology, biogeography, and evolution of reef ecosystems in the Panthalassa Ocean during the Late Triassic: Insights from reef limestone of the Sambosan Accretionary Complex, Shikoku, Japan

name: Hellnmaria Member
remarks: Tightly packed round to sub-round microbialites.Microbialites in zone 1 are stromatolitic, have diameters of between 10 to 30 cm at their longer axes, and are typically 20–40 cm tall. Synoptic relief is about 10–20 cm. The interspace material is an intra-bioclastic grainstone with some minor packstone domains. Allochems, predominantly composed of intraclasts (50%) and trilobite bioclasts (40%), average 0.5–4 mm in length, appear moderately sorted, sub-rounded, but generally are not spherical. Some trilobite bioclasts are over 1 cm long. Zone 1 microbialites have a small areal distribution of about 1 km2. Microbialites in zone 2, which cover the majority of the bed, are also stromatolitic, have diameters that vary from 40 to 70 cm across their longer axes, and have heights that fluctuate from a few dm to about 70 cm. Synoptic relief is about 10–20 cm. The interspace material is an intrabioclastic grainstone with some minor packstone domains. Allochems, predominantly composed of intraclasts (70%) and trilobite bioclasts (20%) average 0.5–2 mm in length, appear well-sorted, well-rounded, and are sub-spherical. These microbialites are chiefly differentiated from those in zone 1 by the presence of a central core composed of mini-stromatolites. Sponges are recognized as spicule networks that typically do not exceed a few cm in size, with many not exceeding 1 cm
authors: Ken P. Coulson, Leonard R. Brand
title: Lithistid Sponge-Microbial Reef-Building Communities Construct Laminated, Upper Cambrian (furongian) 'Stromatolites'

name: Fins, Sharqiyah region
remarks: The micritic to microspariticmatrix supports fragments of red algae, corals, small bivalves, echinoid with syntaxial overgrowth, monaxon sponge spicules (some made of silica, some made of calcium carbonate) and bryozoans. The vuggy pores of a dissolved coral are partly filled with equant, drusy calcite cement
authors: Frank Mattern, Daniel Moraetis, Iftikhar Abbasi, Bushra Al Shukaili, Andreas Scharf, Michel Claereboudt, Elayne Looker, Nihal Al Haddabi, Bernhard Pracejus
title: Coastal dynamics of uplifted and emerged late Pleistocene near-shore coral patch reefs at fins (eastern coastal Oman, Gulf of Oman)

name: Carysfort Outlier Reef, Florida
remarks: Substage 5a reef growth recorded from -15 to -11 m MSL, spanning an age range of 86.2-80.9 ka. Shallow fore- and back-reef facies dominated by the head corals Montastrea annularis and Colpophylia natans, and the branching coral Acropora palmata.
title: Submerged Late Pleistocene reefs on the tectonically-stable S.E. Florida margin: high-precision geochronology, stratigraphy, resolution of Substage 5a sea-level elevation, and orbital forcing.

name: Chanakhchi section, near the village of Zangakatun
remarks: Sponge-microbial build-ups, thrombolitic biostromes
authors: Evelyn Friesenbichler, Sylvain Richoz, Aymon Baud, Leopold Krystyn, Lilit Sahakyan, Sargis Vardanyan, Jörn Peckmann, Joachim Reitner, Katrin Heindel
title: Sponge-microbial build-ups from the lowermost Triassic Chanakhchi section in southern Armenia: Microfacies and stable carbon isotopes

name: Vacuum, Lea County, New Mexico
remarks: a calcisponge-microbialite reef
authors: Gregory P. Wahlman, David M. Orchard, Govert J. Buijs
title: Calcisponge-microbialite reef facies, middle Permian (lower Guadalupian), northwest shelf margin of Permian Basin, New Mexico

name: Kamień Pomorski platform - Benice
remarks: Within the Main Dolomite carbonates of Poland, the most common organosedimentary structures are microbial laminites, stromatolites, and thrombolites, mostly developed in inter- to subtidal facies . The intertidal facies are chiefly composed of planar stromatolites (<50 cm [20 in.] thick) and thrombolites (20 cm[8 in.] thick). Planar stromatolites mainly contain even laminae that consist of light (muddy)-gray and dark (organic) couplets of microsparitic dolomite and darkgray micritic dolomite (deposited in restricted lagoons and intertidal pools). They commonly contain fenestrae filled with sulfate. Micritic organic layers contain algal remains (Mizzia), ostracods and rare foraminifera, coated grains, and peloids, and are built of coccoid-like organomineral forms and microbial filaments. Oncoids and peloids formgrainy planar stromatolites (deposited in inner ooid shoals and tidal channels), dolomitic grainstone, and packstone.
authors: Mirosław Słowakiewicz, Maurice E. Tucker, Richard D. Pancost, Edoardo Perri, Michael Mawson
title: Upper Permian (Zechstein) microbialites: Supratidal through deep subtidal deposition, source rock, and reservoir potential

name: Little Cedar Creek, SW Alabama
remarks: Hydrocarbon-productive microbial and high energy, nearshore carbonate facies were deposited in shallow subtidal water depths in an inner ramp. The buildups are composed of thrombolites. The microbially influenced facies is present throughout the field area, but the thrombolite buildups are restricted to the southern part of the field. The microbially influenced facies varies in texture from packstone to lime mudstone. The packstone is a reservoir in parts of the field, and the lime mudstone serves as part of the updip lateral seal in the northeastern area of the field. Upper grainstone and packstone reservoir and lower boundstone and packstone reservoir are interbedded with three lime mudstone and dolomudstone to wackestone units (upper peritidal, middle deeper water subtidal, and lower transgressive subtidal) throughout the field. And to the northeast and updip in well permit 13,976, the Smackover section essentially consists of lime mudstone and dolomudstone, supporting the interpretation that the petroleum trap for this field is stratigraphic. The thrombolites consist of clotted peloidal boundstone and include a microfauna of benthic foraminifera, ostracods, bivalves, and microtubules.
authors: Ernest A. Mancini, William C. Parcell, Wayne M. Ahr, Victor O. Ramirez, Juan Carlos Llinas, Milo Cameron
title: Upper Jurassic updip stratigraphic trap and associated Smackover microbial and nearshore carbonate facies, eastern Gulf coastal plain

name: Black Warrior Basin of Alabama
remarks: Sponge-microbial boundstone composed primarily of spiculitic clots embedded in a detrital carbonatematrix The mound was buried by foreshoal grainstone, much of which is brecciated. Upper Tuscumbia bryozoan-crinoid grainstone formed in a mobile shoal that quickly aggraded to sea level. Echinoderm debris, brachiopods and bryozoans are abundant. Rugose corals, trilobites, ostracods, and sponges are less common
authors: David C. Kopaska-Merkel, Steven D. Mann, Jack C. Pashin
title: Sponge-microbial mound facies in Mississippian Tuscumbia Limestone, Walker County, Alabama

name: Assoul, High Atlas
remarks: Microbial mound. Mud mound surrounding by cross-bedded oolitic grainstone. As much as 25% of clastic sediments. Microbialites and sponges and ooids within growth cavities. Inner ramp
authors: Frédéric Amour, Maria Mutti, Nicolas Christ, Adrian Immenhauser, Gregory S. Benson, Susan M. Agar, Sara Tomás, Lahcen Kabiri
title: Outcrop analog for an oolitic carbonate ramp reservoir: A scale-dependent geologic modeling approach based on stratigraphic hierarchy

name: Assoul coral microbial, High Atlas
remarks: Coral-microbialsponge reef: scleractinian corals, microbialites, calcareous and siliceous sponges. Distal middle to outer ramp
authors: Frédéric Amour, Maria Mutti, Nicolas Christ, Adrian Immenhauser, Gregory S. Benson, Susan M. Agar, Sara Tomás, Lahcen Kabiri
title: Outcrop analog for an oolitic carbonate ramp reservoir: A scale-dependent geologic modeling approach based on stratigraphic hierarchy

name: Assoul - Molluscan-coralsponge reef, High Atlas
remarks: Oysters, brachiopods, bivalves, scleractinian corals, calcareous sponges, and demosponges. Local deposition of marl. Microencrustation by microbialites, bryozoans, and cyanobacteria. Geopetal fabric. Distal middle ramp
authors: Frédéric Amour, Maria Mutti, Nicolas Christ, Adrian Immenhauser, Gregory S. Benson, Susan M. Agar, Sara Tomás, Lahcen Kabiri
title: Outcrop analog for an oolitic carbonate ramp reservoir: A scale-dependent geologic modeling approach based on stratigraphic hierarchy

name: Hadahid fault
remarks: Poorly cemented, structureless carbonate that contains gastropods, coral, and bivalves. These carbonates are thin (<2 m, laterally discontinuous (up to ca. 300 m wide), and based on the faunal assemblage, are interpreted to have been deposited in small, patch-reef-like buildups
authors: Matthew M. Lewis, Christopher A.-L. Jackson, Robert L. Gawthorpe, Paul S. Whipp
title: Early synrift reservoir development on the flanks of extensional forced folds: A seismic-scale outcrop analog from the Hadahid fault system, Suez rift, Egypt

name: Ermenek area, Mut Basin
remarks: Corals mostly consist of Porites and a few Tarabestrella and Faviidae (hemispherical form). The matrix is composed of fragments of red algae, echinoderms, some bivalves, and gastropods. Frequent small and large benthic foraminifera are found depending on the position along the depositional profile. Encrusting algae and rhodoliths are binding a matrix composed of large benthic foraminifera and bivalves, coral fragments, and some gastropods. Abundant red-algae debris associated with common bivalves, echinoderms, and large benthic foraminifera such as Heterestegina and Amphistegina. Bryozoan and oyster debris can be frequent in some place. Occasional Porites and rare gastropods can be found.
authors: Xavier Janson, Gregor P. Eberli, Florence Bonnaffe, Fabrice Gaumet, Vincent De Casanove
title: Seismic expressions of a Miocene prograding carbonate margin, Mut Basin, Turkey

name: Hantang, Guilin platform
remarks: Hantang mounds represent a microbe-dominated reef-building community with rare skeletal reef builders. The microbial mounds are composed almost exclusively of calcimicrobes, including Renalcis, Rothpletzella, Girvanell, Izhella, Ortonella, Wetheredella and a Stenophycus-like microbe. Mound-building metazoans and metaphytes include receptaculitids, solenoporoid algae, spiculate and stromatoporoid sponges, and massive corals, but the volumes of these skeletal organisms are low. Synsedimentary cements are volumetrically important in the mounds and supported and reinforced the microbial frameworks. The microbial facies can be divided into five sub-facies. In roughly ascending stratigraphic order, they are:(i) Rothpletzella-receptaculitid fabric; (ii) Rothpletzella boundstone fabric: (iii)stromatolite-thrombolite fabric;(iv) Rothpletzella-encruster fabric; and (v)Renalcis fabric.
authors: Jianwei Shen, Gregory E. Webb, Hairuo Qing
title: Microbial mounds prior to the Frasnian-Famennian mass extinctions, Hantang, Guilin, South China

name: Napoleon quarry
remarks: Small build-ups composed primarily of micrite and benthic skeletal remains, termed micro-bioherms.
title: Palaeontological and sedimentological effects of micro-bioherms in the Middle Silurian Massie Formation of southeastern Indiana, USA

name: Paojianggou, SW Tarim Basin
remarks: A Beresella-dominated algal mound. Komia bafflestone of the foremound facies further increased the relief of the crinoid bank on the seafloor. The lower part of the mound framework is dominated by Shamovella–Archaeolithoporella boundstone, while the main (upper) mound framework consists predominantly of Beresella boundstone. Grainstone–packstone characterizes the windward mound flank facies. The mound capping facies include a lower skeletal packstone–wackestone and an upper lagoon facies marlstone and black shale. Various algal colonies performed different roles in the formation of the mound. Komia colonies were the mound constructors that baffled higher energy currents and entrapped fine sediment. Archaeolithoporella, Shamovella and possibly microbes (cyanobacteria) acted as the binders to stabilize mud and fine-grained sediment. Beresella colonies were the major framework constructors whose network entrapped the mud to build the mound.
title: A Late Carboniferous algal mound from the Tarim Basin, NW China: internal structure and palaeoecology

name: Kasim and Walio
remarks: Carbonate fabrics include skeletal wackestones, skeletal packstone, framestone, lime mudstone, and bindstone in order of decreasing occurrences. The skeletal grains are strongly modified by dolomitisation, but were originally dominated by corals and red algae, echinoderms, large and planktonic foraminifera. Lime mud matrix has been recrystallised. The widespread occurrence of corals and red algae is strongly suggestive of deposition in proximity to reefal buildups.
title: Re-Evaluation of the Sedimentology and Evolution of the Kais Carbonate Platform, Salawati Basin, Eastern Indonesia: Exploration Significance

name: Bermejo field, NW Oriente Basin
remarks: Carbonate buildup or a patch reef. Dark and rough top surface and irregular edges. The dip map of the M1 carbonate buildup exhibits dark surface areas and irregular edges, suggesting karst features and mechanical fractures, respectively. The isopach map of the M1 carbonate buildup is even more complex, suggesting localized carbonate growth and weathering. The high but variable seismic amplitude of the top surface of the M1 carbonate buildup may also suggest weathering. The carbonate buildup can contain bbl of liquid.
authors: Gwang H. Lee, John P. Castagna
title: Untested carbonate buildups in the Bermejo field, Ecuador: A potential new play type in the western Oriente Basin

name: Götzis locality, 10 km SW of Dornbirn, Vorarlberg
remarks: Facies type 6b. Patch reefs are composed of corals, stromatoporoids, and bryozoans.
title: Scleractinian corals from the upper Berriasian of central Europe and comparison with contemporaneous coral assemblages

name: Jeddah, Sharm Obhur
remarks: A temporarily exposed 6-m succession of raised reefal limestone terrace. The clayey layer showed higher species richness (65 species) than the limestone layer (18 species), indicating a rapid change in the coral reef environment during the deposition of the interval of MIS 5e.
authors: Ramadan H. Abu-Zied, Rashad A. Bantan
title: Late Pleistocene gastropods from the raised reefal limestone of Jeddah, Saudi Arabia: taxonomic and palaeoenvironmental implications

name: Gawadar and Jiwani, Balochistan coast
remarks: The coral colonies were scattered in large patches on about more than 1-km area. The habitat was mostly rocky, composed of sand stones with fine and coarse sand, boulders and mudstone. Thirty coral species were recorded at this site. Many species were found scattered but a considerable proportion was tightly packed. Coral cover was about 33%. Prominent genera were Favia (11%) and Favites (4%).
authors: Amjad Ali, Pirzada Jamal A. Siddiqui, Kate Bromfield, Athar Ali Khan, Pervaiz Iqbal
title: Quaternary fossil coral communities in uplifted strata along the Balochistan coast of Pakistan: understanding modern coral decline in the Arabian Sea

name: Subeigo section (maceriate), Wuhai
remarks: Maze-like maceriate reef with siliceous sponges and microstromatolites
authors: Lee Jeong-Hyun, Kim Byeong-Jun, Liang Kun, Park Tae-Yoon S., Choh Suk-Joo, Lee Dong-Jin, Woo Jusun
title: Cambrian Reefs in the Western North China Platform, Wuhai, Inner Mongolia

name: Subeigo section (Thrombolite), Wuhai
remarks: Thrombolite, characterized by meter-scale lenticular mounds composed of millimeter- to centimeter-scale mesoclots and wackestone matrix. Thrombolite mesoclots are composed of microstromatolites with alternating dark gray and light gray micritic laminae. Bioturbated micrites that occupy spaces between the mesoclots contain trilobite fragments. Three types of bioturbation are recognized.
authors: Lee Jeong-Hyun, Kim Byeong-Jun, Liang Kun, Park Tae-Yoon S., Choh Suk-Joo, Lee Dong-Jin, Woo Jusun
title: Cambrian Reefs in the Western North China Platform, Wuhai, Inner Mongolia

name: Yangba section
remarks: Microbial carbonate. Thrombolites, laminites, oncolites and stromatolites dominate. The microbial dolostone reservoirs are low in porosity and permeability.
authors: Jinmin Song, Shugen Liu, Hairuo Qing, Luba Jansa, Zhiwu Li, Ping Luo, Di Yang, Wei Sun, Hanlin Peng, Tong Lin
title: The depositional evolution, reservoir characteristics, and controlling factors of microbial carbonates of Dengying Formation in upper Neoprotozoic, Sichuan Basin, Southwest China

name: Katnikova Cave, Nizhnie Sergi
remarks: Packstone bed cropping out near the waterline of the Serga River, with a high content (60%) of crinoid stem fragments. This bed represents the base of a series of 15 thin gradational members separated by beds of dark calcareous clay shale. The bed of bioclastic argillaceous limestone sedimentologically represents fore-reef proximal carbonate debris.
title: Elgaecrinus uralicus gen. et sp. nov., a new crotalocrinitid (Crinoidea, Echinodermata) from the Lower Devonian (Lochkovian) of the Middle Urals

name: Shijiezigou section, Guyuan City
remarks: Patch reef in an open platform has a variety of corals that are preserved in situ. Reef-dwelling organisms include dasycladaceans, crinoids and gastropods. Other layers of the section are bedded limestones, many of which bear corals and crinoids, while others bear dasycladaceans or only the Dasycladacea genus Vermiporella. It contains abundant and diverse tabulate corals, which form bafflestones
authors: Lijing Zheng, Hongping Bao, Yasheng Wu, Liuyi Sun, Hongxia Jiang, Junfeng Ren, Zhengliang Huang, Lijing Liu
title: Distinguishing coral reef facies from coral-bearing open platform facies: Examples from Ordovician Ordos Basin, Northwest China

name: Barzok section
remarks: Coral boundstone, formed by in situ fauna as organic patch reefs, in openmarine settings.
authors: Ebrahim Mohammadi, Mahboubeh Hasanzadeh‑Dastgerdi, Amrollah Safari, Hossein Vaziri‑Moghaddam
title: Microfacies and depositional environments of the Qom Formation in Barzok area, SW Kashan, Iran

name: Gebel Raghawi section
remarks: Toucasia bafflestone, which is dominated by complete valves of requieniid rudists (Toucasia sp.). The inner aragonitic layer of the rudist shell is replaced by blocky calcite, and the outer foliated layer is calcite. The matrix is mainly lime mudstone with abundant benthic foraminifers, rudist fragments and rare dasyclad algae (Fig. 9c). This facies is dominated by low energy micrite and benthic foraminifers. We interpret it as an isolated biostrome developed in the back-reef environment.
authors: Yasser Salama, Michael Grammer, Shaban Saber, Soheir El-Shazly, Gouda Abdel-Gawad
title: Sequence Stratigraphy and Rudist Facies Development of the Upper Barremian-Lower Cenomanian Platform, Northern Sinai, Egypt

name: Meregh-1
remarks: Isolated pinnacle reefs where the limestones are commonly fractured, leached and dolomitized with porosities of up to 19%. The reef builders are predominantly coral and algae.
authors: L. M. Davidson, T. J. Arthur, G. F. Smith, S. Tubb
title: Geology and hydrocarbon potential of offshore SE Somalia

name: Stetten
remarks: Shell accumulation comprising about 54,000 shells of the giant oyster Magallana gryphoides
authors: Ana Puttonen, Mathias Harzhauser, Eetu Puttonen, Oleg Mandic, Balázs Székely, Gábor Molnár, Norbert Pfeifer
title: Automatic determination of 3D orientations of fossilized oyster shells from a densely packed Miocene shell bed

name: Niau, Tuamotu
remarks: Slightly raised atoll with rich shell mollusc assemblage
authors: Bernard Salvat, Jean Tröndlé, Jean Letourneux
title: Pleistocene mollusc assemblage in the slightly raised atoll lagoon of Niau (Tuamotu, French Polynesia)

name: Zebra River Farm
remarks: Microbial reef buildups. The lower reef occurrence appears as isolated mounding biostromes with poor fabric retention while the upper reef is sheetlike and forms a resistant bedding plane that exposes mounds of thrombolites and associated stromatolites. The mounds exhibit directional elongation and contain skeletal material within the fill between individual microbial buildups.
title: Multiscale approach reveals that Cloudina aggregates are detritus and not in situ reef constructions

name: Panlongdong
remarks: Reef flats/caps contain mainly light gray crystal grain dolomites and sparry calcarenite. Reef cores are mostly sponge reef dolomites with the framework filled up by bioclasts and sand cuttings and contain a low content of calcilutite. Reef bases are less dolomitized and largely bioclastic limestones with bioclasts dominated by metacrinus and foraminifera.
authors: Mintong Li, Xiaobing Lin, JingChun Tian, ShunFeng Peng, Liang Xu, Lin Su
title: Study on variously dolomitized reservoir reef at platform margin of Changxing Formation in northeastern Sichuan Basin, southwestern China
editors: Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature

name: Amu-Darya Basin
remarks: carbonate ramp, wherein the thickest sedimentary formations were deposited, and organic reefs, bioclastic shoals, and oolitic shoals were mainly developed. Rudists (50%)- ???, coral, red algae, bryozoans, sponges.
authors: Yongyao He, Han Mu, Yuanyuan Kang, Yingmin Wang, Bojiang Fan
title: Characteristics of an Upper Jurassic Carbonate Ramp in the Northern Amu-Darya Basin

name: Cape Tuzla, Taman and Cape Popov Kamen, Taman Peninsula
remarks: Bryozoan bioherms are formed by Membranipora elliptica, bivalve mollusks (Polititapes abichi) gastropods that form mass accumulations. Early Maeotian
authors: I. A. Goncharova, Yu. V. Rostovtseva
title: Evolution of Organogenic Carbonate Buildups in the Middle through Late Miocene of the Euxine–Caspian Basin (Eastern Paratethys)

name: Lake Tobechik, Kerch Peninsula
remarks: Bryalgal bioherms. The deposits covering bryozoan bioherms contain detrital limestones.
authors: I. A. Goncharova, Yu. V. Rostovtseva
title: Evolution of Organogenic Carbonate Buildups in the Middle through Late Miocene of the Euxine–Caspian Basin (Eastern Paratethys)

name: Skelya and Kamyshlak, Kerch Peninsula
remarks: Oval, up to 2 m in diameter, bioherm bodies in the Early Chokrakian basin were formed by bryozoan colonies of cheilostomates (Membranipora, Schizoporella, Cellaria, Scrupocellaria, Celleporaria) and cyclostomates (Crisia), red algae (Belokrys, 1986), and calcareous worm tubes.
authors: I. A. Goncharova, Yu. V. Rostovtseva
title: Evolution of Organogenic Carbonate Buildups in the Middle through Late Miocene of the Euxine–Caspian Basin (Eastern Paratethys)

name: Mayak, Kerch Peninsula
remarks: The main reef forming organisms in bioherms included seven species of Schizoporella (Schizoporellidae, Cheilostomata) and quite common cyclostomes Diastopora, Tubulipora, and Pustulipora. The majority of the bryozoans have membraniporiform colonies. Vinculariform types are also present. These bioherms occurred at the transition from the upper to lower sublittoral zones.
authors: I. A. Goncharova, Yu. V. Rostovtseva
title: Evolution of Organogenic Carbonate Buildups in the Middle through Late Miocene of the Euxine–Caspian Basin (Eastern Paratethys)

name: Belaya River
remarks: bryozoan colonies of cheilostomates (genera Membranipora, Schizoporella, Cellaria, Scrupocellaria, Celleporaria), cyclostomates and calcareousworm tubes.
authors: I. A. Goncharova, Yu. V. Rostovtseva
title: Evolution of Organogenic Carbonate Buildups in the Middle through Late Miocene of the Euxine–Caspian Basin (Eastern Paratethys)

name: Cape Kop-Takyl
remarks: Serpulid-microbialite buildups (nodular carbonate bodies). Mollusks assemblage, in addition to mass Crypromactra and rare poorly preserved imprints of cardiids, commonly includes gastropods.
authors: I. A. Goncharova, Yu. V. Rostovtseva
title: Evolution of Organogenic Carbonate Buildups in the Middle through Late Miocene of the Euxine–Caspian Basin (Eastern Paratethys)

name: Chimbulat quarry, Kirov Region
remarks: bed of yellow bioclastic limestone with numerous bryozoan imprints, crinoid columnals, brachiopod and molluskan shells
title: Middle Permian Rostroconchs of the Kazanian Stage of the East European Platform

name: Tastuba-Mitrofanovo quarry
remarks: The Mitrofanovo and Tastuba Reefs are composed of organic limestones containing large amounts of diverse fossil animals (foraminifers, brachiopods, bryozoans, gastropods, crinoids, bivalves, trilobites). In the Tastuba Reef, the records of trilobites are restricted to the lower member of massive, cavernous limestones. In the Mitrofanovo Reef, they occur throughout the thickness of the sediments.
title: A New Species of Trilobites from Sakmarian Reefs of Bashkortostan

name: Reinecke field, west Texas
remarks: Two types of dolomite are observed.One type is stratiform, replaced micrite-rich facies, and is interpreted as early dolomite that recrystallized in hydrothermal brines. The second type crosscuts stratigraphy and depositional facies and has vertically continuous morphologies that trend northwest-southeast. The latter dolomite is interpreted as forming in hydrothermal brines derived from latest Permian-aged highly evaporated seawater. Lower porosity but much higher permeability.
authors: Arthur H. Saller, John A. (Tony) D. Dickson
title: Partial dolomitization of a Pennsylvanian limestone buildup by hydrothermal fluids and its effect on reservoir quality and performance
paper: The American Association of Petroleum Geologists

name: Baidar Valley, Crimean Mountains
remarks: Trombolites, incrusted Crescentiella morronensis, and Terebella lapilloides, subordinate corals and sponges, which are interpreted as deep-water (mainly microbial) bioherms and a new type of forereef apron deposit discovered in limestones of the Baidar plateau. Such aprons include gravitation flow sediments. intraclast rudstones and floatstones with clasts of various reef-builders, as well as sorted grainstones, rudstones, and microbreccias that bear structural signs of unidirectional current and gravitation flow in some places.
title: Upper Jurassic Rock Depositional Settings in the Baidar Valley and Evolution of the Crimean Carbonate Platform

name: Browse Basin, Unit 2
remarks: carbonate build-ups with topographic highs marking focal points of aggradation. In such a setting, topographic lows within build-up interiors are indicative of marine incursions. Patch reefs within the interior lagoon to the east were also drowned. Prolonged aggradation resulted in significant margin retreat on the southeast margins. The barrier reef was then drowned and buried, likely establishing open-ocean conditions across the southeastern part of the study area. Southwest striking faults are observed.
authors: James Van Tuyl, Tiago M. Alves, Lesley Cherns
title: Geometric and depositional responses of carbonate build-ups to Miocene sea level and regional tectonics offshore northwest Australia

name: Browse Basin, Unit 4
remarks: Internal seismic reflections in the build-ups are highly discontinuous, producing high-variance, circular to sub-circular depressions. The subtle chaotic appearance on the slope suggest the presence of a debrite. After the generation of this latter debrite, build-ups were onlapped by, and buried under, low-amplitude strata.
authors: James Van Tuyl, Tiago M. Alves, Lesley Cherns
title: Geometric and depositional responses of carbonate build-ups to Miocene sea level and regional tectonics offshore northwest Australia

name: Browse Basin, Unit 1
remarks: Topography prior to the Miocene initiation of carbonate build-ups shows flat-topped bryozoan reefs, and a sharp break in slope to the northwest. This break in slope is regularly incised and controls the northwesterly extent of the Miocene carbonate sequence. Circular to sub-circular topographic highs represent carbonate build-ups with a patch-reef morphology.
authors: James Van Tuyl, Tiago M. Alves, Lesley Cherns
title: Geometric and depositional responses of carbonate build-ups to Miocene sea level and regional tectonics offshore northwest Australia

name: Browse Basin, Unit 3
remarks: Intra-platform seaways were established between build-ups, and evidence exists for large-scale ripples in the southern part of the study area.Fringing reefs, and build-up interiors develop discontinuous seismic reflections with high-variance, and circular to sub-circular depressions
authors: James Van Tuyl, Tiago M. Alves, Lesley Cherns
title: Geometric and depositional responses of carbonate build-ups to Miocene sea level and regional tectonics offshore northwest Australia

name: Pre-Caspian Basin
remarks: Reef limestone predominately developed with limy mudstone present at the basal part. The platform margin reef (bank) is located in a transition zone between the platform and the deep- or deeper-water slope, with the water depth at and near the wave base, where good circulation of water body is available. This environment provides a strong hydrodynamic force, due to the joint control of wave and tidal, and hence allows grain-dominated bank facies bodies to deposit, with locally present organic reefs formed by substantial in-situ biogroups.
authors: Zhen Wang, Yankun Wang, Jiquan Yin, Man Luo, Shuang Liang
title: Lower permian reef-bank bodies’ characterization in the precaspian basin
paper: IOP Conf. Series: Earth and Environmental Science

name: Muang Long, Sukhothai Zone
remarks: Cement-rich reefal sediments composed of Carniphytes multisiphonatus-microbial boundstone and sparse-allochem grainstone, the latter consisting mainly of fragments of Plexoramea gracilis, are common in this limestone. They suggest open-marine sedimentation on a shallow carbonate platform.
authors: Katsumi Ueno, Yoshihito Kamata, Koji Uno, Thasinee Charoentitirat, Punya Charusiri, Khamseng Vilaykhamf, Rossana Martini
title: The Sukhothai Zone (Permian–Triassic island-arc domain of Southeast Asia) in Northern Laos: Insights from Triassic carbonates and foraminifers

name: Lysakow bryozoan reef
remarks: Bryozoan bioherms attaining up to a few meters in length and one meter in thickness. The bioherms are built up by cyclostomate and cheilostomate bryozoans but the frame-building assemblage is monospecific in places, consisting of Fasciculipora janinae sp. n. Branching colonies of the new species are so variable that their isolated fragments might be easily misidentified as belonging to distinct species, or even genera.
title: A new reef-building bryozoan species from the Miocene of Roztocze

name: New Pass, Nevada
remarks: Sponge-Bivalve-Coral reef mound. Sponges dominated the reef mound followed by bivalves, corals and echinoid fragments. The skeletal content within the overall middle ramp environment is low. Micrite comprises 79% while sparry calcite comprises 2%. Radiolarians, and ammonoids dominate this environment. Thus, we categorize this section as the Radiolarian-Ammonoid Biofacies. The sponge reef mound is largely matrix supported with skeletal content.
authors: Nicole Bonuso, Sean Loyd, Nathanial J. Lorentz
title: Pioneer reef communities within a Middle Triassic (Anisian) to Upper Triassic (Carnian) mixed carbonate-siliciclastic ramp system from the Star Peak Group, South Canyon, central Nevada

name: Lop’yu Kyrta, Ilych River
remarks: Among Biohermal limestones stromatolitic ones are predominate, coral, Fistulella-microbial, and stromatoporoid-microbial ones are rarer. The comparison and correlation of transect series allow us to establish the landscapemorphological zonation of Lop’yu Kyrta buildup, an outer slope and a reef-flat are distinguished. Valganskaya Fm. is turbiditic with reworked reef clasts. No formation name given for in situ reef facies
title: Structure of Upper Lochkovian (Lower Devonian) Lop’yu Kyrta organic buildup (Ilych River, Northern Urals)

name: Lesno Brdo Quarry
remarks: Presence of three facies types: fine-grained limestone as a groundmass, blocks and globular masses of sponge-microbialite boundstone, and lens-like aggregations of polychaete (terebellid) tubes. Sponge-microbialite boundstone contains a rather small number of cosmopolitan sponge taxa, solenoporacean red algae, microproblematica, bryozoans, and a small proportion of dwelling fauna. Instead, stromatolites represent the main constituent.
authors: Luka Gale, Camille Peybernes, Bogomir Celarc, Manca Hočevar, Vid Simon Šelih, Rossana Martini
title: Biotic composition and microfacies distribution of Upper Triassic build‑ups: new insights from the Lower Carnian limestone of Lesno Brdo, central Slovenia

name: Eastern Tianshan, Xinjiang
remarks: The coral fauna is composed of mainly large dissepimented solitary corals, accompanied by a few colonial forms. In total, 47 species belonging to 22 genera in the families Adamanophyllidae, Aulophyllidae, Axophyllidae, Amplexidae, Bothrophyllidae, Cyathopsidae, Palaeosmiliidae and Lithostrotionidae were identified. Among these genera, 16 are solitary, and 6 are colonial. In the latter group, 4 genera are massive, and 2 are fasciculate.
authors: Xing Huang, Markus Aretz, Xionghua Zhang, Yuansheng Du, Tengfei Luan
title: Upper Visean coral biostrome in a volcanic-sedimentary setting from the Eastern Tianshan, Northwest China

name: Tabynsk, Voskresenka Mount
remarks: Bioherm facies are represented by bryozoan limestones (baundstones and rudstones) with brachiopods, algae, and ammonoids. They are underlain by layered crinoid limestones (wackestones and grainstones). The rocks contain a foraminiferal assemblage
authors: E. N. Gorozhanina, V. M. Gorozhanin, T. N. Isakova
title: The Carbonate Massif of Voskresenka Mount in the Southern Pre-Urals: Age and Development of the Submerged Carbonate Platform

name: Dark Canyon brachiopod mound
remarks: The small bioherm is about 8 m long, 5.5 m wide, and elongate toward the northwest. Built by brachiopod Sestropoma cribriferum
title: Brachiopod mounds not sponge reefs, Permian Capitan-Tansil Formations, Guadalupe Mountains, New Mexico

name: Marmorbruch Niederehe, Eifel
remarks: Stromatoporoids, tabulate corals and some rugose corals. Mostly reworked reefal debris. Complex encrustation pattern Zisterzienser Marble previously quarried as building stone.
authors: Birenheide, R., Coen-Aubert, M., Lütte, B.-P., Tourneur, F.
title: Devonian coral bearing strata of the Eifel hills and the Ardennes
paper: VI. Intern. Symp. Fossil Cnidaria, Excursion - Guidebook, Exc. B 1

name: Staryi Oskol, Novovasil’evo area, Orenburg, Ardatovo horizon
remarks: Stromatopore–coral limestones. Clayey and bituminous limestones with tentaculites, radiolarians, spongioids, ostracodes, pelecypods, and lingules.
authors: V. G. Kuznetsov, L. M. Zhuravleva
title: Devonian Reef Formation in the Caspian Basin Framing

name: Rybkino
remarks: Biohermal stromatopore limestones, biohermal algal (Shuguria) limestones;
authors: V. G. Kuznetsov, L. M. Zhuravleva
title: Devonian Reef Formation in the Caspian Basin Framing

name: Well WX5-ST1
remarks: Dolomites with high porosity and high permeability
authors: Yuan Yong, Chen Jianwen, Zhang Yuxi, Liang Jie, Zhang Yinguo, Zhang Penghui
title: Tectonic Evolution and Geological Characteristics of Hydrocarbon Reservoirs in Marine Mesozoic– Paleozoic Strata in the South Yellow Sea Basin

name: Quingdao Depression, CZ12-1-1
remarks: Reef-bank. Dolomites contain abundant dissolved pores and are mainly micritic dolomites. These indicate that there are dolomite reservoirs with good porosity distributed in the lower Triassic and lower Carboniferous of the South Yellow Sea.
authors: Yuan Yong, Chen Jianwen, Zhang Yuxi, Liang Jie, Zhang Yinguo, Zhang Penghui
title: Tectonic Evolution and Geological Characteristics of Hydrocarbon Reservoirs in Marine Mesozoic– Paleozoic Strata in the South Yellow Sea Basin

name: Ganjgon, Late Rupelian
remarks: Further down-dip, larger benthic foraminifers (large Nummulites test, Operculina and Neorotalia) packstone-grainstone along with discrete coral patches and coralline red algae
authors: Mohammad Allahkarampour Dill, Hossein Vaziri-Moghaddam, Ali Seyrafiana, Ali Behdad (Ghabeishavi)
title: Oligo-Miocene carbonate platform evolution in the northern margin of the Asmari intra-shelf basin, SW Iran

name: Fath
remarks: Constructed coralgal build-ups.
authors: Mohammad Allahkarampour Dill, Hossein Vaziri-Moghaddam, Ali Seyrafiana, Ali Behdad (Ghabeishavi)
title: Oligo-Miocene carbonate platform evolution in the northern margin of the Asmari intra-shelf basin, SW Iran

name: Ganjgon, Lower Rupelian
remarks: Build-up (main body and flanks). Further down-dip, larger benthic foraminifers (large Nummulites test, Operculina and Neorotalia) packstone-grainstone along with discrete coral patches and coralline red algae
authors: Mohammad Allahkarampour Dill, Hossein Vaziri-Moghaddam, Ali Seyrafiana, Ali Behdad (Ghabeishavi)
title: Oligo-Miocene carbonate platform evolution in the northern margin of the Asmari intra-shelf basin, SW Iran

name: Jowzar
remarks: Polygenetic conglomerate. Meter-thick bedded to massive limestones rich in coral and coralline red algae fragments confining to the platform margin.
authors: Mohammad Allahkarampour Dill, Hossein Vaziri-Moghaddam, Ali Seyrafiana, Ali Behdad (Ghabeishavi)
title: Oligo-Miocene carbonate platform evolution in the northern margin of the Asmari intra-shelf basin, SW Iran

name: Jebel Toksine, Dades Valley
remarks: Two main intervals dominated by lithiotid and lithiotid-coral biostromes. Lithiotid intervals are characterized by alternating ooid-, peloid- and skeletal-rich wackestones to grainstones interbedded with thick lithiotid and lithiotid-coral rudstones to framestones. Bivalve fauna, rare megalodontids.
authors: Hannah-Maria R. Brame, Rowan C. Martindale, Nicholas P. Ettinger, Irena Debeljak, Raphaël Vasseur, Bernard Lathuilière, Lahcen Kabiri, Stéphane Bodin
title: Stratigraphic distribution and paleoecological significance of Early Jurassic (Pliensbachian-Toarcian) lithiotid-coral reefal deposits from the Central High Atlas of Morocco

name: Baimiaozi, Jialing River, Beibei
remarks: 10 microbial mounds Conodont fossils such as Hindeodus parvus? and Isarcicella staeschei were found in the microbial mounds, and these fossils indicate that the age is that of the lower Griesbachian Stage. The microbial mounds in this study can be considered to be composed of three facies, namely, a mound base, mound body, and mound cap. Growth below normal wave base.
authors: Duan X, Shi Z, Chen Y, Chen L, Chen B, Wang L, Han L
title: Early Triassic Griesbachian microbial mounds in the Upper Yangtze Region, southwest China: Implications for biotic recovery from the latest Permian mass extinction

name: Blue River, East Greenland
remarks: The East Greenland bioaccumulations developed within a restricted Boreal mid-paleolatitude seaway, and comprised a monospecific primary framework of microconchid ‘lophophorate’ tubes with shell fragments and phosphatic debris cemented by biogenic calcite. Wordie Creek Group
authors: Zatoń M, Niedźwiedzki G, Rakociński M, Blom H, Kear BP
title: Earliest Triassic metazoan bioconstructions from East Greenland reveal a pioneering benthic community in the immediate aftermath of the end-Permian mass extinction

name: Lower Monte Baria Reef, Cala Gonone, N Oresei Gulg
remarks: Carbonate (bioclastic) debris, microbialites and microencrusters, and reef-building organisms (mainly corals and stromatoporoids). Microframework -rich(microbialites and microencrusters) facies, with abundant skeletal organismus in place. Corals dominate, followed by stromatoporoids, bivalves (including Rudist diceratids), gastropods (including nerineids), echinoid spines.
authors: Ricci, Cristiano, Rusciadelli, Giovanni, Della Porta, Giovanna, Lanfranchi, Alessandro, Jadoul, Flavio, Lathuilière, Bernard
title: Sedimentary evolution of a coral-, microbialites- and debris-rich Upper Jurassic reef (upper Tithonian, eastern Sardinia, Italy)

name: Hönne Valley Reef Complex at Binolen
remarks: Mudstones to bioclastic wackestones with some tabulate corals, rare colonial Rugosa, very rare stromatoporid fragments, some crinoid debris, ostracods, and some mollusk debris.
authors: Ralph Thomas Becker, Zhor Sarah Aboussalam, Sören Stichling, Andreas May, Stephan Eichholt
title: The Givetian-Frasnian Hönne Valley Reef Complex (northern Sauerland) – an outline of stratigraphy and facies development
paper: Münstersche Forschungen zur Geologie und Palaeontologie

name: Hönne Reef, Beul near Eisborn. Loc. 4
remarks: Terminal reef limestones with colonial rugose coral, biostrome blocks and with the overlying top-middle Frasnian, post-reefal nodular limestones, with shark and pelagic conodont fauna
authors: Ralph Thomas Becker, Zhor Sarah Aboussalam, Sören Stichling, Andreas May, Stephan Eichholt
title: The Givetian-Frasnian Hönne Valley Reef Complex (northern Sauerland) – an outline of stratigraphy and facies development
paper: Münstersche Forschungen zur Geologie und Palaeontologie

name: Falcona Alta, Malaguide Complex
remarks: Mainly bafflestones with clotted microbial grainstone to packstone matrix. Reef builders are ramiform thamnoporid corals and twig-like stromatoporoids both with frequent microborings.
title: Frasnian–Famennian crisis in the Malaguide Complex (Betic Cordillera, Spain)

name: Core XK-1, Stone Island
remarks: Coral content varies between 25% and 74%.The corals are dominated by Turbinaria and Favia, with colonies mainly displaying massive morphologies. Accessory components are debris of frequent to rare benthic foraminifera, red algae, echinoids, brachiopods. Red algal and coral frame- to bindstone, red algal bindstone, floatstone, and wackestone.
authors: Feng Wu, Xinong Xie, Christian Betzler, Weilin Zhu, Youhua Zhu, Laiyuan Guo, Zhaoliang Ma, Huaqing Bai, Benjun Ma
title: The impact of eustatic sea-level fluctuations, temperature variations and nutrient-level changes since the Pliocene on tropical carbonate platform (Xisha Islands, South China Sea)

name: Core XK-1, Stone Island
remarks: coral framestone and floatston with minor wackestone and packstone. The corals are dominated by Turbinaria and Favia, with colonies mainly displaying massive morphologies. The coral content can reach 100%. Matrix containing some bioclastic debris. Accessory components are debris of frequent to rare benthic foraminifera, red algae, echinoids, rare green algae, brachiopods, bivalves.
authors: Feng Wu, Xinong Xie, Christian Betzler, Weilin Zhu, Youhua Zhu, Laiyuan Guo, Zhaoliang Ma, Huaqing Bai, Benjun Ma
title: The impact of eustatic sea-level fluctuations, temperature variations and nutrient-level changes since the Pliocene on tropical carbonate platform (Xisha Islands, South China Sea)

name: Laga Beach, Ibarangelu
remarks: Marls with coral biostromes.
authors: O. Bonilla, M.A. López-Horgue, P.A. Fernandez-Mendiola
title: Morphological diversity of Lower Cretaceous (Aptian-Albian) Scleractinian corals, Basque-Cantabrian Basin, Spain
paper: Jornadas de Paleontología y IV Congreso Ibérico de Paleontología

name: Kouquan section
remarks: massive micritic limestone and calcareous mudstone
authors: Khalid Latif, Enzhao Xiao, Muhammad Riaz, Abdullah Ali Ali Hussein
title: Calcified cyanobacteria fossils from the leiolitic bioherm in the Furongian Changshan Formation, Datong (North China Platform)

name: Sampaguita-1, Reed Bank
remarks: Carbonate platform reef
authors: Xuebin Du, Yongchao Lu, Xiangquan Li, Jiangtao Li
title: Development and controlling factors of Upper Oligocene– Lower Miocene carbonate platforms and reefs in the Liyue Basin, South China Sea

name: Sampagita‐1
remarks: Carbonate platform reef
authors: Xuebin Du, Yongchao Lu, Xiangquan Li, Jiangtao Li
title: Development and controlling factors of Upper Oligocene– Lower Miocene carbonate platforms and reefs in the Liyue Basin, South China Sea

name: Huwaiza-1 well
remarks: Very coarse-grained bioclastic rudstone dominated by rudistid debris with abundant of benthonic foraminiferal grainstone in the lagoonal facies.
authors: Aiad Ali Hussien Al-Zaidy, Hussein Shwayel Aoudeh Al Shwaliay
title: Sequence Stratigraphy of the Cenomanian - early Turonian Cycle in the Selected wells, Southeastern Iraq

name: Halfaya-1 wall
remarks: Rudistid biostrome with open shelf lagoon facies. Abundant of benthonic foraminiferal packstone, that indicates to open lagoon environment.
authors: Aiad Ali Hussien Al-Zaidy, Hussein Shwayel Aoudeh Al Shwaliay
title: Sequence Stratigraphy of the Cenomanian - early Turonian Cycle in the Selected wells, Southeastern Iraq

name: Dujaila -1 well
remarks: Skeletal and non-skeletal carbonate grains.
authors: Aiad Ali Hussien Al-Zaidy, Hussein Shwayel Aoudeh Al Shwaliay
title: Sequence Stratigraphy of the Cenomanian - early Turonian Cycle in the Selected wells, Southeastern Iraq

name: Amara -1
remarks: Rudistid biostrome with open shelf lagoon facies
authors: Aiad Ali Hussien Al-Zaidy, Hussein Shwayel Aoudeh Al Shwaliay
title: Sequence Stratigraphy of the Cenomanian - early Turonian Cycle in the Selected wells, Southeastern Iraq

name: Abu Amood -1
remarks: Skeletal and non-skeletal carbonate grains, rudistid debris.
authors: Aiad Ali Hussien Al-Zaidy, Hussein Shwayel Aoudeh Al Shwaliay
title: Sequence Stratigraphy of the Cenomanian - early Turonian Cycle in the Selected wells, Southeastern Iraq

name: Wennan, Xintai area
remarks: Sponge–microbial boundstones, containing lithistid sponges (areal percentage, approximately 14%) and microbial components (areal percentage, approximately 39%). The sponges in this section are anthaspidellid demosponges. The microbial components consist mainly of frequently branched columnar stromatolites. Vacant spaces among frameworks formed by a combination of stromatolites and sponges are filled with lime mud and rare bioclasts, including trilobites, chancelloriid sclerites and sponge spicules.
authors: Adachi, N., Kotani, A., Ezaki, Y., Liu, J.
title: Cambrian Series 3 lithistid sponge–microbial reefs in Shandong Province, North China: reef development after the disappearance of archaeocyaths

name: Tipperary area, Kordephyton-Jawonya-Wagima
remarks: Microbialite columns with Kordephyton bushes (fan pattern) and sporadic Jawonya and Wagima both attached to column surfaces and immured within columns; vagrant Latouchella accordionata on right margin of central column; intercolumn cavity with geopetal infill.
authors: Peter D. Kruse, Joachim R. Reitner
title: Northern Australian microbial-metazoan reefs after the mid-Cambrian mass extinction
paper: Memoirs of the Association of Australasian Palaeontologists

name: Soudan area, Undilla Sub-basin, locality NTGS4648
remarks: Reef fabric comprises mainly explanate and in some cases conical Rankenella, encrusted by more or less distinctly laminated, generally non-skeletal stromatolites. Angulocellularia-type microbial mesoclots and Angulocellularia locally intergrades into Taninia. Stromatolites appear to encrust upper surfaces of Rankenella skeletons, as well as those of other bioclasts such as calciate brachiopods, hyoliths and molluscs.
authors: Peter D. Kruse, Joachim R. Reitner
title: Northern Australian microbial-metazoan reefs after the mid-Cambrian mass extinction
paper: Memoirs of the Association of Australasian Palaeontologists

name: Yazd locality
remarks: Small reefs formed by dendroid and ceroid corals and differents droups of sponges. Chambered sphinctozoans and noc-chambered sphinctozoans are the most abundant sponges. One chambered hexactinellid sponges was also found.
authors: B. Senowbari-Daryan, K. Rashidi, H. Bettollah
title: Hypercalcified sponges from a small reef within the Norian-Rhaetian Nayband Formation near Yazd, central Iran
paper: Rivista Italiana di Paleontologia e Stratigrafia

name: Dagestan, Shakhdag Massif
remarks: Bioherm buildups, represented by the dense gray and greenish grain limestones with a great amount of corals.
title: Architecture of the Southern Marginal Zone of the Upper Jurassic– Valanginian Carbonate Platform of the Northeastern Caucasus (Dagestan, Shakhdag Massif)

name: Well YB1 and Well YB2,Yuanba, Cangxi
remarks: The main reservoir rocks are reef-bank dolomite and dolomitic limestone, which are characterized by medium-low porosity and medium-low permeability.
title: Hydrocarbon Accumulation conditions and key technologies for exploration and development of Yuanba Gas Field

name: Le Perthus
remarks: Coral-microbialite patch reef with fragments of crinoids and dacycladacean algae but profuse ooids.
authors: Simon Boivin, Melanie Gretz, Bernard Lathuiliere, Nicolas Olivier, Annachiara Bartolini, Rossana Martini
title: Coral- and oyster-microbialite patch reefs in the aftermath of the Triassic–Jurassic biotic crisis (Sinemurian, Southeast France)

name: Al Bada
remarks: Massive limestone with low diverse, scattered, small dendroid and massive heads of corals of Heliastraea, Tarbellastraea spp. Microfacies analysis of this facies gave coralline framestone, bioclastic grainstone, bryozoan grainstone, bioclastic wacke/floatstones and bioclastic rudstones. The skeletal grains are dominated by reworked moderately preserved small branched, massive and phaceloid corals, bivalves, gastropods and red algae. Matrix in most back reef is made up of peloidal micrite with abundant organic matter.
title: Facies development of the Middle Miocene reefal limestone in northwest Saudi Arabia

name: Wadi Aynouna, near Al Khuraybah
remarks: Massive bioturbated coralline limestone with low diverse, medium isolated corals heads of Favites, Heliastraea, Tarbellastraea, Porites, Thegioastraea spp. Coralline red algae occur as free-rolling or partly attatched rhodoliths and debris of Lithothamnium and Mesophyllum spp. Red algae play a significant role in construction of the reef facies, where they bind and connect coral colonies and other skeletal and non skeletal constituents into a coherent mass. The bivalves, gastropods and echinoids act as essential rock forming constituents in this lithofacies. Fore-reef sediments mainly gave bioclastic wackestone, algal wackestone, bioclastic packstones, coralline framestone, coralline rudstone and grainstones. Most of these sediments are driven from the reef-core framework. Thin sections show fragments of corals, red algae, benthic foraminifera (miliolids) and ostracods. Most of these fragments were recrystallized due to diagenesis.
title: Facies development of the Middle Miocene reefal limestone in northwest Saudi Arabia

name: Station 20, North of Wadi Tayyib Ism
remarks: reefal carbonates with conglomeratic layers sitting on Arabian basement granitoids with abundant scleractinian heads, gastropods, epifaunal and infaunal bivalves.
authors: Marco Taviani, Paolo Montagna, Najeeb M. A. Rasul, Lorenzo Angeletti, William Bosworth
title: Pleistocene Coral Reef Terraces on the Saudi Arabian Side of the Gulf of Aqaba, Red Sea
paper: Geological Setting, Palaeoenvironment and Archaeology of the Red Sea

name: Station 15, Ash Shaykh Humayd
remarks: MIS5e coral reef terraces, expose reef-edge and back-reef lagoonal deposits with various stony corals, molluscs, echinoids, melobesians, etc.
