authors: Marco Taviani, Paolo Montagna, Najeeb M. A. Rasul, Lorenzo Angeletti, William Bosworth
title: Pleistocene Coral Reef Terraces on the Saudi Arabian Side of the Gulf of Aqaba, Red Sea
paper: Geological Setting, Palaeoenvironment and Archaeology of the Red Sea

name: Station 6, 12 South of Ra’s Suwayhil as Saghir
remarks: Large boulders overgrown by reefal carbonates with variety of well-preserved scleractinian corals and molluscs, gastropods. Large mamelon-like aragonite botryoids are found.
authors: Marco Taviani, Paolo Montagna, Najeeb M. A. Rasul, Lorenzo Angeletti, William Bosworth
title: Pleistocene Coral Reef Terraces on the Saudi Arabian Side of the Gulf of Aqaba, Red Sea
paper: Geological Setting, Palaeoenvironment and Archaeology of the Red Sea

name: Station 27, south of Al Maqnah
remarks: Porites-dominated reefs and intervening sandy sediments host abundant and diverse associated fauna which includes large bivalves and gastropods.
authors: Marco Taviani, Paolo Montagna, Najeeb M. A. Rasul, Lorenzo Angeletti, William Bosworth
title: Pleistocene Coral Reef Terraces on the Saudi Arabian Side of the Gulf of Aqaba, Red Sea
paper: Geological Setting, Palaeoenvironment and Archaeology of the Red Sea

name: B reef and J reef, Madura Strait Basin
remarks: Reefal facies, composed of a coral framework, larger foraminifera, red algae, echinoderm plates, and other minor carbonate bioclasts.
authors: Ran Weimin, Luan Xiwu, Li Yintao, Liu Hong, Yang Jiajia, Zhao Yang, He Wenchang, Yan Zhonghui
title: Formation and evolution of the tertiary carbonate reefs in the Madura Strait Basin of Indonesia

name: O-1Madura Strait Basin
remarks: porosity of the Mundu carbonate rock can reach more than 40%. Mundu is composed of bioclastic grainstone, wackestone and packstone and has been intensely bioturbated.
authors: Ran Weimin, Luan Xiwu, Li Yintao, Liu Hong, Yang Jiajia, Zhao Yang, He Wenchang, Yan Zhonghui
title: Formation and evolution of the tertiary carbonate reefs in the Madura Strait Basin of Indonesia

name: Blue Mountain Inlier
remarks: Rudists as large bouquets of Biradiolites mooretownensis yielding tens of thousands of specimens
authors: Dominik Hennhöfer, Stefan Götz, Simon Mitchell
title: Palaeobiology of a Biradiolites mooretownensis rudist lithosome: seasonality, reproductive cyclicity and population dynamics

name: Atar Group, unit I-5
remarks: Stromatolitic bioherms.
authors: Linda C. Kah, Julie K. Bartley, David A. Teal
title: Chemostratigraphy of the Late Mesoproterozoic Atar Group, Taoudeni Basin, Mauritania: Muted isotopic variability, facies correlation, and global isotopic trends

name: Pizzo Croce Limestone
remarks: Rudist biostrome/buildups, highenergy shelf-margin rudist patches. Caprinidae-Radiolitidae floatstone grading up into amalgamated beds of angular bioclastic rudstone/grainstone. Alternations of foraminifer/ostracod mudstone/wackestone and bioclastic grainstone/fine-rudstone.
title: Cenomanian Rudist-dominated Shelf-margin Limestones from the Panormide Carbonate Platform (Sicily, Italy)' Facies Analysis and Sequence Stratigraphy

name: Wadi Mujib
remarks: Peritidal (mudstones with monotypic ostracodes or microbial lamination) and agitated shallow subtidal environments (rudist patch reefs).
authors: Frauke Schulze, Jochen Kuss, Akmal Marzouk
title: Platform configuration, microfacies and cyclicities of the upper Albian to Turonian of west-central Jordan

name: Nallıhan
remarks: Patch reefs and locally fringing type reefs comprise abundant hippurits and other rudists, algae, bryozoans, coelenterate, echinoid, gastropods, ammonoids.
authors: Muhittin Görmüş, Huriye Demircan, Yusuf Kagan Kadioglu, Fuzuli Yagmurlu, Muhammed Sami Us
title: Microborings as indication of cryptic life modes in the foraminifer Orbitoides: Maastrichtian sediments of the Haymana and Nallıhan districts (Ankara, Turkey)

name: Bird Road, Miami
remarks: More biohermal in form, the reef system appeared to have distinct zonation. coral fauna was present, including Diploria sarasotana, Septastrea marylandica, Septastrea crassa, Porites furcata Lamarck, and the hydrocoral Millepora alcicornis, and over three hundred species of mollusks along with several species of echinoids and crustaceans.
title: The Pliocene Reefs of Miami: Their Geomorphological Significance in the Evolution of the Atlantic Coastal Ridge, Southeastern Florida, U.S.A

name: Tangjiahe
remarks: The Tangjiahe section contains three levels of reefal buildups that were constructed by aconsortium of archaeocyaths and calcimicrobes in varying proportions. The lowest (oldest) reefal buildup is acalcimicrobial biostrome, possibly in the form of a wide mound with a low relief (unconfirmed due to outcroplimitation), which was formed byEpiphytonwith rare small archaeocyaths, and is sandwiched by flat-pebbleconglomerates. The middle reefal buildup is a high-relief calcimicrobial mound, enclosed by oolites, that was built byintergrownRenalcisandTarthinia.
authors: Hao Tang, Stephen Kershaw, Xiu-Cheng Tan, Hong Liu, Fei Li, Cheng Shen, Fei-Fan Lu, Xue-Fei Yang
title: Sedimentology of reefal buildups of theXiannüdong Formation (Cambrian Series 2), SW China

name: Kano-yama limestone, Kanto Mountains
remarks: Algal-microbial mound composed of Anthracoporella, Palaeoaplysina, Tubiphytes, Archaeolithoporella, and bryozoans. The limestone is characterized by abundant micrite, implying a low-energy back-reef depositional environment.
authors: Kohei Tominaga, Katsumi Ueno, Ken‑ichiro Hisada
title: Anthracoporella–Palaeoaplysina mound in Upper Carboniferous mid‑Panthalassan atoll‑type carbonates in a Jurassic accretionary complex, central Japan

name: Fossil Hill
remarks: Serpulid build-ups: massive deposits composed of fossil serpulid worm tubes (Annelida: Serpulidae) and bivalve shells.
authors: Magdalena N. Georgieva, Charles K. Paull, Crispin T. S. Little, Mary McGann, Diana Sahy, Daniel Condon, Lonny Lundsten, Jack Pewsey, David W. Caress, Robert C. Vrijenhoek
title: Discovery of an Extensive Deep-Sea Fossil Serpulid Reef Associated With a Cold Seep, Santa Monica Basin, California

name: Xikou section
remarks: Lower stromatolite bed, lying on the oolitic grainstone, 0.2 m thick. Columnar stromatolites.
authors: Xi-Yang Zhang, Wen-Qian Wang, Dong-Xun Yuan, Hua Zhang, Quan-Feng Zheng
title: Stromatolite-dominated microbialites at the Permian–Triassic boundary of the Xikou section on South Qinling Block, China

name: Xikou section
remarks: Very-thick-bedded sponge framestones and thick-to-very-thick-bedded bioclastic grainstones. Fossils are diverse and abundant and include calcareous sponges, calcareous algae, echinoderms, corals, small foraminifers, fusulinids, brachiopods. Clarkina yini zone.
authors: Xi-Yang Zhang, Wen-Qian Wang, Dong-Xun Yuan, Hua Zhang, Quan-Feng Zheng
title: Stromatolite-dominated microbialites at the Permian–Triassic boundary of the Xikou section on South Qinling Block, China

name: Mtwara Bay
remarks: Coral bioconstruction with two principal facies: siliciclastic sheetstone facies dominated by platy colonies, and carbonate mix-platestone facies including a variety of growth forms (platy, tabular-massive, branching and solitary. Tabular-massive corals can reach a size of up to 50 cm across.
authors: Markus Reuter, Francesca R. Bosellini, Ann F. Budd, Stjepan Coric, Werner E. Piller, Mathias Harzhauser
title: High coral reef connectivity across the Indian Ocean is revealed 6–7 Ma ago by a turbid-water scleractinian assemblage from Tanzania (Eastern Africa)

name: Kotouč Quarry, Štramberk
remarks: Coral-microbial bindstone passing locally to poorly sorted pelbiointraclastic packstone. Corals and micro-encrusters (Lithocodium aggregatum and Crescentiella morronensis) form a framework that supported the sediment during deposition. Bioclasts belong to trepostome bryozoans (colonies and isolated zooecias), calcareous sponges, crinoids and gastropods. Ooids and calcareous dinoflagellate cysts are rare. Cavities are filled with radiaxial-fibrous calcite cement, chalcedony and blocky calcite.
authors: Lucie Vaňková, Tiiu Elbra, Petr Pruner, Zdeněk Vašíček, Petr Skupien, Daniela Reháková, Petr Schnabl, Martin Košťák, Lilian Švábenická, Andrea Svobodová, Miroslav Bubík, Martin Mazuch, Kristýna Čížková, Šimon Kdýr
title: Integrated stratigraphy and palaeoenvironment of the Berriasian peri-reefal limestones at Štramberk (Outer Western Carpathians, Czech Republic)

name: Jebel Taabest
remarks: subtidal lagoon paleoenvironments with olistoliths that show a boundstone to floatstone texture, with solitary and colonial corals, sponges, gastropods, serpulid worms, crinoids, brachiopods, echinoids tests and spines, and occasional chaetetid sponges and microbialites.
authors: Raphaël Vasseur, Simon Boivin, Bernard Lathuilière, Iuliana Lazar, Christophe Durlet, Rowan-Clare Martindale, Stéphane Bodin, Khalid Elhmidi
title: Lower Jurassic corals from Morocco with skeletal structures convergent with those of Paleozoic rugosan corals

name: Koudiat Ech Chehem
remarks: Giant bioherm made of interlayered boundstones (pillarstones and mixstones) and crinoidal grainstones and packstones. Environment in the optimal reef window, at the boundary between shoreface and offshore. Well-lit and diverse communities.
authors: Raphaël Vasseur, Simon Boivin, Bernard Lathuilière, Iuliana Lazar, Christophe Durlet, Rowan-Clare Martindale, Stéphane Bodin, Khalid Elhmidi
title: Lower Jurassic corals from Morocco with skeletal structures convergent with those of Paleozoic rugosan corals

name: Mihangaoqiaogaolu section, West Ujimqin Banner
remarks: Reefs are superimposed upon each other in the lower part of the section, but are isolated in the upper part. They developed on and are overlain by medium- to thick-bedded skeletal wackestone that contains phylloid algae and Shamovella, foraminifers, echinoderms, bryozoans, Rectangulina, and Epimastopora.
authors: Zhen Yan, Jianbo Liu, Xiaochi Jin, Yukun Shi, Haifeng Wang
title: Construction model and paleogeographic distribution of Late Pennsylvanian phylloid algal–microbial reefs: a case study in eastern Inner Mongolia, North China

name: Cioclovina–Bănita area, MFT2
remarks: Platform margin environment, crest—shallow-water patch reefs. Crustose fabrics, biogenic encrustations and perforations; clotted, agglutinated and dome-shaped microbial microstructures, small cavities; the intra-reef sediment is mostly micritic; scarce geopetal structures; radiaxial- fibrous cements and late diagenetic druse/ mosaic spar occur locally
authors: George Pleş, Alin Oprişa, Ioan I. Bucur, Emanoil Săsăran, Cristian V. Mircescu, Gelu Oltean, Răzvan G. Iacob
title: The central‑western Getic Carbonate Platform: Upper Jurassic to Lower Cretaceous biostratigraphy and sedimentary evolution of the Cioclovina–Băniţa sector (Southern Carpathians, Romania)
editors: Facies

name: Gunung Subis
remarks: Massive and branching corals, coralline red algae, benthic foraminifera, bivalves, gastropods, echinoids, and occasionally bryozoans and sponges. Eight microfacies types and four environments were defined to describe the Subis Limestone: outer talus, inner talus, reef rim, and lagoon. Nine genera of benthic foraminifera.
authors: Bing Bing Saw, Markus Schlaich, Michael C. Pöppelreiter, Mu. Ramkumar, Peter Lunt, Jose Antonio Gamez Vintaned, Syed Haroon Ali
title: Facies, depositional environments, and anatomy of the Subis build‑up in Sarawak, Malaysia: implications on other Miocene isolated carbonate build‑ups

name: Kuh-e Siah section, Borazjan city
remarks: Angular rudist and coral with minor amounts of echinoids and benthic foraminifera fragments. Middle shelf and ramp environments
authors: Parisa Gholami Zadeh, Mohammad Hossein Adabi, Abbas Sadeghi
title: Microfacies, Geochemistry and Sequence Stratigraphy of the Sarvak Formation (Mid Cretaceous) in the Kuh-e Siah and Kuh-e Mond, Fars Area, Southern Iran

name: Kuh-e Mond well, Fars Area
remarks: Bioclastic pelloidal packstone consists mainly of pelloid with small benthic foraminifera, such as textulariids, alveolina, plaealveolina, conical orbitolina, echinoderms and rudist fragments. The pelloidal nature of this facies together with rudist and echinoid bioclasts indicate shallow open marine environment with good water circulation.
authors: Parisa Gholami Zadeh, Mohammad Hossein Adabi, Abbas Sadeghi
title: Microfacies, Geochemistry and Sequence Stratigraphy of the Sarvak Formation (Mid Cretaceous) in the Kuh-e Siah and Kuh-e Mond, Fars Area, Southern Iran

name: Northern shore of the Cíjara dam
remarks: Bioherms, shelly-microbial buildups.The reef-core facies consists of Cloudina-thromboid to stromatoid-thromboid boundstones and floatstones. Due to neomorphism, the calcified microbial communities are heterogeneously preserved, with clotted pseudospar textures occurring directly encrusting both microsparitic substrates and shelly walls. The microbial framestone is dominated by clotted, peloidal, fenestral textures, and subsidiary stromatolitic microsparite/sparry textures. Predominant skeletal components are Cloudina carinata, C. hartmanae (probably C. xuanjiangpingensis), Sinotubulites baimatuoensis, and rare Protolagena sp.
authors: J. Javier Álvaro, Iván Cortijo, Sören Jensen, Mónica Martí Mus, Teodoro Palacios
title: Cloudina-microbial reef resilience to substrate instability in a Cadomian retroarc basin of the Iberian Peninsula

name: Phu Pha Sing and Phu Pha Noi hills
remarks: Phylloid algal reef mound association is mainly composed of massive phylloid algal boundstone dominated, up 30% of bioclasts, by cup-shaped phylloid algae with locally common algal-skeletal packstone and wackestone. Red algae,calcimicrobes, forams, rugose coral, peloids, echinoderms, brachiopods,fusulinds, ostracods can be found.
authors: Kaylee D. Anderson, Annette D. George
title: Evolution of Pennsylvanian inner-platform phylloid algal reef mounds, Pha Nok Khao Platform, northeastern Thailand

name: Değirmençay, Mersin Province
remarks: Red algae, coral and benthic foraminifera bearing reefal limestone.
title: Ostracoda and Foraminifera Assemblages of the Lower-Middle Miocene Reefal Carbonates within the Değirmençay Area, NW Mersin/S Turkey
paper: Çukurova University Journal of the Faculty of Engineering and Architecture

name: Lumazhai and Zhongxinzhai locality
remarks: Grey thick-bedded microbial carbonate and phylloid algae boundstone. The substrate is composed of grey thick-bedded wackestone and packstone. Peloids, microbial mat debris, bioclasts constitute most of the volume of the lower part. Bioclasts, including bryozoans, small brachiopod shells, gastropods, ostracods, crinoids, and foraminifera. The substrate becomes clotted wackestone towards the mound and the biodiversity decreases. Skeletal grains have micritic envelopes.
authors: Wen-Tao Huang, Yong-Li Zhang, Chang-Qing Guan, Zhuo-Wei Miao, Xiao-Hong Chen, Zhen-Yuan Yang, Xiao Li, En-Pu Gong
title: Role of calcimicrobes and microbial carbonates in the Late Carboniferous (Moscovian) mounds in southern Guizhou, South China
